('82', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 82 : 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 1
('82', 0, 1, 2, 42) 1. ADIVASIS
('82', 0, 2, 3, 54) Adivasis have become the fourteenth item in the constructive programme.
('82', 0, 2, 4, 126) 1 But they are not the least in point of importance.
('82', 0, 2, 5, 179) Our country is so vast and the races so varied that the best of us, in spite of every effort, cannot know all there is to know of men and their condition.
('82', 0, 2, 6, 334) As one comes upon layer after layer of things one ought to know as a national servant, one realizes how difficult it is to make good our claim to be one nation whose every unit has a living consciousness of being one with every other.
('82', 0, 3, 7, 569) The Adivasis are 2 1 4 crores in all India, i.e., 6 1 4 per cent of the total population or nearly half of the Harijan population.
('82', 0, 4, 8, 700) Shri Balasaheb Kher has thrown himself with his usual zeal into this much needed service in the Thana District.
('82', 0, 4, 9, 812) He says in the pamphlet issued by him, on behalf of the Adivasi Seva Mandal of which he is President: 2
('82', 0, 5, 10, 916) Balasaheb has made a modest beginning.
('82', 0, 5, 11, 955) He has started with a hostel for Adivasi boys.
('82', 0, 5, 12, 1002) His work is all unassuming and solid.
('82', 0, 5, 13, 1040) If he gets the true type of workers, what is a small beginning may one day blossom forth into an all India organization covering the whole of the Adivasi population.
('82', 0, 5, 14, 1206) Truly “the harvest is rich and the labourers few.” Who can deny that all such service is not merely humanitarian but solidly national and brings us nearer to true independence?
('82', 0, 6, 15, 1383) SEVAGRAM, February 9, 1942
('82', 0, 7, 16, 1410) Harijan, 15 2 1942
('82', 0, 8, 17, 1429) 1 Vide “Constructive Programme: Its Meaning and Place“ 13 12 1941. In the revised edition it became the sixteenth item.
('82', 0, 8, 18, 1549) 2 The pamphlet, not reproduced here, described the miserable plight of the Adivasis and their exploitation by zamindars and forest contractors.
('82', 1, 0, 1, 1693) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 1, 1, 2, 1733) 2. QUESTION BOX
('82', 1, 2, 3, 1749) THE ETERNAL PROBLEM
('82', 1, 3, 4, 1769) Q.Why can’t you see that whilst there is possession it must be defended
('82', 1, 4, 5, 1841) against all odds?
('82', 1, 4, 6, 1859) Therefore your insistence that violence should be eschewed in all
('82', 1, 5, 7, 1925) circumstances is utterly unworkable and absurd.
('82', 1, 5, 8, 1973) I think non violence is possible only
('82', 1, 6, 9, 2011) for select individuals.
('82', 1, 7, 10, 2035) A.This question has been answered often enough in some form or other in these columns as also in those of Young India.
('82', 1, 7, 11, 2154) But it is an evergreen.
('82', 1, 7, 12, 2178) I must answer it as often as it is put, especially when it comes from an earnest seeker as this one does.
('82', 1, 7, 13, 2284) I claim that even now, though the social structure is not based on a conscious acceptance of non violence, all the world over mankind lives and men retain their possessions on the sufferance of one another.
('82', 1, 7, 14, 2491) If they had not done so, only the fewest and the most ferocious would have survived.
('82', 1, 7, 15, 2576) But such is not the case.
('82', 1, 7, 16, 2602) Families are bound together by ties of love, and so are groups in the so called civilized society called nations.
('82', 1, 7, 17, 2716) Only they do not recognize the supremacy of the law of non violence.
('82', 1, 7, 18, 2785) It follows, therefore, that they have not investigated its vast possibilities.
('82', 1, 7, 19, 2864) Hitherto out of sheer inertia, shall I say, we have taken it for granted that complete non violence is possible only for the few who take the vow of non possession and the allied abstinences.
('82', 1, 7, 20, 3056) Whilst it is true that the votaries alone can carry on research work and declare from time to time the new possibilities of the great eternal law governing man, if it is the law, it must hold good for all.
('82', 1, 7, 21, 3262) The many failures we see are not of the law but of the followers, many of whom do not even know that they are under that law willy nilly.
('82', 1, 7, 22, 3400) When a mother dies for her child she unknowingly obeys the law.
('82', 1, 7, 23, 3464) I have been pleading for the past fifty years for a conscious acceptance of the law and its zealous practice even in the face of failures.
('82', 1, 7, 24, 3603) Fifty years’ work has shown marvellous results and strengthened my faith.
('82', 1, 7, 25, 3677) I do claim that by constant practice we shall come to a state of things when lawful possession will command universal and voluntary respect.
('82', 1, 7, 26, 3818) No doubt such possession will not be tainted.
('82', 1, 7, 27, 3864) It will not be an insolent demonstration of the inequalities that surround us everywhere.
('82', 1, 7, 28, 3954) Nor need the problem of unjust and unlawful possessions appal the votary of non violence.
('82', 2, 0, 1, 4044) VOL. 82 : 9 FEBRUARY 1940 6 JUNE, 1940 3
('82', 2, 1, 2, 4085) has at his disposal the non violent weapon of satyagraha and non co operation which hitherto has been found to be a complete substitute of violence whenever it has been applied honestly in sufficient measure.
('82', 2, 1, 3, 4294) I have never claimed to present the complete science of non violence.
('82', 2, 1, 4, 4364) It does not lend ittself to such treatment.
('82', 2, 1, 5, 4408) So far as I know no single physical science does, not even the very precise science of mathematics.
('82', 2, 1, 6, 4508) I am but a seeker, and I have fellow seekers like the questioner whom I invite to accompany me in the very difficult but equally fascinating search.
('82', 2, 2, 7, 4657) SEVAGRAM, February 9, 1942 Harijan, 22 2 1942
('82', 2, 3, 8, 4703) 3. PASSING OF THE FIRST STAGE OF THE A.I.V.I.A 1
('82', 2, 4, 9, 4752) One would have thought that I had enough on my hands without taking the additional burden of the presidentship of the A. I. V. I. A. I have been its guide ever since its inception 2, but the importunity of the Board was irresistible.
('82', 2, 4, 10, 4986) Readers will lighten my task by sharing it with me by (a) becoming members, (b) contributing funds (c) contributing solid work.
('82', 2, 5, 11, 5114) SEVAGRAM, February 9, 1942
('82', 2, 6, 12, 5141) Harijan, 22 2 1942
('82', 2, 7, 13, 5160) 4. FROM THE OLDEST CONGRESSMAN
('82', 2, 8, 14, 5191) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('82', 2, 9, 15, 5207) I congratulate you upon your dissociation with the believers of violence as far as possible.
('82', 2, 9, 16, 5300) God gave you an opportunity to do so at Poona, but at Bombay you forgot all about that God given opportunity.
('82', 2, 9, 17, 5410) At Bardoli God gave you that opportunity again.
('82', 2, 9, 18, 5458) I am exceedingly glad that you did not make the same mistake at Wardha as you had done at Bombay.
('82', 2, 10, 19, 5556) Violence was created by God who gave it a limited life.
('82', 2, 10, 20, 5612) God in His infinite wisdom now finds that violence was given a trial and found wanting in preserving world peace.
('82', 2, 10, 21, 5726) This world war may not be the longest but it must
('82', 2, 11, 22, 5776) 1 J. C. Kumarappa’s article about the new constitution of the A.I.V.I.A. to which this note was appended is not reproduced here.
('82', 2, 11, 23, 5905) 2 In 1934
('82', 3, 0, 1, 5915) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 3, 1, 2, 5955) be the last, and a new world with perfect peace and tranquillity will emerge out of the ashes of violence and armament for the benefit of mankind.
('82', 3, 2, 3, 6102) God believing India will not have man given violence and armament controlled freedom for exploiting the weaker section of humanity.
('82', 3, 2, 4, 6234) She must have God given freedom for their service—seva.
('82', 3, 3, 5, 6290) God given freedom can be obtained only by satyagraha, sufferings for which can be successfully undertaken only by those whose surrender to Him is complete.
('82', 3, 3, 6, 6446) The number of satyagrahis is steadily increasing.
('82', 3, 3, 7, 6496) Let the advocates of violence say and do whatever they may, the number of believers in non violence will steadily go on increasing and the world will have real peace.
('82', 3, 4, 8, 6663) HARA DAYAL NAG
('82', 3, 5, 9, 6678) Chandpur, 24 1 1942
('82', 3, 6, 10, 6698) Though the foregoing 1 has an intrinsic value as an expression of robust faith, it is printed as being from the pen of the oldest living Congressman who clings to non violence as an infant to its mother’s breast.
('82', 3, 7, 11, 6911) SEVAGRAM, February 9, 1942

('82', 3, 12, 23, 7441) How can you expect to impose on somebody else a duty which you yourself are not ready to perform?
('82', 3, 12, 24, 7539) If I had anybody with me, I would have taken charge of Ratilal long ago.
('82', 3, 12, 25, 7612) I acknowledge no duties

('82', 4, 10, 16, 8353) I have also read what you wrote to Ramnarayanji.

('82', 4, 10, 18, 8446) What answer can I give to your questions?

('82', 5, 0, 1, 8946) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 5, 1, 2, 8986) 8. ‘SUPPOSE GERMANY WINS’
('82', 5, 2, 3, 9012) Suppose Germany wins with India not having entered the war, would
('82', 5, 3, 4, 9078) Hitler leave India alone?
('82', 5, 3, 5, 9104) Certainly not, my dear Mr. Gandhi, he will have a
('82', 5, 4, 6, 9154) greater say in India than what Britain has now.
('82', 5, 4, 7, 9202) The difference is this.
('82', 5, 4, 8, 9226) You can
('82', 5, 5, 9, 9234) fight the Englishman, but you cannot fight the German once he puts his foot
('82', 5, 6, 10, 9310) on India’s soil.
('82', 5, 6, 11, 9327) Civil disobedience is the terror of the Englishman, it is the
('82', 5, 7, 12, 9389) daily bread of the Nazi.
('82', 5, 7, 13, 9414) This is a question extracted from a very long and earnest letter from an English correspondent from South Africa.
('82', 5, 7, 14, 9528) The first fallacy is that India is assumed not to have entered the war when to all intents and purposes she is in the war in spite of the powerful protest of the Congress.
('82', 5, 7, 15, 9700) She is so much in the war that Great Britain is effectively using all the available fighting material which her generals have brought into being and trained, and is draining all the money she can.
('82', 5, 7, 16, 9897) Politically minded Indians have never been trained except for doing the rulers’ clerical work.
('82', 5, 7, 17, 9992) They are certainly holding themselves aloof until certain obviously necessary conditions are fulfilled.
('82', 5, 7, 18, 10096) I do not see how they can be blamed for demanding the very liberty in defence of which the Allied Powers are said to be fighting.
('82', 5, 7, 19, 10226) What Indians can do even if their demand is accepted is to give their moral weight to the struggle.
('82', 5, 7, 20, 10326) This the rulers evidently do not care for.
('82', 5, 7, 21, 10369) It cannot, in their opinion, turn the scales in their favour.
('82', 5, 7, 22, 10431) Moral values do not count when each party swears by its material and physical resources.
('82', 5, 7, 23, 10520) The Congress, with all the will in the world to defeat Nazism, cannot thrust its help on Great Britain which evidently does not want it or about which it is at least indifferent.
('82', 5, 7, 24, 10699) If, therefore, Great Britain suffers defeat, it will not be for want of Congress co operation but for causes over which the Congress can have no control.
('82', 5, 8, 25, 10853) If the Nazis come to India, the Congress will give them the same fight that it has given Great Britain.
('82', 5, 8, 26, 10957) I do not underrate the power of satyagraha as the questioner does.
('82', 5, 8, 27, 11024) But that is pure speculation.
('82', 5, 8, 28, 11054) Imperialism has kept its grip on India for more than 150 years.
('82', 5, 8, 29, 11118) If it is overthrown by a worse type of rule, the Congress can have the negative satisfaction of knowing that no other ‘ism’ can possibly last beyound a few years even if it establishes a foothold in India.
('82', 5, 8, 30, 11324) That is as I read the Congress mind.
('82', 5, 8, 31, 11361) Personally I think the end of this giant
('82', 6, 0, 1, 11402) VOL. 82 : 9 FEBRUARY 1940 6 JUNE, 1940 7
('82', 6, 1, 2, 11443) war will be what happened in the fabled Mahabharata War.
('82', 6, 1, 3, 11500) The Mahabharata has been aptly described by a Travancorian as the permanent History of Man.
('82', 6, 1, 4, 11592) What is described in that great epic is happening today before our very eyes.
('82', 6, 1, 5, 11670) The warring nations are destroying themselves with such fury and ferocity that the end will be mutual exhaustion.
('82', 6, 1, 6, 11784) The victor will share the fate that awaited the surviving Pandavas.
('82', 6, 1, 7, 11852) The mighty warrior Arjuna was looted in broad daylight by a petty robber.
('82', 6, 1, 8, 11926) And out of this holocaust must arise a new order for which the exploited millions of toilers have so long thirsted.
('82', 6, 1, 9, 12042) The prayers of peace lovers cannot go in vain.
('82', 6, 1, 10, 12089) Satyagraha is itself an unmistakable mute prayer of an agonized soul.
('82', 6, 2, 11, 12159) SEVAGRAM, February 10, 1942
('82', 6, 3, 12, 12187) Harijan, 15 2 1942
('82', 6, 4, 13, 12206) 9. SETH JAMNALAL BAJAJ 1
('82', 6, 5, 14, 12231) In Seth Jamnalal Bajaj, death has taken a mighty man.
('82', 6, 6, 15, 12285) Whenever I wrote of wealthy men becoming trustees of their wealth for the common good I always had this merchant prince principally in mind.
('82', 6, 6, 16, 12426) If his trusteeship did not reach the ideal, the fault was not his.
('82', 6, 6, 17, 12493) I deliberately restrained him.
('82', 6, 6, 18, 12524) I did not want him in his enthusiasm to take a single step which in his cool moments he might regret.
('82', 6, 6, 19, 12626) His simplicity was all his own.
('82', 6, 6, 20, 12658) Every house he built for himself became a dharmashala.
('82', 6, 6, 21, 12713) His contribution as a satyagrahi was of the highest order.
('82', 6, 6, 22, 12772) In political discussions he held his own.
('82', 6, 6, 23, 12814) His judgements were sound.
('82', 6, 6, 24, 12841) As an act of renunciation his last was the crown of all.
('82', 6, 6, 25, 12898) He wanted to take up a constructive activity to which he could devote the rest of his life and in which he could use all his abilities.
('82', 6, 6, 26, 13034) This was the preservation of the cattle wealth of India personifed in the cow.
('82', 6, 6, 27, 13113) He threw himself into the work with a single mindedness and zeal I had never seen surpassed.
('82', 6, 6, 28, 13206) His generosity knew no distinction of race, creed or colour.
('82', 6, 6, 29, 13267) He wanted to perform a rare thing for a busy man.
('82', 6, 6, 30, 13317) He wanted to control his thoughts so as to prevent a single intruder
('82', 6, 7, 31, 13386) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('82', 6, 7, 32, 13417) 2 Jamnalal Bajaj had died of cerebral haemorrhage in the afternoon.
('82', 6, 7, 33, 13485) For an account by Mahadev Desai, vide Appendix “Mahadev Desai’s Letter to C. Rajagopalachari”, 14 2 1942.

('82', 7, 3, 9, 14027) 10. LETTER TO CHIANG KAI SHEK
('82', 7, 4, 10, 14057) February 11, 1942
('82', 7, 5, 11, 14075) DEAREST FRIEND, As you know I am living in a village out of touch with the outside world.
('82', 7, 5, 12, 14165) I came to know of your arrival in my country side by side with the precious message from Pandit Nehru that you were coming to Wardha and to grace my cottage with your presence.
('82', 7, 5, 13, 14342) And so I refrained from sending you a word of welcome.
('82', 7, 5, 14, 14397) But to my great sorrow I have just learnt that you would not be able to come to Wardha and you would not think of letting me come to you.
('82', 7, 5, 15, 14535) I must leave you to imagine my sorrow that although you are in my country I shall miss seeing you and your noble partner.
('82', 7, 5, 16, 14657) We know each other through correspondence but much more through Jawaharlal Nehru.
('82', 7, 5, 17, 14739) I have many ties with your country.
('82', 7, 5, 18, 14775) I know that yours is a vaster country than mine.
('82', 7, 5, 19, 14824) And I do not know that yours is not a more ancient culture than ours.
('82', 7, 5, 20, 14894) I know what it is to lose one’s liberty, having lost it for so many centuries.
('82', 7, 5, 21, 14973) My whole heart goes out to you in your fight to preserve your own.
('82', 7, 5, 22, 15040) May God crown your effort with success.
('82', 7, 5, 23, 15080) The knowledge that circumstances over which you and I have no control make it impossible for us to meet brings us closer in spirit.
('82', 7, 7, 24, 15212) Your sincere friend, M. K. GANDHI
('82', 7, 8, 25, 15246) H. E. GENERALISSIMO CHIANG KAI SHEK
('82', 7, 9, 26, 15282) From a copy: Gandhi Nehru Papers, 1942 Courtesy: Nehru Memorial Museum and Library
('82', 7, 10, 27, 15365) 1 However, Gandhiji met the addressee on February 18, 1942.

('82', 8, 9, 14, 16051) 12. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('82', 8, 10, 15, 16080) February 11, 1942
('82', 8, 11, 16, 16098) We wondered where we should perform the cremation rites—at the Sevagram hillock, the public cremation ground or Gopuri.
('82', 8, 11, 17, 16218) And it was decided to perform the rites at Gopuri where Jamnalalji had finally settled and for which work he had finally dedicated himself by renouncing his all.
('82', 8, 11, 18, 16380) I was neutral in the matter but I welcomed the decision.
('82', 8, 12, 19, 16437) Thousands of people converged on Gopuri to bid farewell to the body.
('82', 8, 12, 20, 16506) After the cremation Vinoba recited the full text of the Ishavasyopanishad in his sweet voice.
('82', 8, 12, 21, 16600) Then I asked him to recite Chapter XII from Gitai 1 so that all those who were assembled could understand.
('82', 8, 12, 22, 16707) He recited the 9th.
('82', 8, 12, 23, 16727) I had suggested the 12th because it is short.
('82', 8, 12, 24, 16773) But Vinoba has everything committed to memory.
('82', 8, 12, 25, 16820) Hence he recited the 9th.
('82', 8, 12, 26, 16846) But I was not to be satisfied with that.
('82', 8, 12, 27, 16887) I asked him to
('82', 8, 13, 28, 16902) 1 Vinoba Bhave’s metrical Marathi rendering of the Gita.
('82', 8, 13, 29, 16959) Chapters IX and XII deal with devotion.
('82', 9, 0, 1, 16999) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 9, 1, 2, 17040) recite an abhanga.
('82', 9, 1, 3, 17059) 1 He recited one from Tukaram.
('82', 9, 1, 4, 17090) Lastly I requested him to sing ‘Vaishnavajana’.
('82', 9, 1, 5, 17138) He then sang this bhajan too.
('82', 9, 1, 6, 17168) Parachure Shastri had of course arrived there.
('82', 9, 1, 7, 17215) He recited hymns from the Vedas and, at my request, explained their gist to the assembly.
('82', 9, 1, 8, 17305) The hymns selected conveyed, as was proper, the most solemn thoughts.
('82', 9, 1, 9, 17375) Their purport was to this effect:
('82', 9, 2, 10, 17409) The light that was confined within Jamnalalji has now merged in the Cosmic Light [present] in us all.
('82', 9, 2, 11, 17511) The body is reduced to ashes but what was enduring and yet confined within certain bounds has now come to us all.
('82', 9, 2, 12, 17625) Jamnalalji belonged to a few, now he belongs to the universe.
('82', 9, 2, 13, 17687) The body has been cast off, but his vows, his pledges, his goseva, his khadi work, his devotion to truth and non violence, these have merged in us all; they have become our legacy.
('82', 9, 2, 14, 17868) Whatever he has done in pursuance of all his vows belongs to us no doubt, but what remains to be done is for us to complete.
('82', 9, 2, 15, 17993) Today he hands it over to us to learn and practise.
('82', 9, 3, 16, 18045) What message could have been more proper?
('82', 9, 3, 17, 18087) How can I say that I am not grieved over his passing away?
('82', 9, 3, 18, 18146) It is but natural.
('82', 9, 3, 19, 18165) I may say he was for me a Kamadhenu cow.
('82', 9, 3, 20, 18206) If I was in a quandary, I would send for Jamnalalji; if I wanted to undertake anything I would consult Jamnalalji.
('82', 9, 3, 21, 18321) He always responded to my call.
('82', 9, 3, 22, 18353) How can I then help being grieved?
('82', 9, 3, 23, 18388) But I forget my grief when I think of the work he has done and the message he has left for us.
('82', 9, 4, 24, 18483) What we have to bear in mind today is that we are occupying what he built.
('82', 9, 4, 25, 18558) I know his love for Sevagram.
('82', 9, 4, 26, 18588) He was concerned how every cowrie in Sevagram was spent and how it was accounted for, because in his life he kept account of every pie.
('82', 9, 4, 27, 18724) And he always insisted that the conduct and behaviour of anyone who went out of Sevagram were worthy of its fair name.
('82', 9, 5, 28, 18843) And what a life he himself lived!
('82', 9, 5, 29, 18877) Once he came to me saying: “You love me well enough, but I want to be a son to you just as Devdas is.” How could I make a son of that mountain of a man?
('82', 9, 5, 30, 19030) But I gave in to his love and insistence and granted his request.

('82', 10, 2, 20, 20460) 1 But neither I nor anyone else will restrain you, if you kindle the fire of yoga and consign yourself to its flames.
('82', 10, 2, 21, 20578) But this is not possible.
('82', 10, 2, 22, 20604) That is why I say you can now prove yourself a devoted wife only by becoming a yogi, i.e., by pursuing his ideals.
('82', 10, 2, 23, 20719) You can become a true sati by renouncing your all for the sake of his work.” Ghanshyamdasji who was present said, “We have a custom of taking a pious vow on such occasions.
('82', 10, 2, 24, 20892) Advise Janakidevi to take one.” Janakidevi spontaneously said, “Here is my vow: I dedicate for his ideals everything that he has left me.” She showed me her accounts also.
('82', 10, 2, 25, 21064) The amount was more than two lacs.
('82', 10, 2, 26, 21099) All this she has devoted to goseva and vowed to bury herself in the work at Gopuri.
('82', 10, 2, 27, 21183) In this way she became the sati.
('82', 10, 2, 28, 21216) But who can say whether all this is a result of pure renunciation or of momentary impulse?

('82', 10, 2, 30, 21381) Vinoba who was present there told her that if there was a pious wish God was sure to give the strength to realize it.

('82', 13, 1, 2, 24892) 14. TALK WITH BAJAJ FAMILY
('82', 13, 2, 3, 24919) February 12, 1942
('82', 13, 3, 4, 24937) To Kamalnayan Bajaj, the eldest son of Jamnalal Bajaj, Gandhiji said : According to Hinduism the eldest son like the other sons does inherit the father’s wealth but along with it he also becomes the trustee of the family’s traditions and his father’s ethics and principles.
('82', 13, 3, 5, 25211) Hence I would say to you that if you are already engaged in business, continue to do so; earn wealth if you want, but like Jamnalalji all your earnings should be fair earnings.
('82', 13, 3, 6, 25388) Again, bear in mind that for the good of the people you too have to be a trustee of your wealth.
('82', 13, 3, 7, 25485) you shall spend what you earn not for your own self but to serve the people.
('82', 13, 3, 8, 25562) Only then will your trusteeship have meaning.
('82', 13, 4, 9, 25608) Then explaining things to the younger brother, Ramakrishna, he said: Now, I expect you to dedicate your whole life to service and completing whatever work Jamnalal left incomplete.
('82', 13, 4, 10, 25789) But I don’t want to compel you to do it.
('82', 13, 4, 11, 25830) Pledge yourself to it, if you have the strength.
('82', 13, 4, 12, 25879) Remember God always grants us the strength to carry out all our pious vows.
('82', 13, 4, 13, 25955) And there will be no harm even if we do not succeed.
('82', 13, 4, 14, 26008) According to the Gita even one who has fallen from yoga does not meet with a sad end.
('82', 13, 5, 15, 26094) Then he spoke to Jamnalalji’s brother’s son, Radhakrishnaji : You very well know the vow that Janakidevi has taken.
('82', 13, 5, 16, 26210) I think if she comes by a right adviser, as Queen Victoria had in Melbourne, she is sure to add prestige to the Presidentship of the Goseva Sangh.
('82', 13, 5, 17, 26357) She is a daughter to Mother Cow, she can therefore render the best service to her own ‘mother’.
('82', 13, 5, 18, 26453) I don’t want to lay greater burden on her in her present failing health.
('82', 13, 5, 19, 26526) But I know the strength born of resolve makes the body of an ‘incarnation of sacrifice’ strong as the thunderbolt.
('82', 13, 5, 20, 26641) You will remember that after all the responsibilities are shared what remains shall rest on your shoulders.
('82', 13, 6, 21, 26749) Finally, talking to Jamnalalji’s daughters 1Gandhiji said: You have heard all that I have just spoken to Kamalnayan and
('82', 13, 7, 22, 26869) 1 Kamala Nevatia, Madalasa and Umadevi Agrawal
('82', 14, 0, 1, 26916) VOL. 82 : 9 FEBRUARY 1940 6 JUNE, 1940 15
('82', 14, 1, 2, 26958) Ramakrishna and the others.
('82', 14, 1, 3, 26986) Remember you too have to do likewise.
('82', 14, 1, 4, 27024) I shall expect from you too sacrifice according to your own strength.
('82', 14, 1, 5, 27094) Never forget, whatever Jamnalalji had earned he had surren dered to Lord Krishna.
('82', 14, 1, 6, 27176) If you have any share from it know that you have it subject to the conditions of trusteeship.
('82', 14, 1, 7, 27270) It is not for your personal comforts and luxuries but only so that you too like Jamnalalji should act as its trustees.

('82', 21, 1, 2, 36357) 26. OASIS IN A DESERT 1
('82', 21, 2, 3, 36381) In the midst of the desert of adverse but ill thought criticism of Government officials of basic education it is refreshing to find the following appreciation of the basic schools of Bihar from the pen of Mr. E. R. J. R. Cousins, Adviser to H.E. the Governor of Bihar, received by Shri Aryanayakum, Secretary of the Hindustani Talimi Sangh.
('82', 21, 3, 4, 36722) I was able to meet the teachers and pupils of 18 out of the 27 schools
('82', 21, 4, 5, 36793) I was impressed with the cleanliness, intelligence and obvious pleasure of
('82', 21, 5, 6, 36868) the pupils in their work, and I am confident that we are proceeding on the right
('82', 21, 6, 7, 36949) lines, and that children of 14 who have gone through the entire basic
('82', 21, 7, 8, 37019) curriculum will not fail in comparison with those who have gone through the
('82', 21, 8, 9, 37095) ordinary school course up to the same age.
('82', 21, 9, 10, 37138) A particularly encouraging feature, and one upon which I place the
('82', 21, 10, 11, 37205) greatest emphasis, is that the schools have undoubtedly succeeded in capturing
('82', 21, 11, 12, 37284) the goodwill and interest of the village people, and as long as this can be
('82', 21, 12, 13, 37360) retained it is impossible for the system to fail of being a success.
('82', 21, 13, 14, 37429) confident that .
('82', 21, 13, 15, 37446) in addition to education in the ordinary sense the village
('82', 21, 14, 16, 37505) boys of the future will acquire at the school such attributes of mental alertness,
('82', 21, 15, 17, 37588) manual dexterity, health and cleanliness as will make the villages in future
('82', 21, 16, 18, 37665) more healthy, attractive and enlightened places than they have been in the
('82', 21, 18, 19, 37740) SEVAGRAM, February 16, 1942
('82', 21, 19, 20, 37768) Harijan, 22 2 1942

('82', 22, 0, 1, 37871) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 23
('82', 22, 1, 2, 37913) 27. MODEL SCHOOLS FOR HARIJANS
('82', 22, 2, 3, 37944) Seth Ghanshyamdas Birla, President of the Harijan Sevak Sangh, writes :
('82', 22, 3, 4, 38016) We are thinking of establishing a few residential schools mainly for
('82', 22, 4, 5, 38085) educating Harijan boys, though not exclusively.
('82', 22, 4, 6, 38133) So far, whenever we have
('82', 22, 5, 7, 38158) talked of Harijan hostels or schools, we have thereby meant cheap schools or
('82', 22, 6, 8, 38235) cheap hostels conducted by ill educated and ill paid teachers and wardens with
('82', 22, 7, 9, 38314) boys half starved.
('82', 22, 7, 10, 38333) So long as we educate Harijans or children of poor parents
('82', 22, 8, 11, 38392) in these cheap institutions, the boys will never succeed in shedding the
('82', 22, 9, 12, 38465) inferiority complex from which they often suffer.
('82', 22, 9, 13, 38515) And what will they learn
('82', 22, 10, 14, 38540) from these unqualified and ill paid teachers?
('82', 22, 10, 15, 38586) These boys never get the
('82', 22, 11, 16, 38611) opportunity to mix with the other boys.
('82', 22, 11, 17, 38651) The harm due to this lack of contact
('82', 22, 12, 18, 38688) between the poor and the well to do or between Harijans and Savarnas is
('82', 22, 13, 19, 38760) mutual.
('82', 22, 13, 20, 38768) I therefore propose that we should have a few residential schools
('82', 22, 14, 21, 38834) established in pleasing environment.
('82', 22, 14, 22, 38871) They should be of a standard that would
('82', 22, 15, 23, 38911) compare favourably in every respect with a well conducted public school.
('82', 22, 16, 24, 38984) should start a few such schools first of all as a trial.
('82', 22, 17, 25, 39041) They should be of the matriculation standard and affiliated to a
('82', 22, 18, 26, 39106) university.
('82', 22, 18, 27, 39118) They should, of course, be mostly residential.
('82', 22, 18, 28, 39165) Personal attention
('82', 22, 19, 29, 39184) to students should be a speciality.
('82', 22, 19, 30, 39220) Education should be imparted through the
('82', 22, 20, 31, 39261) medium of the mother tongue.
('82', 22, 20, 32, 39290) English should be taught as a second language.
('82', 22, 21, 33, 39337) During the period of this education, the boys should be taught useful
('82', 22, 22, 34, 39407) handicrafts chosen for their educative value.
('82', 22, 23, 35, 39453) In order to make this education thorough and self sufficient, we should
('82', 22, 24, 36, 39525) take two years more than the time needed for the matriculation examination.
('82', 22, 25, 37, 39601) These two years should be utilized in giving extra training to the boys besides
('82', 22, 26, 38, 39681) what they learn for the matriculation course.
('82', 22, 27, 39, 39727) We propose to have three crafts, one of which will be taken up by every
('82', 22, 28, 40, 39799) boy at his option.
('82', 22, 28, 41, 39818) These will be :
('82', 22, 29, 42, 39834) Either (1) Carding, Spinning, Weaving, Dyeing and Bleaching; or (2)
('82', 22, 30, 43, 39902) Carpentry and Smithy; or (3) Paper making, Book binding, and Ordinary
('82', 22, 31, 44, 39972) Composing.
('82', 22, 32, 45, 39983) It is intended to employ a superior staff, adequately paid, to ensure good
('82', 22, 33, 46, 40058) qualifications.
('82', 22, 33, 47, 40074) The underlying idea is that the boys may not feel the want of a
('82', 23, 0, 1, 40138) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 24
('82', 23, 1, 2, 40179) college education.
('82', 23, 1, 3, 40198) There will be no bar to such.
('82', 23, 1, 4, 40228) The boys, it is hoped, will not
('82', 23, 2, 5, 40260) find it difficult to earn an honest livelihood after finishing the course.
('82', 23, 2, 6, 40335) It will
('82', 23, 3, 7, 40343) be the duty of the Board to accommodate such boys as may like to be.
('82', 23, 4, 8, 40412) Besides the university course and craft, special attention will be given to
('82', 23, 5, 9, 40488) increasing their general knowledge and hygiene.
('82', 23, 5, 10, 40536) Music games, exercises,
('82', 23, 6, 11, 40560) riding, swimming, etc., should be taught.
('82', 23, 6, 12, 40602) Religious or moral training should
('82', 23, 7, 13, 40637) not be neglected.
('82', 23, 7, 14, 40655) Equal respect for all religions should be inculcated, along
('82', 23, 8, 15, 40715) with a good grounding in the principles of Hinduism and the peculiar beauties
('82', 23, 9, 16, 40793) of our own culture.
('82', 23, 10, 17, 40813) Half the number of the students should be Harijans who would have free
('82', 23, 11, 18, 40884) education and free boarding and lodging.
('82', 23, 11, 19, 40925) The other half of the students, i.e.,
('82', 23, 12, 20, 40963) Savarnas, should be charged fees.
('82', 23, 13, 21, 40997) This is a very rough and brief outline of my idea of a good high school.
('82', 23, 14, 22, 41070) But there is difference amongst us about this outline.
('82', 23, 14, 23, 41125) Some say: Why
('82', 23, 15, 24, 41139) should we have the matriculation course?
('82', 23, 15, 25, 41180) Others say: We should not undertake
('82', 23, 16, 26, 41216) costly education as this will be a bad example to set.
('82', 23, 16, 27, 41271) It is argued that we may
('82', 23, 17, 28, 41296) employ most qualified men, but only if they come on a bare maintenance and
('82', 23, 18, 29, 41371) out of a spirit of sacrifice.
('82', 23, 18, 30, 41401) In other words, in their opinion, in this school
('82', 23, 19, 31, 41450) there would be no room for teachers other than those prepared to lead a simple
('82', 23, 20, 32, 41529) life of sacrifice.
('82', 23, 20, 33, 41548) Some go to the extent of saying that we should rather have no
('82', 23, 21, 34, 41610) school than start one which is not manned by a highly self sacrificing staff.
('82', 23, 22, 35, 41688) I consider all this unpractical.
('82', 23, 22, 36, 41721) I need not give my arguments.
('82', 23, 22, 37, 41751) They are
('82', 23, 23, 38, 41760) obvious.
('82', 23, 24, 39, 41769) Will you express your views on this question?
('82', 23, 24, 40, 41815) I whole heartedly support Seth Ghanshyamdas’s scheme.
('82', 23, 24, 41, 41869) The arguments advanced in opposition seem to be based more on caution than on principle.
('82', 23, 24, 42, 41958) I too should side with the opposition, if the scheme was to be financed out of the meagre funds of the Harijan Board.
('82', 23, 24, 43, 42076) But I assume that the model schools would be financed by special donations enough to guarantee their full working.
('82', 23, 24, 44, 42191) Having lived in South Africa for twenty years where every Indian is treated almost as a pariah, I know how sensitive the mind becomes under unnatural treatment.
('82', 23, 24, 45, 42352) I took some time to regain my balance though I never lost the sensitiveness.
('82', 23, 24, 46, 42429) I felt that I was a strange creature in the company of the general body of Europeans.
('82', 23, 24, 47, 42515) The plight of Harijans in India is much worse because of their much greater ignorance and still greater
('82', 24, 0, 1, 42619) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 25
('82', 24, 1, 2, 42661) poverty.
('82', 24, 1, 3, 42670) Therefore, if we are to break down the double complex, we have to bring up a fair number of Harijan lads in surroundings in no way inferior to those that are available to the well to do class boys.
('82', 24, 1, 4, 42868) The scheme under examination does not contemplate the production of clerks who would be too big for their boots and who would be naturally discontented because no one would have them as clerks.
('82', 24, 1, 5, 43062) Boys trained under the scheme would be in no way inferior in knowledge to the other matriculates.
('82', 24, 1, 6, 43160) But these will be better placed because their bodies will be specially looked after and their hands will have their cunning fully developed.
('82', 24, 1, 7, 43301) Such boys will have their future assured.
('82', 24, 1, 8, 43343) They will have self confidence.
('82', 24, 1, 9, 43375) They will not be torn from their kith and kin; on the contrary, they will be expected to serve fellow Harijans and give them benefit of the teaching they have received.
('82', 24, 2, 10, 43544) It may be objected that I am inconsistent in that I have written and spoken against the present system of education.
('82', 24, 2, 11, 43661) The objection would be superficial.
('82', 24, 2, 12, 43697) In the first place, the worst features of the system will be eliminated in that the training will be in the mother tongue and the boys will be taught handicrafts which should enable them to earn an independent and decent living.
('82', 24, 2, 13, 43926) Secondly, an objection that may be applicable to boys who can be better educated cannot be held good in the case of boys who have no choice and who smart under the knowledge that they cannot have the education that thousands of boys have simply because they are not Harijans.
('82', 24, 2, 14, 44202) I would not insult Harijan lads by arguing with them that what the thousands of non Harijan lads are doing is wrong, and that therefore they had better be satisfied with the shanties which Seth Ghanshyamdas has referred to in his letter.
('82', 24, 3, 15, 44440) I plump for his scheme.
('82', 24, 3, 16, 44464) I wish him all success.
('82', 24, 3, 17, 44488) The sooner it is launched, the better for Harijans and better for India.
('82', 24, 3, 18, 44561) These schools will be potent instruments for exorcising the demon of untouchability.
('82', 24, 4, 19, 44646) SEVAGRAM, February 16, 1942 Harijan, 22 2 1942
('82', 25, 0, 1, 44693) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 26
('82', 25, 1, 2, 44734) 28. FIERY ORDEAL
('82', 25, 2, 3, 44751) Twenty two years ago a young man of thirty came to me and said, “I want to ask something of you.”
('82', 25, 3, 4, 44849) “Ask, and it shall be given, if it is at all within my power to give,” I replied with some surprise.
('82', 25, 4, 5, 44950) “Regard me as your son Devdas,” the young man said.
('82', 25, 5, 6, 45002) “Agreed,” I replied.
('82', 25, 5, 7, 45023) “But what have you asked of me?
('82', 25, 5, 8, 45055) You are the giver, I am the gainer.”
('82', 25, 6, 9, 45092) The young man was no other than Jamnalal Bajaj.
('82', 25, 6, 10, 45140) People know something of what this sacrament meant.
('82', 25, 6, 11, 45192) But few know the extent of the part played by the self adopted son.
('82', 25, 6, 12, 45260) Never before, I can say, was a mortal blessed with a ‘son’ like him.
('82', 25, 6, 13, 45329) Of course I have many sons and daughters in the sense that they do some of my work.
('82', 25, 6, 14, 45413) But Jamnalalji surrendered himself and his without reservation.
('82', 25, 6, 15, 45477) There is hardly any activity of mine in which I did not receive his full hearted co operation and in which it did not prove to be of the greatest value.
('82', 25, 6, 16, 45630) He was gifted with a quick intelligence.
('82', 25, 6, 17, 45671) He was a merchant prince.
('82', 25, 6, 18, 45697) He placed at my disposal his ample possessions.
('82', 25, 6, 19, 45745) He was constantly on the vigil and looked after my work, my comforts, my health and my finances.
('82', 25, 6, 20, 45842) He would also bring up the workers to me.
('82', 25, 6, 21, 45884) Where am I to get another son like him now?
('82', 25, 6, 22, 45928) The day he died he and Janakidevi were to come to me.
('82', 25, 6, 23, 45982) We had to decide a number of things.
('82', 25, 6, 24, 46019) But God willed it otherwise and he died almost at the very hour he should have been with me.
('82', 25, 6, 25, 46112) The death of such a son is a stunning blow to the father.
('82', 25, 6, 26, 46170) Never before have I felt so forlorn except when Maganlal was snatched from me fourteen years ago 1. But I had no doubt then, as I have none now, that a calamity of that kind is a blessing in disguise.
('82', 25, 6, 27, 46371) God wants to try me through and through.
('82', 25, 6, 28, 46412) I live in the faith that He will give me the strength too to pass through the ordeal.
('82', 25, 7, 29, 46498) SEVAGRAM, February 16, 1942

('82', 25, 9, 31, 46564) 1 In April 1928; vide “My Best Comrade Gone”, 26 4 1928.

('82', 27, 1, 2, 47910) 31. LETTER TO SULTANA RAZIA
('82', 27, 2, 3, 47938) February 16, 1942
('82', 27, 3, 4, 47956) DEAR SISTER,
('82', 27, 4, 5, 47969) Bapuji has received your letter.

('82', 27, 9, 11, 48193) 32. PLEA FOR CALMNESS
('82', 27, 10, 12, 48215) The recent British reverses ought not to create panic in the land.
('82', 27, 10, 13, 48282) In all the wars that Britain has fought or in which she has been engaged there have been reverses some of which may be considered disastrous.
('82', 27, 10, 14, 48424) But the British have a knack of surviving them and turning them into stepping stones to success.
('82', 27, 10, 15, 48521) Hence the saying peculiar to them that they blunder through to success.
('82', 27, 10, 16, 48593) Failures do not dismay or demoralize them.
('82', 27, 10, 17, 48636) They take them with calmness and in a sportsmanlike spirit.
('82', 27, 10, 18, 48696) Wars are for them a national game like football.
('82', 27, 10, 19, 48745) The defeated team heartily congratulates the successful one almost as if it was a joint victory, and drowns the sorrow of defeat in an exchange of glasses of whisky.
('82', 27, 10, 20, 48911) If we have learnt nothing worth from the contact with the British, let us at least their calmness in the face of misfortunes.
('82', 27, 11, 21, 49037) And is there the slightest cause for alarm?
('82', 27, 11, 22, 49081) Certainly not for those who believe in non violence.
('82', 27, 11, 23, 49134) For fear and distrust of self are no part of their composition, nor are they part of a panoplied soldier.
('82', 27, 11, 24, 49240) The attribute of non violence is perhaps only a copy book maxim.
('82', 27, 11, 25, 49305) We do not see it in actual practice in any measure.
('82', 27, 11, 26, 49357) But this war is abundant proof that neither party though steeped in violence betrays any fear or distrust.
('82', 27, 11, 27, 49464) I am filled with amazement and admiration at the reckless bravery displayed by combatants on either side.
('82', 27, 11, 28, 49570) This war is a demonstration of the unthinkable nerve that human beings are capable
('82', 28, 0, 1, 49653) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 29
('82', 28, 1, 2, 49695) of possessing.
('82', 28, 1, 3, 49710) Looked at from either standpoint, therefore, we should be ashamed of fear, distrust and nervelessness in the face of danger.
('82', 28, 1, 4, 49835) It is, therefore, the sacred duty of every worker to steel himself against cowardly panic and prevent its spread as far as he can.
('82', 28, 1, 5, 49966) “Cowards die many times before their death.” Let this not be proved of us.
('82', 28, 2, 6, 50041) The true danger exists only for cities.
('82', 28, 2, 7, 50081) It may be very near due to the fall of Singapore and probable loss of Burma.
('82', 28, 2, 8, 50158) One of the best precautions consists in those people who are not wanted in the cities or those who want to shun danger, migrating to the villages in an orderly manner.
('82', 28, 2, 9, 50326) There should be no panicky rush.
('82', 28, 2, 10, 50359) Those who must remain in the cities whether for business or otherwise should carry out instructions that may be issued by the authorities from time to time.
('82', 28, 2, 11, 50516) Those who will not, for any reason whatsoever, should clear out in good time.
('82', 28, 2, 12, 50594) If this simple precaution is taken, we may face the future without perturbation.
('82', 28, 2, 13, 50675) More I cannot say, for we are a house divided against itself and there is no living bond between the rulers and the ruled.
('82', 28, 2, 14, 50798) It is tragic but it is true.
('82', 28, 2, 15, 50827) The tragedy is deepened by the knowledge that all parties feel so helpless.
('82', 28, 3, 16, 50903) ON THE TRAIN TO CALCUTTA, February 17, 1942 Harijan, 22 2 1942
('82', 28, 4, 17, 50966) 33. EYES TO THE BLIND 1
('82', 28, 5, 18, 50990) Though I had heard a lot about the reputation of Dr. Mathuradas of Moga, I had never had occasion to witness any of his famous operations for cataract, until I saw them in Wardha last month.
('82', 28, 5, 19, 51181) He came specially at the invitation of Jamnalalji, and with his assistants restored eyes to about three hundred people who had been blinded by cataract.
('82', 28, 6, 20, 51334) These mass operations have been described as a yajna (sacrifice).
('82', 28, 6, 21, 51400) And yajna it certainly is, as any act of selfless service is a sacrifice.
('82', 28, 6, 22, 51474) This yajna began some years ago in the Bhagavadbhakti Ashram at Rewari, with which Jamnalalji was closely connected.
('82', 28, 6, 23, 51591) He therefore invited the doctor this time to Wardha.
('82', 28, 6, 24, 51644) I bowed to Dr.
('82', 28, 7, 25, 51659) 1 This appeared under “Notes” The Hindi original appeared in Harijan Sevak, 22 2 1942.
('82', 29, 0, 1, 51746) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 30
('82', 29, 1, 2, 51787) Mathuradas in admiration for his unerring and quick surgical hand.
('82', 29, 1, 3, 51854) He performed operations at the rate of one in a minute, there was scarcely a mishap.
('82', 29, 1, 4, 51939) Thousands thus get back their eyes free, as he charges no fee to the poor.
('82', 29, 2, 5, 52014) The doctor told me that nowhere except in India was cataract so common as was also rhinoplasty.
('82', 29, 2, 6, 52110) These operations, therefore, place him in the forefront of the surgeons for cataract throughout the world.
('82', 29, 2, 7, 52217) No doubt many doctors have now taken up the work and copy his example.
('82', 29, 2, 8, 52288) It is just as it should be, for the medical profession should be one of selfless service.
('82', 29, 2, 9, 52378) And there was no humanitarian mission for which Jamnalalji was not ready.
('82', 29, 2, 10, 52452) It came to him as naturally as any of his business enterprises.
('82', 29, 2, 11, 52516) That was why he had a scheme in hand for making these operations a periodical feature in C.P.
('82', 29, 3, 12, 52610) I hope that the scheme will not be interrupted by his death, and Dr. Mathuradas is always ready for these yajnas.

('82', 35, 12, 13, 59969) 48. DISCUSSION WITH CHIANG KAI SHEK AND WIFE 2
('82', 35, 13, 14, 60016) CALCUTTA, February 18, 1942 3
('82', 35, 14, 15, 60046) “I would not think of asking you to come to the Government House,” said the Generalissimo.
('82', 35, 14, 16, 60137) “We would come again, after you have had your meal and rest.” Gandhiji replied : But I have had my meal on the train in order to give you the whole of my time here, and I would suggest, if it were not inconvenient to you, to stay here, have an Indian meal with us, and we can then talk until the minute of my departure.
('82', 35, 14, 17, 60457) We can thus save the time of going to and coming back from Barrackpore.
('82', 35, 15, 18, 60529) And so the guests stayed on .
('82', 35, 15, 19, 60559) and talked with Gandhiji until the moment of his departure for the station .
('82', 35, 16, 20, 60636) 1 Pattabhi Sitaramayya 2 Reproduced from Mahadev Desai’s “A Historic Meeting”.
('82', 35, 16, 21, 60715) Chiang Kai shek and his wife called on Gandhiji within an hour of his arrival at Birla Park.
('82', 35, 16, 22, 60808) 3 From Amrita Bazar Patrika
('82', 36, 0, 1, 60836) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 37
('82', 36, 1, 2, 60878) Part of the time was taken up by Gandhiji in explaining the genesis and course of satyagraha and non co operation, and also in demonstrating to the Generalissimo and the Madame the action of his “weapon of war”—a weapon which, as he explained, “makes no noise, which does not kill, but which, if anything, gives life”.
('82', 36, 1, 3, 61197) The Madame watched the working of the dhanush takli and said: “You will have to teach me this.” Come to Sevagram, and I shall teach it to you.
('82', 36, 1, 4, 61340) Let the Generalissimo leave you here as his ambassador, and I adopt you as my daughter.
('82', 36, 2, 5, 61428) For half an hour or so the official interpreter who accompanied the Generalissimo interpreted him.
('82', 36, 2, 6, 61527) Then, said Gandhiji : But surely ours is not a formal official talk.
('82', 36, 2, 7, 61596) Why should not the Madame interpret you?
('82', 36, 3, 8, 61637) “Now, now, Mahatmaji, that is devastating”, she said.
('82', 36, 3, 9, 61691) “Now I know how everyone succumbs to you.
('82', 36, 3, 10, 61733) My husband is most taxing.
('82', 36, 3, 11, 61760) Whenever there is something very difficult to interpret, some delicate nuances of his thought to be conveyed, I must interpret him.
('82', 36, 3, 12, 61892) But for one year I have been having an easy time asking the official interpreter to do it for me.” Said Gandhiji, laughing : That means that you are a faithless wife.
('82', 36, 4, 13, 62059) “Surely,” retorted the Madame, “he did not marry an interpreter, he married a woman.” 1
('82', 36, 5, 14, 62147) The Generalissimo was sure that non co operation was good for India, but he was not sure that it would serve equally well for other countries—unless of course they were like India in their circumstances and environments.
('82', 36, 5, 15, 62368) He was naturally full of indignation at what Japan had done and was doing in China, and he had grave fears of India having to go through China’s terrible fate if the Japanese overran India.
('82', 36, 5, 16, 62558) It was not possible for Gandhiji to discuss the whole of our non violent technique, but he left the Generalissimo in no doubt that Japan or Germany would be confronted with fierce non co operation or civil resistance.
('82', 36, 5, 17, 62776) “Your civil resistance,” said the Generalissimo, “is not mere passivity, I am sure.
('82', 36, 5, 18, 62860) But these foes may not listen to active civil resistance, and may make even the preaching of non violence impossible.” All I can say is that God gives me the guidance to react to situations as they arise.
('82', 36, 5, 19, 63065) Though, therefore, I cannot say how exactly I
('82', 36, 6, 20, 63111) 1 At the end of the first talk the Madame said: “I have met too many men to succumb to anyone.
('82', 36, 6, 21, 63206) But the Mahatma has captivated me.” Introducing the next paragraph, Mahadev Desai writes: “The rest of the talk had better be guessed.”
('82', 37, 0, 1, 63342) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 38
('82', 37, 1, 2, 63383) will react in case of an invasion, I know that God will give me the proper guidance.
('82', 37, 1, 3, 63468) But this talk cannot, I know, satisfy you.
('82', 37, 1, 4, 63511) I would invite you to come to Sevagram where we can discuss the subject quietly for days.
('82', 37, 1, 5, 63601) I know of course that it is an impossible request, for you cannot possibly stay.
('82', 37, 2, 6, 63682) “Who knows,” said the Madame, “we may be back here sooner than later.
('82', 37, 3, 7, 63752) after all Calcutta is only 12 hours from Chunking.”

('82', 39, 4, 5, 68038) 50. CRIMINAL ASSAULTS 1
('82', 39, 5, 6, 68062) The whole world is on trial today.
('82', 39, 5, 7, 68097) No one can escape from the war.
('82', 39, 5, 8, 68129) Whilst the Ramayana and the Mahabharata are products of poets’ imagination, their authors were not mere rhymsters.
('82', 39, 5, 9, 68244) They were seers.
('82', 39, 5, 10, 68261) 2 What they depicted is happening before our very eyes today.
('82', 39, 5, 11, 68323) Ravanas are warring with each other.

('82', 57, 0, 1, 106905) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 57, 1, 2, 106946) 59. KHADI STUDENTS 1
('82', 57, 2, 3, 106967) I have been asked to write something in regard to khadi students of today.
('82', 57, 2, 4, 107042) I have already written a little but it cannot be too clearly stated nor enough stressed that knowledge of spinning, carding and the other processes alone does not constitute true khadi learning.
('82', 57, 2, 5, 107237) That may be termed its mechanics.
('82', 57, 2, 6, 107271) To understand the inner meaning of khadi one has to know why it has to be turned out by hand and not by power machinery.
('82', 57, 2, 7, 107392) Why should innumerable hands be employed when a single person can manipulate an engine which can produce the same amount of cloth in far less time?
('82', 57, 2, 8, 107540) If khadi has to be produced by hand, why not by the takli only?
('82', 57, 2, 9, 107604) And if the takli, why not the bamboo takli?
('82', 57, 2, 10, 107648) And if we could get the necessary work by suspending yarn by means of a stone, why even takli?
('82', 57, 2, 11, 107743) Such questions are perfectly natural.
('82', 57, 2, 12, 107781) To find proper answers to all such is a necessary part of khadi research.
('82', 57, 2, 13, 107855) I do not want to discuss these questions here.
('82', 57, 2, 14, 107902) All I want to say is that true knowledge of khadi goes far beyond the mechanical processes, and requires patient research.
('82', 57, 2, 15, 108025) We have not the means of imparting such knowledge today.
('82', 57, 2, 16, 108082) Therefore khadi instructors have to improve their knowledge even whilst they are teaching.
('82', 57, 2, 17, 108173) And students have to acquire knowledge through their own diligence.
('82', 57, 2, 18, 108241) In olden times when no scientific knowledge was available, students used to be their own teachers and became firstrate scholars and experts.
('82', 57, 2, 19, 108382) We are more or less in the same position today.

('82', 62, 1, 2, 113843) 67. QUESTION BOX 1
('82', 62, 2, 3, 113862) RICHES V. POVERTY
('82', 62, 3, 4, 113880) Q. How is it possible to earn lakhs in a righteous way?
('82', 62, 3, 5, 113936) 2 Jamnalalji, the
('82', 62, 4, 6, 113954) merchant prince, used to say it was not.
('82', 62, 4, 7, 113995) Moreover, however careful a rich man is, he
('82', 62, 5, 8, 114039) is bound to spend more on himself than his actual requirements merit.
('82', 62, 5, 9, 114109) Therefore why
('82', 62, 6, 10, 114123) not lay more stress on not becoming wealthy than on trusteeship of riches?
('82', 62, 7, 11, 114198) A.The question is apt and has been put to me before.
('82', 62, 7, 12, 114251) 3 What Jamnalalji could have meant was in the Gita sense that every action is tainted.
('82', 62, 7, 13, 114338) It is my conviction that it is possible to acquire riches without consciously doing wrong.
('82', 62, 7, 14, 114429) For example, I may light on a gold mine in my one acre of land.
('82', 62, 7, 15, 114493) But I accept the proposition that it is better not to desire wealth than to acquire it and become its trustee.
('82', 62, 7, 16, 114604) I gave up my own long ago, which should be proof enough of what I would like others to do.
('82', 62, 7, 17, 114695) But what am I to advise those who are already wealthy or who would not shed the desire for wealth?
('82', 62, 7, 18, 114794) I can only say to them that they should use their wealth for service.
('82', 62, 7, 19, 114864) It is true that generally the rich spend more on themselves than they need.
('82', 62, 7, 20, 114940) But this can be avoided.
('82', 62, 7, 21, 114965) Jamnalalji spent far less on himself than men of his own economic status and even than many middle class men.
('82', 62, 7, 22, 115075) I have come across innumerable rich persons who are stingy with themselves.
('82', 62, 7, 23, 115151) For some it is part of their nature to spend next to nothing on themselves, and they do not think that they acquire merit in so doing.
('82', 62, 8, 24, 115286) The same applies to the sons of the wealthy.
('82', 62, 8, 25, 115331) Personally I do not believe in inherited riches.
('82', 62, 8, 26, 115380) The well to do should educate and bring up their children so that they may learn how to be independent.
('82', 62, 8, 27, 115484) The tragedy is that they do not do so.
('82', 62, 8, 28, 115523) Their children do get some education, they even recite verses in praise of poverty, but they have no compunction about helping themselves to parental wealth.
('82', 62, 8, 29, 115681) That being so, I exercise my common sense and advise what is practicable.
('82', 62, 8, 30, 115755) Those of us, however, who consider it a duty to adopt poverty
('82', 62, 9, 31, 115817) 1 The Hindi original appeared in Harijan Sevak, 1 3 1942. 2 Vide “A Deplorable Incident”, 25 1 1942; also “Talk with Bajaj Family”, 12 2 1942. 3 Vide “Not Necessarily Impure”, 8 2 1942.
('82', 63, 0, 1, 116003) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 63, 1, 2, 116044) and who believe in and desire economic equality may not be jealous of the rich but should 1 exhibit real happiness in their poverty which others may emulate.
('82', 63, 1, 3, 116202) The sad fact is that those who are thus happy are few and far between.
('82', 63, 2, 4, 116273) THE DUTY OF A MANAGER
('82', 63, 3, 5, 116295) Q.Is it correct for the head of an institution, while demanding the utmost from
('82', 63, 4, 6, 116375) his subordinates in the way of simple life, to live in comparative luxury himself even
('82', 63, 5, 7, 116462) though the money he spends on himself be his own earnings?
('82', 63, 6, 8, 116521) A.The manager who expects more from his co workers than what he does is bound to fail.
('82', 63, 6, 9, 116608) This of course applies only to philanthropic institutions whose managers have accepted the ideal of poverty.
('82', 63, 7, 10, 116717) INDIVIDUAL V. COLLECTIVE COW KEEPING
('82', 63, 8, 11, 116754) Q.Please explain more fully why individual care of the cow is violent and
('82', 63, 9, 12, 116828) collective effort non violent.
('82', 63, 10, 13, 116859) A.The present pitiable condition of cattle is surely enough proof.
('82', 63, 10, 14, 116926) The cow today is a burden simply because individual owner ship and care have failed.
('82', 63, 10, 15, 117011) In a previous article 3 I have explained how the individual cannot take proper care of his cattle, how he cannot keep a bull or grazing ground for himself, and how difficult it is for him to make proper arrangements for the sale of milk and ghee.
('82', 63, 10, 16, 117258) It would be quite impossible for individuals in any country to make their own arrangements for sending their letters with the ease that the postal department does for crores of people, rich and poor alike.
('82', 63, 10, 17, 117464) The same applies to cows.
('82', 63, 10, 18, 117490) If at all the problem can be solved, it will be through collective ownership or use.
('82', 63, 10, 19, 117575) Ownership and service go ill together.
('82', 63, 10, 20, 117614) I may belong to one person, but thousands can serve me.
('82', 63, 10, 21, 117670) If one person alone were to claim the right to serve me, where would I be?
('82', 63, 10, 22, 117745) This is exactly what is happening to the cow.
('82', 63, 10, 23, 117791) Individuals own the cow, they do not serve it.
('82', 63, 11, 24, 117838) 1 The Hindi here adds: “be content if the latter put their wealth to noble use, and”.
('82', 63, 11, 25, 117924) 2 The Hindi here adds: “We should therefore show through our own lives that poverty adopted as a matter of dharma is the true wealth.” 3 Vide “Individual or Collective?”, 8 2 1942.
('82', 64, 0, 1, 118105) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 65
('82', 64, 1, 2, 118147) HOW TO SERVE WITH THE BODY?
('82', 64, 2, 3, 118175) Q.You say we should devote our body, intellect and wealth to Jamnalalji’s
('82', 64, 3, 4, 118249) many activities.
('82', 64, 3, 5, 118266) I can understand giving [wealth] and to some extent I can understand
('82', 64, 4, 6, 118335) how we can serve with our intellect.
('82', 64, 4, 7, 118372) But how with the body?
('82', 64, 5, 8, 118395) A. 1 A’s heart may lean towards cow service or khadi.
('82', 64, 5, 9, 118449) But he has no money, he has to earn his own living, then how can he spare time for either service?
('82', 64, 5, 10, 118548) When he can spare a few moments after his day’s work he can persuade his friends to become members of the Goseva Sangh.
('82', 64, 5, 11, 118668) He can sell and distribute literature without charge; he can do propaganda for and sell cow’s milk and ghee or sandals made from non violent cow hide; he can sell khadi too.
('82', 64, 5, 12, 118842) If he wants to devote his whole life to the cause, he can do so by entering on a living wage the service of the Sangh concerned.

('82', 66, 1, 2, 121888) 70. LETTER TO PURUSHOTTAMDAS TANDON
('82', 66, 2, 3, 121924) February 25, 1942
('82', 66, 3, 4, 121942) BHAI TANDONJI, I had your letter.
('82', 66, 3, 5, 121976) The group of friends whom I had invited after Jamnalalji’s death included Rajendra Babu, Rajaji, Kaka saheb, Bhai Satyanarain and Bhai Shriman.
('82', 66, 3, 6, 122120) I had discussed with them the formation of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha.
('82', 66, 3, 7, 122193) Rajaji advised me, and others agreed with him, that I should write to you in detail.
('82', 66, 3, 8, 122278) The said Sabha will propagate both the forms simultaneously, prepare the [text ] books and sell them, conduct the examinations and so on.
('82', 66, 3, 9, 122416) Could the members of such a sabha also work for the Rashtrabhasha Samiti which is functioning at Wardha?
('82', 66, 3, 10, 122521) How could they call Hindi alone the national language?
('82', 66, 3, 11, 122576) If national language means Hindi + Urdu, Hindi or Urdu should only be regarded as a part of the national language and not the national language.
('82', 66, 3, 12, 122721) Does not your Abohar resolution imply that Hindi alone should be considered the national language, not Urdu?
('82', 66, 3, 13, 122830) If this interpretation is correct, would it not be better for the members of the Hindustani Prachar [Sabha] to sever their connection with the [Hindi] Sahitya Sammelan?
('82', 66, 3, 14, 122999) Whatever it be, all of us desire that the Standing Committee should discuss the point dispassionately and come to a decision.
('82', 66, 4, 15, 123125) Yours, M. K. GANDHI
('82', 66, 5, 16, 123145) From a copy of the Hindi: Rajendra Prasad Papers.

('82', 69, 3, 4, 125720) MUNNALAL, What can I do?

('82', 70, 1, 2, 126944) 78. LETTER TO VIJAYA M. PANCHOLI
('82', 70, 2, 3, 126977) February 26, 1942
('82', 70, 3, 4, 126995) VIJAYA, I should have written this letter four days ago, but I could find no time at all.
('82', 70, 3, 5, 127085) I would not have known about your heroism had Vallabhram Vaidya not written to me about it.
('82', 70, 3, 6, 127177) Why need you feel embarrassed about the fact or hide it from me?
('82', 70, 3, 7, 127242) When you got married I knew that there could be but one result, and we have it now.
('82', 70, 3, 8, 127326) It is indeed a blessed one.
('82', 70, 3, 9, 127354) The real test of you two will come now.
('82', 70, 3, 10, 127394) We have to see whether, even while living a householder’s life, you can render the fullest service.
('82', 70, 3, 11, 127494) “Fullest” means not double but four times [the previous service].
('82', 70, 3, 12, 127560) As the number increases, strength increases not in the same proportion but at least twice as much as the increase in the number, that is, four times, if the number has doubled and six times if it has trebled.
('82', 70, 3, 13, 127769) This is by the way.
('82', 70, 4, 14, 127789) It is your duty now to be calm always and nourish the baby inside you.
('82', 70, 4, 15, 127860) The baby’s education starts from the moment of conception.
('82', 70, 4, 16, 127919) Your thoughts, the work you do and the food you eat, will have an effect on it.
('82', 70, 4, 17, 127999) Get a copy of Dr. Tribhovandas’s very old—but ever fresh—book, Mane Shikhaman 1, and read it.
('82', 70, 4, 18, 128093) Nanabhai will help you to get one.
('82', 70, 4, 19, 128128) Manubhai will be knowing of other books of that type.
('82', 70, 4, 20, 128182) Go through them also.
('82', 70, 4, 21, 128204) Start preparing from now on.
('82', 70, 4, 22, 128233) Make your body strong.
('82', 70, 4, 23, 128256) Don’t stint in the matter of your food.
('82', 70, 4, 24, 128296) Drink milk and eat ghee, fruit and uncooked vegetables in quantities you can digest.
('82', 70, 4, 25, 128381) If uncooked vegetables do not agree with you leave them out.
('82', 70, 5, 26, 128442) Ba is quite well.
('82', 70, 6, 27, 128460) After Jamnalalji’s passing away the burden on me has increased very much indeed.
('82', 70, 6, 28, 128541) But God still gives me enough strength.
('82', 70, 6, 29, 128581) Otherwise I would stop working.
('82', 70, 7, 30, 128613) Blessings from
('82', 70, 9, 31, 128628) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 7145. Also C.W. 4637. Courtesy:

('82', 72, 9, 20, 130686) Dr. Menkel, who is also a dietetist, comments 1 as follows in The Oriental Watchman on my note on ‘Real War Effort’ 2 in Harijan of January 25th :
('82', 72, 10, 21, 130833) While I appreciate Dr. Menkel’s endorsement of my remarks, I like better his correction of my apparent lukewarmness about fruit.
('82', 72, 10, 22, 130962) No one perhaps, as far as I know, has eaten as much fruit as I have, having lived for six years entirely on fruits and nuts and always having had a liberal supply of fruit as part of my ordinary diet.
('82', 72, 10, 23, 131163) But I had in my mind, when writing, the special conditions of India.
('82', 72, 10, 24, 131232) Its people should have, by reason of its extent and variety of climate, a most liberal supply of fruit, vegetables and milk.
('82', 72, 10, 25, 131357) Yet it is the poorest country in this respect.
('82', 72, 10, 26, 131404) I therefore suggested what seemed to me to be feasible.
('82', 72, 10, 27, 131460) But I heartily endorse the proposition that for retaining health fresh fruit and fresh vegetables should form the main part of our diet.
('82', 72, 10, 28, 131597) It is for the medical profession to study the peculiar

('82', 76, 1, 2, 135599) 88. TALK TO MEMBERS OF MAHILA ASHRAM 1
('82', 76, 2, 3, 135638) SEVAGRAM, [Before March 1, 1942] 2
('82', 76, 3, 4, 135673) Members of the Mahila Ashram, in particular, owed a deep debt of gratitude to
('82', 76, 4, 5, 135751) How were they going to repay it?
('82', 76, 4, 6, 135784) There must be no idle tears.
('82', 76, 4, 7, 135813) The best memorial
('82', 76, 5, 8, 135831) to him was service.
('82', 76, 5, 9, 135851) The soul does not die.
('82', 76, 5, 10, 135874) It is the body alone that perishes.
('82', 76, 5, 11, 135910) But not everyone lives for ever in the hearts of men as Jamnalalji will.
('82', 76, 5, 12, 135983) The Mahila Ashram students and staff must pull their full weight in making Wardha an ideal town.
('82', 76, 5, 13, 136080) Clean it, remove illiteracy, spread the gospel of khadi, remove untouchability and serve the women.
('82', 76, 5, 14, 136180) Then all of you can become members of the Goseva Sangh and help in enlisting members too.
('82', 76, 5, 15, 136270) The pledge is not a rigid one, and, if you love the cow, you will willingly sign it.
('82', 76, 5, 16, 136355) Last but not the least there is Urdu.
('82', 76, 5, 17, 136393) Each one of you should begin to study the Urdu script.
('82', 76, 5, 18, 136448) Only those who know both Hindi and Urdu will be able in due course to create that beautiful mixture, the Hindustani of my dream, which shall be the national language.
('82', 76, 6, 19, 136615) Jamnalalji created the Mahila Mandal in order to create women workers.
('82', 76, 6, 20, 136686) The least each one of you can do is to imbibe his spirit of service and take it as your armour when you go into the wider sea of life.
('82', 76, 6, 21, 136821) Most of you will marry.
('82', 76, 6, 22, 136845) It is the natural thing to do, and I used to chaff Jamnalalji and call him a registrar of marriages because he was always arranging marriages.
('82', 76, 6, 23, 136988) He was no less anxious than I that many of our girls should elect to remain unmarried for the sake of serving their less fortunate sisters, but such women are rare.
('82', 76, 6, 24, 137153) In any case I shall expect service from you, and when married you will be two persons and will have to give fourfold.
('82', 76, 6, 25, 137271) In many ways married life—if well and truly lived, not for the sake of satisfying carnal desires—is harder than celibacy.
('82', 76, 7, 26, 137393) 1 Reproduced from Amrit Kaur’s article “Jamnalalji and Women”, dated March 1 1940. The members of the Mahila Ashram joined the evening prayers and presented their sacrificial yarn, spun in memory of Jamnalal Bajaj.
('82', 77, 0, 1, 137608) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 77, 1, 2, 137649) Jamnalalji was a rare man.
('82', 77, 1, 3, 137676) He was born to serve and serve universally.
('82', 77, 1, 4, 137720) Nothing that he did was done half heartedly.
('82', 77, 1, 5, 137765) His diligence was amazing.
('82', 77, 1, 6, 137792) He had even begun to tend the cow that gave him milk.
('82', 77, 1, 7, 137846) Such was his thoroughness.
('82', 77, 1, 8, 137873) He died in harness as he would have wished.

('82', 77, 3, 12, 138216) 89. DISGRACEFUL 1
('82', 77, 4, 13, 138234) The Punjab Press reports a deliberate and unprovoked attack on Pandit Sunderlal and Lala Jagannath of the Servants of People Society by four young Hindus at 11 o’clock at night while they were on their way to Lajpatrai Bhavan.
('82', 77, 4, 14, 138461) The attack is said to have been made because of Pandit Sunderlal having delivered addresses in Lahore on Hindu Muslim unity in which all offensive language was studiously avoided.
('82', 77, 4, 15, 138641) One can understand, though never pardon, an attack on some provocation.
('82', 77, 4, 16, 138713) But an attack such as was delivered on Pandit Sunderlal has no extenuating circumstances.
('82', 77, 4, 17, 138803) These young men are reported to be members of the Hindu Mahasabha.
('82', 77, 4, 18, 138870) I hope that the responsible officials will repudiate the action of the youths.
('82', 77, 4, 19, 138949) Public opinion should make such hooliganism impossible.
('82', 77, 4, 20, 139005) As for Pandit Sunderlal, his cause will prosper for the savagery, and more so because of his dignified disregard and forgiveness of it.

('82', 80, 1, 2, 141548) 94. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('82', 80, 2, 3, 141579) March 1, 1942
('82', 80, 3, 4, 141593) JAWAHARLAL, I got your letter yesterday.
('82', 80, 3, 5, 141634) I did not intend replying, nor do I want to do so now.
('82', 80, 3, 6, 141689) I wish to remind you of the hot weather.
('82', 80, 3, 7, 141730) The heat is severe.
('82', 80, 3, 8, 141750) I am having a wet pack on my head.
('82', 80, 3, 9, 141785) Indu should not come this side during such heat.
('82', 80, 3, 10, 141834) I would suggest that both of them should go to Khali or Kashmir.
('82', 80, 3, 11, 141899) They should visit Sevagram and other places only after the rains.
('82', 80, 3, 12, 141965) But if Indu has the courage to face the heat here, I shall, of course, be happy to meet the two.
('82', 80, 4, 13, 142062) One thing more.
('82', 80, 4, 14, 142078) Khurshedbehn had written to you.
('82', 80, 4, 15, 142111) She says you have written to her that you are awaiting an invitation from the Mahatma.
('82', 80, 4, 16, 142198) Why do you need an invitation from me?
('82', 80, 4, 17, 142237) It is always there for you.
('82', 80, 4, 18, 142265) There was no special work for which I should put you to the trouble of coming here.
('82', 80, 4, 19, 142349) I do not understand the implications of an “open city”, that is why I have said: “I must consult Jawaharlal before I say anything.
('82', 80, 4, 20, 142480) I depend upon Jawaharlal in such matters.”
('82', 80, 5, 21, 142523) We are meeting soon.
('82', 80, 6, 22, 142544) Blessings from BAPU

('82', 80, 8, 25, 142654) 95. NOTES
('82', 80, 9, 26, 142664) INDIRA NEHRU’S ENGAGEMENT
('82', 80, 10, 27, 142690) I have received several angry and abusive letters and some professing to reason about Indira’s engagement with Feroz Gandhi.
('82', 80, 10, 28, 142815) Not a single correspondent has anything against Feroz Gandhi as a man.
('82', 80, 10, 29, 142886) His only crime in their estimation is that he happens to be a Parsi.
('82', 80, 10, 30, 142955) I have been, and I am still, as strong an opponent of either party changing religion for the sake of marriage.
('82', 80, 10, 31, 143066) Religion is not a garment to be caste off at will.
('82', 80, 10, 32, 143117) In the present case there is no question of change of religion.
('82', 80, 10, 33, 143181) Feroz Gandhi has been for years an inmate of the
('82', 80, 11, 34, 143230) 1 Indira Nehru was engaged to Feroz Gandhi on February 26.
('82', 81, 0, 1, 143289) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 81, 1, 2, 143330) Nehru family.
('82', 81, 1, 3, 143344) He nursed Kamala Nehru in her sickness.
('82', 81, 1, 4, 143384) He was like a son to her.
('82', 81, 1, 5, 143410) During Indira’s illness in Europe he was of great help to her.
('82', 81, 1, 6, 143473) A natural intimacy grew up between them.
('82', 81, 1, 7, 143514) The friendship has been perfectly honourable.
('82', 81, 1, 8, 143560) It has ripened into mutual attraction.
('82', 81, 1, 9, 143599) But neither party would think of marrying without the consent and blessing of Jawaharlal Nehru.
('82', 81, 1, 10, 143695) This was given only after he was satisfied that the attraction had a solid basis.
('82', 81, 1, 11, 143777) The public know my connection with the Nehrus.
('82', 81, 1, 12, 143824) I had also talks with both the parties.
('82', 81, 1, 13, 143864) It would have been cruelty to refuse consent to this engagement.
('82', 81, 1, 14, 143929) As time advances such unions are bound to multiply with benefit to society.
('82', 81, 1, 15, 144005) At present we have not even reached the stage of mutual toleration, but as toleration grows into mutual respect for religions such unions will be welcomed.
('82', 81, 1, 16, 144161) No religion which is narrow and which cannot satisfy the test of reason will survive the coming reconstruction of society in which the values will have changed and character, not possession of wealth, title or birth, will be the sole test of merit.
('82', 81, 1, 17, 144410) The Hinduism of my conception is no narrow creed.
('82', 81, 1, 18, 144460) It is a grand evolutionary process as ancient as time, and embraces the teachings of Zoroaster, Moses, Christ, Mohammed, Nanak and other prophets that I could name.
('82', 81, 1, 19, 144625) It is thus defined :
('82', 81, 2, 20, 144646) Know that to be (true) religion which the wise and the good and those who are ever free from passion and hate follow and which appeals to the heart.
('82', 81, 3, 21, 144795) If it is not that, it will perish.
('82', 81, 3, 22, 144830) My correspondents will pardon me for not acknowledging their letters.
('82', 81, 3, 23, 144900) I invite them to shed their wrath and bless the forthcoming marriage.
('82', 81, 3, 24, 144970) Their letters betray ignorance, intolerance and prejudice—a species of untouchability, dangerous because not easily to be so classified.
('82', 81, 4, 25, 145107) SEVAGRAM, March [2] 1 1942

('82', 82, 1, 2, 145365) URDU MADE EASY
('82', 82, 2, 3, 145380) Charity begins at home.
('82', 82, 2, 4, 145404) As I was speaking to Jamnalalji’s friends 1 on the necessity of their learning Urdu if they believed in Rashtrabhasha as recommended by the Congress, I thought of the good English proverb, and I began the charity of spreading the knowledge of Urdu in Sevagram.
('82', 82, 2, 5, 145665) The result was a quick and good response.
('82', 82, 2, 6, 145707) A class commenced last Wednesday, i.e., 25th February.
('82', 82, 2, 7, 145762) Practically all, young and old,women and men, joined the class.
('82', 82, 2, 8, 145826) The teacher captured their imagination.
('82', 82, 2, 9, 145866) They learnt the primary letters in two sittings of thirty minutes each.
('82', 82, 2, 10, 145938) By the time this is in print they should have learnt the forms for joining the letters.
('82', 82, 2, 11, 146026) They will have learnt the alphabet in practically three hours.
('82', 82, 2, 12, 146089) I know a friend who mastered it in four hours at a single sitting.
('82', 82, 2, 13, 146156) The difficulty of reading Urdu is undoubtedly there.
('82', 82, 2, 14, 146209) That can only be overcome by practice.
('82', 82, 2, 15, 146248) Given the will, the way is easy.
('82', 82, 2, 16, 146281) And love of the country should surely be sufficient spur to the will.
('82', 82, 3, 17, 146351) SEVAGRAM, March 2, 1942

('82', 83, 6, 13, 147869) 97. AN APPEAL TO QUAID E AZAM
('82', 83, 7, 14, 147899) I have been painfully but regularly going through the English weeklies that come to me and that are devoted to the cause of the Muslim League.
('82', 83, 7, 15, 148042) I read them so as to keep myself informed of what the Muslim mind as influenced by the Muslim League thinks.
('82', 83, 7, 16, 148151) Not a week passes but these weeklies contain what to me appear to be distortions of truth and vilification of the Congress and Congressmen and Hindus.
('82', 83, 7, 17, 148302) What has prompted me to write these lines is a virulent attack on Hinduism in one of the weeklies.
('82', 83, 7, 18, 148401) Here is an extract from the article :
('82', 83, 8, 19, 148439) Hinduism is the greatest curse of India, and it is based on intolerance and
('82', 83, 9, 20, 148515) inequality.
('82', 83, 9, 21, 148527) To call oneself a ‘Hindu’ is to confess that one is reactionary and
('82', 83, 10, 22, 148595) narrow minded.
('82', 83, 10, 23, 148610) No decent, civilized, honest and sincere human being who
('82', 83, 11, 24, 148667) knows what Hinduism is and what it stands for, would like to be known as a
('82', 83, 12, 25, 148742) Hindu or join this faith of primitive barbarians.
('82', 83, 12, 26, 148792) For it is on barbarity that this
('82', 83, 13, 27, 148825) so called religion is based.
('82', 83, 13, 28, 148854) No other word can describe the state of 97 per cent
('82', 83, 14, 29, 148906) of the population who have been decreed by the gods and goddesses of this
('82', 83, 15, 30, 148980) precious religion as impure and unclean beings fit only to serve the remaining
('82', 83, 16, 31, 149059) 3 per cent of the population.
('82', 83, 16, 32, 149089) We would far rather suggest to the students to
('82', 83, 17, 33, 149136) prepare in their laboratories of the mind deadly bombs which would
('82', 83, 18, 34, 149203) completely smash and destroy Hinduism, the greatest menace to India’s
('82', 83, 19, 35, 149273) welfare and well being.
('82', 83, 20, 36, 149297) I hope I shall not be told that the article in question is taken
('82', 84, 0, 1, 149362) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 85
('82', 84, 1, 2, 149404) from another newspaper.
('82', 84, 1, 3, 149428) It has been taken in order to hold up Hinduism to scorn.
('82', 84, 1, 4, 149485) Though the founder of this paper is Quaid e Azam himself and it is issued under the direction of Nawabzada Liaquat Ali Khan, Hon.
('82', 84, 1, 5, 149615) Secretary of the League, I fancy that they have not seen the article in question.
('82', 84, 2, 6, 149697) What will be the state of Hindus under Pakistan?
('82', 84, 2, 7, 149746) Will they be suppressed as barbarians?
('82', 84, 2, 8, 149785) There is no attempt in the papers at looking at the other side.
('82', 84, 2, 9, 149849) The policy adopted in the papers must lead to the promotion of bitterness and strife between the two communities.
('82', 84, 2, 10, 149963) If the end is to be attained through strife and force and not by persuasion and argument, I can have nothing to say.
('82', 84, 2, 11, 150080) But I observe from Quaid e Azam’s speeches that he has no quarrel with the Hindus.
('82', 84, 2, 12, 150163) He wants to live at peace with them.
('82', 84, 2, 13, 150200) I plead, therefore, for a juster estimate of men and things in papers representing the policy and programme of the Muslim League.
