('82', 86, 1, 2, 151975) 101. THE MARRIED ESTATE 1
('82', 86, 2, 3, 152001) A sister, who is a good worker and was anxious to remain celibate in order better to serve the country’s cause, has recently married having met the mate of her dreams.
('82', 86, 2, 4, 152169) But she imagines that in doing so she has done wrong and fallen from the high ideal which she had set before herself.
('82', 86, 2, 5, 152287) 2 I have tried to rid her mind of this delusion.
('82', 86, 3, 6, 152336) It is no doubt an excellent thing for girls to remain unmarried for the sake of service, but the fact is that only one in a million is able to do so.
('82', 86, 3, 7, 152486) Marriage is a natural thing in life, and to consider it derogatory in any sense is wholly wrong.
('82', 86, 3, 8, 152583) When one imagines any act a fall it is difficult, however hard one tries, to raise oneself.
('82', 86, 3, 9, 152675) The ideal is to look upon marriage as a sacrament and therefore to lead a life of self restraint in the married estate.
('82', 86, 3, 10, 152795) Marriage in Hinduism is one of the four ashramas.
('82', 86, 3, 11, 152845) In fact the other three are based on it.
('82', 86, 3, 12, 152886) But in modern times marriage has unfortunately come to be regarded purely as a physical union 4. The other three ashramas are all but non existent.
('82', 86, 4, 13, 153034) The duty of the above mentioned and other sisters who think like her is, therefore, not to look down upon marriage but to give it its due place and make of it the sacrament it is.
('82', 86, 4, 14, 153214) If they exercise the necessary self restraint, they will find growing within themselves a greater strength for service.
('82', 86, 4, 15, 153334) She who wishes to serve will naturally choose a partner in life who is of the same mind, and their joint service will be the country’s gain.
('82', 86, 5, 16, 153475) It is a tragedy that generally speaking our girls are not taught the duties of motherhood.
('82', 86, 5, 17, 153566) But if married life is a religious duty, motherhood must be so too.
('82', 86, 5, 18, 153634) To be an ideal mother is no easy task.
('82', 86, 5, 19, 153673) The procreation of children has to be undertaken with a full sense of responsibility.
('82', 86, 5, 20, 153759) The mother should know what is her duty from the moment she conceives right up to the time the child is born.
('82', 86, 5, 21, 153869) And she who gives intelligent, healthy and well brought up children to the
('82', 86, 6, 22, 153944) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('82', 86, 6, 23, 153975) The Hindi original appeared in Harijan Sevak, 8 3 1942. 2 Vide the preceding item.
('82', 86, 6, 24, 154058) 3 The Hindi here adds: “But I know there are many other sisters like her and for their benefit I am giving a gist of the letter I wrote to her” 4 The Hindi here adds: “thus giving rise to harmful results”.
('82', 87, 0, 1, 154264) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 87, 1, 2, 154305) country is surely rendering a service.
('82', 87, 1, 3, 154344) When the latter grow up they too will be ready to serve.
('82', 87, 1, 4, 154401) The truth of the matter is that those who are filled with a living spirit of service will always serve whatever their position in life.

('82', 90, 1, 2, 158966) 105. LETTER TO PATTABHI SITARAMAYYA
('82', 90, 2, 3, 159002) SEVAGRAM, March 5, 1942
('82', 90, 3, 4, 159026) MY DEAR PATTABHI, I have now heard from Jawaharlal.
('82', 90, 3, 5, 159078) He leaves everything to me.
('82', 90, 3, 6, 159106) With Jamnalalji’s death the question of finance becomes most difficult.
('82', 90, 3, 7, 159178) I suggest some such notice by you as Editor.
('82', 90, 3, 8, 159223) ‘Arrangements are being made to turn the States’ People into a weekly and to make it a kind of guide to the people of the States from week to week.
('82', 90, 3, 9, 159371) For the time being therefore the publication will be suspended.
('82', 90, 3, 10, 159435) Meanwhile I would like the workers in the different States to inform me how many copies they would take, the payment being in advance.
('82', 90, 3, 11, 159570) The idea is to make the paper self supporting from the start.
('82', 90, 3, 12, 159632) The paper is intended to supply a felt want.
('82', 90, 3, 13, 159677) A sure test of a felt want is that there are enough subscribers to pay for the upkeep.
('82', 90, 3, 14, 159764) The estimated cost of the paper for one year would be not more than, say, Rs. 5,000, the Editor being honorary.
('82', 90, 3, 15, 159876) For 1,000 subscribers, therefore, the annual subscription will be Rs. 5 each.
('82', 90, 3, 16, 159954) This ought not to prove an unbearable burden.
('82', 90, 3, 17, 160000) The sooner the names are sent to me the better it is for the cause.
('82', 90, 3, 18, 160068) In any case all the names should be sent to me with contributions which will be refunded if the paper is not issued within one month from the date of closing the list.’
('82', 90, 4, 19, 160237) This you will issue if you agree with my proposal.
('82', 90, 4, 20, 160288) You will check the estimates before publishing this figure and I presume that you have no difficulty about paper.
('82', 90, 4, 21, 160402) I would like you to keep yourself in touch with Jawaharlal.
('82', 90, 5, 22, 160462) Either I have destroyed your estimates or have mislaid your letter and estimates.
('82', 90, 5, 23, 160544) Please send me a copy of the latter.
('82', 90, 5, 24, 160581) If you feel like coming, do come.
('82', 90, 7, 25, 160615) From a copy.
('82', 90, 7, 26, 160628) Pyarelal Papers.
('82', 90, 7, 27, 160645) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('82', 91, 1, 2, 160705) 106. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('82', 91, 2, 3, 160733) [March 5, 1942] 2
('82', 91, 3, 4, 160751) (1) Should human society be constituted by holding it within the confines
('82', 91, 4, 5, 160825) of religion or by means of the levelling stone of democracy?
('82', 91, 4, 6, 160886) What should be a man’s
('82', 91, 5, 7, 160909) contribution to it?
('82', 91, 5, 8, 160929) Does the training in truth and non violence pass from an
('82', 91, 6, 9, 160986) individual to society or does society train the individual?
('82', 91, 6, 10, 161046) With the bonds of religion alone.
('82', 91, 6, 11, 161080) A man can make his contribution by fulfilling his dharma.
('82', 91, 6, 12, 161138) All the training comes to society through its members.
('82', 91, 7, 13, 161193) (2) A community can be raised high through one’s own [spiritual] uplift.
('82', 91, 8, 14, 161266) You are achieving public weal through your efforts towards spiritual uplift whereas we
('82', 91, 9, 15, 161353) all seem to have equated our entire duty with the welfare of the masses.
('82', 91, 9, 16, 161426) Could it be the
('82', 91, 10, 17, 161442) reason why we meet with difficulties in achieving either?
('82', 91, 10, 18, 161500) Ultimately the obstruction is bound to go.
('82', 91, 11, 19, 161543) (3) Is it proper to employ the language of war in a movement based on
('82', 91, 12, 20, 161613) truth and non violence?
('82', 91, 12, 21, 161637) Indeed, isn’t it true that aspirants to this category cannot be
('82', 91, 13, 22, 161701) guided by the ways of war?
('82', 91, 13, 23, 161728) There is nothing wrong in employing the same phraseology, although it would surely be better to adopt a new one.
('82', 91, 14, 24, 161841) (4) I believe, after having accepted a certain way [of life], one must
('82', 91, 15, 25, 161912) perform the ritual practices that go with it.
('82', 91, 15, 26, 161958) If however they are found to be
('82', 91, 16, 27, 161990) uninteresting, it should mean that one’s own faith in it or one’s understanding of it is
('82', 91, 17, 28, 162079) not perfect.
('82', 91, 17, 29, 162092) It is quite natural that what is good seems [at first] uninteresting.
('82', 91, 17, 30, 162162) However, after it has its impact what is good is bound to hold one’s interest.
('82', 91, 18, 31, 162241) (5)The idea of Pakistan is a result of Muslim fears and the want of a liberal
('82', 91, 19, 32, 162319) attitude on the part of our Hindu brethren.
('82', 91, 19, 33, 162363) One of the demands of the Muslim League is
('82', 91, 20, 34, 162406) for equal representation on the central cabinet.
('82', 91, 20, 35, 162455) It may be an unjust demand.
('82', 91, 20, 36, 162483) But if we
('82', 91, 21, 37, 162493) want to achieve independence and trust that communal strife will not survive the
('82', 91, 22, 38, 162574) passage of time, doesn’t it deserve to be accepted?
('82', 91, 22, 39, 162626) Since the present circumstances
('82', 91, 23, 40, 162658) will then have undergone a change, will not the hearts of both communities unite?
('82', 91, 24, 41, 162740) 1 Submitted in writing from time to time by Ghulam Rasul Qureshi 2 The last answer was written on this date.

('82', 95, 8, 18, 170408) Thus, whoever faces his wicked assailants single handed is a non 
('82', 95, 9, 19, 170474) violent person, is he not?
('82', 95, 9, 20, 170501) One can certainly restrict or widen [one’s idea of non violence].
('82', 95, 9, 21, 170567) You ought to understand why Zeke was considered non violent.
('82', 95, 9, 22, 170628) If a lone unarmed person struggling against an attack by a hundred, uses his teeth, shouldn’t he still be regarded as non violent?
('82', 95, 9, 23, 170759) Can you say that the mouse is violent to the cat?
('82', 95, 9, 24, 170809) Try to grasp this thoroughly.

('82', 103, 0, 1, 181147) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 103, 1, 2, 181189) Sasta Sahitya Mandal 1. His life was a living literature.
('82', 103, 2, 3, 181247) [From Hindi]
('82', 103, 3, 4, 181260) Panchven Putrako Bapuke Ashirvad, p.
('82', 103, 4, 5, 181297) 116. ON ITS TRIAL
('82', 103, 5, 6, 181315) I am a pacifist still in one sense; that is to say, I realize that Christians
('82', 103, 6, 7, 181393) should be able to meet material force with spiritual power.
('82', 103, 6, 8, 181453) It is horrifying to
('82', 103, 7, 9, 181473) reflect that after nineteen hundred years, we are still unable to do it except in
('82', 103, 8, 10, 181555) individual cases and on a small scale.
('82', 103, 8, 11, 181594) But to me it seems merely ‘wishful
('82', 103, 9, 12, 181629) thinking’ to act as though we had a power which in fact we have not and for
('82', 103, 10, 13, 181705) which we have neither trained nor disciplined ourselves in the past.
('82', 103, 11, 14, 181774) power does not come to those who have not disciplined themselves, at the last
('82', 103, 12, 15, 181852) moment, in the hour of need.
('82', 103, 12, 16, 181881) It has not come to us.
('82', 103, 12, 17, 181904) I would rather, therefore,
('82', 103, 13, 18, 181931) do what I can in defence of principles which I believe to be both right in
('82', 103, 14, 19, 182006) themselves and of enormous importance to the future of the human race, than
('82', 103, 15, 20, 182082) stand aside and do nothing.
('82', 103, 15, 21, 182110) It is doing nothing that is the worst expedient of
('82', 103, 17, 22, 182161) When, therefore, my pacifist friends ask me whether I can imagine Jesus
('82', 103, 18, 23, 182233) Christ dropping a bomb or firing a gun I am entitled to reply: ‘No, I cannot;
('82', 103, 19, 24, 182311) but neither can I imagine him standing aside and doing nothing at all.’
('82', 103, 20, 25, 182383) I am compelled to echo the words of a very dear relative of mine who,
('82', 103, 21, 26, 182453) loathing war as much as any pacifist that ever breathed, said to me at the
('82', 103, 22, 27, 182528) beginning of the last war (in which he lost his life): “If you can stop war with
('82', 103, 23, 28, 182609) spiritual power, do it.
('82', 103, 23, 29, 182633) If you can’t, let me do what I can; and if you are right in
('82', 103, 24, 30, 182693) thinking that war is so damnable that anyone who takes part in it is damned,
('82', 103, 25, 31, 182770) then I would rather be damned than let these things go on without doing all I
('82', 103, 26, 32, 182848) can to stop them, even at the cost of my own life.”
('82', 103, 27, 33, 182900) Is this not very close to the meaning of our Lord when he said: “He that
('82', 103, 28, 34, 182973) loseth his life shall save it”?
('82', 103, 28, 35, 183005) The foregoing is the concluding portion of a touchingly sorrowful article contributed to The Survey Graphic of December 1941 by the celebrated Dr. Maude Royden of the Guildhouse, London.
('82', 103, 28, 36, 183192) She is one of the foremost pacifists of the West.
('82', 103, 28, 37, 183242) Like many she has felt compelled to revise her position and is now most
('82', 103, 29, 38, 183314) 1 Publishers of Hindi books.
('82', 104, 0, 1, 183343) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 105
('82', 104, 1, 2, 183386) reluctantly but fully ranged on the side of the defenders of the British Isles.
('82', 104, 2, 3, 183466) The article demands a considered reply.
('82', 104, 2, 4, 183506) I have been in constant touch with the Western pacifists.
('82', 104, 2, 5, 183564) In my opinion Dr. Royden has surrendered her position in the portion I have quoted.
('82', 104, 2, 6, 183648) If individuals have lived up to the Christian teaching (i.e., on non violence) and that on a small scale, one would think practice should make such a life possible for many people and on a large scale.
('82', 104, 2, 7, 183850) It is undoubtedly wrong and foolish “to act as though one had the power which in fact one has not”.
('82', 104, 2, 8, 183950) “But,” says the worthy writer, “such power does not come to those who have not disciplined themselves, at the last moment, in the hour of need.”
('82', 104, 3, 9, 184095) I suggest that with the knowledge of the defect no time should be lost in seeking to remove it.
('82', 104, 3, 10, 184191) That by itself is doing not only something but the right thing.
('82', 104, 3, 11, 184255) To deny one’s faith by contrary practice is surely the worst thing one can do.
('82', 104, 4, 12, 184334) And I am not sure that “doing nothing is the worst expedient of all.” In sceptic treatment, for instance, doing nothing is not only expedient, it is obligatory.
('82', 104, 5, 13, 184495) There is no cause whatsoever for despondency, much less for denial of one’s faith at the crucial moment.
('82', 104, 5, 14, 184600) Why should not British pacifists stand aside and remodel their life in its entirety?
('82', 104, 5, 15, 184685) They might be unable to bring about peace outright, but they would lay a solid foundation for it and give the surest test of their faith.
('82', 104, 5, 16, 184823) When, in the face of an upheaval such as we are witnessing, there are only a few individuals of immovable faith, they have to live up to their faith even though they may produce no visible effect on the course of events.
('82', 104, 5, 17, 185044) They should believe that their action will produce tangible results in due course.
('82', 104, 5, 18, 185127) Their staunchness is bound to attract sceptics.
('82', 104, 5, 19, 185175) I would also suggest that individuals like Dr. Maude Royden are not mere camp followers.
('82', 104, 5, 20, 185264) They are leaders.
('82', 104, 5, 21, 185282) Therefore, they have to live their lives in strict accord with the Sermon on the Mount, and they will find immediately that there is much to give up and much to remodel.
('82', 104, 5, 22, 185452) The greatest thing that they have to deny themselves is the fruit of imperialism.
('82', 104, 5, 23, 185534) The present complicated life of the Londoner and his high living is possible only because of the hoards brought from Asia,
('82', 105, 0, 1, 185657) 106 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 105, 1, 2, 185699) Africa and other parts of the world.
('82', 105, 1, 3, 185736) In spite of the fierce criticism which has been levelled against my letter “To Every Briton”, 1 I adhere to every word of it, and I am convinced that posterity will adopt the remedy suggested therein against violence however organized and fierce.
('82', 105, 1, 4, 185983) And now that the enemy is at the gates of India I am advising my countrymen the same course of action I advised the British people.
('82', 105, 1, 5, 186115) My advice may or may not be accepted by my countrymen.
('82', 105, 1, 6, 186170) I would remain unmoved.
('82', 105, 1, 7, 186194) Their non acceptance will be no test of failure of non violence.
('82', 105, 1, 8, 186259) I would subscribe to the charge of my imperfection.
('82', 105, 1, 9, 186311) But a satyagrahi does not wait for perfection before he invites others to experiment with him, provided always that his faith is immovable like a mountain.
('82', 105, 1, 10, 186467) The advice that Dr. Royden’s relative gave her and which she quotes approvingly is altogether wrong.
('82', 105, 1, 11, 186568) If the war is damnable, how can he stop the things that go on by taking part in it, even though it may be on the defensive side and at the cost of his own life?
('82', 105, 1, 12, 186729) For the defence has to resort to all the damnable things that the enemy does, and that with greater vigour if it has to succeed.
('82', 105, 1, 13, 186858) Such a giving of life is not only not saving it but a mere waste.
('82', 105, 2, 14, 186924) I have attended the Doctor’s services in her Church where a living belief in the efficacy of prayer is much in vogue.
('82', 105, 2, 15, 187042) When the impenetrable gloom surrounded her, why did she not find strength and consolation and real action in heart prayer?
('82', 105, 2, 16, 187165) It is never too late to mend.
('82', 105, 2, 17, 187195) She and her fellow pacifists, many of whom I have the privilege of knowing, should take heart and, like Peter, repent of the momentary loss of faith and return to the old faith in non violence with renewed vigour.
('82', 105, 2, 18, 187409) Their return will mean no material loss to the war effort but will mean a great deal to the anti war effort which is bound to succeed sooner rather than later, if man is to live as man and not become a two footed brute.
('82', 105, 3, 19, 187629) SEVAGRAM, March 8, 1942

('82', 107, 14, 17, 190307) and encouraging.

('82', 107, 17, 22, 190535) inhabitant in almost all the villages has come to feel a sort of consciousness
('82', 107, 18, 23, 190614) of his right as well as of responsibility and of love for his village.

('82', 108, 3, 4, 191464) GOPALAN NAMBIAR
('82', 108, 4, 5, 191480) Gopalan Nambiar is a patriotic youth who in the heat of the moment is said to have instigated a crowd, at a meeting in Malabar, to assault a Sub Inspector of Police resulting in his unfortunate death.
('82', 108, 4, 6, 191681) The High Court at Madras has sentenced him to be hanged.
('82', 108, 4, 7, 191738) I take it that the evidence justified the sentence, but it is a clear case for commutation of the sentence by the Government.
('82', 108, 4, 8, 191864) This is no case of private murder deliberately committed.
('82', 108, 4, 9, 191922) We are living in the midst of murders on a wholesale scale which no court of law can ever reach.
('82', 108, 4, 10, 192019) It is a mockery to send a young man to the gallows for an act, however indefensible otherwise, in which malice is wholly absent.
('82', 108, 4, 11, 192148) I am glad, therefore, that leaders of public opinion and the Press are moving in order to secure a reprieve.
('82', 108, 4, 12, 192257) It is hoped that the Government will listen to the public voice.
('82', 108, 4, 13, 192322) SEVAGRAM, March 9, 1942 Harijan, 15 3 1942
('82', 108, 5, 14, 192365) 119. HINDUSTANI 1
('82', 108, 6, 15, 192383) Dr. Tara Chand, who has made a close study of the vexed question of the national language, recently wrote a Hindi letter to Shri Kakasaheb, from which the following important extracts are translated below : 2
('82', 108, 7, 16, 192592) Hindustani and Brij were both colloquial languages at one time.
('82', 108, 7, 17, 192656) Hindi or Hindustani made its first appearance in the 13th century, and its literature actually came into being in the 14th and 15th centuries in South India.
('82', 108, 7, 18, 192814) Its language is the same as Khari Boli and is the basis of modern Hindi.
('82', 108, 8, 19, 192887) The Muslims were the first to create literature in Hindustani.
('82', 108, 8, 20, 192950) Their fakirs and saints used this language for their religious teachings and explained the principles of the Sufi religion in it also.
('82', 108, 8, 21, 193085) Later, poets adopted it, and because Muslims used the language there came about
('82', 108, 9, 22, 193165) 1 The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 15 3 1942. 2 Of which only excerpts are reproduced here
('82', 109, 0, 1, 193277) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 109, 1, 2, 193319) a mixture of Persian and Hindi words.
('82', 109, 1, 3, 193357) The sounds of Persian and Arabic letters also crept in which are not found in Brij but which have remained in Hindi up to date.
('82', 109, 2, 4, 193485) The colloquial language which the Muslims employed is the language spoken even today round about Meerut and Delhi.
('82', 109, 2, 5, 193600) It is termed Khari Boli or Hindustani.
('82', 109, 3, 6, 193639) Modern Hindustani, Hindi and Urdu are three forms of this language.
('82', 109, 3, 7, 193707) Hindi and Urdu are its literary forms, into which many Sanskrit and Persian and Arabic words have freely crept.
('82', 109, 3, 8, 193819) Hindustani is that form of the language which includes both Sanskrit and Persian words.
('82', 109, 3, 9, 193907) Writers of Hindustani lean towards one or the other according to their taste.
('82', 109, 3, 10, 193985) But they try to avoid both as much as possible.
('82', 109, 4, 11, 194033) In my opinion neither Hindi nor Urdu should be the lingua franca of India.
('82', 109, 4, 12, 194108) Either we must agree to call Hindi the language of the Hindus and Urdu that of the Muslims, or we must try to make Hindustani the common language.
('82', 109, 4, 13, 194255) So long as we call either Hindi or Urdu the national language we are certain to raise a controversy.
('82', 109, 5, 14, 194356) SEVAGRAM, March 9, 1942 Harijan, 29 3 1942

('82', 109, 7, 23, 194974) The scarcity of water can be overcome only if the Kathiawar Princes make joint efforts.
('82', 109, 7, 24, 195062) Private institutions will be able to achieve precious little in spite of their great efforts.

('82', 111, 7, 18, 196918) 124. DESIRABILITY OF EXODUS
('82', 111, 8, 19, 196946) A correspondent asks for my detailed views on the exodus that I have advised 1 from the cities of all who are not wanted there and all who are unfit or unwilling to stay there.
('82', 111, 8, 20, 197123) No one is obliged to stay in against his will.
('82', 111, 8, 21, 197170) In the event of bombardment, it is clear that non combatants can only be a burden in every way.
('82', 111, 8, 22, 197266) Successful defence against a powerful enemy requires exclusive concentration on holding the enemy at bay.
('82', 111, 8, 23, 197372) The defenders’ attention must not be divided.
('82', 111, 8, 24, 197418) This is from the military point of view.
('82', 111, 9, 25, 197459) But we have war resisters too, either humanitarian or political.
('82', 111, 9, 26, 197524) They may not stay unless their object is merely to cause embarrassment for the sake of it.
('82', 111, 9, 27, 197615) I hope there are none such.
('82', 111, 9, 28, 197643) They should, therefore, be out of the cities.
('82', 111, 9, 29, 197689) Then there are those who do not know what to do in the event of bombardment.
('82', 111, 9, 30, 197766) They should all evacuate.
('82', 111, 9, 31, 197792) As the reader will see, my opinion has little to do with my
('82', 111, 10, 32, 197852) 1 Vide “Plea for Calmness”, 17 2 1942.
('82', 112, 0, 1, 197891) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 113
('82', 112, 1, 2, 197934) war resistance.
('82', 112, 1, 3, 197950) For in this case and up to a point military necessity and duty of war resisters demand the same action.
('82', 112, 1, 4, 198054) If I could convert any city or all cities wholly, including the combatants of yesterday, I should welcome the invading host and try to convert even them or challenge them to do their worst, without offering retaliation.
('82', 112, 1, 5, 198274) But no such good luck awaits me.
('82', 112, 1, 6, 198307) If the cities were converted, all India including the rulers would be converted and there would be peace in India and peace in the world.
('82', 112, 1, 7, 198445) But that must remain a day dream yet awhile.
('82', 112, 1, 8, 198490) Only I won’t be moved from my position by being told that the Jap or the Nazi is not the same man as the Englishman.
('82', 112, 1, 9, 198607) I draw no such fundamental distinction between man and man.
('82', 112, 1, 10, 198667) But I must not detain the reader on the speculative side of the matter of fact question that faces us.
('82', 112, 1, 11, 198770) Assuming then that all who should or a part of them have evacuated the cities and have gone to the villages or are about to go, what should they do?
('82', 112, 1, 12, 198919) They must go with the village mind to live the village life as much as possible.
('82', 112, 1, 13, 199000) They may not reproduce city conditions and build temporary palaces.
('82', 112, 1, 14, 199068) They should go to villages in a spirit of service, study their economic and other conditions, and ameliorate them not by giving alms but by giving the villagers work of a permanent nature.
('82', 112, 1, 15, 199257) In other words, they should work the constructive programme among the villagers.
('82', 112, 1, 16, 199338) Thus they will identify themselves with the villagers and become a kind of co operative society with an ordered programme of economic, social, hygienic and political reconstruction.
('82', 112, 1, 17, 199520) The greatest problem the new comers will have to tackle will be to deal with loot and dacoities.
('82', 112, 1, 18, 199617) It will tax their resources to the utmost.
('82', 112, 1, 19, 199660) The non violent way is there.
('82', 112, 1, 20, 199690) If that is not clear to them, with the co operation of the villagers they should organize themselves for armed defence against robbers and dacoits.
('82', 112, 1, 21, 199838) We have too long looked to the Government to do this elementary work for us, not excluding even the reclamation of castes called criminal tribes.
('82', 112, 1, 22, 199984) The Government cannot do much, if anything at all, at this critical time.
('82', 112, 1, 23, 200058) The work has perforce to be done by the evacuees violently, non violently, or both ways.
('82', 112, 2, 24, 200147) SEVAGRAM, March 10, 1942 Harijan, 15 3 1942

('82', 116, 6, 12, 204371) 131. TALK TO STUDENTS OF KHADI VIDYALAYA 1
('82', 116, 7, 13, 204414) SEVAGRAM, March 11, 1942
('82', 116, 8, 14, 204439) Every day morning and evening we recite the Ekadashavrata mantra at the conclusion of the prayer.
('82', 116, 8, 15, 204537) Mere observance of a vow, whether it is big or small, is enough to make one’s life.
('82', 116, 8, 16, 204621) The whole world of sentient beings, the whole universe, the earth, the sun, the moon and the like are said to follow, each its own vow, for they move on their different paths according to their set motions.
('82', 116, 8, 17, 204828) After all even inertia is relative.
('82', 116, 8, 18, 204864) We cannot call it mere inertia where laws are so strictly followed.
('82', 116, 8, 19, 204932) Astronomers tell us that if a single planet or stellar body in the sky should cease in its motion or deviate in the slightest degree the whole planetary system would go out of order and come to an end.
('82', 116, 8, 20, 205134) Thus if the whole of Nature reveals the supremacy of laws there must be some agency to preserve and to enforce those laws.
('82', 116, 8, 21, 205257) That agency is God.
('82', 116, 8, 22, 205277) With Him as witness the cosmos follows its
('82', 116, 9, 23, 205320) 1 The students had assembled to observe the masika (the monthly ceremony) of Jamnalal Bajaj.
('82', 116, 9, 24, 205413) After half an hour’s spinning they read out the vows they had taken.
('82', 117, 0, 1, 205482) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 118
('82', 117, 1, 2, 205524) preordained path.
('82', 117, 1, 3, 205542) But we puny creatures cannot follow even the little vows that we take.
('82', 117, 2, 4, 205613) You who have taken vows here are all students of the Khadi Vidyalaya.
('82', 117, 2, 5, 205683) You have come here in pursuit of a specific aim, to fulfil a specific programme.
('82', 117, 2, 6, 205764) You must remember that in the years to come the Charkha Sangh will depend on you.
('82', 117, 2, 7, 205846) Our experience showed that if the Charkha Sangh was to make progress a school was necessary where instruction in the techniques of khadi should be imparted.
('82', 117, 2, 8, 206003) What is taught in ordinary school is forgotten as soon as the examinations are over.
('82', 117, 2, 9, 206088) But you have to absorb in your lives what you learn here.
('82', 117, 2, 10, 206146) So far as I know there is no other institution of this kind anywhere in India.
('82', 117, 2, 11, 206225) You therfore carry a great responsibility.
('82', 117, 2, 12, 206268) If after completing your education here some of you want to become rich you may, but the ideal which has brought you here requires that your entire life should be dedicated to Lord Krishna.
('82', 117, 2, 13, 206458) You have a loftier aim than riches.
('82', 117, 2, 14, 206494) You have to transact business worth crores of rupees, but not for yourselves.
('82', 117, 2, 15, 206572) You have to do so in order to meet the wants of the poor.
('82', 117, 2, 16, 206630) Today we do not have enough khadi even to meet the needs of the poor.
('82', 117, 2, 17, 206700) But in the years to come you will have to manage the production, sale and accounting of Khadi worth hundreds of crores of rupees, and, what is more, you will have to do it scientifically.
('82', 117, 2, 18, 206888) Today we do not have a theory of khadi production.
('82', 117, 2, 19, 206939) We do not even know the rudiments of village economics.
('82', 117, 2, 20, 206995) We have to learn all this.
('82', 117, 2, 21, 207022) Thus you have taken upon your shoulders something that affects the whole world.
('82', 117, 2, 22, 207102) For this we require workers who are firm in keeping vows.
('82', 117, 2, 23, 207160) If we unite the heart and the head the result will be far reaching and beyond our imagination.
('82', 117, 2, 24, 207255) You should move ever forward.
('82', 117, 2, 25, 207285) You should develop the habit of introspection and correction.
('82', 117, 2, 26, 207347) You should observe what happens around you in the Ashram.
('82', 117, 2, 27, 207405) But you should have eyes only for what is good, not for flaws.
('82', 117, 2, 28, 207468) If you can absorb good qualities the result is bound to be good.

('82', 120, 13, 22, 210961) 138. ‘SCORCHED EARTH’
('82', 120, 14, 23, 210983) The Russian technique of scorched earth has staggered humanity, but humanity has been powerless to do anything except applaud the amazing sacrifice and bravery that counted no cost too great to circumvent the enemy.
('82', 120, 14, 24, 211199) I have shared the amazement with the admirers but not their admiration.
('82', 120, 15, 25, 211271) 1 Ceiotropis Gigantica 2 One word is illegible.
('82', 121, 0, 1, 211319) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 122
('82', 121, 1, 2, 211361) We like to imitate what we admire.
('82', 121, 1, 3, 211396) Now that the prospect faces us, are we able to contemplate with equanimity, or feel the glow of bravery and sacrifice at the prospect of India’s earth being scorched and everything destroyed in order that the enemy’s march may be hampered?
('82', 121, 2, 4, 211636) As a war resister my answer can only be one.
('82', 121, 2, 5, 211681) I see neither bravery nor sacrfice in destroying life or property for offence of defence.
('82', 121, 2, 6, 211771) I would far rather leave, if I must, my crops and homestead for the enemy to use than destroy them for the sake of preventing their use by him.
('82', 121, 2, 7, 211915) There is reason, sacrifice and even bravery in so leaving my homestead and crops, if I do so not out of fear but because I refuse to regard anyone as my enemy—that is, out of a humanitarian motive.
('82', 121, 3, 8, 212113) But in India’s case there is, too, a practical consideration.
('82', 121, 3, 9, 212175) Unlike Russia’s, India’s masses have no national instinct developed in the sense that Russia’s have.
('82', 121, 3, 10, 212276) India is not fighting.
('82', 121, 3, 11, 212299) Her conquerors are.
('82', 121, 3, 12, 212319) Supposing that the conquerors are worsted and the Japanese come, the inarticulate masses will not even notice the change for the time being or for a long time.
('82', 121, 3, 13, 212479) The intelligentsia are divided on the issue of the war.
('82', 121, 3, 14, 212535) The motive here is irrelevant.
('82', 121, 3, 15, 212566) India’s soldiers are in no sense a national army.
('82', 121, 3, 16, 212616) They are soldiers because it is their profession.
('82', 121, 3, 17, 212666) They will as soon fight under the Japanese or any other provided they are paid for fighting.
('82', 121, 3, 18, 212759) In these circumstances the policy of scorched earth would be a wholly indefensible act.
('82', 121, 4, 19, 212847) It is therefore a matter for satisfaction that Indian opinion is being expressed against the policy of scorching.
('82', 121, 4, 20, 212961) I know nothing of the requirements of the military, but they can never be allowed to supersede national or humanitarian considerations which the nation may have accepted.
('82', 121, 4, 21, 213132) The military must thus be an arm of the dominant civil power, not its substitute.
('82', 121, 4, 22, 213214) The Government of India will considerable ease the situation and allay anxiety by declaring in unequivocal terms that they will not apply, if the occasion ever arise, the scorched earth policy to India, especially regard being had to her peculiar position.
('82', 121, 5, 23, 213471) SEVAGRAM, March 16, 1942 Harijan, 22 3 1942
('82', 122, 0, 1, 213515) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 123
('82', 122, 1, 2, 213558) 139. A HARIJAN COLONY IN BIHAR 1
('82', 122, 2, 3, 213591) Raja Bahadur Kamakhya Narayan Sinha, while opening a Harijan Colony in Arrah the other day, spoke against the sin of untouchability in a way which reminds one of the recent message 2 to Harijans sent by the Maharaja Saheb of Indore :
('82', 122, 3, 4, 213825) It is a crime on tha part of us so called caste Hindus to treat lakhs of
('82', 122, 4, 5, 213898) people as untouchables.
('82', 122, 4, 6, 213922) They too are God’s creation.
('82', 122, 4, 7, 213951) They have the same
('82', 122, 5, 8, 213970) physical form as we, they are activated by the same human desires, they feel
('82', 122, 6, 9, 214047) insults and misery just as keenly as we do.
('82', 122, 6, 10, 214091) But they are today powerless to
('82', 122, 7, 11, 214123) raise their voice in protest.
('82', 122, 7, 12, 214153) Their cry of distress, however, does go up to
('82', 122, 8, 13, 214199) heaven, and we shall surely be damned by it if we do not mend.
('82', 122, 8, 14, 214262) We must atone
('82', 122, 9, 15, 214276) for our sins.
('82', 122, 9, 16, 214290) That we have put up for them a dwellng place of brics and mortar
('82', 122, 10, 17, 214355) is only a drop in the ocean.
('82', 122, 10, 18, 214384) We shall have atoned only when we give them a
('82', 122, 11, 19, 214430) dwelling place in our hearts and shall embrace them as the great Bharat
('82', 122, 12, 20, 214502) embraced the humble boatman Guha and thereby raised himself.
('82', 122, 12, 21, 214563) If all caste Hindus were to root out untouchability from their hearts as Raja Bahadur has done, this blot would soon be removed from our society.
('82', 122, 13, 22, 214709) SEVAGRAM, March 16, 1942 Harijan, 22 2 1942

('82', 122, 19, 30, 215047) right ideals to set things right.
('82', 122, 19, 31, 215081) A. It should be part and parcel of the work of civic guards to protect people as far as possible from hunger and exploitation.
('82', 122, 19, 32, 215208) I have already given some advice as to how to economize in food during
('82', 122, 20, 33, 215279) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.

('82', 123, 1, 2, 215474) times of stress.
('82', 123, 1, 3, 215491) 1 Such economy should begin from today.
('82', 123, 1, 4, 215531) 1. Food should be regulated scientifically so that there is no waste and a maximum of economy.

('82', 125, 3, 5, 218718) 144. FOREWORD TO “THE MEDIUM OF INSTRUCTION”
('82', 125, 4, 6, 218763) March 18, 1942 Principal Shriman Narayan Agrawal’s treatise is timely and should go a long way in dispelling the fear and distrust about the possibility and desirability of giving the highest instruction through the mother tongue.
('82', 125, 4, 7, 218994) For me it is tragic that such an obvious truth requires arguing.
('82', 125, 4, 8, 219059) Although Principal Agrawal imbibed all that his ambition could desire of the English language, he never allowed his love of mother tongue to be displaced by his regard for English.
('82', 125, 4, 9, 219240) He is, therefore, well equipped for the mission which he has made his own.
('82', 125, 4, 10, 219315) I hope that he will not rest till the mother tongues in the various provinces have come into their own.
('82', 125, 4, 11, 219419) I have no doubt whatsoever that if those who have the education of the youth in their hands will but make up their minds, they will discover that the mother tongue is as natural for the development of the man’s mind as mother’s milk is for the development of the infant’s body.
('82', 125, 4, 12, 219697) How can it be otherwise?
('82', 125, 4, 13, 219722) The babe takes its first lessons from its mother.
('82', 125, 4, 14, 219772) I, therefore, regard it as a sin against the motherland to inflict upon her children a tongue other their mother’s for their mental development.
('82', 125, 5, 15, 219917) The Medium of Instruction
('82', 125, 6, 16, 219943) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('82', 125, 6, 17, 219974) 2 In the article “Passing of the First Stage of the A.I.V.I.A.”

('82', 126, 12, 19, 220617) 147. THE ANDHRAS
('82', 126, 13, 20, 220634) The following has been sent to me by Maharaj Kumar Vijaya Anand of Vizianagram:
('82', 126, 14, 21, 220714) There is a strong feeling amongst us Andhras that you do not like us, that you are against the formation and the establishment of a separate province.
('82', 126, 14, 22, 220865) Despite Andhra Desh being overwhelmingly Congress, it never received your blessings.
('82', 126, 14, 23, 220950) If three crores of yearning hearts are asking for a separate existence, would you not allow them the “right to sing” as the great Tilak Maharaj once said?
('82', 126, 14, 24, 221105) People of my Desh are so definite about your dislike for the Andhras that they even attribute your visit to Benares recently for the purpose of commanding me to drop the Andhra agitation.
('82', 126, 14, 25, 221293) The Andhras would like to know whether you ever gave any advice to Tamil Nad regarding Andhras, and also wish to know whether during the last ministry the Andhra question was
('82', 127, 0, 1, 221468) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 128
('82', 127, 1, 2, 221510) referred to you or not; if so, what advice did you give them?
('82', 127, 1, 3, 221572) Do you put the Andhra question on the same footing as that of Karnataka and Kerala whose revenues may not be enough to have separate provinces?
('82', 127, 1, 4, 221716) Pray, what is your opinion regarding Andhra Desh being self supporting?
('82', 127, 1, 5, 221788) Is it not a fact that, owing to steadfast loyalty of the Andhras to the Congress movement, they did not achieve what Orissa did?
('82', 127, 1, 6, 221917) It is felt that, had the Andhras taken a different line of action when the Simon Commission came to India, they would have got their hearts’ desire.
('82', 127, 1, 7, 222066) I can only say that the Maharaj Kumar is in bad hands.
('82', 127, 1, 8, 222121) Being a novice in the art of handling masses, he has evidently not taken care to inquire into the credentials of his informants.
('82', 127, 1, 9, 222250) I should like to know the Andhras who have given him the information which he has chosen to transmit to me.
('82', 127, 1, 10, 222358) I am not a stranger to Andhra Desh myself.
('82', 127, 1, 11, 222401) I refer the Maharaj Kumar to Deshabhakta Konda Venkatappayya, Shri Prakasam, Dr. Pattabhi Sitaramayya, Shri Kaleshwara Rao and Shri Sitaram Sastry.
('82', 127, 1, 12, 222549) They will probably bear witness to the fact that I was principally instrumental in securing from the Congress the recognition of the redistribution of the Provinces for Congress purposes on a linguistic basis.
('82', 127, 1, 13, 222759) I have always agitated for the acceptance by the Government of such redistribution.
('82', 127, 1, 14, 222843) I have indeed advised Tamil Nad, when such advice was needed, not to resist the Andhra demand.
('82', 127, 1, 15, 222938) I know that the Congress ministry headed by Shri C. Rajagopalachari tried its best to get Andhra recognized as a separate province, and it was no fault of the ministry that Andhra Desh has not yet been so recognized.
('82', 127, 1, 16, 223155) But it is true that I recognize no distinction between Karnataka, Kerala and Andhra or for that matter any other province recognized by the Congress as a separate province.
('82', 127, 1, 17, 223328) I do not know enough about any province to be able to say which can be self supporting on being recognized as separate.
('82', 127, 1, 18, 223448) As to my visit to Benares, the purpose is too well known to need any clarification.
('82', 127, 1, 19, 223532) The Maharaj Kumar is a sportsman, and he should be above worrying about baseless suggestions made about him.
('82', 127, 1, 20, 223641) He would be an unworthy leader who can be deflected from his mission even by a Mahatma.
('82', 127, 1, 21, 223729) I hope this answer will satisfy the Maharaj Kumar, if not even those who duped this him into putting the questions he has.
('82', 127, 2, 22, 223852) Sevagram, March 20, 1942

('82', 128, 6, 13, 224524) 149. LETTER TO DESMOND YOUNG
('82', 128, 7, 14, 224553) March 21, 1942
('82', 128, 8, 15, 224568) DEAR MR. YOUNG, I was glad to read your letter to Mahadev Desai and know that you had returned safe and sound.
('82', 128, 8, 16, 224679) I hope you are none the worse for the hard life you must have had at the front.
('82', 128, 9, 17, 224759) With reference to the subject matter of your letter, I can only give you my assurance that I am not in the habit of writing anything without ascertaining facts.
('82', 128, 9, 18, 224920) And when I have evidence from persons I know, for the sake of truth and for the sake of protecting the public I write and then, too, cautiously.
('82', 128, 9, 19, 225065) If you think that absence of complaint means absence of guilt, you are vastly mistaken.
('82', 128, 9, 20, 225153) The behaviour of troops, white or brown, has become a public scandal.
('82', 128, 9, 21, 225223) Even respectable and well known women are not free from danger.
('82', 128, 9, 22, 225287) You may not know that an Indian official’s wife was recently ravished by soldiers (Indian) on the train.
('82', 128, 9, 23, 225392) The official had lodged a complaint too but at the instance of his superiors he withdrew it.
('82', 128, 9, 24, 225485) The instances of looting in
('82', 129, 0, 1, 225513) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 130
('82', 129, 1, 2, 225555) the open are too common to be decently challenged.
('82', 129, 1, 3, 225606) There are guarded admission of some of these by high functionaries.
('82', 129, 1, 4, 225674) I get almost daily complaints of such cases.
('82', 129, 1, 5, 225719) Having been absent for some time you do not know how things have deteriorated in such matters.
('82', 129, 1, 6, 225814) No wonder.
('82', 129, 1, 7, 225825) Full blooded soldiers not on duty find vent for their exuberant physical energy by taking liberties which cannot be allowed in a society not used to such conduct.
('82', 129, 2, 8, 225988) In Wardha, only a few days ago, soldiers who were loitering in the streets of the town were molesting a woman.
('82', 129, 2, 9, 226099) A strong gymnast, seeing the molestation, belaboured the soldiers and they took to their heels.
('82', 129, 2, 10, 226195) A wealthy merchant was waiting for his train at Wardha Station when a troop train steamed in.
('82', 129, 2, 11, 226289) He saw two of them take milk from an old woman on the platform without payment.
('82', 129, 2, 12, 226369) On seeing the latter weeping this merchant intervened.
('82', 129, 2, 13, 226424) He was thereupon slapped, caught by the neck and taken to the soldiers’ compartment to receive proper punishment.
('82', 129, 2, 14, 226538) Happily, the bystanders who knew the merchant intervened and he was saved from serious injury.
('82', 129, 2, 15, 226633) I can multiply such cases.
('82', 129, 2, 16, 226660) I have thought fit not to give publicity to them.
('82', 129, 2, 17, 226710) Nor have I advised reporting to the authorities.
('82', 129, 3, 18, 226759) You will ill serve the common cause by ignoring facts behind the worn out plea that absence of complaint before the police means absence of crime.
('82', 129, 3, 19, 226906) Happily in responsible quarters there has come over a slow but sure awakening.
('82', 129, 3, 20, 226985) I wish you would find leisure to study facts and help as much as you can to remove a growing menace.
('82', 129, 4, 21, 227086) Yours sincerely,
('82', 129, 5, 22, 227103) M. K. GANDHI
('82', 129, 6, 23, 227116) From a photostat: C.W. 10369. Courtesy: India Office Library, London

('82', 133, 1, 2, 230603) 156. INHUMAN IF TRUE
('82', 133, 2, 3, 230624) The Honorary Secretary of the Social Service Department of the Marwari Relief Society writes: 1
('82', 133, 3, 4, 230720) I have to place before you a very brief review of the activities of the
('82', 133, 4, 5, 230792) Marwari Relief Society, Calcutta, in connection with rendering relief to
('82', 133, 5, 6, 230865) evacuees from Burma and Malaya, absolutely irrespective of caste, creed and
('82', 133, 6, 7, 230941) colour, and also to humbly seek your invaluable advice on a very grave
('82', 133, 7, 8, 231012) matter.
('82', 133, 8, 9, 231020) In this connection I beg to report a certain very regrettable incident to
('82', 133, 9, 10, 231094) you, and shall be grateful if you kindly advise me as to my duties in the matter.
('82', 133, 10, 11, 231176) On the night of the 14th March, shortly after the arrival of the
('82', 133, 11, 12, 231241) Chittagong Mail, as I, in company with a number of volunteers, was attending
('82', 133, 12, 13, 231318) to the wants of the evacuees, a British tommy got hold of a small child
('82', 133, 13, 14, 231390) belonging to one of the poor evacuees and threw it under the train.
('82', 133, 13, 15, 231458) Although I
('82', 133, 14, 16, 231469) am a humble follower of your noble creed of non violence, it was with the
('82', 133, 15, 17, 231543) greatest difficulty that I restrained myself and my volunteers from punishing
('82', 133, 16, 18, 231621) the soldier bodily for his brutal act.
('82', 133, 16, 19, 231660) I reported the matter to the station
('82', 133, 17, 20, 231697) military authorities, but their attitude was anything but sympathetic.
('82', 133, 17, 21, 231768) I later
('82', 133, 18, 22, 231776) approached Mr. K. C. Sen, I.C.S., over the matter, and though he promised to
('82', 133, 19, 23, 231853) duly enquire into the matter, nothing has been done as yet to rectify it.
('82', 133, 20, 24, 231927) are still large numbers of soldiers loitering about the platforms every night,
('82', 133, 21, 25, 232006) and a violent clash between these soldiers and relief volunteers and the public
('82', 133, 22, 26, 232086) is a possibility which has to be tackled in no time.
('82', 133, 22, 27, 232139) I have already placed the
('82', 133, 23, 28, 232165) matter before the Bengal Congress Civil Protection Committee.
('82', 133, 24, 29, 232227) I should be thankful, if you kindly advised me on the following points:
('82', 133, 25, 30, 232299) 1. Should I start an agitation in the press over the matter?
('82', 133, 26, 31, 232360) 2. Supposing a soldier behaves indecently towards a helpless female
('82', 133, 27, 32, 232428) evacuee, are we to put up with it silently, or should the soldier be forcibly dealt
('82', 133, 29, 33, 232512) It would help us very greatly, if you kindly issued a statement in Harijan
('82', 133, 30, 34, 232587) in this connection.
('82', 133, 30, 35, 232607) I am prepared to accept all responsibility regarding the
('82', 133, 31, 36, 232664) truthfulness of the above incident.
('82', 133, 32, 37, 232700) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('82', 134, 0, 1, 232737) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 135
('82', 134, 1, 2, 232780) I have suppressed many letters giving me authentic details about the misbehaviour of soldiers.
('82', 134, 1, 3, 232875) I have published them when it would have been wrong, if not cowardly, to suppress them.
('82', 134, 1, 4, 232963) The letter in question demands, in my opinion, the widest publicity, not merely for the safety of the public but also for the sake of the soldiers and the Government.
('82', 134, 1, 5, 233130) The Marwari Relief Society is a big philanthropic institution of twenty five years’ standing having an all India reputation.
('82', 134, 1, 6, 233255) It has funds and seasoned workers.
('82', 134, 1, 7, 233290) Its prestige should have been enough security for the good behaviour of the soldiers in the presence of its workers.
('82', 134, 1, 8, 233407) The soldier must have run amuck or been under the influence of drink to have behaved as he is reported to have done.
('82', 134, 1, 9, 233524) I trust that the Marwari Relief Society will not leave the matter till it is thoroughly thrashed out; and I trust too that the authorities will not wish to hush up the matter but will make ample amends, if the case is proved as reported by my correspondent.
('82', 134, 2, 10, 233782) So much for the case itself.
('82', 134, 2, 11, 233811) The correspondent desires my guidance about similar cases in future.
('82', 134, 2, 12, 233880) The action of himsa or ahimsa would have been identical.
('82', 134, 2, 13, 233937) The volunteers should have, if they could, bodily prevented the soldier from touching the child or snatched the child from him, even if the soldier had been hurt in the act of preventing or snatching.
('82', 134, 2, 14, 234138) The proceedings after the delivery of the child or the failure of the attempt would vary according as the deliverers were actuated violently or non violently.
('82', 134, 2, 15, 234297) Non violent behaviour would dictate generous and gentle behaviour towards the culprit.
('82', 134, 2, 16, 234384) But generosity and gentleness would have to be thoughtful and reasoned.
('82', 134, 2, 17, 234456) It is difficult to lay down in advance the rule of conduct applicable in all cases.
('82', 134, 2, 18, 234540) I can say this much that a truly generous act demands sincere recognition on the part of the culprit.
('82', 134, 2, 19, 234642) I have known instances of Africans in South Africa insulted at railway stations saying to the rude white men, “My brother, God will forgive you for your rudeness,” and the white men giggling, if not adding injury to insult.
('82', 134, 2, 20, 234866) In similar circumstances I have myself remained silent and suffered the insult.
('82', 134, 2, 21, 234946) I am quite clear that the Africans’ so called generosity was a mere mechanical act justly evoking derision.
('82', 134, 2, 22, 235054) Mine was timidity.
('82', 134, 2, 23, 235073) I did not wish to evoke further insult.
('82', 134, 2, 24, 235113) I certainly did not want to take legal proceedings.
('82', 134, 2, 25, 235165) I was trying then to shape my non violent conduct.
('82', 134, 2, 26, 235216) If I had the real courage, I would have expostulated
('82', 135, 0, 1, 235269) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 136
('82', 135, 1, 2, 235311) with the insulters and risked the worst.
('82', 135, 2, 3, 235352) I have interpolated an examination of so called non violent conduct in cases of personal insult or injury.
('82', 135, 2, 4, 235459) What about the child injured or the injury imagined by my correspondent?
('82', 135, 2, 5, 235532) I think non violent conduct would not, should not, be different.
('82', 135, 2, 6, 235597) The distinction that is often drawn between personal injury and injury done to wards is unjustified, if not wrong.
('82', 135, 2, 7, 235712) A man is not expected to do more for his wards than he would for himself.
('82', 135, 2, 8, 235786) He would no doubt sacrifice himself for his ward’s honour, but he would be expected to do likewise for his own.
('82', 135, 2, 9, 235898) If he did otherwise, he would be voted a coward and is not likely to protect his ward’s honour, if he is not able to protect his own.
('82', 135, 2, 10, 236032) But I own that correct non violent conduct does not come through mere reasoning.
('82', 135, 2, 11, 236113) Reason is a necessary preliminary.
('82', 135, 2, 12, 236148) But correctness of conduct will come only through repeated practice, may be even repeated failures.
('82', 135, 3, 13, 236248) What violent conduct should be surely needs no examination.
('82', 135, 4, 14, 236308) SEVAGRAM, March 23, 1942 Harijan, 29 3 1942
('82', 135, 5, 15, 236352) 157. QUESTION BOX
('82', 135, 6, 16, 236370) ABOUT CHILDREN
('82', 135, 7, 17, 236385) Q. I quite agree that as society advances marriages between the different
('82', 135, 8, 18, 236459) communities will increase and should be welcomed.
('82', 135, 8, 19, 236509) You rightly advocate no change
('82', 135, 9, 20, 236540) of religion for the parties con cerned.
('82', 135, 9, 21, 236580) 1 But what do you advocate for the children?
('82', 135, 10, 22, 236625) which religion should they be brought up, the father’s or the mother’s?
('82', 135, 11, 23, 236697) A. Presumption in such marriages is that the parents respect each other’s religions.
('82', 135, 11, 24, 236782) If they are religiously minded, the children will unconsciously imbibe what they think is best for them and choose their own faith without let or hindrance from the parents.
('82', 135, 11, 25, 236956) If the latter are indifferent, the children will also be probably indifferent and label themselves anyhow.
('82', 135, 11, 26, 237063) This is what I have observed in such marriages.
('82', 135, 11, 27, 237111) The difficulty crops up when there is a serious difference arising between the parents as to the upbringing of the children.
('82', 135, 12, 28, 237236) 1 Vide “Indira Nehru’s Engagement” sub title of “Notes”, 2 3 1942
('82', 136, 0, 1, 237302) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 137
('82', 136, 1, 2, 237345) CONVERSION WITHOUT CONVICTION
('82', 136, 2, 3, 237375) Q. You oppose all conversion without conviction.
('82', 136, 2, 4, 237424) But are you not
('82', 136, 3, 5, 237440) inconsistent?
('82', 136, 3, 6, 237454) You profess equal respect for all religions.
('82', 136, 3, 7, 237499) Why then worry about how
('82', 136, 4, 8, 237524) the conversion is brought about?
('82', 136, 5, 9, 237557) A. I have extracted the question from your long and plausible letter, cleverly written.
('82', 136, 5, 10, 237645) Conversion without convicition is a mere change and not conversion which is a revolution in one’s life.
('82', 136, 5, 11, 237749) You seem too to forget that equal respect implies respect for my own faith as much as for yours or any other neighbour’s.
('82', 136, 5, 12, 237871) My respect for my own faith forbids my being indifferent to my children abandoning their parents’ faith without conviction.
('82', 136, 5, 13, 237995) And I should have little respect for you, if you led my children astray by making all kinds of worldly promises in which matters of the spirit had no play.
('82', 136, 6, 14, 238151) SEVAGRAM, March 23, 1942 Harijan, 29 3 1942
('82', 136, 7, 15, 238195) 158. NOTES
('82', 136, 8, 16, 238206) THE NATIONAL WEEK
('82', 136, 9, 17, 238224) The National Week comes every year with the certainty of seasons.
('82', 136, 9, 18, 238290) It has come for over twenty years now, and yet we seem to be as far as ever from our freedom or communal unity or univers alization of khadi.
('82', 136, 9, 19, 238432) We started the celebration with these three definite things.
('82', 136, 9, 20, 238493) They were convertible terms.
('82', 136, 9, 21, 238522) If we had unity, we could get freedom, and so also if all were converted to the khadi cult.
('82', 136, 9, 22, 238614) Though we have added many things since to our constructive programme, the original is true today as it was when it was first conceived and started.
('82', 136, 10, 23, 238762) How shall we behave during the forthcoming Week?
('82', 136, 10, 24, 238811) Let us not treat freedom apart from its components.
('82', 136, 10, 25, 238863) Then there remain communal unity and the thirteen other items, at the centre of which stands khadi in its widest sense.
('82', 136, 11, 26, 238983) Communal unity at the top will come in its time.
('82', 136, 11, 27, 239032) We want freedom for the masses, and so do we want communal unity for and among the masses.
('82', 136, 11, 28, 239123) If we have it in our hearts, let us show it in our daily little acts towards one another.
('82', 137, 0, 1, 239213) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 138
('82', 137, 1, 2, 239255) I will not mention the other items.
('82', 137, 1, 3, 239291) All organizations will look after them.
('82', 137, 1, 4, 239331) A word is necessary about khadi.
('82', 137, 1, 5, 239364) Hitherto we have had khadi sales.
('82', 137, 1, 6, 239398) This time, thanks to many causes, we have no khadi to sell.
('82', 137, 1, 7, 239458) But we can all produce, we can all collect funds.
('82', 137, 1, 8, 239508) If we have enough capital, we can produce more khadi.
('82', 137, 1, 9, 239562) But we can also do tunai or carding and even weaving, not for self but for the nation.
('82', 137, 1, 10, 239649) We would therefore give our output to the A.I.S.A. at its depots in our localities.
('82', 137, 2, 11, 239733) And let me not forget the 24 hours’ fast on the 6th and the 13th April.
('82', 137, 2, 12, 239805) 1 Thousands believed in it when we began.
('82', 137, 2, 13, 239847) We did not err in fasting.
('82', 137, 2, 14, 239874) Let those who have faith in it not forget fasting and prayer.

('82', 137, 12, 26, 240538) should not the A.I.S.A. dispense with those washermen who observe
('82', 137, 13, 27, 240604) untouchability in their profession?

('82', 137, 13, 30, 240713) All institution which deny access to Harijans should be boycotted by those, whether Congressmen or others, who feel keenly that the curse of untouchability has to be removed if Hinduism is to remain as a faith to live for and, if need be, to die for.

('82', 137, 13, 32, 241032) But nothing can be achieved unless serious difficulties are seriously faced and surmounted.
('82', 137, 13, 33, 241124) The question gives rise to a dilemma on some occasions.
('82', 137, 13, 34, 241180) The washermen are supported by the A.I.S.A. in common with the other artisans.
('82', 137, 13, 35, 241259) These cling to untouchability with a tenacity that defies all attempt to make them see the superstition that the curse is.
('82', 137, 13, 36, 241382) Whilst I cannot off hand ask A.I.S.A. workers to boycott the artisans that

('82', 140, 1, 2, 243917) 163. LITERARY v.CRAFT WORK 1
('82', 140, 2, 3, 243946) Shri Narahari Parikh writes:
('82', 140, 3, 4, 243975) I feel that in many of our khadi and other schools the emphasis laid on
('82', 140, 4, 5, 244047) literary training is wholly wrong.
('82', 140, 4, 6, 244082) Certain hours are assigned to craft work and
('82', 140, 5, 7, 244127) certain to literary work, but it is believed that knowledge can only be imbibed
('82', 140, 6, 8, 244207) through book reading.
('82', 140, 6, 9, 244229) I hold that more intellectual progress is possible for
('82', 140, 7, 10, 244284) our students through craft work than books.
('82', 140, 7, 11, 244328) I shall be grateful if you will give
('82', 140, 8, 12, 244365) your opinion on this issue.
('82', 140, 8, 13, 244393) The writer’s complaint is justified.
('82', 140, 8, 14, 244430) Literary training does not always mean expansion of the intellect.
('82', 140, 8, 15, 244497) Primarily it is a matter of memorizing.
('82', 140, 8, 16, 244537) A letter is imprinted on the brain in the same way as any other picture.
('82', 140, 8, 17, 244610) But literary training is more than mere reading.
('82', 140, 8, 18, 244659) 2 The same thing is true of handicrafts.
('82', 140, 8, 19, 244700) A knowledge of handicrafts is not limited to the mere craft.
('82', 140, 8, 20, 244761) It includes a knowlege of its science.
('82', 140, 8, 21, 244800) Then the expansion of the intellect is much greater and quicker than in high schools and colleges.
('82', 140, 8, 22, 244899) 3 Therefore, to run down craft work or give it a secondary place in the school programme is greatly to be deplored.
('82', 140, 8, 23, 245015) Students thus underrate the value and place of craft knowledge in the expansion of the intellect.
('82', 140, 8, 24, 245113) 4 Book learning damages the eyes and cramps thought and originality.
('82', 140, 8, 25, 245182) 5 There is no such danger in learning crafts and their science.
('82', 140, 8, 26, 245246) This too involves some study of books.
('82', 140, 8, 27, 245285) But that study is related to crafts and, therefore, requires the exertion of the intellect.
('82', 140, 8, 28, 245377) This is what I mean by basic training.
('82', 140, 8, 29, 245416) It must, in time, come into its own, for it is so true.
('82', 140, 8, 30, 245472) But meanwhile let there be no
('82', 140, 9, 31, 245502) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('82', 140, 9, 32, 245533) The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 5 4 1942. 2 The Gujarati here has: “Reading and understanding books on different subjects is also included in literary training.” 3 The Gujarati here adds: “It is memory rather than intellect that is developed by literary training.
('82', 140, 9, 33, 245822) This can be said of hundreds of students who graduate from the high schools and colleges.
('82', 140, 9, 34, 245912) But in the case of scientific knowledge of a craft there can be no such undesirable result.
('82', 140, 9, 35, 246004) And the hours of training should not be divided under the heads ‘Learning’ and Craft’.” 4 The Gujarati here adds: “They are lured by books and then both suffer.
('82', 140, 9, 36, 246165) Mere reading does not develop the intellect.” 5 The Gujarati here has: “And when one develops a dislike for craft work one’s knowledge of its science remains superficial.
('82', 140, 9, 37, 246336) Everything fits into its own place.”

('82', 145, 1, 2, 250592) 171. NOTES
('82', 145, 2, 3, 250603) PRAJA MANDALS AND CONGRESS Thus writes a correspondent from an Indian State:
('82', 145, 3, 4, 250680) On page 67 of Harijan (of March 8, 1942) there is a question which is of great interest and importance to Praja Mandals in Indian States.
('82', 145, 3, 5, 250818) 1 The latter part of the question is, “Who should be responsible for political policies there (in States)?” I am afraid that the answer does not sufficiently clear the position.
('82', 145, 3, 6, 250996) From what appeared in this connection in Harijan before, and from the present answer, in an indirect way, it seems that you wish the Praja Mandals to be responsible for the political policy in the States concerned.
('82', 145, 3, 7, 251211) It would follow that the local branch of the Congress would not independently initiate any politcal policy or come into conflict with the policy of the local Praja Mandal.
('82', 145, 3, 8, 251383) I think there was no confusion about my answer.
('82', 145, 3, 9, 251431) The Congress organization has its centre and chief work in British India.
('82', 145, 3, 10, 251505) It has branches in some States.
('82', 145, 3, 11, 251537) They are not expected to dabble in local politics.
('82', 145, 3, 12, 251588) They are, therefore, advised to confine themselves to constructive work.
('82', 145, 3, 13, 251661) But Praja Mandals have to do constructive work always, and political work properly so called wherever it is allowed or where there are brave and able enough men to carry on the political struggle.
('82', 145, 3, 14, 251858) It is thus purely a question of local ability and opportunity.
('82', 145, 3, 15, 251921) At the present moment when everything is in the melting pot, no heroics in politics are called for in the States.
('82', 145, 4, 16, 252035) STOPPING ANIMAL SACRIFICE
('82', 145, 5, 17, 252061) A Belgaum correspondent writes: 2
('82', 145, 6, 18, 252095) This is indeed good news.
('82', 145, 6, 19, 252121) Shri Keshwain deserves congratu lations for his humanitarian spirit.
('82', 145, 6, 20, 252190) Those who wish to may eat what meats they like, but it is defaming God to offer animal sacrifices in temples.
('82', 145, 6, 21, 252300) What God wants, if He can be said to want anything, is the sacrifice made by a humble and contrite heart.
('82', 145, 6, 22, 252406) ON THE WAY TO DELHI, March 26, 1942 Harijan, 5 4 1942
('82', 145, 7, 23, 252460) 1 Vide “Question Box”, 2 3 1942. 2 The letter, not reproduced here, described how S.N.Keshwain, President, Canara District Harijan Sevak Sangh and one of the trustees of the Sirsi temple, had the custom of animal sacrifice abolished.

('82', 146, 1, 2, 252737) 172. A YOUNG CANADIAN’S QUESTION
('82', 146, 2, 3, 252770) From my American post I pick up the following typical letter from Vancouver: 1
('82', 146, 3, 4, 252849) Denuded of the courtesies, the writer’s straight question is, “Will there be room for Britishers and foreigners in free India?” The question should have nothing to do with my spirituality supposed or real.
('82', 146, 3, 5, 253055) It does not arise for free America or free Britain.
('82', 146, 3, 6, 253107) And it will not arise when India become really free.
('82', 146, 3, 7, 253160) For India will then be free to do what she likes, without let or hindrance from anybody.
('82', 146, 3, 8, 253249) But it is pleasing to speculate what India would do if she becomes free, as she must sooner or later.
('82', 146, 3, 9, 253351) If I have any influence over her policies, foreigners will be welcome, provided their presence is beneficial to the country.
('82', 146, 3, 10, 253476) They will never be allowed to exploit and impoverish the country as they have done hitherto.
('82', 146, 4, 11, 253569) What free India will otherwise look like remains to be seen.
('82', 146, 4, 12, 253630) 2 She has nothing to fear from the contemplation of the helplessness of the small nations of Europe, if she continues to tread the non violent course she has done with more or less perfection and with more or less success.
('82', 146, 4, 13, 253853) For a non violent State bigness is wholly unnecessary for its protection against aggression.
('82', 146, 4, 14, 253946) Such a State will need spend nothing for protection against aggression from without.
('82', 146, 4, 15, 254031) Whether such a State will ever come into being is a fair question to ask.
('82', 146, 4, 16, 254105) Reason suggests no flaw in the theoretical conception of it.
('82', 146, 4, 17, 254166) Whether human nature will respond to what has been called an exacting 3 call is another question.
('82', 146, 4, 18, 254264) It has been known in individual cases to rise to unimaginable heights.
('82', 146, 4, 19, 254335) There is nothing to prevent its multiplication by patient endeavour.
('82', 146, 4, 20, 254404) Anyway I am not going to lose my faith and abandon the attempt because I can show no visible sign of such a response from India.
('82', 146, 4, 21, 254533) One might as well abandon all hope, as some have done, for the attainment of India’s unadulterated freedom.
('82', 146, 4, 22, 254641) For they say, it will take
('82', 146, 5, 23, 254668) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('82', 146, 5, 24, 254705) 2 The correspondent had further asked: “I should like to know just what stand your new democracy would take in world politics.
('82', 146, 5, 25, 254832) The small countries of Europe thought that they would keep their finger out of the pie, as the saying goes, but look where they are now.” 3 The source has “exactious”.
('82', 147, 0, 1, 255000) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 148
('82', 147, 1, 2, 255042) centuries for India, which is largely and wholly unarmed, to become a military nation.
('82', 147, 1, 3, 255129) I refuse to be prey to such despair.
('82', 147, 1, 4, 255166) In the ringing words of Lokamanya, “Freedom is India’s birthright, and she will have it cost what it may.” Glory lies in the attempt to reach one’s goal and not in reaching it.
('82', 147, 1, 5, 255343) I passionately believe in the possibility of attainment through the perfection of the non violent technique whose hidden resources no one has fathomed.
('82', 147, 1, 6, 255495) We have only found a foothold.
('82', 147, 1, 7, 255526) Perseverance opens up treasures which bring perennial joy.
('82', 147, 1, 8, 255585) If the toil is great, so is the fruit thereof.
('82', 147, 2, 9, 255632) ON THE WAY TO DELHI, March 26, 1942 Harijan, 5 4 1942
('82', 147, 3, 10, 255686) 173. VACATION WORK
('82', 147, 4, 11, 255705) A Poona correspondent writes:
('82', 147, 5, 12, 255735) Students are now going on long leave for their summer vacation.
('82', 147, 5, 13, 255799) Most of them will leave the cities and go to their native places.
('82', 147, 5, 14, 255865) Looking to the urgent exigencies in the country due to the war situation, and its consequent responsibilities on the people of India, will it not be useful if a message is sent to the student world reminding them of their responsibility and duty at this critical juncture?
('82', 147, 5, 15, 256138) May I therefore request you to kindly issue an appeal at the earliest to the students calling them for some action during the vacation and after?
('82', 147, 5, 16, 256284) My humble suggestions are as follows:
('82', 147, 6, 17, 256322) 1. Reading out the news to the villages about the war and the Indian
('82', 147, 7, 18, 256391) political situation and special articles from Harijan.
('82', 147, 8, 19, 256446) 2. Explaining to them the present emergency and possible events.
('82', 147, 9, 20, 256511) 3. Organizing Nagarik samrakshan dals 1.
('82', 147, 10, 21, 256552) 4. Propagating and organizing the idea of self sufficiency in villages, so far as food and clothing is concerned.
('82', 147, 11, 22, 256666) 5. A persistent campaign against untouchability.
('82', 147, 11, 23, 256715) It is possible that the students, some of whom are under the fanatic influence of communal organizations, might harm rather than help the cause in view.
('82', 147, 11, 24, 256868) But we have to take the chances with the students as they are, and hence I have deliberately dropped, out of the above list, items of communal unity and Congress ideology and mentioned only such items as would give least scope for either communal or ideological differences.
('82', 147, 12, 25, 257143) 1 Civil defence corps
('82', 148, 0, 1, 257165) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 149
('82', 148, 1, 2, 257208) I have no difficulty in endorsing the suggestions made by the correspondent.
('82', 148, 2, 3, 257285) Self sufficiency is a big word.
('82', 148, 2, 4, 257317) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru has adopted that and self reliance as slogans in his U.P. speeches.
('82', 148, 2, 5, 257409) They should prove catching at this juncture.
('82', 148, 2, 6, 257454) Villages will be swept away, if they are not self sufficient as to their primary wants and self reliant as to their protection against internal disruption by dissensions and disease and external danger from thieves and dacoits.
('82', 148, 2, 7, 257682) Self sufficience, therefore, means all the cotton processes and growing of seasonal food crops and fodder for cattle.
('82', 148, 2, 8, 257800) Unless this is done there will be starvation.
('82', 148, 2, 9, 257846) And self reliance means corporate organization ensuring adjustment of internal differences through arbitration by the wise men of villages and cleanliness by corporate attention to sanitation and common diseases.
('82', 148, 2, 10, 258059) No mere individual effort is going to suffice.
('82', 148, 2, 11, 258106) And above all villagers must be taught to feel their own strength by combined effort to make their villages proof against thieves and dacoits.
('82', 148, 2, 12, 258249) This is best done by corporate non violence.
('82', 148, 2, 13, 258294) But if the way to non violence does not seem clear to workers, they will not hesitate to organize corporate defence through violence.
('82', 148, 2, 14, 258428) I am not having in mind Congressmen who have adopted non violence as their final creed and so have no choice in the matter.
('82', 148, 3, 15, 258552) Thus the students, if they will, can have a strenuous vacation.
('82', 148, 3, 16, 258616) Who knows that the vacation may not prove even indefinite?
('82', 148, 3, 17, 258675) But if it is not, two months are good enough time for laying down a good foundation for self sufficiency and self reliance.
('82', 148, 4, 18, 258799) My correspondent is timid.
('82', 148, 4, 19, 258826) There is no cause to fear communal strife.
('82', 148, 4, 20, 258869) Student who take the village reorganization cannot afford to be communal.
('82', 148, 4, 21, 258943) Communalism is an urban product fated to flourish only on urban soil.
('82', 148, 4, 22, 259013) In rural areas the people are too poor and too interdependent to find time for communal quarrels.
('82', 148, 4, 23, 259111) Be that as it may, student workers are assumed, for this note, to be free from the virus.
('82', 148, 5, 24, 259201) ON THE WAY TO DELHI, March 26, 1942
('82', 148, 6, 25, 259237) Harijan, 5 4 1942
