('82', 149, 1, 2, 259297) 174. FROM UNOFFICIAL NOTES
('82', 149, 2, 3, 259324) I extract the following useful information from the unofficial notes 1 published from time to time by the Principal Information Officer of the Government of India, which sometimes make intere sting and instructive reading.
('82', 149, 3, 4, 259547) ON THE WAY TO DELHI, March 26, 1942 Harijan, 5 4 1942
('82', 149, 4, 5, 259601) 175. QUESTION BOX
('82', 149, 5, 6, 259619) WEAKENING NON VIOLENCE?
('82', 149, 6, 7, 259643) Q. In the instructions issued by the Working Committee of the Congress in
('82', 149, 7, 8, 259717) the matter of organizing Congress volunteers it has been clearly stated that the
('82', 149, 8, 9, 259798) organization should be based on “strictly non violent basis”.
('82', 149, 8, 10, 259860) In the pledge forms
('82', 149, 9, 11, 259880) prepared in this behalf by some Congress committees, however, it is stated that
('82', 149, 10, 12, 259960) volunteers when on duty only should observe non violence.
('82', 149, 11, 13, 260018) The Karnataka P. C. C. has prepared the volunteers’ pledge in this form.
('82', 149, 12, 14, 260091) Chief Organizer of volunteers in the Province appointed by the K.P.C.C. declared in a
('82', 149, 13, 15, 260177) public meeting held for the prupose of enrolling volunteers that a Congress volunteer
('82', 149, 14, 16, 260263) even on duty might exercise the right of private defence by resorting to violence in
('82', 149, 15, 17, 260348) an emergency, and further that such an action on his part did not contravene the
('82', 149, 16, 18, 260429) instructions of the Working Committee.
('82', 149, 16, 19, 260468) All this is creating confusion.
('82', 149, 17, 20, 260500) instructions of the Working Committee are not to be strictly carried out, it would be
('82', 149, 18, 21, 260586) better that the condition of non violence were dropped altogether rather than were
('82', 149, 19, 22, 260669) allowed to be diluted to suit individual ideas.
('82', 149, 19, 23, 260717) What is your opinion in the matter?
('82', 149, 20, 24, 260753) A My answers must not be taken as authentic in questions the answers to which require the imprimatur of the Congress as this one does.
('82', 149, 20, 25, 260888) My personal opinion is Decisive.
('82', 149, 20, 26, 260921) Violence in self defence has no place in any corps organized by or in the name of the Congress.
('82', 149, 20, 27, 261017) There can be no laxity in the enforcement of this rule without risking a breakdown of the whole non violent structure in the Congress.
('82', 149, 20, 28, 261152) Use of violence in private self defence is said to be
('82', 149, 21, 29, 261206) 1 Not reproduced here.
('82', 149, 21, 30, 261229) They deal with reports of researches in indigenous medicinal plants, fish liver oils, manuring of paddy and registration of cattle.
('82', 150, 0, 1, 261361) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 151
('82', 150, 1, 2, 261404) permitted by the Congress because the Congress does not and cannot regulate the personal and private life of individual Congressmen.
('82', 150, 1, 3, 261537) The individual in his private life is unfettered by the rules of the Congress.
('82', 150, 1, 4, 261616) He is dominated by his own ethical code, if any.
('82', 150, 2, 5, 261665) FULL FAITH IN NON VIOLENCE
('82', 150, 3, 6, 261692) Q. There are some Congressmen, though their number is very small, who have full faith in non violence and who desire to organize on that basis.
('82', 150, 3, 7, 261836) Should not Congress committees organize such men?
('82', 150, 3, 8, 261886) Or should not Congress committees allow such men to form their corps under the auspices of the Congress?
('82', 150, 4, 9, 261991) A. Congress committees cannot organize sections.
('82', 150, 4, 10, 262040) The Cong ress can have only one policy.
('82', 150, 4, 11, 262080) Today it is pure non violence so far as internal affairs are concerned.
('82', 150, 4, 12, 262152) Therefore I see no reason for separate peace committees.
('82', 150, 4, 13, 262209) Purists, if they are humble and not self opinionated, will act as a leaven in bodies which may contain men and women even of doubtful faith, as there must be in democratic organizations.
('82', 150, 5, 14, 262396) BEWILDERING CONFLICT
('82', 150, 6, 15, 262417) Q. There is a bewildering conflict of opinion among Congress leaders.
('82', 150, 6, 16, 262487) Sardar speaks with one voice, Rajaji with another, Maulana with a third and Jawaharlalji with a fourth—not to speak of the lesser lights.
('82', 150, 6, 17, 262625) Whom is one to follow, who is to be regarded as the sole authority to interpret the Congress policy and resolutions?
('82', 150, 7, 18, 262742) A. Legally and constitutionally the President is the sole authority.
('82', 150, 7, 19, 262811) If there is a conflict of opinion between the majority of the Working Committee and the President, as was once the case in the early stages, the majority view would supersede the President’s.
('82', 150, 7, 20, 263003) But on critical occasions legal opinion is not of much value.
('82', 150, 7, 21, 263065) People have their favourite heroes, and they will follow the heroes even blindly.
('82', 150, 7, 22, 263147) My advice, therefore, is that in the ticklish question of ahimsa each one should be his own authority not on the law but on interpretation.
('82', 150, 7, 23, 263287) If all the four distinguished leaders whom you have mentioned were to sit together, they would probably give the same interpretation, but in the course of their speeches each would put his special emphasis on one aspect or another of the same matter.
('82', 150, 7, 24, 263538) ON THE WAY TO DELHI, March 26, 1942 Harijan, 5 4 1942

('82', 151, 1, 2, 263634) 176. DEPLORABLE
('82', 151, 2, 3, 263650) A student writes from Poona : 1
('82', 151, 3, 4, 263682) I am a student of the Law College in Poona.
('82', 151, 3, 5, 263726) After reading your article “Sacho Yuddhaprayaina” 2 I thought of a total abjuration of sweets.
('82', 151, 3, 6, 263821) And I have vowed not to partake of such rich food so long as the war lasts.
('82', 151, 4, 7, 263897) I am a boarder in the college hostel where, on every Sunday, they serve two or more kinds of sweets.
('82', 151, 4, 8, 263998) These are more wasted than consumed.
('82', 151, 4, 9, 264035) After the feast some students stealthily throw at one another things like pies.
('82', 151, 4, 10, 264115) They are proud of indulging in this kind of fun.
('82', 151, 4, 11, 264164) While on your way to Benares you spoke of students boycotting you.
('82', 151, 4, 12, 264231) Bapu, this is not the whole truth.
('82', 151, 4, 13, 264266) The talk of my being boycotted was only a joke.
('82', 151, 4, 14, 264314) I am experiencing every day the sorrows of being called a great man.
('82', 151, 4, 15, 264383) If there is any joy in it I am yet to experience it.
('82', 151, 4, 16, 264436) I do have sweet memories of the days before I became a Mahatma.
('82', 151, 4, 17, 264500) I can however fill several pages with the unpleasant memories of the days after I became a Mahatma.
('82', 151, 4, 18, 264600) One such experience that I have to undergo every day is that I cannot utter a single word without being reported in the papers.
('82', 151, 4, 19, 264728) It is no doubt painful to have the words reported, although correctly; but one can bear it.
('82', 151, 4, 20, 264820) But it becomes insufferable when all sorts of meanings are attributed to them.
('82', 151, 4, 21, 264899) I am now hardened and don’t care if I am hurt.
('82', 151, 4, 22, 264946) This is only my nature, not that they no more hurt me.
('82', 151, 4, 23, 265001) This talk of my being boycotted is such an instance of twisting words.
('82', 151, 4, 24, 265072) Had they interpreted the boycott as a joke they could have derived a different kind of pleasure and an altogether different meaning from it.
('82', 151, 4, 25, 265213) But let it be.
('82', 151, 4, 26, 265228) How have I wronged the students that they would boycott me?
('82', 151, 4, 27, 265288) There is bound to be ebb as well as flow.
('82', 151, 4, 28, 265330) Indeed, I cannot always say or write sweet things.
('82', 151, 4, 29, 265381) I have to administer bitter rebukes too and then some students are annoyed for a little while.
('82', 151, 4, 30, 265476) But their annoyance is momentary.
('82', 151, 4, 31, 265510) I consider myself a student and hence my contact with students is sure to endure.
('82', 151, 4, 32, 265592) The correspondent deserves to be congratulated on his sacrifice I hope it will be sustained.
('82', 151, 4, 33, 265685) He gives a painful picture of student life.
('82', 151, 4, 34, 265729) In my view, student life should be one of restraint.
('82', 151, 4, 35, 265782) Students should [learn to] enjoy the
('82', 151, 5, 36, 265819) 1 Only extracts from the letter are translated here.
('82', 151, 5, 37, 265872) 2 Vide “Real War Effort”, 19 1 1942.
('82', 152, 0, 1, 265909) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 153
('82', 152, 1, 2, 265952) special pleasure that is to be found in restraint.
('82', 152, 1, 3, 266003) ‘They may have innocent pleasure from wherever they like.’ It is a grave error to delight in tossing about things like food or in filthy jokes or in committing secret acts of sin.
('82', 152, 1, 4, 266183) Many boarding houses have the practice of serving sweets every week.
('82', 152, 1, 5, 266252) If the students and their guardians realized that education in our country is had at the cost of the poor millions, no thoughtful student would live a life of luxury.
('82', 152, 1, 6, 266419) And at this time when there is an ever growing scarcity of all food stuffs, anyone consuming a grain more than necessary should be regarded as more then committing a crime.
('82', 152, 1, 7, 266592) What then need I say about the students?

('82', 155, 1, 2, 270078) 182. INTERVIEW TO EVE CURIE 1
('82', 155, 2, 3, 270108) [Before March 29, 1942] 2
('82', 155, 3, 4, 270134) Miss Curie’s question was direct—on the present situation.
('82', 155, 3, 5, 270193) She admired the
('82', 155, 4, 6, 270209) sincerity with which Sir Stafford Cripps was trying to bring about a settlement, and
('82', 155, 5, 7, 270294) she wanted to know Gandhiji’s reaction to his efforts.
('82', 155, 5, 8, 270349) Sir Stafford is a very good man, but he has entered bad machinery—British Imperialism.
('82', 155, 5, 9, 270436) He hopes to improve that machinery, but in the end it will be the machinery that will get the better of him.
('82', 155, 6, 10, 270545) “Axis Powers’ triumph would bring India to a fate comparable to that inflicted
('82', 155, 7, 11, 270624) on Poland and France.
('82', 155, 7, 12, 270646) That is why the average citizen of conquered countries puts his
('82', 155, 8, 13, 270710) belief and hope in Allied victory,” she said.
('82', 155, 8, 14, 270756) India can win her laurels only through non violence.
('82', 155, 8, 15, 270809) What we have achieved during the last twenty years shows what immense results could be obtained if the principle of non violence was generally practised by our people.
('82', 155, 9, 16, 270977) But Indians will have a tougher time opposing by non violence German and
('82', 155, 10, 17, 271050) Japanese divisions than undermining British rule.
('82', 155, 10, 18, 271100) Quite possible.
('82', 155, 10, 19, 271116) But this is the hour to live up to our faith.
('82', 155, 10, 20, 271162) If the Japanese invaded India, I would not encourage our people to fight with arms.
('82', 155, 10, 21, 271246) Neither would I suffer them to make a pact with aggressors.
('82', 155, 10, 22, 271306) Our struggle will be hard, but it will bring out the best in us.
('82', 155, 11, 23, 271371) So you accept the idea of India refusing to fight or even to be defended by
('82', 155, 12, 24, 271447) others.
('82', 155, 12, 25, 271455) It is physically impossible to transform India suddenly into an armed nation.
('82', 155, 12, 26, 271533) To give our people weapons and to teach them non violence are two different methods of making them strong.
('82', 155, 12, 27, 271640) Both take time.
('82', 155, 12, 28, 271656) I simply believe that my method is surer, more precise, and in the long run more successful.
('82', 155, 12, 29, 271749) In order to beat the Japanese and German armies by force, you must become stronger than they are,
('82', 155, 13, 30, 271847) 1 Reproduced from Mahadev Desai’s report entitled “With Foreign Corresp ondents”.
('82', 155, 13, 31, 271929) Eve Curie represented New York Herald, Tribune and allied news papers in London.
('82', 155, 13, 32, 272010) 2 The interview took place before the Congress Working Committee session began on March 29.
('82', 156, 0, 1, 272102) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 157
('82', 156, 1, 2, 272145) and therefore worse and more ruthless.
('82', 156, 1, 3, 272184) Then what have you won?
('82', 156, 1, 4, 272208) Nothing.
('82', 156, 1, 5, 272217) On the contrary, nations fighting with non violence are unconquerable, for their strength does not depend on the number of rifles and machine guns they possess.
('82', 156, 1, 6, 272378) And when the method is good, there is no need to worry about immediate results.
('82', 156, 1, 7, 272458) Success is bound to come in the end.
('82', 156, 1, 8, 272495) In a non violent struggle there are two alternatives: either the enemy comes to terms with you, then you win without blood; or the enemy annihilates you.
('82', 156, 1, 9, 272649) This last solution is not worse than what a violent war in any case brings about.
('82', 156, 1, 10, 272731) I don’t blame you for wanting to liberate France just as I want to see India free; but it is a sign of too great impatience to think that any country can really be liberated by use of arms.

('82', 156, 2, 12, 272940) 183. CAVEESHAR 1
('82', 156, 3, 13, 272957) Lala Dunichand of Ambala writes : 2
('82', 156, 4, 14, 272993) I have been asked by the dear and near ones of S. Sardul Singh
('82', 156, 5, 15, 273056) Caveeshar, who is being detained without trial, to write this letter to you.
('82', 156, 6, 16, 273133) Since his arrest about a fortnight ago, he is being detained inside the
('82', 156, 7, 17, 273205) Lahore Fort, and he is not being allowed to have any kind of contact with his
('82', 156, 8, 18, 273283) relations and friends.
('82', 156, 8, 19, 273306) I am reliably informed that S. Caveeshar is being
('82', 156, 9, 20, 273356) kept by himself in a cell, and this amounts to solitary confinement.
('82', 156, 9, 21, 273425) He is not
('82', 156, 10, 22, 273435) being allowed even those few facilities such as newspapers, correspondence,
('82', 156, 11, 23, 273511) etc., which other detenus enjoy.
('82', 156, 11, 24, 273544) The fact that he had been suffering from fever
('82', 156, 12, 25, 273591) for a long time at the time of his arrest adds poignancy to his case.
('82', 156, 13, 26, 273661) detenus of similar position such as Babu Sarat Chandra Bose and others are
('82', 156, 14, 27, 273736) being treated properly.

('82', 156, 15, 29, 273868) Therefore, in spite of my having received angry letters, I have observed silence about Sarat Babu’s detention 3 though I have felt keenly about it.
('82', 156, 15, 30, 274016) There was no question of his ill treatment.

('82', 157, 1, 2, 274281) if what Lala Dunichand says is true.

('82', 158, 10, 18, 276158) 187. SCORCHED EARTH 1
('82', 158, 11, 19, 276180) From the well reasoned Press statement of Shri Gaganvihari L. Mehta, President of the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry, I give below the following important extracts 2 :
('82', 158, 12, 20, 276372) It should be pointed out that economic relationships are so close,
('82', 158, 13, 21, 276439) complex and delicate that it would be impossible to demolish important
('82', 158, 14, 22, 276510) industries or plants without grave repercussions on the economic fabric and
('82', 158, 15, 23, 276586) life of the country.
('82', 158, 15, 24, 276607) For example, if industrial plants like those of jute, cotton
('82', 158, 16, 25, 276668) or sugar are destroyed, they will take years to be rebuilt even after the war and,
('82', 158, 17, 26, 276751) meanwhile, not merely the owners of the factories but also the cultivators of
('82', 158, 18, 27, 276829) these commodities, the industrial workers as well as those engaged in
('82', 158, 19, 28, 276899) ancillary and subsidiary industries, trades and occupations would all suffer.
('82', 158, 20, 29, 276977) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('82', 158, 20, 30, 277008) 2 From which only an excerpt is reproduced here
('82', 159, 0, 1, 277056) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 160
('82', 159, 1, 2, 277098) Such demolition of industries built up after years of struggle at large expense
('82', 159, 2, 3, 277178) and often against heavy odds will cause economic dislocation and
('82', 159, 3, 4, 277243) disorganization altogether disproportionate to any benefits secured as a
('82', 159, 4, 5, 277316) measure of war.
('82', 159, 4, 6, 277332) Scorched earth policy is a self defeating measure.
('82', 159, 4, 7, 277383) 1 Time will show how true this remark is.

('82', 163, 4, 7, 280953) 197. TALK WITH AN AUSTRALIAN JOURNALIST 1
('82', 163, 5, 8, 280995) [Before April 3, 1942] 2
('82', 163, 6, 9, 281020) What I cannot understand is man hating brother man and thirsting for his blood.
('82', 163, 6, 10, 281100) I can see no justification for the war that is going on and fast enveloping the earth.
('82', 163, 6, 11, 281187) It is based on hate and vengeance and will leave a crop of hate and vengeance behind.
('82', 163, 6, 12, 281273) The waste of human life and material that might be useful otherwise for the world is appalling and sickening.
('82', 163, 6, 13, 281383) Why should your country and mine have to be involved in this war?
('82', 163, 6, 14, 281449) You are a fine resourceful people.
('82', 163, 6, 15, 281484) Rather than that you should build up your country and make it useful to the rest of the world.
('82', 163, 6, 16, 281579) Why should you be asked to sacrifice your manhood?
('82', 163, 6, 17, 281630) And what is more painful is that it is all to no purpose.
('82', 163, 6, 18, 281688) I do not know why all this fighting is going on, for whose benefit, with what great end in view.
('82', 163, 7, 19, 281785) JOURNALIST: I doubt if anyone knows.
('82', 163, 8, 20, 281822) GANDHIJI: There is this thing.
('82', 163, 8, 21, 281853) Perhaps God wills peace to come as a lesson of this carnage.
('82', 163, 9, 22, 281914) J. Could you possibly say something about what is going on at present.
('82', 163, 10, 23, 281985) G. For that, you must go to the men in office.
('82', 163, 10, 24, 282032) I can say nothing.
('82', 163, 11, 25, 282051) J. But, Sir, you are with them.
('82', 163, 12, 26, 282083) G. And, yet, it will surprise you when I tell you that those things do not interest me.
('82', 163, 12, 27, 282171) I relinquished my membership of the Congress
('82', 163, 13, 28, 282216) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Two Australian Visitors”.
('82', 163, 13, 29, 282276) The source does not mention the name of the journalist, who was a war correspondent.
('82', 163, 13, 30, 282361) Gandhiji talked to him while out on a stroll.
('82', 163, 13, 31, 282407) 2 Mahadev Desai has referred to the visit of this journalist in an article “How to Be Worthy of Our Heritage”, dated April 3 and published in Harijan, 12 4 1942 .
('82', 164, 0, 1, 282570) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 165
('82', 164, 1, 2, 282613) eight years ago.
('82', 164, 1, 3, 282630) 1 I go to the Congress, attend meetings of the Working Committee, even advise in a detached way when my advice is sought.
('82', 164, 1, 4, 282752) You will be surprised to hear that I have never listened to a radio, nor have I ever been to a cinema.
('82', 164, 2, 5, 282855) J. Do you think these things are bad?
('82', 164, 3, 6, 282893) G. I will not say so.
('82', 164, 3, 7, 282915) I may say that cinema films are often bad.
('82', 164, 3, 8, 282958) About the radio I do not know.
('82', 164, 3, 9, 282989) I can certainly say this that I do not care to have news from all quarters of the globe within the space of half an hour.
('82', 164, 3, 10, 283111) It leaves one little time to think.
('82', 164, 3, 11, 283147) And why must one have news from all quarters of the globe every half an hour or so?
('82', 164, 3, 12, 283231) I should be content to react to my nearest surroundings and happenings therein.
('82', 164, 4, 13, 283311) J. But the youth whispered some question about the Working Committee.
('82', 164, 5, 14, 283381) G. I do not mind telling you that there are differences between me and the Working Committee.
('82', 164, 5, 15, 283475) The whole nation is not with me on the non violence question.
('82', 164, 5, 16, 283537) If the nation as a whole was absolutely peaceful, I am sure we should not be in the war, I am sure we should not have this foreign domination here.
('82', 164, 5, 17, 283685) The alien rulers should not be dictating to us.
('82', 164, 5, 18, 283733) We should have people here from foreign lands on terms of friendship, and we should gladly make use of their talents at our will.
('82', 164, 5, 19, 283863) But I am not worrying over the nation not being with me.
('82', 164, 5, 20, 283920) When I have failed to convert my nearest associates, the members of the Working Committee, I have no business to be impa tient with my people.
('82', 164, 5, 21, 284063) It must be my fault.
('82', 164, 5, 22, 284084) It means that there is not sufficient non violence in me to enable me to carry everyone with me.
('82', 164, 5, 23, 284181) But my faith in non violence is undimmed and unshaken.
('82', 164, 5, 24, 284236) In fact it is growing every day.
('82', 164, 6, 25, 284269) Harijan, 3 5 1942
('82', 164, 7, 26, 284287) 1Vide “Statement to the Press”, 17 9 1934, 15 10 1934, “Speech at Subjects Committee Meeting”, A.I.C.C.”, 23 10 1934 and 26 10 1934.
('82', 165, 0, 1, 284420) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 165, 1, 2, 284462) 198. INTERVIEW TO BERTRAM STEVENS 1
('82', 165, 2, 3, 284498) DELHI, [On or before April 4, 1942] 2
('82', 165, 3, 4, 284536) BERTRAM STEVENS: I have heard a lot about you from Mr. Birla.
('82', 165, 3, 5, 284598) You have been
('82', 165, 4, 6, 284612) to England, to Europe, and you stayed long in South Africa.
('82', 165, 4, 7, 284672) But you have never been
('82', 165, 5, 8, 284696) to Australia.
('82', 165, 6, 9, 284710) GANDHIJI: No, thanks to you.
('82', 165, 7, 10, 284739) B. S. You have made a very good reply, Mr. Gandhi.
('82', 165, 8, 11, 284790) G. Haven’t I?
('82', 165, 8, 12, 284804) You have vast living spaces, you can absorb millions and millions of human beings.
('82', 165, 8, 13, 284887) But I know what you are doing.
('82', 165, 8, 14, 284918) I have followed the history of your country for over 35 years.
('82', 165, 8, 15, 284981) White Australia is your policy, and as a result you are without the wonderful accession of strength that would have been yours if you had followed a policy of brothering all.
('82', 165, 9, 16, 285156) B. S. I agree.
('82', 165, 9, 17, 285171) But our country is only 150 years old.
('82', 165, 9, 18, 285210) Prejudices die hard, but
('82', 165, 10, 19, 285235) they are dying.
('82', 165, 10, 20, 285251) G. You might very well have absorbed our people.
('82', 165, 10, 21, 285300) Wherever they have gone they have been able to show that they are business like, able, and quite competent to take care of themselves.
('82', 165, 10, 22, 285435) Your country with its infinite resources would have been a different country with these Indian settlers.
('82', 165, 11, 23, 285540) B. S. Yes, Australia is half as big again as India.
('82', 165, 11, 24, 285592) But it is not quite so fertile as India.
('82', 165, 11, 25, 285633) But I agree with what you say.
('82', 165, 11, 26, 285664) There is nothing like developing vital contacts between the peoples of different countries.
('82', 165, 11, 27, 285756) During my sojourn in India I have met many people.
('82', 165, 11, 28, 285807) I have found them quite capable and industrious, and the more our business people could know and come together with your business people the better for both Australia and India.
('82', 165, 11, 29, 285985) And, Sir, we must not forget that the old world is already passing, old ideas are fast changing, and we are getting ready for the coming of a new world.
('82', 165, 11, 30, 286138) G. I am sure.
('82', 165, 12, 31, 286152) Harijan, 3 5 1942
('82', 165, 13, 32, 286170) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Two Australian Visitors”.
('82', 165, 13, 33, 286230) Bertram Stevens was a member of the Eastern Group Conference and sometime Prime Minister of the Province of New South Wales in Australia.
('82', 165, 13, 34, 286368) 2 Gandhiji left Delhi on April 4.
('82', 166, 0, 1, 286402) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 167
('82', 166, 1, 2, 286445) 199. NON VIOLENT RESISTANCE
('82', 166, 2, 3, 286473) Japan is knocking at our gates.
('82', 166, 2, 4, 286505) What are we to do in a non violent way?
('82', 166, 2, 5, 286545) If we were a free country, things could be done non violently to prevent the Japanese from entering the country.
('82', 166, 2, 6, 286658) As it is, non violent resistance could commence the moment they effected a landing.
('82', 166, 2, 7, 286742) Thus non violent resisters would refuse them any help, even water.
('82', 166, 2, 8, 286809) For it is no part of their duty to help anyone to steal their country.
('82', 166, 2, 9, 286880) But if a Japanese had missed his way and was dying of thirst and sought help as a human being, a non violent resister, who may not regard anyone as his enemy, would give water to the thirsty one.
('82', 166, 2, 10, 287076) Suppose the Japanese compel resisters to give them water, the resisters must die in the act of resistance.
('82', 166, 2, 11, 287183) It is conceivable that they will exterminate all resisters.
('82', 166, 2, 12, 287243) The underlying belief in such non violent resistance is that the aggressor will, in time, be mentally and even physically tired of killing non violent resisters.
('82', 166, 2, 13, 287405) He will begin to search what this new (for him) force is which refuses co operation without seeking to hurt, and will probably desist from further slaughter.
('82', 166, 2, 14, 287563) But the resisters may find that the Japanese are utterly heartless and that they do not care how many they kill.
('82', 166, 2, 15, 287676) The non violent resisters will have won the day in as much as they will have preferred extermination to submission.
('82', 166, 3, 16, 287792) But things will not happen quite so simply as I have put them.
('82', 166, 3, 17, 287855) There are at least four parties in the country.
('82', 166, 3, 18, 287903) First the British and the army they have brought into being.
('82', 166, 3, 19, 287964) The Japanese declare that they have no designs upon India.
('82', 166, 3, 20, 288023) Their quarrel is only with the British.
('82', 166, 3, 21, 288063) In this they are assisted by some Indians who are in Japan.
('82', 166, 3, 22, 288123) It is difficult to guess how many, but there must be a fairly large number who believe in the declaration of the Japanese and think that they will deliver the country from the British yoke and retire.
('82', 166, 3, 23, 288324) Even if the worst happens, their fatigue of the British yoke is so great that they would even welcome the Japanese yoke for a change.
('82', 166, 3, 24, 288458) This is the second party.
('82', 166, 3, 25, 288484) The third are the neutrals, who though not non violent will help neither the British nor the Japanese.
('82', 166, 3, 26, 288587) The fourth and last are non violent resisters.
('82', 166, 3, 27, 288634) If they are only a few, their resistance will be ineffective except as an example for the future.
('82', 166, 3, 28, 288732) Such resisters will calmly die wherever they are but will
('82', 167, 0, 1, 288790) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 167, 1, 2, 288832) not bend the knee before the aggressor.
('82', 167, 1, 3, 288872) They will not be deceived by promises.
('82', 167, 1, 4, 288911) They do not seek deliverance from the British yoke through the help of a third party.
('82', 167, 1, 5, 288997) They believe implicitly in their own way of fighting and no other.
('82', 167, 1, 6, 289064) Their fight is on behalf of the dumb millions who do not perhaps know that there is such a thing as deliverance.
('82', 167, 1, 7, 289177) They have neither hatred for the British nor love for the Japanese.
('82', 167, 1, 8, 289245) They wish well to both as to all others.
('82', 167, 1, 9, 289286) They would like both to do what is right.
('82', 167, 1, 10, 289328) They believe that non violence alone will lead men to do right under all circumstances.
('82', 167, 1, 11, 289416) Therefore, if for want of enough companions non violent resisters cannot reach the goal, they will not give up their way but pursue it to death.
('82', 167, 1, 12, 289561) The task before the votaries of non violence is very difficult.
('82', 167, 1, 13, 289625) But no difficulty can baffle men who have faith in their mission.
('82', 167, 1, 14, 289691) This is going to be a long drawn out agony.
('82', 167, 1, 15, 289735) Let non violent resisters not make impossible attempts.
('82', 167, 1, 16, 289791) Their powers are limited.
('82', 167, 1, 17, 289817) A resister in Kerala is not physically responsible for the defence of Assam which is just now in imminent danger.
('82', 167, 1, 18, 289931) If Assam is non violently inclined, it is well able to take care of itself.
('82', 167, 1, 19, 290007) If it is not, no party of non violent resisters from Kerala can help it or any other province.
('82', 167, 1, 20, 290102) Kerala can help Assam, etc., by demonstrating its non violence in Kerala itself.
('82', 167, 1, 21, 290183) The Japanese army, if it gets a foothold in India, will not stop at Assam.
('82', 167, 1, 22, 290258) In order to defeat the British, it has to overrun the whole country.
('82', 167, 1, 23, 290327) The British will fight every inch of the ground.
('82', 167, 1, 24, 290376) Loss of India will probably be admission of complete defeat for them.
('82', 167, 1, 25, 290446) But whether it is so or not, it is quite clear that Japan will not rest till India is wholly in her hands.
('82', 167, 1, 26, 290553) Hence non violent resisters must remain at their posts wherever they are.
('82', 167, 1, 27, 290627) One thing has to be made clear.
('82', 167, 1, 28, 290659) Where the British army is actually engaging the ‘enemy’, it would be perhaps improper for direct resistance to function.
('82', 167, 1, 29, 290780) It will not be non violent resistance when it is mixed with, or allies itself to, violence.
('82', 167, 1, 30, 290872) Let me therefore reiterate what I have said so often.
('82', 167, 1, 31, 290926) The best preparation for, and even the expression of, non violence lies in the determined pursuit of the constructive programme.
('82', 167, 1, 32, 291055) Anyone who believes that without the backing of the constructive programme he will show non violent strength when the testing time comes will fail
('82', 168, 0, 1, 291202) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 169
('82', 168, 1, 2, 291245) miserably.
('82', 168, 1, 3, 291256) It will be, like the attempt of a starving unarmed man to match his physical strength against a fully fed and panoplied soldier, foredoomed to failure.
('82', 168, 1, 4, 291408) He who has no belief in the constructive programme has, in my opinion, no concrete feeling for the starved millions.
('82', 168, 1, 5, 291525) He who is devoid of that feeling cannot fight non violently.
('82', 168, 1, 6, 291586) In actual practice the expansion of my non violence has kept exact pace with that of my identification with starved humanity.
('82', 168, 1, 7, 291712) I am still far from the non violence of my conception, for am I not still far away from the identification of my conception with dumb humanity?

('82', 169, 5, 7, 293621) POLICY OF NON VIOLENCE 1
('82', 169, 6, 8, 293646) More than a month ago Dr. Katju sent to Shri Kishorelal Mashruwala what may be called a short thesis on non violence.
('82', 169, 6, 9, 293764) The latter was to decide what to make of it and, if he liked, show it to me.
('82', 169, 6, 10, 293841) Shri Mashruwala gave it to me some time ago.
('82', 169, 6, 11, 293886) But I could get time to read it only during the journey.
('82', 169, 6, 12, 293943) I read it carefully.
('82', 169, 6, 13, 293964) It was too long for publication in Harijan; and yet I felt that it should be placed before the readers of Harijan in some form.
('82', 169, 6, 14, 294092) The following is the result.
('82', 169, 6, 15, 294121) I have spent considerable time in reducing the original without leaving out the essential argument.
('82', 169, 6, 16, 294221) I wholly agree with Dr. Katju that non violence cannot make further headway without the Congress making it a creed.
('82', 169, 6, 17, 294337) He suggests that there should be a plan to show how it can be worked under given circumstances.
('82', 169, 6, 18, 294433) He suggested a book or a series for the guidance of the votaries.
('82', 169, 6, 19, 294499) Much literature has sprung up on the subject.
('82', 169, 6, 20, 294545) Richard Gregg has spent years of labour in research.
('82', 169, 6, 21, 294598) He has written text books for the guidance of the votaries of the West.
('82', 169, 6, 22, 294670) His books are very readable.
('82', 169, 6, 23, 294699) Let Dr. Katju set apart time for producing a book which would be a guide for us in India at this critical hour.

('82', 173, 9, 16, 299818) 208. QUESTION BOX
('82', 173, 10, 17, 299836) EXPEDIENCE
('82', 173, 11, 18, 299847) Q. Several years ago I once had the temerity to ask whether the fact that you
('82', 173, 12, 19, 299925) had allowed non violence to come into the Congress as an expedient rather than as a
('82', 173, 13, 20, 300009) creed would not be conducive to its breakdown at the critical time: You said you did
('82', 173, 14, 21, 300094) not think so.
('82', 173, 14, 22, 300108) But do you still feel the same?
('82', 173, 14, 23, 300140) Would you not today have had an
('82', 173, 15, 24, 300172) organized band of believers in non violence whom you could have sent in groups all
('82', 173, 16, 25, 300255) over the country?
('82', 173, 16, 26, 300273) It almost seems as if we had lost time and are found unprepared, as it
('82', 173, 17, 27, 300344) were, to shoulder responsibility?
('82', 173, 18, 28, 300378) A. Yes, I adhere to my opinion that I did well to present to the Congress non violence as an expedient.
('82', 173, 18, 29, 300482) I could not have done otherwise if I was to introduce it into politics.
('82', 173, 18, 30, 300554) In South Africa too I introduced it as an expedient.
('82', 173, 18, 31, 300607) It was successful there because resisters were a small number in a compact area and therefore easily controlled.
('82', 173, 18, 32, 300720) Here we had numberless persons scattered over a huge
('82', 174, 0, 1, 300773) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 175
('82', 174, 1, 2, 300816) country.
('82', 174, 1, 3, 300825) The result was that they could not be easily controlled or trained.
('82', 174, 1, 4, 300893) And yet it is a marvel the way they have responded.
('82', 174, 1, 5, 300945) They might have responded much better and shown far better results.
('82', 174, 1, 6, 301013) But I have no sense of disappointment in me over the results obtained.
('82', 174, 1, 7, 301084) If I had started with men who accepted non violence as a creed, I might have ended with myself.
('82', 174, 1, 8, 301180) Imperfect as I am, I started with imperfect men and women and sailed on an uncharted ocean.
('82', 174, 1, 9, 301272) Thank God that, though the boat has not reached its haven, it has proved fairly storm proof.
('82', 174, 2, 10, 301365) THE ROMAN SCRIPT
('82', 174, 3, 11, 301382) Q. You are prejudiced against the Roman script because you are prejudiced against the English.
('82', 174, 3, 12, 301477) Otherwise you would unhesitatingly advocate it in the place of Devanagari and Persian.
('82', 174, 3, 13, 301564) A. You are wrong.
('82', 174, 3, 14, 301582) I am prejudiced against neither.
('82', 174, 3, 15, 301615) But I am against anything or anybody usurping a place not belonging to it or him.
('82', 174, 3, 16, 301697) The Roman script has come to stay in India.
('82', 174, 3, 17, 301741) But it cannot take the place of the Indian scripts.
('82', 174, 3, 18, 301793) If I had my way, there would be only the Devanagari script, for all the provincial languages, and Devanagari and Persian for the all lndia speech.
('82', 174, 3, 19, 301940) The Arabic script, from which the Persian is derived, is a necessity for Muslims as Sanskrit is for Hindus.
('82', 174, 3, 20, 302048) Roman has been suggested as a compromise and not for its merits.
('82', 174, 3, 21, 302113) It has none except that it is almost universal in the West.
('82', 174, 3, 22, 302173) But it must not displace either Devanagari, which is the parent of most provincial languages and is the most perfect of all the known scripts, or Persian, because it is written by millions of Hindus and Muslims in the North.
('82', 174, 3, 23, 302398) So far as the scripts are keeping them apart, Hindus and Muslims will not come together by adopting a neutral and imperfect script.
('82', 174, 3, 24, 302530) But they will, if both take the trouble, for the love of one another, to learn both scripts.
('82', 174, 3, 25, 302623) The Roman script has its own great and unique place.
('82', 174, 3, 26, 302676) It need not aspire after greater.

('82', 175, 0, 1, 302753) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 175, 1, 2, 302795) 209. SCORCHED EARTH
('82', 175, 2, 3, 302815) Thus writes a correspondent on my article “Scorched Earth’’ 1
('82', 175, 3, 4, 302877) in Harijan.
('82', 175, 4, 5, 302889) In your article headed ‘Scorched Earth’ appearing in Harijan of the 22nd
('82', 175, 5, 6, 302962) March you say as follows:
('82', 175, 6, 7, 302988) “As a war resister my answer can only be one.
('82', 175, 6, 8, 303034) I see neither bravery nor
('82', 175, 7, 9, 303060) sacrifice in destroying life or property for offence or defence.
('82', 175, 7, 10, 303125) I would far rather
('82', 175, 8, 11, 303144) leave, if I must, my crops and homestead for the enemy to use than destroy
('82', 175, 9, 12, 303219) them for the sake of preventing their use by him.
('82', 175, 9, 13, 303269) There is reason, sacrifice and
('82', 175, 10, 14, 303300) even bravery in so leaving my homestead and crops, if I do so not out of fear
('82', 175, 11, 15, 303378) but because I refuse to regard anyone as my enemy—that is, out of a
('82', 175, 12, 16, 303446) humanitarian motive.”
('82', 175, 13, 17, 303468) Firstly, although I do not approve of the violence which characterized
('82', 175, 14, 18, 303539) Russia’s resistance, 1 am of the view that there is great bravery and sacrifice in
('82', 175, 15, 19, 303622) the scorched earth policy which they are adopting to resist the invader.
('82', 175, 16, 20, 303695) cannot, therefore, understand your saying that there is neither bravery nor
('82', 175, 17, 21, 303771) sacrifice in destroying property for defence.
('82', 175, 17, 22, 303817) Secondly, although you ask
('82', 175, 18, 23, 303844) people to resist the invader, you would prefer them to leave their crops and
('82', 175, 19, 24, 303921) homestead for the invader to use, not out of fear but out of a humanitarian
('82', 175, 20, 25, 303997) motive.
('82', 175, 20, 26, 304005) I cannot understand how this can be reconciled with your teaching of
('82', 175, 21, 27, 304074) resistance to evil.
('82', 175, 21, 28, 304094) I think that non violent resistance to the invader demands it
('82', 175, 22, 29, 304156) of me that I should prevent anything which will be of use to him, such as crops
('82', 175, 23, 30, 304236) or homestead, etc., from falling into his hands even if this means sacrificing
('82', 175, 24, 31, 304315) my life.
('82', 175, 24, 32, 304324) May I request you to clarify this subject because it is of vital
('82', 175, 25, 33, 304389) importance that people should know how they should offer non violent
('82', 175, 26, 34, 304458) resistance to the invader?
('82', 175, 26, 35, 304485) Surely the meaning is plain.
('82', 175, 26, 36, 304514) There is no bravery in my poisoning my well or filling it in so that my brother who is at war with me may not use the water.
('82', 175, 26, 37, 304639) Let us assume that I am fighting him in the orthodox manner.
('82', 175, 26, 38, 304700) Nor is there sacrifice in it, for it does not purify me, and sacrifice, as its root meaning implies, presupposes purity.
('82', 175, 26, 39, 304821) Such destruction may be likened to cutting one’s nose to spite one’s face.
('82', 175, 26, 40, 304896) Warriors of old had wholesome laws of war.
('82', 175, 26, 41, 304939) Among the
('82', 175, 27, 42, 304949) 1 Vide “Scorched Earth”, 16 3 1942.
('82', 176, 0, 1, 304985) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 177
('82', 176, 1, 2, 305028) excluded things were poisoning wells and destroying food crops.
('82', 176, 1, 3, 305092) But I do claim that there are bravery and sacrifice in my leaving my wells, crops and homestead intact, bravery in that I deliberately run the risk of the enemy feeding himself at my expense and pursuing me, and sacrifice in that the sentiment of leaving something for the enemy purifies and ennobles me.
('82', 176, 1, 4, 305397) My questioner has missed the conditional expression “if I must”.
('82', 176, 1, 5, 305462) I have imagined a state of things in which I am not prepared just now to die and therefore I want to retreat in an orderly manner in the hope of resisting under other and better auspices.
('82', 176, 1, 6, 305650) The thing to consider here is not resistance but non destruction of food crops and the like.
('82', 176, 1, 7, 305743) Resistance, violent or non violent, has to be well thought out.
('82', 176, 1, 8, 305807) Thoughtless resistance will be regarded as bravado in military parlance, and violence or folly in the language of non violence.
('82', 176, 1, 9, 305935) Retreat itself is often a plan of resistance and may be a precursor of great bravery and sacrifice.
('82', 176, 1, 10, 306035) Every retreat is not cowardice which implies fear to die.
('82', 176, 1, 11, 306093) Of course a brave man would more often die in violently or non violently resisting the aggressor in the latter’s attempt to oust him from his property, but he will be no less brave if wisdom dictates present retreat.
('82', 176, 2, 12, 306310) SEVAGRAM, April 7, 1942 Harijan, 12 4 1942

('82', 184, 4, 7, 314541) 226. NOTES
('82', 184, 5, 8, 314552) LINGUISTIC BASIS
('82', 184, 6, 9, 314569) My reply 1 to .the Maharajkumar of Vizianagram on the Andhra Province has brought me lengthy correspondence about Hindi and Marathi speaking provinces.
('82', 184, 6, 10, 314721) The argument is that all Hindi speaking areas should be regarded as one province, as also should Marathi speaking areas.
('82', 184, 6, 11, 314842) So far as I am concerned I am quite in sympathy with the suggestion.
('82', 184, 6, 12, 314911) I believe that the linguistic basis is the correct basis for demarcating provinces.
('82', 184, 6, 13, 314995) I should not mind two provinces speaking the same language, if they are not contiguous.
('82', 184, 6, 14, 315083) If Kerala and Kashmir were speaking the same language, I would treat them as two distinct provinces.
('82', 184, 6, 15, 315184) The writers suggest, however, that I should lead the agitation for the redistribution, or in this case amalgamation, of the Marathi speaking and Hindi speaking areas.
('82', 184, 6, 16, 315351) This is an impracticable proposition.
('82', 184, 6, 17, 315389) The demand for amalga mation has to be made by Congressmen living in the respective areas.
('82', 184, 6, 18, 315480) If it is unanimous, the Congress cannot resist it.
('82', 184, 6, 19, 315531) The thing is entirely in their own hands.
('82', 184, 6, 20, 315573) Let my correspondents and others not mix up the Andhra agitation with their proposals.
('82', 184, 6, 21, 315660) Andhra is already a separate province for the Congress.
('82', 184, 6, 22, 315716) But, whilst the Congress ministry was in office, the Andhras agitated for legal recognition.
('82', 184, 6, 23, 315809) My correspondents ask for Congress recognition of their proposals.
('82', 184, 6, 24, 315876) Whilst on merits I endorse the proposal, I would discountenance any such agitation and diversion from the main then before the country—the duty of every Indian in face of the impending invasion of India by Japan.
('82', 184, 7, 25, 316089) 1 Vide “The Andhras”, 20 3 1942.
('82', 185, 0, 1, 316122) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 185, 1, 2, 316164) Redistribution of provinces, etc., important matters though they are in themselves, pale in insignificance before the question which overshadows every other.
('82', 185, 1, 3, 316322) Those things may easily await the termi nation of the war.
('82', 185, 1, 4, 316381) We hope to see a new vision and a new order at the end of the present catastrophe.
('82', 185, 2, 5, 316464) HISSAR FAMINE AND SPINNING
('82', 185, 3, 6, 316491) Dr. Gopichand has been discussing with me famine in Hissar.
('82', 185, 3, 7, 316551) It seems to have become almost chronic.
('82', 185, 3, 8, 316591) The A.I.S.A. has been working for many years in that district and giving relief to the poor people through spinning.
('82', 185, 3, 9, 316708) Dr. Gopichand thinks that, if more capital can be made available, much aid can be given.
('82', 185, 3, 10, 316797) It is perhaps not possible to make a successful appeal outside Hissar.
('82', 185, 3, 11, 316868) There is so much distress everywhere, and with the terrible spectre of war much more is to be expected.
('82', 185, 3, 12, 316972) Therefore everywhere local charity has to be depended upon.
('82', 185, 3, 13, 317032) As often happens even in poor areas there are to be found monied men.
('82', 185, 3, 14, 317102) Bhiwani is a big trade centre in Hissar, and it has several monied men.
('82', 185, 3, 15, 317174) Let me hope that they and those others in Hissar who can will come to the rescue and do what they can for the much needed relief.
('82', 185, 4, 16, 317304) SEVAGRAM, April 12, 1942 Harijhan, 19 4 1942

('82', 187, 6, 8, 318740) 230. UNITY IS VITAL IN INDIA 1
('82', 187, 7, 9, 318771) [After April 12, 1942] 2
('82', 187, 8, 10, 318796) The proposals that Sir Stafford Cripps advanced for settling the Political deadlock in India contemplated splitting the country into three parts, each part to have a different system of government.
('82', 187, 8, 11, 318994) 3 These proposals, it would seem, would be to the liking of many of India’s Muslim leaders, since they have for long advocated dividing the country between Hindus and Muslims.
('82', 187, 8, 12, 319170) Yet Sir Stafford’s plan differed in many respects from the Muslim League’s plan, and so it received no more enthusiastic a reception from them than it received from the Indian National Congress.
('82', 187, 8, 13, 319365) 4 The Muslim League represents Muslims; the Indian National Congress purports to represent Hindus and Muslims alike.
('82', 187, 8, 14, 319482) Can the Congress claim be supported?
('82', 187, 8, 15, 319519) It can.
('82', 187, 8, 16, 319527) From its beginning it has been national, representing all beliefs, not one alone.
('82', 187, 8, 17, 319609) Its originator was an Englishman, strange though that may seem
('82', 187, 9, 18, 319672) 1 The article had originally been published in the November 1942 issue of Picture World, an American magazine.
('82', 187, 9, 19, 319783) 2 This was obviously written after Sir Stafford Cripps left India on April 12, 1942 3 Sir Stafford Cripps arrived in Delhi on March 22, 1942 for resolving he ‘Indian deadlock’.
('82', 187, 9, 20, 319960) For his proposals, vide Appendix “British War Cabinet’s Proposals”, before 27 3 1942. 4 Both the Indian National Congress and the Muslim League rejected the Cripps formula; the Congress because it did not concede independence immediately, left the control of defence of India with the British Government and indirectly envisaged partition of India by giving rights to the provinces to secede if they wished.
('82', 187, 9, 21, 320368) The Muslim League opposed it because the fundamental proposals were not open to any modifications.
('82', 188, 0, 1, 320467) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 189
('82', 188, 1, 2, 320510) to some.
('82', 188, 1, 3, 320519) It has always had one or two Muslim secretaries.
('82', 188, 1, 4, 320568) It has had Muslim, English, Christian and Parsi Presidents.
('82', 188, 1, 5, 320628) Through its whole history, now running into the second half of a century, the Congress has ever striven to represent the whole of India, in a manner no other organization has done.
('82', 188, 1, 6, 320809) Every victory scored by the Congress has benefited all communities, Muslims and Hindus alike.
('82', 188, 2, 7, 320903) I believe that the Congress embodies the hopes and aspirations of all India.
('82', 188, 2, 8, 320980) Its traditions unfit it to represent Hindus as against Muslims or vice versa.
('82', 188, 2, 9, 321058) It is fit only to represent the common interest of all sons of Hindustan.
('82', 188, 2, 10, 321132) Yet, differences between Hindus and Muslims remain, and it is said that Hinduism and Islam represent two antagonistic cultures and doctrines that cannot live peacefully together, and that therefore they must be separated into two different nations.
('82', 188, 3, 11, 321381) I myself could never subscribe to the partitioning of the country.
('82', 188, 3, 12, 321448) I would fight it with every means at my disposal and yet I must declare that national independence is an impossibility until Indians have solved this communal problem.
('82', 188, 3, 13, 321616) There are two ways of solving it.
('82', 188, 3, 14, 321650) One is the way of non violence, the other the way of violence.
('82', 188, 3, 15, 321713) Unfortunately, at the present moment, those Hindus who do not know the use of violence, of deadly weapons, would fain learn the trick, so as to be able to match what they describe as Muslim violence.
('82', 188, 3, 16, 321913) If peace is ever to come in that manner, through both parties being equally matched in violent weapons, I know that it will not come in my lifetime, and if it came, I should not care to be a witness of it.
('82', 188, 3, 17, 322119) For it will be an armed peace, to be broken at any moment.
('82', 188, 3, 18, 322178) Whether those who believe in the two nation theory can live as friends with those who believe in one nation, I do not know.
('82', 188, 3, 19, 322302) If the vast majority of Muslims regard themselves as a separate nation having nothing in common with the Hindus and others, no power on earth can compel them to think otherwise.
('82', 188, 3, 20, 322480) If they want partition of India on that basis, they must have partition, unless the Hindus want to fight against such a division.
('82', 188, 3, 21, 322610) So far as I can see, preparation for such a fight is going on now on behalf of both parties.
('82', 188, 4, 22, 322703) I dread to see it.
('82', 188, 4, 23, 322722) That way lies national suicide.
('82', 188, 4, 24, 322754) One party or the other will call in outside help.
('82', 188, 4, 25, 322804) In that case, good bye to independence.
('82', 189, 0, 1, 322844) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 189, 1, 2, 322886) The only true and just way is the way of unity and non violence of regarding one another not as members of hostile cultures but as sons of the same great motherland.
('82', 189, 1, 3, 323052) Hindus and Muslims have worked and do work together in peace; they lived together in peace in the past; they can live together in peace in the future.
('82', 189, 1, 4, 323203) Our task is to assure each son of the motherland that whatever his beliefs, his rights and religious and cultural interests will be protected by the laws of the land, formulated by a national assembly democratically elected.
('82', 189, 2, 5, 323428) Now, with the aggressor at the gates, more than ever unity is vital in India.
('82', 189, 2, 6, 323506) I desire above all things to see a joint struggle against him and to achieve independence.
('82', 189, 2, 7, 323597) In the very process of doing this, it is highly likely that we shall have forgotten our quarrels in the same common goal.
('82', 189, 2, 8, 323719) But if we find that we have not forgotten them, then will be the time to quarrel among ourselves, if quarrel we must.
('82', 189, 2, 9, 323837) Not now.
('82', 189, 2, 10, 323846) Now India herself stands in the balance.
('82', 189, 3, 11, 323887) The Bombay Chronicle, 25 4 1942

('82', 189, 6, 24, 324691) But his instinct and heart were always with the reformer, and he expressed his

('82', 191, 1, 2, 327079) 232. QUESTION BOX
('82', 191, 2, 3, 327097) WHY NOT IN UNIVERSITIES?
('82', 191, 3, 4, 327122) Q. You have expressed yourself against communalism in cricket.
('82', 191, 3, 5, 327185) Are not communal universities also to be deplored?
('82', 191, 3, 6, 327236) In colleges and hostels that are open to all, deep friendships spring up and religious tolerance becomes a natural thing, Would not well endowed chairs in common centres of learning serve the purpose of advancing different cultures?
('82', 191, 4, 7, 327469) A. You are right.
('82', 191, 4, 8, 327487) If we can do without communal institutions, it would be good.
('82', 191, 4, 9, 327549) But I am unable to say that there should be no Muslim or Hindu Universities as I am able to say positively that there should be no communal cricket.
('82', 191, 4, 10, 327698) The communal universities, if their origin is not tainted, may conceivably serve a national purpose.
('82', 191, 4, 11, 327799) Thus the Hindu University and the Muslim University may, as they ought to, be seats of communal concord.
('82', 191, 4, 12, 327904) But communal sports seem to be a contradiction in terms.
('82', 191, 4, 13, 327961) I wholly agree with you that there should be, as there are, non communal colleges and hostels.
('82', 191, 4, 14, 328056) Unfortunately the virus has entered even these.
('82', 191, 4, 15, 328104) Let us hope that it is a passing phase.
('82', 191, 5, 16, 328144) WHEN LEADERS DIFFER
('82', 191, 6, 17, 328164) Q. You say people in the cities should evacuate under certain circumstances.
('82', 191, 7, 18, 328241) Panditji and Rajaji say they should not on any account.
('82', 191, 7, 19, 328297) What are we to do?
('82', 191, 8, 20, 328316) A. I appreciate your difficulty.
('82', 191, 8, 21, 328349) I can only advise you to use your judgment and choose that advice which appeals to your reason.
('82', 191, 8, 22, 328445) We are living in hard times such as we have never experienced before.
('82', 191, 8, 23, 328515) I am quite sure of my ground.
('82', 191, 8, 24, 328545) People who are not wanted should evacuate from cities which are within the danger zone.
('82', 191, 8, 25, 328633) There is no cowardice in orderly withdrawal.
('82', 191, 8, 26, 328678) Women and children and aged people and all those who are not wanted should evacuate so as to enable the defenders the better to regulate defence of cities under their control.
('82', 191, 8, 27, 328854) The evacuees will show real courage if they will settle down in villages and tackle problems that face villagers.
('82', 191, 8, 28, 328968) Differences of opinion between leaders ought not to worry people.
('82', 191, 8, 29, 329034) Honest differences are often a healthy sign of progress.
('82', 191, 8, 30, 329091) And the differences you refer to are honest.
('82', 191, 9, 31, 329136) SEVAGRAM, April 13, 1942 Harijan, 19 4 1942

('82', 192, 1, 2, 329267) 233. THAT ILL FATED PROPOSAL
('82', 192, 2, 3, 329296) It is a thousand pities that the British Government should have sent a proposal 1 for dissolving the political deadlock, which, on the face of it, was too ridiculous to find acceptance anywhere.
('82', 192, 2, 4, 329491) And it was a misfortune that the bearer should have been Sir Stafford Cripps, acclaimed as a radical among radicals and a friend of India.
('82', 192, 2, 5, 329630) I have no doubt about his goodwill.
('82', 192, 2, 6, 329666) He believed that no one could have brought anything better for India.
('82', 192, 2, 7, 329736) But he should have known that at least the Congress would not look at Dominion Status even though it carried the right of secession the very moment it was taken.
('82', 192, 2, 8, 329898) He knew too that the proposal contemplated the splitting up of India into three parts each having different ideas of governance.
('82', 192, 2, 9, 330027) It contemplated Pakistan, and yet not the Pakistan of the Muslim League’s conception.
('82', 192, 2, 10, 330113) And last of all it gave no real control over defence to responsible ministers.
('82', 192, 2, 11, 330192) The fact is that Sir Stafford Cripps, having become part of the Imperial machinery, unconsciously partook of its quality.
('82', 192, 2, 12, 330314) Such is its strength.
('82', 192, 2, 13, 330336) It is the almost invariable experience in India that those Indians who are drawn into it lose their originality and become like their companions in the service and often outdo the latter in their loyalty to the Moloch of Imperialism.
('82', 192, 2, 14, 330570) Had Sir Stafford remained detached, he would have conferred with his radical friends in India and secured their approbation before undertaking his very difficult mission.
('82', 192, 2, 15, 330741) If it be said in answer that he could not very well do so, that is exactly what I mean when I say that, having become part of the machinery, he was bound to fall under its spell and could not do the obvious thing.
('82', 192, 2, 16, 330955) But it is no use brooding over the past or British mistakes.
('82', 192, 2, 17, 331016) It is more profitable to look within.
('82', 192, 2, 18, 331054) The British will take care of themselves, if we will take care of ourselves.
('82', 192, 2, 19, 331131) Our mistakes or rather defects are many.
('82', 192, 2, 20, 331172) Why blame the British for our own limitations?
('82', 192, 2, 21, 331219) Attainment of Independence is an impossibility till we have solved the communal tangle.
('82', 192, 2, 22, 331307) We may not blind ourselves to the naked fact.
('82', 192, 2, 23, 331353) How to tackle the problem is another question.
('82', 192, 2, 24, 331400) We will never tackle it so long as either or both parties think that independence will or can come without any solution of the tangle.
('82', 192, 2, 25, 331535) There are two ways of solving what has almost become
('82', 192, 3, 26, 331588) 1 Vide Appendix “British War Cabinet’s Proposals”, before 27 3 1942.
('82', 193, 0, 1, 331657) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 193, 1, 2, 331699) insoluble.
('82', 193, 1, 3, 331710) The one is the royal way of non violence, and the other of violence.
('82', 193, 1, 4, 331779) In the first way the formal consent or co operation of the other party is unnecessary.
('82', 193, 1, 5, 331866) If there is a dispute between two boys over the ownership of an apple, the non violent way is to leave the apple for the other party to take, the latter well knowing that it would mean non co operation on the surrendering party’s part.
('82', 193, 1, 6, 332102) The second way is the usual way of violence.
('82', 193, 1, 7, 332147) There the parties fight with each other till one is for the time being worsted.
('82', 193, 1, 8, 332227) All interested in freedom have to make the choice.
('82', 193, 1, 9, 332278) I suppose the choice has already been made by the chief actors.
('82', 193, 1, 10, 332342) But the rank and file do not know their own minds.
('82', 193, 1, 11, 332393) It is necessary for them, if they can, to think independently and take to non violent action in terms of unity.
('82', 193, 1, 12, 332505) It consists in Hindus and Muslims on the wayside fraternizing with one another, if they believe that joint life is a perfect possibility, nay, a necessity.
('82', 193, 1, 13, 332661) Whether those who believe in the two nation theory and communal partition of India can live as friends co operating with one another I do not know.
('82', 193, 1, 14, 332809) If the vast majority of Muslims regard themselves as a separate nation having nothing in common with Hindus and others, no power on earth can compel them to think otherwise.
('82', 193, 1, 15, 332983) And if they want to partition India on that basis, they must have the partition, unless Hindus want to fight against such a division.
('82', 193, 1, 16, 333117) So far as I can see such a preparation is silently going on behalf of both the parties.
('82', 193, 1, 17, 333205) That way lies suicide.
('82', 193, 1, 18, 333228) Each party will probably want British or foreign aid.
('82', 193, 1, 19, 333282) In that case, good bye to independence.
('82', 193, 1, 20, 333322) The fight will then range round not independence but the imaginary apple after the manner of the imaginary boys.
('82', 193, 1, 21, 333435) I dare not contemplate the actuality.
('82', 193, 1, 22, 333473) I should not like to be its living witness.
('82', 193, 1, 23, 333517) I would love to see a joint fight for independence.
('82', 193, 1, 24, 333569) In the very process of securing independence it is highly likely that we shall have forgotten our quarrels.
('82', 193, 1, 25, 333677) But if we have not, it will be then only time to quarrel, if we must.
('82', 193, 2, 26, 333747) SEVAGRAM, April 13, 1942 Harijan, 19 4 1942

('82', 198, 1, 2, 337861) 241. DISTRESS IN BENGAL 1
('82', 198, 2, 3, 337887) Bengal has suffered from communal riots, it is suffering from famine, and now it threatens to be the target of Japan.
('82', 198, 2, 4, 338005) Military preparations are inevitable.
('82', 198, 2, 5, 338043) This means eviction of villagers.
('82', 198, 2, 6, 338077) Satis Babu sends me a graphic account of an eviction near Chittapore.
('82', 198, 2, 7, 338147) Thirty three villages have been evacuated under very short notice.
('82', 198, 2, 8, 338214) The notices were dated 1st April, served on the 2nd, and the villagers had to leave on the 4th.
('82', 198, 2, 9, 338310) The troops entered on the 4th.
('82', 198, 2, 10, 338341) In one village the villagers got the notice on the same day that the troops entered.
('82', 198, 2, 11, 338426) The evacuees were paid removal cost at the rate of Rs. 10 to 100 according to the Union rates they were paying.
('82', 198, 2, 12, 338538) Compensation is to be determined and paid hereafter.
('82', 198, 2, 13, 338591) The rules framed for evacuation are elaborate and read reasonable.
('82', 198, 2, 14, 338658) But however reasonable they may be, the hardship of sudden evacuation is inevitable, and the enforcement of the rules having unavoidably to be left in the hands of many and petty officials, fairness cannot be ensured.
('82', 198, 2, 15, 338876) Under the circumstances the utmost that workers like Satis Babu can do is to cheer up the people.
('82', 198, 2, 16, 338974) Their solid contribution must be to teach the villagers to face the inevitable hardships calmly and bravely and derive comfort from within.
('82', 198, 2, 17, 339114) Unless they are depressed by their so called comforters, they respond to the best in them and cheerfully face the worst.
('82', 198, 2, 18, 339235) This is not to say that the authorities should be callous to the sufferings of the poor.
('82', 198, 2, 19, 339324) In the present case I do not see what they could have done if the troops had to be located where they have been all of a sudden.
('82', 198, 2, 20, 339453) Laymen cannot judge whether the military officers should not have anticipated events and made arrangements in good time.

('82', 202, 10, 23, 344712) 248. KHADI AND VILLAGE INDUSTRY 1
('82', 202, 11, 24, 344746) [Before April 15, 1942] 2
('82', 202, 12, 25, 344772) Q. You have often said that khadi and village industry are supplementary to each other.
('82', 202, 12, 26, 344860) But you have created separate organizations for them with the result that a khadi worker, when he goes to a village, is unable to spare time from his own particular work for either village industries or uplift.
('82', 202, 12, 27, 345071) Recently you have asked for khadi and village industry bhandars to be run jointly.
('82', 202, 12, 28, 345154) Times are such that transport of goods is becoming increasingly difficult.
('82', 202, 12, 29, 345229) Should not khadi and village industry centres, therefore, be converted into one?
('82', 202, 12, 30, 345310) Would it not be a good thing if khadi
('82', 202, 13, 31, 345348) 1 This appeared in Harijan under “Notes”, and was originally published in Sarvodaya and Khadi Jagat under the date 15 4 1942. 2 ibid.
('82', 203, 0, 1, 345482) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 203, 1, 2, 345524) workers gave up all ideas of sending locally produced khadi to distant places and concentrated on both khadi and village industry production for local use?
('82', 203, 1, 3, 345680) Khadi workers are asked to penetrate into the houses of artisans with charkha and train them, to rouse a love of village products in them, improve their ways of living, health, sanitation, etc.
('82', 203, 1, 4, 345874) But if they have no time to spare, how can they do all that is expected of them?
('82', 203, 1, 5, 345955) A. I admit that, if a khadi worker’s entire time is employed in khadi work, he cannot possibly attend to either village uplift or industry.
('82', 203, 1, 6, 346095) Three persons would be required for the three tasks.
('82', 203, 1, 7, 346148) My idea is that in a well organized village one person should suffice.
('82', 203, 1, 8, 346219) For example, one worker may devote two hours to taking in yarn, distributing slivers and spinning tools, and sales of khadi; village industry work might take even less, and the remainder of the time he could give to village uplift and general education.
('82', 203, 1, 9, 346473) This has not till now been possible because the khadi workers’ time has been devoted to teaching people how to spin, etc.
('82', 203, 1, 10, 346595) But now the time has come when khadi and village products, locally produced, must also be locally absorbed.
('82', 203, 1, 11, 346703) In that case one person will be able to do all the work.
('82', 203, 1, 12, 346760) Today it suffices to say that all this work is complementary— and must become one as far as possible.
('82', 203, 1, 13, 346862) The amalgamation cannot be imposed; it must be a natural growth.
('82', 203, 1, 14, 346927) I do not, I cannot, apportion any blame to anyone for the existing position.
('82', 203, 1, 15, 347004) Our plans have progressed as far as our intelligence and experience could have taken them.
('82', 203, 1, 16, 347095) The creation of khadi vidyalayas is meant to expand and improve the technique of work.
('82', 203, 1, 17, 347182) We shall learn from them how all departments of village work can be amalgamated.
('82', 203, 1, 18, 347263) Harijan, 31 5 1942

('82', 207, 5, 6, 352140) 256. MEANING OF YARN CURRENCY 1
('82', 207, 6, 7, 352172) I find that I have not been able fully to explain to my co workers my idea of yarn currency.
('82', 207, 6, 8, 352265) I attempt to do so here.
('82', 207, 6, 9, 352290) Metal coins or paper notes are not a true standard because their value is arbitrarily determined.
('82', 207, 6, 10, 352388) The value of the paper of a five rupee note is even less than one pice.
('82', 207, 6, 11, 352460) It has a value because of the government stamp on it.
('82', 207, 6, 12, 352514) However, this or any such standard is very necessary for carrying on business transactions on a very large scale.
('82', 207, 6, 13, 352628) But the idea behind khadi and other village industries is quite different.
('82', 207, 6, 14, 352703) We do not want business on a large scale.
('82', 207, 6, 15, 352745) We want to restrict our attention to only one of the seven lakhs of villages.
('82', 207, 6, 16, 352823) We want the same independence for that village as we want for any other of the seven lakh villages and the world at large.
('82', 207, 6, 17, 352946) So our villages should at least become self reliant as far as food and clothing are concerned.
('82', 207, 7, 18, 353041) In such villages there cannot be any need for metal or any other imposed currency for mutual transactions.
('82', 207, 7, 19, 353148) Our standard should be a rural product, which everyone can make, which can be stored and the price of which does not fluctuate daily.
('82', 207, 7, 20, 353282) What can this be?
('82', 207, 7, 21, 353300) It can neither be soap, nor oil, nor vegetables.
('82', 207, 7, 22, 353349) Thus after enumerating and eliminating all the things only yarn remains.
('82', 207, 7, 23, 353422) Everyone can produce it.
('82', 207, 7, 24, 353447) There is always a demand for it.
('82', 207, 7, 25, 353480) It can be stored well.
('82', 207, 7, 26, 353503) If we can introduce yarn currency in the villages, they will make great progress and become self reliant very soon.
('82', 207, 7, 27, 353619) This is not an attempt to enumerate all the advantages of yarn currency.
('82', 207, 7, 28, 353692) I want to tell you only what it means and how it will function.
('82', 207, 8, 29, 353756) For this a shop is needed where items of daily use for villagers can be available.
('82', 207, 8, 30, 353839) All the villagers could buy anything from this shop by giving only yarn—there should not be any exception to this.
('82', 207, 9, 31, 353954) 1 This was originally published in the April issue of Khadi Jagat.
('82', 208, 0, 1, 354021) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 209
('82', 208, 1, 2, 354064) result all the villagers will have to spin to buy things from the above mentioned shops.
('82', 208, 1, 3, 354153) In these shops yarn of given strength and in given quantity will be accepted and therefore the yarn spun by the villagers will be properly tied.
('82', 208, 1, 4, 354298) A villager will not let even a single strand of it be wasted because so many things could be bought with it.
('82', 208, 1, 5, 354407) The importance of yarn will increase.
('82', 208, 1, 6, 354445) The commodities secured in exchange of yarn will be of good quality and will not be expensive.
('82', 208, 1, 7, 354540) Even a child will be able to buy from there without fear of being cheated.
('82', 208, 1, 8, 354615) As the shops cannot accept any kind of yarn, there will be need for a yarn examiner whose function will be to test the yarn currency.
('82', 208, 1, 9, 354749) To prevent the yarn from getting dirty it will have to be wrapped in paper or some such thing.
('82', 208, 1, 10, 354844) The shopkeeper will blindly accept the yarn which is well wrapped by the examiner.
('82', 208, 2, 11, 354927) As the examiner and the shopkeepers are connected with an institution such as the Charkha Sangh, the yarn will be daily sent to the Sangh office and from there to the weavers.
('82', 208, 3, 12, 355103) There is no room for loss in such shops.
('82', 208, 3, 13, 355144) There is no possibility of much fluctuation in the prices of things sold there.
('82', 208, 3, 14, 355224) Generally only those things which are available in the villages will be kept.
('82', 208, 3, 15, 355302) The number of such things will increase gradually.
('82', 208, 4, 16, 355353) In such a scheme every house can become a mint and can make as much money (yarn) as it wants.
('82', 208, 4, 17, 355447) It is clear that in such shops intoxicants, imported things and harmful products will not be sold.
('82', 208, 4, 18, 355546) And therefore the yarn nexus will remain more or less pure.
('82', 208, 5, 19, 355606) SEVAGRAM, April 17, 1942
('82', 208, 6, 20, 355631) [From Hindi]
('82', 208, 7, 21, 355644) Harijan Sevak, 3 5 1942

('82', 209, 7, 9, 356007) 258. LETTER TO S. SATYAMURTI
('82', 209, 8, 10, 356036) April 17, 1942
('82', 209, 9, 11, 356051) DEAR SATYAMURTI, Your letter.
('82', 209, 10, 12, 356081) I am doing all I can in the way of showing the non violent approach to the pending menace.
('82', 209, 10, 13, 356172) But I am helpless if the Congress policy changes from moment to moment.
('82', 209, 11, 14, 356244) I do not know how Hindu Muslim understanding can be brought about.
('82', 209, 11, 15, 356311) Our meeting can be easily brought about.
('82', 209, 11, 16, 356352) I have only to walk to his place.
('82', 209, 11, 17, 356386) Having gone there, what am I to do or say?
('82', 209, 11, 18, 356429) If I knew that, I would go.
('82', 209, 11, 19, 356457) There seems to me to be no meeting ground.
('82', 209, 12, 20, 356500) Ba is quite well.
('82', 209, 12, 21, 356518) Thanks.
('82', 209, 13, 22, 356526) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
