('82', 211, 0, 1, 357431) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 211, 1, 2, 357473) 261. TEN QUESTIONS REGARDING THE NATIONAL LANGUAGE 1
('82', 211, 2, 3, 357526) Q. 1. The Persian script did not originate in India.
('82', 211, 2, 4, 357579) It came during the Mogul
('82', 211, 3, 5, 357604) period just as the Roman script has with the advent of the British.
('82', 211, 3, 6, 357672) But you do not
('82', 211, 4, 7, 357687) advocate the Roman script for the national language.
('82', 211, 4, 8, 357740) Why then the Persian?
('82', 211, 4, 9, 357762) A. If the Roman script had made a home for itself in India in the same way as the Persian, I would agree with you.
('82', 211, 4, 10, 357877) But the knowledge of the former is confined to a mere handful of English knowing persons, while crores of Hindus and Muslims are conversant with the latter.
('82', 211, 4, 11, 358034) You should try to find out the exact number of persons knowing the Roman and Persian scripts respectively.
('82', 211, 5, 12, 358141) Q. 2. If you advocate the learning of Urdu for the sake of Hindu Muslim unity,
('82', 211, 6, 13, 358220) then please remember that a large number of Mussalmans in India do not know Urdu.
('82', 211, 7, 14, 358302) They are conversant only with their own provincial languages.
('82', 211, 7, 15, 358364) These people would
('82', 211, 8, 16, 358383) far more easily understand a national language comprising words familiar to their
('82', 211, 9, 17, 358465) provincial languages.
('82', 211, 9, 18, 358487) The North Indian languages are all derived from Sanskrit and
('82', 211, 10, 19, 358548) therefore resemble each other a good deal.
('82', 211, 10, 20, 358591) Sanskrit words have even crept to a large
('82', 211, 11, 21, 358633) extent into the Southern languages.
('82', 211, 11, 22, 358669) Then why advocate for these people the learning
('82', 211, 12, 23, 358717) of an unfamiliar Urdu tongue full of Arabic and Persian words?
('82', 211, 13, 24, 358780) A. There is force in your argument.
('82', 211, 13, 25, 358816) But I would like you to delve a little deeper into the question.
('82', 211, 13, 26, 358881) I admit that in asking people to learn the Persian script I have at the back of my mind a contribution to Hindu Muslim unity.
('82', 211, 13, 27, 359007) There has been a long standing conflict between the Hindi and Urdu tongues as between the two scripts.
('82', 211, 13, 28, 359110) Today it has assumed a virulent form.
('82', 211, 13, 29, 359148) In 1935 in Indore the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan, while defining Hindi, gave a definite place to the Persian script.
('82', 211, 13, 30, 359261) 2 In 1925 the Congress gave the national language the name of Hindustani.
('82', 211, 13, 31, 359335) 3 Both scripts were made permissible.
('82', 211, 13, 32, 359373) Thus Hindi plus Urdu was recognized as the national language.
('82', 211, 13, 33, 359435) The question of Hindu Muslim unity was definitely in the forefront in all
('82', 211, 14, 34, 359509) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 26 4 1942. This English translation is reproduced from Harijan.
('82', 211, 14, 35, 359632) 2 Vide “Speech at Hindi Sahitya Sammelan, Indore”, 20 4 1935. 3 Vide “The Annual Demonstration”, 7 1 1926
('82', 212, 0, 1, 359738) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 213
('82', 212, 1, 2, 359781) these decisions.
('82', 212, 1, 3, 359798) I have not raised this issue today.
('82', 212, 1, 4, 359834) I have only given it a concrete form.
('82', 212, 1, 5, 359872) It is a logical outcome of events.
('82', 212, 1, 6, 359907) If we want to develop the national language to the fullest extent, it behoves us to give the two scripts an equal status.
('82', 212, 1, 7, 360029) In the end whichever is appreciated more by the people will be the more widespread.
('82', 212, 2, 8, 360113) The provincial languages are closely allied to Sanskrit, and it is true that lacs of Muslims are conversant only with their provincial languages, and that Hindi and the Devanagari script will, therefore, be easier for them to learn than Urdu and the Persian characters.
('82', 212, 2, 9, 360383) My scheme will not interfere with this.
('82', 212, 2, 10, 360423) In fact the people will benefit more than ever by learning the Persian script.
('82', 212, 2, 11, 360502) Your trouble arises because you look upon this as a burden.
('82', 212, 2, 12, 360562) Whether it is a gain or a burden depends on the outlook of the learner.
('82', 212, 2, 13, 360634) He who is filled with a love of country will never consider such learning a burden.
('82', 212, 2, 14, 360718) There will be no compulsion by my scheme.
('82', 212, 2, 15, 360760) Only those who consider it a gain will learn the Persian script or the Devanagari as the case may be.
('82', 212, 3, 16, 360862) Q. 3. A very large proportion of persons in India know the Devanagari script.
('82', 212, 4, 17, 360940) Surely Punjabis, Sindhis and the Frontier folk can easily learn it too.
('82', 212, 5, 18, 361012) A. The reply to this is really embodied in the preceding answer.
('82', 212, 5, 19, 361077) Frontier people and others will have to learn the Devanagari script.
('82', 212, 6, 20, 361146) Q. 4. A national language is really more for speech than literary purposes.
('82', 212, 7, 21, 361222) script is, therefore, not so essential or is, at any rate, of secondary importance.
('82', 212, 8, 22, 361306) Moreover is it not easier to learn the national language through the script of the
('82', 212, 9, 23, 361389) mother tongue?
('82', 212, 9, 24, 361404) And where would be the harm in so doing?
('82', 212, 10, 25, 361445) A. You are right.
('82', 212, 10, 26, 361463) It is easier to learn the national language through the script of the mother tongue.
('82', 212, 10, 27, 361548) As far as I know this is being done in Southern India though perhaps not systematically.
('82', 212, 10, 28, 361637) Unlike you I do not look upon the learning of two scripts as a burden.
('82', 212, 10, 29, 361708) It is not so hard as you fear.
('82', 212, 10, 30, 361739) I can never be opposed to the learning of the national language through the script of the mother tongue.
('82', 212, 10, 31, 361844) Given the keenness to learn it, all systems will be employed.
('82', 212, 11, 32, 361906) Q. 5. If it is not possible to make real contacts with the non Hindi knowing
('82', 212, 12, 33, 361983) provinces until some of us have learnt the national language, why not limit the
('82', 212, 13, 34, 362063) acquiring of this knowledge to workers only?
('82', 212, 13, 35, 362108) Why make it obligatory for the whole
('82', 212, 14, 36, 362145) of India?
('82', 213, 0, 1, 362155) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 213, 1, 2, 362197) A. The question of everyone learning Hindustani does not arise.
('82', 213, 1, 3, 362261) Indeed everyone will never do so.
('82', 213, 1, 4, 362295) The necessity is for those who have to travel and those who want to serve.
('82', 213, 1, 5, 362370) The latter’s ability for service will be greatly increased by a knowledge of both languages and scripts.
('82', 213, 1, 6, 362475) If you agree, your opposition and suspicion should subside.
('82', 213, 2, 7, 362535) Q. 6. Today the national language is written in both scripts.
('82', 213, 2, 8, 362597) Whoever wants to
('82', 213, 3, 9, 362614) learn can choose the one he prefers.
('82', 213, 3, 10, 362651) Why the insistence on both?
('82', 213, 4, 11, 362679) A. In spite of my so called insistence, only those will learn it who find real gain in so doing.
('82', 213, 4, 12, 362776) In my eyes he who knows only one of the languages and one script will be half equipped.
('82', 213, 4, 13, 362864) If he desires a full certificate from me, he must be conversant with both.
('82', 213, 4, 14, 362939) I am sure you will have no objection to the desirability of there being many such persons in the country.
('82', 213, 4, 15, 363045) And unless this number goes on increasing there will never be a proper blending of Hindi and Urdu.
('82', 213, 4, 16, 363144) The Congress ideal of Hindustani will never be fulfilled.
('82', 213, 4, 17, 363202) That Hindus and Mussalmans in the Hindi knowing provinces should have a common speech is a consummation devoutly to be wished.
('82', 213, 4, 18, 363329) Many of us cling to this hope, and some day it will certainly come to pass.
('82', 213, 5, 19, 363405) Q. 7. Will it not be a terrible burden and a futile endeavour for people of the
('82', 213, 6, 20, 363485) non Hindi speaking provinces to learn the national language through both scripts at
('82', 213, 7, 21, 363569) the same time?
('82', 213, 7, 22, 363584) To learn first one and then the other would surely be simple.
('82', 213, 8, 23, 363646) A. The answer to this will best come from experience.
('82', 213, 8, 24, 363700) He who does not know either script will not learn both at the same time.
('82', 213, 8, 25, 363773) He will master one before commencing on the other.
('82', 213, 8, 26, 363824) So far as the vocabulary is concerned the words used in the text books in the early stages will more or less be the same.
('82', 213, 8, 27, 363946) I look upon my scheme as a most important and useful experiment.
('82', 213, 8, 28, 364011) If it is properly worked, it will be found to have energized the nation and made a big contribution towards giving practical shape to the Congress resolution.
('82', 213, 8, 29, 364170) I hope lacs of patriotic men and women will take to it.
('82', 213, 9, 30, 364226) Q. 8. Certain changes must inevitably take place in any language, as for
('82', 213, 10, 31, 364299) example, the ingress of foreign words which become part of the language and cannot
('82', 213, 11, 32, 364382) be evicted.
('82', 213, 11, 33, 364394) But Devanagari has been the traditional script all through the ages.
('82', 213, 12, 34, 364463) the period of the Mogul dynasty the Persian script came in.
('82', 213, 12, 35, 364523) But Gujarati, Marathi,
('82', 213, 13, 36, 364546) etc., while assimilating Persian, Arabic and English words, have not abandoned the
('82', 213, 14, 37, 364629) script.
('82', 213, 14, 38, 364637) Why should the Devanagari script then not be maintained?
('82', 214, 0, 1, 364694) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 215
('82', 214, 1, 2, 364737) A. There is no question of giving up anything that is ours by tradition.
('82', 214, 1, 3, 364810) It is a question of adding to or improving what already exists.
('82', 214, 1, 4, 364874) If I know Sanskrit, what harm if I learn Arabic too, or vice versa?
('82', 214, 1, 5, 364942) The result will probably be an enrichment of my knowledge of either language.
('82', 214, 1, 6, 365020) And my contacts with the Arabs or Hindus, as the case may be, will increase.
('82', 214, 1, 7, 365097) Surely there can be no opposition to the acquiring or right knowledge in any sphere.
('82', 214, 2, 8, 365182) Q. 9. From the point of view of easy mastery over the pronunciation of the
('82', 214, 3, 9, 365257) national language, is not the Devanagari script the best?
('82', 214, 3, 10, 365315) The Persian script is surely
('82', 214, 4, 11, 365344) defective for the purpose.
('82', 214, 4, 12, 365371) A. You are right, but your opposition to the Persian script has no place here.
('82', 214, 4, 13, 365450) Devanagari is not to be displaced.
('82', 214, 4, 14, 365485) It is a question of adding to the existing knowledge.
('82', 214, 5, 15, 365539) Q. 10. Where is the need for a national language?
('82', 214, 5, 16, 365589) Will not the mother tongue
('82', 214, 6, 17, 365616) and an international language suffice?
('82', 214, 6, 18, 365655) And then why not the Roman script for both?
('82', 214, 7, 19, 365699) A. Your question surprises me.
('82', 214, 7, 20, 365730) English no doubt is the international language.
('82', 214, 7, 21, 365778) But can it ever be our national language?
('82', 214, 7, 22, 365820) The latter must be the common property of millions of our people.
('82', 214, 7, 23, 365886) How can they sustain the burden of learning the English tongue?
('82', 214, 7, 24, 365950) Hindustani is the natural national language, for it is already understood by 21 crores.
('82', 214, 7, 25, 366038) The remainder of the population can also easily understand it.
('82', 214, 7, 26, 366101) But English may be said to be the mother tongue of a mere handful—say, a lac at the most.
('82', 214, 7, 27, 366191) If India is a nation, it must have a national language.
('82', 214, 7, 28, 366247) English will appropriately remain the international language with the Roman script.
('82', 214, 7, 29, 366331) But the latter can never be the script of the national language.
('82', 214, 8, 30, 366396) SEVAGRAM, April 19, 1942 Harijan, 26 4 1942
('82', 215, 0, 1, 366440) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 215, 1, 2, 366482) 262. FOREIGN SOLDIERS IN INDIA
('82', 215, 2, 3, 366513) Among the multitude of questions contained in my correspo ndence is the one referring to the advent of foreign soldiers in India.
('82', 215, 2, 4, 366643) We have foreign prisoners enough.
('82', 215, 2, 5, 366677) Now we have promise of a never ending stream of soldiers from America and possibly China.
('82', 215, 2, 6, 366767) I must confess that I do not look upon this event with equanimity.
('82', 215, 2, 7, 366834) Cannot a limitless number of soldiers be trained out of India’s millions?
('82', 215, 2, 8, 366908) Would they not make as good fighting material as any in the world?
('82', 215, 2, 9, 366975) Then why foreigners?
('82', 215, 2, 10, 366996) We know what American aid means.
('82', 215, 2, 11, 367029) It amounts in the end to American influence, if not American rule added to British.
('82', 215, 2, 12, 367113) It is a tremendous price to pay for the possible success of Allied arms.
('82', 215, 2, 13, 367186) I see no Indian freedom peeping through all this preparation for the so called defence of India.
('82', 215, 2, 14, 367283) It is a preparation pure and simple for the defence of the British Empire, whatever may be asserted to the contrary.
('82', 215, 2, 15, 367400) If the British left India to her fate as they had to leave Singapore, non violent India would not lose anything.
('82', 215, 2, 16, 367513) Probably the Japanese would leave India alone.
('82', 215, 2, 17, 367560) Perhaps India, if the main parties composed their differences as they probably would, would be able effectively to help China in the way of peace and in the long run may even play a decisive part in the promotion of world peace.
('82', 215, 2, 18, 367789) But all these happy things may not happen if the British will leave India only when they must.
('82', 215, 2, 19, 367884) How much more creditable, how much braver it would be for Britain to offer battle in the West and leave the East to adjust her own position!
('82', 215, 2, 20, 368025) There is no guarantee that she will be able to protect, during this war, all her vast possessions.
('82', 215, 2, 21, 368124) They have become a dead weight round her.
('82', 215, 2, 22, 368166) If she wisely loosens herself from this weight, and the Nazis, the Fascists or the Japanese instead of leaving India alone choose to subjugate her, they will find that they have to hold more than they can in their iron hoop.
('82', 215, 2, 23, 368391) They will find it much more difficult than Britain has.
('82', 215, 2, 24, 368447) Their very rigidity will strangle them.
('82', 215, 2, 25, 368487) The British system had an elasticity which served so long as it had no powerful rivals.
('82', 215, 2, 26, 368575) British elasticity is of no help today.
('82', 215, 2, 27, 368615) I have said more than once in these columns that the Nazi power had risen as a nemesis to punish Britain for her sins of exploitation and enslavement of the Asiatic and African races.
('82', 216, 0, 1, 368799) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 217
('82', 216, 1, 2, 368842) Whatever the consequences, therefore, to India, her real safety and Britain’s too lie in orderly and timely British withdrawal from India.
('82', 216, 1, 3, 368981) All talk of treaties with the Princes and obligations towards minorities are a British creation designed for the preservation of British rule and British interests.
('82', 216, 1, 4, 369146) It must melt before the stern reality that faces all of us.
('82', 216, 1, 5, 369206) Princes, in so far as they rely upon their armed strength, are more than able to defend themselves against unarmed India.
('82', 216, 1, 6, 369328) The fiction of majority and minority will vanish like the mist before the morning sun of liberty.
('82', 216, 1, 7, 369426) Truth to tell there will be neither majority nor minority in the absence of the paralysing British arms.
('82', 216, 1, 8, 369531) The millions of India would then be an undefined but one mass of humanity.
('82', 216, 1, 9, 369606) I have no doubt that at that time the national leaders will have wisdom enough to evolve an honourable solution of their difficulties.
('82', 216, 1, 10, 369741) This presupposes Japan and other powers leaving India alone.
('82', 216, 1, 11, 369802) If they do not, I should hope even then for wisdom to guide the principal parties to devise a scheme whereby they can act with one mind to face the new menace.
('82', 216, 2, 12, 369962) Holding the views I do, it is clear why I look upon the introduction of foreign soldiers as positive danger thoroughly to be deplored and distrusted.
('82', 216, 2, 13, 370112) The present state of things and the attempt to uphold it are a distinct sign of corroding consumption of the body politic in India.
('82', 216, 3, 14, 370244) SEVAGRAM, April 19, 1942 Harijan, 26 4 1942
('82', 216, 4, 15, 370288) 263. QUESTION BOX
('82', 216, 5, 16, 370306) IF THEY REALLY MEAN?
('82', 216, 6, 17, 370327) Q. If the Japanese really mean what they say and are willing to help to free

('82', 216, 8, 20, 370547) The Japanese may free India from the British yoke, but only to put in their own instead.
('82', 216, 8, 21, 370636) I have always maintained that we should not seek any other Power’s help to free India from the British yoke.
('82', 216, 8, 22, 370745) That would not be a non violent approach.
('82', 216, 8, 23, 370787) We should have to pay a heavy price if we ever consented to take foreign aid against the British.

('82', 217, 7, 27, 372599) It will take no effect.

('82', 217, 7, 30, 372869) I am, therefore, not perturbed by the ‘apostasy’ either of Jawaharlal or Rajaji.

('82', 217, 7, 32, 373047) Neither goes to violence for his belief in it.
('82', 217, 7, 33, 373094) They do so because they think probably that India must have a course of violence before coming to non violence.
('82', 217, 7, 34, 373206) No one can say beyond doubt how events will shape

('82', 218, 1, 14, 374291) To aid the British effort in the violent way without any official connection and after the failure of the recent negotiations appears to me to court national disgrace.

('82', 220, 1, 2, 376279) 267. DEENBANDHU ANDREWS MEMORIAL
('82', 220, 2, 3, 376312) Deenbandhu Andrews Memorial and Gurudev Memorial are convertible terms.
('82', 220, 2, 4, 376384) Gurudev had initiated the Deenbandhu Memorial, but before it had fully materialized Gurudev followed Deenbandhu.
('82', 220, 3, 5, 376497) Therefore Deenbandhu Memorial has become also Gurudev Memorial.
('82', 220, 3, 6, 376561) The purpose is worthy of the two great souls—the impro vement and upkeep of Santiniketan, Visvabharati and Sriniketan.
('82', 220, 3, 7, 376680) These are all in reality one.
('82', 220, 3, 8, 376710) It is a matter of great shame and sorrow that the paltry sum of five lacs of rupees has still not come whether from the rich or the students or the labour world.
('82', 220, 3, 9, 376872) Everybody admitthat Gurudev and his institution have brought a name and prestige to India which no one and nothing else have done.
('82', 220, 3, 10, 377003) It was Santiniketan which stirred Generalissimo and Madame Chiang Kaishek who gave very handsome contributions.
('82', 220, 3, 11, 377115) For the work done at Santiniketan, the expense is ridiculously small.
('82', 220, 3, 12, 377185) The reason is the comparatively low salaries paid where the work done is not purely honorary.
('82', 220, 3, 13, 377279) The donations so far collected amount to nearly one lac.
('82', 220, 3, 14, 377336) I hope that the balance will be forthcoming without delay and absolve me from having to venture out on a collection tour.
('82', 220, 3, 15, 377458) I am in honour bound to finish the collection.
('82', 220, 3, 16, 377505) When Gurudev was dying the last letter I wrote to him was that, if it was God’s will, I would finish the Deenbandhu collection.
('82', 220, 3, 17, 377633) It was also a trust handed by Andrews in that Santiniketan’s financial condition was his daily concern.
('82', 220, 3, 18, 377737) It is a call from these two servants of India and humanity which I dare not neglect.
('82', 220, 3, 19, 377822) Let those who revere their memory and who value Gurudev’s living creation help me to discharge the self imposed trust.
('82', 220, 4, 20, 377941) SEVAGRAM, April 20, 1942 Harijan, 26 4 1942
('82', 220, 5, 21, 377985) 268. EVACUEES FROM BURMA 2
('82', 220, 6, 22, 378012) Much has been written about the hardships of evacuees from Burma.
('82', 220, 6, 23, 378078) Making allowance for all possible exaggerations, the remainder itself is a horrible tale of woes.
('82', 220, 6, 24, 378176) Some of them must be
('82', 220, 7, 25, 378197) 1 Rabindranath Tagore died on August 7, 1941. 2 This appeared under “Notes”.
('82', 221, 0, 1, 378274) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 221, 1, 2, 378316) inevitable in the circumstances that face us.
('82', 221, 1, 3, 378362) What has to be dealt with is the avoidable hardships and blatant discrimination said to be in vogue in the treatment of Britishers and Indians.
('82', 221, 1, 4, 378506) I understand that there are over eight lacs of Indians in Burma yet to be evacuated.
('82', 221, 1, 5, 378591) Life for them in Burma is impossible.
('82', 221, 1, 6, 378629) The question is too big to be tackled by any existing organization.
('82', 221, 1, 7, 378697) It requires a special temporary committee of experienced men whose sole work would be to attend to the orderly and quick evacuation of the eight to nine lacs of men and their disposal after they are on Indian soil.
('82', 221, 1, 8, 378912) Let us hope that there are enough public spirited men who will make it their business to form themselves into a committee and see this very humanitarian work through.

('82', 225, 8, 13, 384417) 277. HINDUSTANI PRACHAR SABHA
('82', 225, 9, 14, 384447) The Hindustani Prachar Sabha to which I referred in Harijan Sevak is about to be formed now.
('82', 225, 9, 15, 384540) A draft constitution has been prepared.
('82', 225, 9, 16, 384580) It has been sent to some friends.
('82', 225, 9, 17, 384614) In a few days the scheme of the Sabha will be put before the public.
('82', 225, 9, 18, 384683) Many people are under the impression that the Sabha will be a rival of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan.
('82', 225, 9, 19, 384782) How can I knowingly oppose the Sammelan with which I have been associated since 1918?
('82', 225, 9, 20, 384868) There has to be a solid reason for my doing so.
('82', 225, 9, 21, 384916) But there is none.
('82', 225, 9, 22, 384935) Yes, it is true that as far as Urdu is concerned I go a little further than the other members.
('82', 225, 9, 23, 385030) They think I am going back.
('82', 225, 9, 24, 385058) Only time will decide who is right.
('82', 225, 10, 25, 385094) To make it clear that I am not opposed to the Sammelan, I entered into correspondence with Shri Purushottamdas Tandon, as a result of which the standing committee of the Sammelan passed the following resolution.
('82', 225, 11, 26, 385306) The Hindi Sahitya Sammelan has from its very inception regarded Hindi
('82', 225, 12, 27, 385376) as the national language and it continues to do so.
('82', 225, 12, 28, 385428) Urdu is a literary style
('82', 225, 13, 29, 385453) deriving from Hindi and having an admixture of Arabic and Persian words.
('82', 225, 14, 30, 385526) Sammelan propagates Hindi but is not opposed to Urdu.
('82', 225, 15, 31, 385580) In the opinion of this Committee, members of Mahatma Gandhi’s
('82', 225, 16, 32, 385642) proposed Hindustani Prachar Sabha can become members of the Hindi Sahitya
('82', 226, 0, 1, 385716) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 227
('82', 226, 1, 2, 385759) Sammelan and its sub committees, but from the practical point of view it will
('82', 226, 2, 3, 385837) be better that the office bearers of the Rashtrabhasha Prachar Samiti should
('82', 226, 3, 4, 385914) not become office bearers of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha.
('82', 226, 3, 5, 385973) I could not have expected more generosity than this.
('82', 226, 3, 6, 386026) I was and still am of opinion that there could have been no question of conflict if the office bearers could be the same.
('82', 226, 3, 7, 386148) There is a possibility of conflict in the present arrangement but if both the parties behave with gentlemanliness this can be avoided.

('82', 227, 8, 12, 387227) 280. LETTER TO HORACE ALEXANDER
('82', 227, 9, 13, 387259) SEVAGRAM, via WARDHA (C.P.), April 22, 1942
('82', 227, 10, 14, 387303) MY DEAR HORACE, I have been wanting to write to you and Agatha all this time but my preoccupations have come in the way.
('82', 227, 10, 15, 387424) But more than that, the reluctance to send you a cheerless letter has been the cause.
('82', 227, 10, 16, 387510) It is still there greater than ever.
('82', 227, 10, 17, 387547) Nevertheless I must write what I feel.
('82', 227, 10, 18, 387586) I hope you had my wire about Olive 2. How well I remember her radiant face in spite of her permanent disability.
('82', 227, 10, 19, 387699) God gave and He has taken her away.
('82', 227, 10, 20, 387735) I know it is well with her, for she walked in His light.
('82', 227, 10, 21, 387792) Sir Stafford has come and gone.
('82', 227, 10, 22, 387824) How nice it would have been if he had not come with that dismal mission.
('82', 227, 10, 23, 387897) He of all people should never have without having at least ascertained Jawaharlal’s wishes.
('82', 227, 10, 24, 387989) How could the British Government, at this critical hour, have behaved as they did?
('82', 227, 10, 25, 388072) Why should they have sent proposals without discussing them with the principal parties?
('82', 227, 10, 26, 388160) Not one single party was satisfied.
('82', 227, 10, 27, 388196) In trying to please all the proposals pleased none.
('82', 227, 11, 28, 388248) I talked to him frankly but as a friend, if for nothing else, for Andrews’s sake.
('82', 227, 11, 29, 388330) I told him that I was speaking to him with Andrews’s
('82', 227, 12, 30, 388383) 1 Addressee’s wife 2 ibid.
('82', 228, 0, 1, 388410) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 229
('82', 228, 1, 2, 388453) spirit as my witness.
('82', 228, 1, 3, 388475) I made suggestions but all to no avail.
('82', 228, 1, 4, 388515) As usual they were not practical.
('82', 228, 1, 5, 388549) I had not wanted to go.
('82', 228, 1, 6, 388573) I had nothing to say being anti all wars.
('82', 228, 1, 7, 388615) I went because he was anxious to see me.
('82', 228, 1, 8, 388656) All this I mention in order to give you the background.
('82', 228, 1, 9, 388712) I was not present throughout the negotiations with the W.C. I had come away.
('82', 228, 1, 10, 388789) You know the result.
('82', 228, 1, 11, 388810) It was inevitable.
('82', 228, 1, 12, 388829) The whole thing has left a bad taste in the mouth.
('82', 228, 2, 13, 388880) My firm opinion is that the British should leave India now in an orderly manner and not run the risk that they did in Singapore and Malaya and Burma.
('82', 228, 2, 14, 389030) That act would mean courage of a high order, confession of human limitations and right doing by India.
('82', 228, 2, 15, 389133) Britain cannot defend India, much less herself on Indian soil with any strength.
('82', 228, 2, 16, 389214) The best thing she can do is to leave India to her fate.
('82', 228, 2, 17, 389271) I feel somehow that India will not do badly then.
('82', 228, 2, 18, 389321) I must not argue this point if it is not obvious to you.

('82', 230, 0, 1, 391537) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 231
('82', 230, 1, 2, 391580) 283. DRAFT RESOLUTION FOR A.I.C.C. 1
('82', 230, 2, 3, 391617) [Before April 24, 1942] 2
('82', 230, 3, 4, 391643) Whereas the British War Cabinet’s proposals sponsored by Sir Stafford Cripps have shown up British imperialism in its nakedness as never before, the A.I.C.C. has come to the following conclusions: The A.I.C.C. is of opinion that Britain is incapable of defending India.
('82', 230, 3, 5, 391913) It is natural that whatever she does is for her own defence.
('82', 230, 3, 6, 391974) There is an eternal conflict between Indian and British interests.
('82', 230, 3, 7, 392041) It follows that their notions of defence would also differ.
('82', 230, 3, 8, 392101) The British Government has no trust in India’s political parties.
('82', 230, 3, 9, 392167) The Indian army has been maintained up till now mainly to hold India in subjugation.
('82', 230, 3, 10, 392252) It has been completely segregated from the general population who can in no sense regard it as their own.
('82', 230, 3, 11, 392358) This policy of mistrust still continues and is the reason why national defence is not entrusted to India’s elected representatives.
('82', 230, 4, 12, 392490) Japan’s quarrel is not with India.
('82', 230, 4, 13, 392525) She is warring against the British Empire.
('82', 230, 4, 14, 392568) India’s participation in the war has not been with the consent of the representatives of the Indian people.
('82', 230, 4, 15, 392676) It was purely a British act.
('82', 230, 4, 16, 392705) If India were freed her first step would probably be to negotiate with Japan.
('82', 230, 4, 17, 392783) The Congress is of opinion that if the British withdrew from India, India would be able to defend herself in the event of Japanese or any aggressor attacking India.
('82', 230, 4, 18, 392948) The A.I.C.C. is, therefore, of opinion that the British should withdraw from India.
('82', 230, 4, 19, 393032) The plea that they should remain in India for protecting the Indian Princes is wholly untenable.
('82', 230, 4, 20, 393129) It is additional proof of their determination to maintain their hold over India.
('82', 230, 4, 21, 393210) The Princes need have no fear from unarmed India.
('82', 230, 4, 22, 393260) The question of majority and minority is a creation of
('82', 230, 5, 23, 393315) 1 The A.I.C.C. at its meeting on April 27, took up consideration of the resolution, which Mirabehn carried with her from Wardha to Allahabad since Gandhiji did not attend the meeting, and continued discussion on it till May 1 along with certain amendments proposed by Rajendra Prasad.
('82', 230, 5, 24, 393600) The text of this revised version is to be found in The Transfer of Power, pp.
('82', 230, 5, 25, 393678) 66 70. Finally on May 1 an alternative resolution proposed by Nehru was passed, for the text of which vide Appendix “Resolution passed by A.I.C.C.”, 1 5 1942. 2 Vide “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 24 4 1942.
('82', 231, 0, 1, 393885) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 231, 1, 2, 393927) the British Government and would disappear on their withdrawal.
('82', 231, 1, 3, 393991) For all these reasons the Committee appeals to Britain, for the sake of her own safety, for the sake of India’s safety and for the cause of world peace to let go her hold on India even if she does not give up all Asiatic and African possessions.
('82', 231, 2, 4, 394237) This Committee desires to assure the Japanese Government and people that India bears no enmity either towards Japan or towards any other nation.
('82', 231, 2, 5, 394382) India only desires freedom from all alien domination.
('82', 231, 2, 6, 394436) But in this fight for freedom the Committee is of opinion that India while welcoming universal sympathy does not stand in need of foreign military aid.
('82', 231, 2, 7, 394588) India will attain her freedom through her non violent strength and will retain it likewise.
('82', 231, 2, 8, 394680) Therefore, the Committee hopes that Japan will not have any designs on India.
('82', 231, 2, 9, 394758) But if Japan attacks India and Britain makes no response to its appeal the Committee would expect all those who look to Congress for guidance to offer complete non violent non co operation to the Japanese forces and not render any assistance to them.
('82', 231, 2, 10, 395009) It is no part of the duty of those who are attacked to render any assistance to the attacker.
('82', 231, 2, 11, 395103) It is their duty to offer complete non co operation.
('82', 231, 2, 12, 395156) It is not difficult to understand the simple principle of non violent non co operation:
('82', 231, 3, 13, 395244) 1. We may not bend the knee to the aggressor nor obey any of his orders.
('82', 231, 4, 14, 395317) 2. We may not look to him for any favours nor fall to his bribes.
('82', 231, 4, 15, 395383) But we may not bear him any malice nor wish him ill.
('82', 231, 5, 16, 395436) 3. If he wishes to take possession of our fields we will refuse to give them up even if we have to die in the effort to resist him.
('82', 231, 6, 17, 395568) 4. If he is attacked by disease or is dying of thirst and seeks our aid we may not refuse it.
('82', 231, 7, 18, 395662) 5. In such places where the British and Japanese forces are fighting our non co operation will be fruitless and unnecessary.
('82', 231, 7, 19, 395787) At present our non co operation with the British Government is limited.
('82', 231, 7, 20, 395859) Were we to offer them complete non co operation when they are actually fighting, it would be tantamount to placing our country deliberately in Japanese hands.
('82', 231, 7, 21, 396018) Therefore not to put any obstacle in the way of the British forces will often be the only way of demonstrating our non co operation with the Japanese.
('82', 231, 7, 22, 396169) Neither may
('82', 232, 0, 1, 396181) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 233
('82', 232, 1, 2, 396224) we assist the British in any active manner.
('82', 232, 1, 3, 396268) If we can judge from their recent attitude, the British Government do not need any help from us beyond our non interference.
('82', 232, 1, 4, 396393) They desire our help only as slaves—a position we can never accept.
('82', 232, 1, 5, 396461) 1 It is necessary for the Committee to make a clear declaration in regard to the scorched earth policy.
('82', 232, 1, 6, 396565) If, in spite of our non violent resistance, any part of the country falls into Japanese hands we may not destroy our crops, water supply, etc.
('82', 232, 1, 7, 396708) if only because it will be our endeavour to regain them.
('82', 232, 1, 8, 396765) The destruction of war material is another matter and may under certain circumstances be a military necessity.
('82', 232, 1, 9, 396876) But it can never be the Congress policy to destroy what belongs to or is of use to the masses.
('82', 232, 2, 10, 396971) Whilst non co operation against the Japanese forces will necessarily be limited to a comparatively small number and must succeed if it is complete and genuine, the true building up of swaraj consists in the millions of India whole heartedly working the constructive programme.
('82', 232, 2, 11, 397248) Without it the whole nation cannot rise from its age long torpor.
('82', 232, 2, 12, 397314) Whether the British remain or not it is our duty always to wipe out unemployment, to bridge the gulf between rich and poor, to banish communal strife, to exorcise the demon of untouchability, to reform dacoits and save the people from them.
('82', 232, 2, 13, 397555) If crores of people do not take a living interest in this nation building work, freedom must remain a dream and unattainable by either non violence or violence.
('82', 232, 3, 14, 397716) FOREIGN SOLDIERS
('82', 232, 4, 15, 397733) The A.I.C.C. is of opinion that it is harmful to India’s interests and dangerous to the cause of India’s freedom to introduce foreign soldiers in India.
('82', 232, 4, 16, 397886) It therefore appeals to the British Government to remove these foreign legions and henceforth stop further introduction.
('82', 232, 4, 17, 398007) It is a crying shame to bring foreign troops in spite of India’s inexhaustible manpower and is a proof of the immorality that British Imperialism is.

('82', 232, 5, 19, 398217) 283 5, also
('82', 232, 6, 20, 398229) The Transfor of Power, 1942 7, Vol. II, pp.
('82', 232, 7, 21, 398273) 1 In the version reproduced in The Transfer of Power the words “a position we can never accept” form part only of the revised draft.

('82', 235, 4, 8, 401228) 288. QUESTION BOX
('82', 235, 5, 9, 401246) ARE YOU NOT INVITING JAPANESE?
('82', 235, 6, 10, 401277) Q. It is all very well for you to invite bravery, but are you not inviting the
('82', 235, 7, 11, 401356) Japanese to attack India by asking the British rulers to withdraw?
('82', 235, 8, 12, 401423) A. I am not.
('82', 235, 8, 13, 401436) I feel convinced that the British presence is the incentive for the Japanese attack.
('82', 235, 8, 14, 401521) If the British wisely decided to withdraw and leave India to manage her own affairs in the best way she could, the Japanese would be bound to reconsider their plans.
('82', 235, 8, 15, 401687) The very novelty of the British stroke will confound the Japanese, dissolve the subdued hatred against the British, and the atmosphere will be set up for the ending of an unnatural state of things that has dominated and choked Indian life.
('82', 235, 8, 16, 401927) As far as I can see the Japanese seem to have made their plans independently of Indian opinion.
('82', 235, 8, 17, 402023) They are not to be affected by any writing of mine.
('82', 235, 8, 18, 402075) But they will be confounded by the action I have advised the British to take.
('82', 235, 9, 19, 402153) EVACUATION
('82', 235, 10, 20, 402164) Q. You have advised evacuation from the cities of those who are not wanted for
('82', 235, 11, 21, 402243) service or other reasons.
('82', 235, 11, 22, 402269) 1 But what are those poor people to do who have no homes to
('82', 235, 12, 23, 402329) go to and who would be unwelcome wherever they go?
('82', 235, 13, 24, 402380) A. This is a real difficulty.
('82', 235, 13, 25, 402410) They must be provided for by the people of the provinces to which they belong.
('82', 235, 13, 26, 402489) If we are one nation, we
('82', 235, 14, 27, 402514) 1 Vide “Question Box”, sub title, “When Leaders Differ”, 13 4 1942.
('82', 236, 0, 1, 402582) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 237
('82', 236, 1, 2, 402625) should have no difficulty in providing for every contingency that may arise.
('82', 236, 1, 3, 402702) If we are to establish a new order of society, we can act from now.
('82', 236, 1, 4, 402770) I can only speak from the non violent angle and no other.
('82', 236, 1, 5, 402828) If the national mind is working in that direction, consciously or unconsciously individuals and institutions will, without fuss, be absorbing all such persons as you mention.
('82', 236, 1, 6, 403003) I know that the process is going on, but not on a scale large enough to be impressive.
('82', 236, 1, 7, 403090) No able bodied person should be put on charity; he should be given work enough to feed him properly.
('82', 236, 1, 8, 403191) This shifting of the population, if it is wisely done, must result in a silent re organization of villages.

('82', 237, 7, 11, 404117) 291. QUESTION BOX
('82', 237, 8, 12, 404135) NO NARROW PROVINCIALISM
('82', 237, 9, 13, 404159) Q. There are, in certain places, some people who have come from other
('82', 237, 10, 14, 404229) provinces but who have practically settled in those places.
('82', 237, 10, 15, 404289) There is already a feeling
('82', 237, 11, 16, 404316) in certain provinces that when time were good these people came from outside,
('82', 237, 12, 17, 404394) earned, and enjoyed themselves, but that when danger is drawing near and when their
('82', 237, 13, 18, 404478) help and assistance would be needed by the residents of the province, they are
('82', 237, 14, 19, 404557) thinking of fleeing to their ‘homes’ Should you not advise such people to stay where
('82', 237, 15, 20, 404642) they are and not to give vent any narrow provincialism?
('82', 237, 16, 21, 404698) A. This question has come to me in various forms.
('82', 237, 16, 22, 404748) It comes from Bengal and Assam.
('82', 237, 16, 23, 404780) Merchants from other provinces have settled there for generations.
('82', 237, 16, 24, 404847) Though they went to the respective provinces for their own sakes, they supplied a want, often useful.
('82', 237, 16, 25, 404949) There is no doubt that their sudden withdrawal must hit hard those who have been hitherto used to make their daily purchases from these merchants.
('82', 237, 16, 26, 405096) They cannot be easily and suddenly replaced, especially at a critical time like this.
('82', 237, 16, 27, 405182) there for these merchants to wind up their businesses would certainly amount to desertion of duty, if they do not before leaving, ensure the continuance of shops by proper substitute.
('82', 237, 16, 28, 405366) It would be a different thing if the customers themselves evacuated and the merchants had to follow.
('82', 237, 16, 29, 405467) The situation that faces
('82', 238, 0, 1, 405492) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 239
('82', 238, 1, 2, 405535) the country is so novel that no opinion or solution can claim infallibility, nor can judgment be pronounced without carefully weighing all the facts.
('82', 238, 1, 3, 405685) But it seems to me to be the duty of mercantile organizations to examine the situation and give guidance to the merchants affected.
('82', 238, 2, 4, 405817) NOT AN INCITEMENT
('82', 238, 3, 5, 405835) Q. You have written:“If the vast majority of Muslims regard themselves as a
('82', 238, 4, 6, 405911) separate nation .
('82', 238, 4, 7, 405929) no power on earth can compel them to think otherwise.
('82', 238, 5, 8, 405983) they want to partition India on that basis, they must have the partition, unless Hindus
('82', 238, 6, 9, 406071) want to fight against such a division.
('82', 238, 6, 10, 406110) So far as I can see such a preparation is silently
('82', 238, 7, 11, 406161) going on behalf of both parties.” 1
('82', 238, 8, 12, 406197) As far as the Muslims are concerned I can say with better knowledge than you
('82', 238, 9, 13, 406274) that there is no such preparation.
('82', 238, 9, 14, 406309) It would be foolish in the midst of the present
('82', 238, 10, 15, 406357) Armageddon.
('82', 238, 10, 16, 406369) But since you are apparently aware of the preparation to fight on the
('82', 238, 11, 17, 406439) part of Hindus, is it not criminal for you not to prevent your co religionists from this
('82', 238, 12, 18, 406528) suicidal activity?
('82', 238, 12, 19, 406547) Your article is both cowardly and mischievous; indeed it is an
('82', 238, 13, 20, 406610) incitement to the Hindus.
('82', 238, 14, 21, 406636) A. This is the mildest indictment I have picked up from many I have received.
('82', 238, 14, 22, 406714) Even from this much poison has been removed.
('82', 238, 14, 23, 406759) It is perhaps wise to notice some of the criticism to which I am exposed.
('82', 238, 14, 24, 406833) I must not mind it.
('82', 238, 14, 25, 406853) It has been my lot throughout my public career.
('82', 238, 14, 26, 406901) I suppose it is that of every public servant.
('82', 238, 14, 27, 406947) But when the criticism is ignorant, as this is, it harms the critic and the cause he espouses.
('82', 238, 14, 28, 407042) I take notice of it in the hope that sober men will use their influence to restrain ignorant criticism.
('82', 238, 14, 29, 407146) I have no special knowledge of the preparation on behalf of the Hindus.
('82', 238, 14, 30, 407218) All the knowledge I have is derived from the speeches of the leaders of both the parties and from the cuttings I receive from correspondents.
('82', 238, 14, 31, 407360) They are proof positive of the preparations to which I have referred.
('82', 238, 14, 32, 407430) But if what you say is right, in spite of the writings in the Muslim Press, no preparation on one side alone can possibly provoke strife.
('82', 238, 14, 33, 407568) It takes two to make a quarrel.
('82', 238, 14, 34, 407600) You would be right, if I did not do so, in saying that it would be criminal on my part not to prevent my ‘‘co religionists from this suicidal activity”.

('82', 239, 3, 11, 408391) 292. SCORCHED EARTH POLICY AGAIN
('82', 239, 4, 12, 408424) Thus writes a correspondent:
('82', 239, 5, 13, 408453) The controversy on the scorched earth policy has had reference to what
('82', 239, 6, 14, 408524) the people have to do when their fields are touched by the ‘enemy’.
('82', 239, 6, 15, 408592) That may
('82', 239, 7, 16, 408601) or may not happen.
('82', 239, 7, 17, 408620) But what about the destruction that is going on of crops,
('82', 239, 8, 18, 408678) wells, tanks, houses, boats, cycles, etc., in the name of preparation for war?
('82', 239, 9, 19, 408757) The people are summarily driven out of their villages and houses in cities.
('82', 239, 10, 20, 408833) you will suffer this destruction, then how can you oppose destruction to
('82', 239, 11, 21, 408906) prevent destruction?
('82', 239, 11, 22, 408927) This is a very difficult question.
('82', 239, 11, 23, 408962) The destruction that is going on is certain.
('82', 239, 11, 24, 409007) The destruction that the enemy may work or which the receding portion of the population affected may have to do is problematical.
('82', 239, 11, 25, 409137) And, in any case, such destruction would be nothing, even if it overtook us, compared to the crores already drained from the country for warding off a threatened danger.
('82', 239, 11, 26, 409307) Money taken through taxation has not been felt so keenly as is the direct deprivation of thousands of homesteads as in Feni.
('82', 239, 11, 27, 409432) No promise of compensation can be any comfort for the dispossession of the present tenements.
('82', 239, 11, 28, 409526) To the poor people it is like taking away their bodies.
('82', 239, 11, 29, 409582) The dispossession of the country boats is almost like that of the tenements.
('82', 239, 11, 30, 409659) To deprive the people in East Bengal of their boats is like cutting off a vital limb.
('82', 239, 11, 31, 409745) I wrote almost in defence of the procedure adopted by the authorities in Feni.
('82', 239, 11, 32, 409824) I have polite but angry protests against my endorsement.
('82', 239, 11, 33, 409881) The correspondents tell me that I know nothing of the conditions of life in East Bengal.
('82', 239, 11, 34, 409970) I cannot plead guilty
('82', 240, 0, 1, 409992) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 241
('82', 240, 1, 2, 410035) to the charge.
('82', 240, 1, 3, 410050) Only I felt that people must be asked to resign themselves to the inevitable.
('82', 240, 1, 4, 410128) Later information from Feni compels a revision of the attitude I had adopted.
('82', 240, 1, 5, 410206) I had assumed considerate action by the authorities in the face of the impending danger.
('82', 240, 1, 6, 410295) But I must defer final judgement.
('82', 240, 1, 7, 410329) The authorities are reported to be carrying on an investigation.
('82', 240, 1, 8, 410394) I hope it will be comprehensive.
('82', 240, 2, 9, 410427) Certain risks have to be taken even when danger overtakes us.
('82', 240, 2, 10, 410489) Thus people cannot be asked or advised to starve or die of thirst for fear of the Japanese helping themselves to the people’s provisions or water.
('82', 240, 2, 11, 410636) They may fight them to prevent their use, but they must risk their loss and not die before their death in order to prevent their use by the Japanese forces.
('82', 240, 3, 12, 410793) It is time I came to the last and the most vital part of the question.
('82', 240, 3, 13, 410864) As an out and out war resister, is it my duty to ask the affected people to resist, non violently of course, the deprivation of their holdings including boats?
('82', 240, 3, 14, 411024) But my very non violence has deterred me from offering opposition to the point of embarrassment.
('82', 240, 3, 15, 411121) Whether embarrassment through opposition in Feni would have been avoidable or not is a question of fact on which I cannot yet pronounce opinion.
('82', 240, 3, 16, 411266) I would hesitate up to the last moment.
('82', 240, 3, 17, 411306) I can only hope that the authorities will find a way whereby they can avoid distress such as has been caused in Feni.

('82', 240, 7, 21, 411507) In the Ashram, let no one from among us eat to please the palate, let us eat to live.

('82', 240, 7, 25, 411765) Generally, no one should eat both rice and wheat, but if someone needs both, he or she should be given both.

('82', 243, 2, 4, 414988) 298. TRAVANCORE
('82', 243, 3, 5, 415004) In spite of the high percentage of education among men and women in Travancore, there is no such thing as real liberty in that unhappy land.
('82', 243, 3, 6, 415145) Shri Thanu Pillai, the President of the State Congress, and Shri Ramachandran, a member of the Executive of the Travancore State Congress, have been sentenced to six months’ rigorous imprisonment for defying the ban on meetings of the Congress.
('82', 243, 3, 7, 415390) If bans are imposed on public meetings because they are held under the auspices of certain organizations which ask for responsible government, they have to be defied.
('82', 243, 3, 8, 415557) The leaders of such movements cannot stultify themselves by entirely gagging themselves.
('82', 243, 3, 9, 415646) It is too great a price to pay for nominal liberty.
('82', 243, 3, 10, 415698) Shri T. Pillai and Shri Ramachandran will serve the cause better through their imprisonment than they will by submitting to gagging orders.
('82', 243, 3, 11, 415838) Here is Shri Ramachandran’s statement before the Magistrate:
('82', 243, 4, 12, 415899) There was first of all a communiqué issued by the Chief Secretary to the
('82', 243, 5, 13, 415972) Government of Travancore, in which he had said that the celebration of the
('82', 243, 6, 14, 416047) All India States’ Peoples’ Day would not be permitted.
('82', 243, 6, 15, 416102) This was followed by
('82', 243, 7, 16, 416123) an order of the District Magistrate, Trivandrum, served on some of us
('82', 243, 8, 17, 416193) prohibiting the celebration of the States’ Peoples’ Day.
('82', 243, 8, 18, 416250) My offence relates to
('82', 243, 9, 19, 416272) this order of the District Magistrate.
('82', 243, 9, 20, 416311) In that order it was made out that, if such
('82', 243, 10, 21, 416355) a meeting was held and speeches made, there was the likelihood of a breach of
('82', 243, 11, 22, 416433) the peace in Trivandrum.
('82', 243, 11, 23, 416458) It further stated that, if the meeting was held and
('82', 243, 12, 24, 416510) speeches made, there would come about an estrangement between the people
('82', 243, 13, 25, 416583) and the Government.
('82', 243, 13, 26, 416603) Immediately on receipt of this prohibitory order Shri
('82', 243, 14, 27, 416657) Pattom Thanu Pillai and myself wrote a letter to the District Magistrate, in
('82', 243, 15, 28, 416734) which we made it clear that this meeting was to be held not for the purpose of
('82', 243, 16, 29, 416813) initiating an agitation but that it was just in response to an all India
('82', 243, 17, 30, 416886) observance.
('82', 243, 17, 31, 416898) The meeting was to be held not in a public place but inside the
('82', 243, 18, 32, 416962) Congress House premises.
('82', 243, 18, 33, 416987) We made it clear also that the apprehension of a
('82', 243, 19, 34, 417036) breach of the peace was absolutely unfounded.
('82', 243, 19, 35, 417082) We had said that, if in spite of
('82', 244, 0, 1, 417115) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 245
('82', 244, 1, 2, 417158) this clarification the meeting was prohibited, we would be violating the order.
('82', 244, 2, 3, 417238) This explanatory letter did not elicit any reply from the District Magistrate.
('82', 244, 3, 4, 417317) So the meeting was held.
('82', 244, 3, 5, 417342) After Shri Thanu Pillai’s arrest I took charge of the
('82', 244, 4, 6, 417396) meeting and spoke for an hour.
('82', 244, 4, 7, 417427) I must observe here that I had never seen a
('82', 244, 5, 8, 417471) quieter meeting in my life.
('82', 244, 5, 9, 417499) The position we took, therefore, viz., that there
('82', 244, 6, 10, 417549) would be absolutely no breach of the peace, was confirmed by the meeting
('82', 244, 7, 11, 417622) itself.
('82', 244, 7, 12, 417630) The second point in the District Magistrate’s order was that the meeting
('82', 244, 8, 13, 417703) would bring about estrangement between the Government and the people.
('82', 244, 9, 14, 417773) my view this certainly was not one of the results of the meeting.
('82', 244, 9, 15, 417839) It was,
('82', 244, 10, 16, 417847) therefore, proved beyond any shadow of doubt that the District Magistrate’s
('82', 244, 11, 17, 417923) apprehensions were absolutely unfounded.
('82', 244, 11, 18, 417964) Therefore, though I am technically
('82', 244, 12, 19, 417999) guilty— because I certainly did violate the District Magistrate’s order—the
('82', 244, 13, 20, 418075) District Magistrate and not I was in the wrong.
('82', 244, 13, 21, 418123) I am entitled, therefore, to an
('82', 244, 14, 22, 418155) honourable acquittal.
('82', 244, 14, 23, 418177) This technical guilt I had to take upon myself for the
('82', 244, 15, 24, 418232) simple reason that I was not going to be persuaded not to do a thing which I
('82', 244, 16, 25, 418309) considered wholly right and which my self respect dictated that I should do.

('82', 248, 15, 19, 422999) 307. STATEMENT ON HINDUSTANI 1
('82', 248, 16, 20, 423030) May 2, 1942
('82', 248, 17, 21, 423042) The work for the propagation of the national language among the people has brought the realization that what the Congress calls ‘Hindustani’ is a simplified blend of Urdu and Hindi.
('82', 248, 17, 22, 423224) This is the
('82', 248, 18, 23, 423236) 1 This was signed by Gandhiji, Rajendra Prasad and others.
('82', 249, 0, 1, 423295) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 249, 1, 2, 423337) language that is spoken and understood in North India and is understood and used in a large measure in other parts of India too.
('82', 249, 1, 3, 423466) Hindi and Urdu, which are the literary forms of this language, are drifting apart more and more.
('82', 249, 1, 4, 423563) The need is for these two forms to be brought closer to each other and to propagate Hindustani as the national language in those parts of the country where other languages are spoken.
('82', 249, 1, 5, 423747) We therefore propose to establish an association which will simultaneously propagate both simple Hindi and simple Urdu and every member of which shall know both these forms as well as both the scripts of Hindustani and be able to employ either whenever the need arises.
('82', 249, 1, 6, 424017) This will lead, first, to an easy and clear language coming into use all over the country and, secondly, to a literature being developed in the same simple language, capable of giving expression to sophisticated thoughts and sentiments.
('82', 249, 1, 7, 424254) In pursuance of this objective we are this day, the 2nd May, 1942, convening an association to be called the Hindustani Prachar Sabha.
('82', 249, 2, 8, 424389) [From Hindi]

('82', 249, 6, 18, 425153) Q. The Harijan Sevak Sangh is looked upon as a part of the Congress.
('82', 249, 6, 19, 425222) But very
('82', 249, 7, 20, 425231) 1 For the aims and objects of Hindustani Prachar Sabha, vide Appendix “Section in the Constitution of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha defining its Aims and Functions”, before 1 6 1942

('82', 250, 1, 2, 425455) few Congressmen are Harijan workers.
('82', 250, 2, 3, 425492) A. The Sangh is not a part of the Congress.
('82', 250, 2, 4, 425536) It was the outcome of the fast I undertook in 1932 when I was in jail.
('82', 250, 2, 5, 425607) 1 The meeting of Hindus drawn from every class, which was held under the presidentship of Pandit Malaviyaji and which gave birth to the Sangh, deliberately decided to keep the organization separate from the Congress and non political.
('82', 250, 2, 6, 425842) It was this quality of the Sangh that enabled Sheth G.D. Birla to become its President and Shri Thakkar Bapa its Secretary.
('82', 250, 2, 7, 425966) Nevertheless there are and ought to be many Congressmen in the Sangh, because practically all reformers are drawn into the Congress fold.
('82', 250, 2, 8, 426104) But it is true that there are plenty of non Congress persons in the Sangh.
('82', 250, 2, 9, 426179) It is also true that those Congressmen who are only interested in politics do not come into it.
('82', 250, 2, 10, 426275) It is, therefore, sometimes wrongly thought that Congressmen do not take an interest in the Sangh.
('82', 250, 2, 11, 426374) It is the duty of every Congressman to remove untouchability, root and branch, from his life.
('82', 250, 3, 12, 426468) Q. Harijan service has really developed into mere Harijan uplift.
('82', 250, 3, 13, 426534) Practically no
('82', 250, 4, 14, 426549) work is done among caste Hindus for the removal of untouchability.
('82', 250, 4, 15, 426616) What is the
('82', 250, 5, 16, 426628) remedy for this?
('82', 250, 6, 17, 426645) A. Experience shows that propaganda among caste Hindus can only be successfully carried out by influential persons whose word carried weight with the general public.
('82', 250, 6, 18, 426811) Such persons are hard to find.
('82', 250, 6, 19, 426842) But it is within the capacity of every Harijan worker to carry on mute propaganda.
('82', 250, 6, 20, 426925) Our caste Hindu workers are often satisfied with mere uplift work among the Harijans, which is not sufficient.
('82', 250, 6, 21, 427036) Many workers, while they do not observe untouchability themselves, are unable even to convert their own families.
('82', 250, 6, 22, 427150) How then can they influence the outside world?
('82', 250, 6, 23, 427197) Moreover it is my confirmed opinion that every Harijan worker has to make it a point to beg for even one pice for Harijans from those caste Hindus with whom he comes in contact.
('82', 250, 6, 24, 427375) If all devoted themselves, heart and soul, to this task, very good results would ensue.
('82', 250, 7, 25, 427463) Q. Should not the Sangh take upon itself the service of those Harijans who
('82', 250, 8, 26, 427538) have been converted to Christianity or Islam and are yet treated as untouchables?
('82', 250, 9, 27, 427620) 1 Vide “Interview to the Press”, 20 9 1932.
('82', 251, 0, 1, 427664) 252 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 251, 1, 2, 427706) we not out to remove untouchability root and branch and therefore help all who come
('82', 251, 2, 3, 427790) under its sway?
('82', 251, 3, 4, 427806) A. This question has already been answered in the columns of Harijan but must bear repetition so long as it is raised.
('82', 251, 3, 5, 427925) The moment untouchability is utterly banished from Hindu society it will, ipso facto, disappear from elsewhere too.
('82', 251, 3, 6, 428041) Whatever the merits or demerits of the case, it is clear that our interference with converts will be the cause of strife with Muslims and Christians.
('82', 251, 3, 7, 428191) Such converts have either broken off all contacts with, or they have been in their turn boycotted by, Hindus.
('82', 251, 3, 8, 428301) They have thrown in their lot with other sects whose leaders will not allow them to maintain their old contacts.
('82', 251, 3, 9, 428414) Hence the H.S.S. quite rightly decided from its inception to confine its area of work to Harijans who had not left the Hindu fold.
('82', 251, 3, 10, 428545) A convert, having left his original fold, is no longer guided or controlled by it.
('82', 251, 4, 11, 428628) Q. What should be the attitude of the Sangh if Harijan boys wish to enlist in
('82', 251, 5, 12, 428706) the army?
('82', 251, 6, 13, 428716) A. They should be allowed to do so.
('82', 251, 6, 14, 428752) They may not be controlled by the Congress policy or ahimsa.
('82', 251, 6, 15, 428813) They must be given absolute freedom of choice.
('82', 251, 7, 16, 428860) Q. Harijans are of opinion that caste Hindus who are sympathetic to their cause
('82', 251, 8, 17, 428940) should not use those temples where they are not allowed entry.
('82', 251, 9, 18, 429003) A. They are right.
('82', 251, 9, 19, 429022) It is the bounden duty of Harijan workers not to go where Harijans are not allowed and likewise to dissuade caste Hindus.
('82', 251, 10, 20, 429144) Q. Harijans are legally entitled to send their children to many educational

('82', 251, 11, 22, 429274) But public sentiment still
('82', 251, 12, 23, 429301) militates against this being put into practice.
('82', 251, 12, 24, 429349) Should Harijans resort to the law courts
('82', 251, 13, 25, 429390) for justice in these matters or wait patiently until the caste Hindus are converted?
('82', 251, 14, 26, 429475) A. Where there is no danger of violence being done to them, the Harijans should exercise their legal right and where necessary resort to law courts.
('82', 251, 14, 27, 429624) Harijan workers must continue agitation among caste Hindus and not rest content with mere legal rights.
('82', 251, 15, 28, 429728) Q. Is it not essential to reform the insanitary methods employed by sweepers
('82', 251, 16, 29, 429805) for cleaning latrines and scavenging?
('82', 251, 17, 30, 429843) A. It is most necessary.
('82', 251, 17, 31, 429868) What is more, until this is done the
('82', 252, 0, 1, 429905) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 253
('82', 252, 1, 2, 429948) condition of sweepers will remain pitiable.
('82', 252, 1, 3, 429992) To this end it is the duty of Harijan workers and caste Hindus to do sweepers’ work themselves.
('82', 252, 1, 4, 430088) No caste Hindu will employ the methods used by sweepers.
('82', 252, 1, 5, 430145) He will do the work scientifically.
('82', 252, 1, 6, 430181) For example, he will never remove excreta in a basket or carry it on his head; he will cover excreta with dry earth and remove it in a metal vessel.
('82', 252, 1, 7, 430330) He will avoid touching dirt with his hands as far as possible; he will clean the vessels with water and a rod; he will bathe immediately after doing the work; he will wear special clothes when scavenging.
('82', 252, 1, 8, 430535) These reforms do not cost much.
('82', 252, 1, 9, 430567) They require intelligence, hard work and love of an ideal.
('82', 252, 1, 10, 430626) We may not relegate sweepers’ work to one particular class.
('82', 252, 1, 11, 430686) Therefore all should learn it in the same way as cooking.
('82', 252, 1, 12, 430744) Each person should be his own Sweeper.
('82', 252, 1, 13, 430783) If this ideal were to be put into practice in society, the miserable condition of sweepers would at once be rectified.

('82', 253, 8, 11, 431917) STATES AND THEIR PEOPLE
('82', 253, 9, 12, 431941) I have suggested in these columns that the people of the States should remain calm and so far as possible not precipitate a clash, 2 as events are shaping themselves in spite of us.
('82', 253, 9, 13, 432123) But there is a limit to every such proposal.
('82', 253, 9, 14, 432168) In Travancore, Mysore and Jodhpur things seem to have gone beyond endurance.
('82', 253, 10, 15, 432245) I have already referred to Travancore where two of its best workers 3 have been cast into prison for the simple reason that they are too public spirited to submit to autocracy.
('82', 253, 11, 16, 432422) The same thing is happening in Mysore though in a slightly different manner.
('82', 253, 11, 17, 432499) The cause is identical.
('82', 253, 11, 18, 432523) The Mysore State Congress must not be tolerated.
('82', 253, 11, 19, 432572) I know how the members have tried to placate authority.
('82', 253, 11, 20, 432628) They have refrained from raising large issues save that they must keep the goal of liberty before the Mysoreans.
('82', 253, 12, 21, 432741) And now comes serious news from Jodhpur.
('82', 253, 12, 22, 432782) There, as in the other States, the local Parishad people have tried to work in co

('82', 254, 1, 2, 433145) operation with authority.
('82', 254, 1, 3, 433171) They have raised no awkward questions.
('82', 254, 1, 4, 433210) But the Rajputana States, like many others, have many jagirdars who are co sharers with the Princes and derive authority from them.
('82', 254, 1, 5, 433342) They may be termed States within States.
('82', 254, 1, 6, 433383) These have no law governing them.

('82', 254, 1, 8, 433468) The Princes are ever afraid of them.

('82', 254, 1, 10, 433618) The result is that the people within these jagirdaris are the worst off in the Indian hierarchy.

('82', 254, 2, 16, 434383) OPIUM ADDICTS
('82', 254, 3, 17, 434397) A correspondent writes as follows:
('82', 254, 4, 18, 434432) I do not know whether you are aware that in Rajputana (Marwar) the
('82', 254, 5, 19, 434499) inhabitants are terrible opium addicts.
('82', 254, 5, 20, 434539) A wedding or death or any ceremonial
('82', 254, 6, 21, 434576) occasion necessitates the offering of opium to the visitors.
('82', 254, 6, 22, 434637) It may even mean
('82', 254, 7, 23, 434654) the pawning of goods or mortgaging of property, but the opium has to be
('82', 254, 8, 24, 434726) offered.
('82', 254, 8, 25, 434735) It is quite an ordinary matter for a person to take 1 1/2 or 2 tolas of
('82', 254, 9, 26, 434807) opium per day and sometimes even more.
('82', 254, 9, 27, 434846) I know of some who can swallow as
('82', 254, 10, 28, 434880) much as five.
('82', 254, 10, 29, 434894) When my father died I went home.
('82', 254, 10, 30, 434927) A Brahmin friend came to
('82', 254, 11, 31, 434952) condole.

('82', 254, 12, 33, 435029) special box.
('82', 254, 12, 34, 435042) There were three tolas in it.
('82', 254, 12, 35, 435072) The Brahmin said he would help
('82', 254, 13, 36, 435103) himself.
('82', 254, 13, 37, 435112) To my astonishment he emptied the entire contents on the palm of
('82', 254, 14, 38, 435177) his hand and swallowed them.
('82', 254, 14, 39, 435206) Having done so he said he was not satisfied.
('82', 254, 15, 40, 435251) When I asked him how much was sufficient he replied ‘four tolas’!
('82', 254, 16, 41, 435317) course, if opium eaters do not get their dope at the proper time, they are no

('82', 256, 0, 1, 437690) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 257
('82', 256, 1, 2, 437733) impressions of the first interview with him after the declaration of war.
('82', 256, 1, 3, 437807) I have nothing to withdraw, nothing to repent of.
('82', 256, 1, 4, 437857) I remain the same friend today of the British that I was then.
('82', 256, 1, 5, 437920) I have not a trace of hatred in me towards them.
('82', 256, 1, 6, 437969) But I have never been blind to their limitations as I have not been to their great virtues.
('82', 256, 2, 7, 438061) I do not deny the existence of hatred among the people at large, nor its increase with the march of events.
('82', 256, 2, 8, 438169) But I claim that my national prescription has kept it under subjection and even sterilized it to an extent.
('82', 256, 3, 9, 438277) I am convinced, therefore, that the time has come during the war, not after it, for the British and the Indians to be reconciled to complete separation from each other.
('82', 256, 3, 10, 438446) That way and that way alone lies the safety of both and, shall I say, the world.
('82', 256, 3, 11, 438527) I see with the naked eye that the estrangement is growing.
('82', 256, 3, 12, 438586) Every act of the British Government is being interpreted, and I think rightly, as being in its own interest and for its own safety.
('82', 256, 3, 13, 438718) There is no such thing as joint common interest.
('82', 256, 3, 14, 438767) To take the extreme case, a British victory over the Japanese will not mean a victory for India.
('82', 256, 3, 15, 438864) But that is not a near event.
('82', 256, 3, 16, 438894) Meanwhile the introduction of foreign soldiers, the admitted inequalities of treatment of Indian and European evacuees, and the manifestly overbearing behaviour of the troops are adding to the distrust of British intentions and declarations.
('82', 256, 3, 17, 439136) I feel that they cannot all of a sudden change their traditional nature.
('82', 256, 3, 18, 439209) Racial superiority is treated not as a vice but as a virtue.
('82', 256, 3, 19, 439270) This is true not only in India; it is equally true in Africa, it is true in Burma and Ceylon.
('82', 256, 3, 20, 439364) These countries could not be held otherwise than by assertion of race superiority.
('82', 256, 4, 21, 439447) This is a drastic disease requiring a drastic remedy.
('82', 256, 4, 22, 439501) I have pointed the remedy—complete and immediate orderly withdrawal of the British from India at least, in reality and properly from all non European possessions.
('82', 256, 4, 23, 439664) It will be the bravest and the cleanest act of the British people.
('82', 256, 4, 24, 439731) It will at once put the Allied cause on a completely moral basis and may even lead to a most honourable peace between the warring nations.
('82', 256, 4, 25, 439870) And the clean end of imperialism is likely to be the end of Fascism and Nazism.
('82', 256, 4, 26, 439950) The suggested action will certainly blunt the edge of Fascism and Nazism which are an offshoot of imperialism.

('82', 257, 1, 2, 440103) British distress cannot be relieved by nationalist India’s aid in the manner suggested by the writer.

('82', 257, 4, 20, 441408) 313. QUESTION BOX
('82', 257, 5, 21, 441426) BARREN COWS
('82', 257, 6, 22, 441438) Q. Why may not work such as ploughing or grinding corn be taken from barren
('82', 257, 7, 23, 441514) Would that not be one way of preventing their going to the slaughter house?
('82', 257, 8, 24, 441590) A. This question used to be much discussed at one time owing to the enthusiasm of a Punjabi who used to advocate the use even of milch cows for draft purposes.
('82', 257, 8, 25, 441750) He used to claim that they would yield more and richer milk for the exercise given to them.
('82', 257, 8, 26, 441842) Anyway my devotion to the cow does not preclude me from taking such labour as she can perform without the slightest detriment to her body.

('82', 257, 8, 28, 442056) I would welcome the use of barren cows for gentle labour, if only it
('82', 258, 0, 1, 442125) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 259
('82', 258, 1, 2, 442168) would make people more considerate than they are towards the other animals.
('82', 258, 2, 3, 442244) FROM THE FRYING PAN?
('82', 258, 3, 4, 442265) Q. You advise evacuation 1 of cities likely to be bombed and migration to the
('82', 258, 4, 5, 442343) villages.

('82', 263, 9, 23, 450625) 322. MYSORE
('82', 263, 10, 24, 450637) Reference has already been made in these columns about the Mysore Government’s repressive measures against the State Congress.
('82', 263, 10, 25, 450764) 1 Now comes the news of a worse tragedy in the shape of a police charge at Bhadravati resulting in three deaths including a child three years old, from firing by the police on an unarmed crowd.
('82', 263, 10, 26, 450958) I do not wish to enter into the details.
('82', 263, 10, 27, 450999) According to the Congress version the whole tragedy arose out of a peaceful labour demonstration.
('82', 263, 10, 28, 451097) There is a suggestion on the Government side that the firing had to be resorted to because the crowd had attacked the police station in Bhadravati.
('82', 263, 10, 29, 451245) The President of the Congress denies the charge and demands an inquiry.
('82', 263, 10, 30, 451317) It will be worthless unless it is admittedly impartial.
('82', 263, 10, 31, 451373) If the crowd had attacked the police station, what was the cause?
('82', 263, 10, 32, 451439) If the crowd was non violent, was the firing a mere wanton
('82', 263, 11, 33, 451498) 1 Vide “Notes”, sub title, “States and Their People”, 4 5 1942.
('82', 264, 0, 1, 451562) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 265
('82', 264, 1, 2, 451605) awe inspiring process?
('82', 264, 1, 3, 451628) In either case the people must learn the art of being killed, and if they are non violent, without any reason therefore save for their love of liberty.
('82', 264, 1, 4, 451780) It is a duty then to face death as cheerfully as we face imprisonment.
('82', 264, 1, 5, 451851) Indeed, I do not know that such a swift ending is not more welcome than the prolonged agony that jail life sometimes becomes.
('82', 264, 1, 6, 451977) As the struggle becomes wider and more earnest and more real, imprisonment is bound to be, as past experience teaches, increasingly hard to bear.
('82', 264, 1, 7, 452123) Death for a brave and strong willed man will then be a welcome relief.

('82', 264, 2, 9, 452248) 323. QUESTION BOX

('82', 264, 4, 11, 452286) Q. Maulana Saheb has made what I consider a very wise and patriotic
('82', 264, 5, 12, 452354) suggestion that the Congress Working Committee will nominate five representatives

('82', 264, 7, 14, 452518) trust it will commend itself to you.

('82', 264, 10, 20, 453052) INGENIOUS METHOD
('82', 264, 11, 21, 453069) Q. Your advocacy of the learning of Urdu as part of the national language
('82', 264, 12, 22, 453143) which you have called Hindustani is all very well.
('82', 264, 12, 23, 453194) What do you say to the propaganda
('82', 264, 13, 24, 453228) that is being carried on in the Nizam’s Dominions on behalf of Urdu?
('82', 264, 13, 25, 453297) Here is the first
('82', 264, 14, 26, 453315) question in a Telugu examination paper:
('82', 264, 15, 27, 453355) “If for the purposes of Federation a common language for India is
('82', 264, 16, 28, 453421) indispensable and the case of Hindustani is strong enough, then it seems to me
('82', 264, 17, 29, 453500) that as far as this University is concerned it should immediately make Urdu its
('82', 264, 18, 30, 453580) medium of instruction especially when it happens to be the mother tongue of
('82', 265, 0, 1, 453656) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 265, 1, 2, 453698) this province.
('82', 265, 1, 3, 453713) Those who would wait till it grows richer are sadly mistaken
('82', 265, 2, 4, 453774) and argue in a circle.
('82', 265, 2, 5, 453797) It will remain poor as long as the universities make no
('82', 265, 3, 6, 453853) use of it in teaching all branches of knowledge.”
('82', 265, 4, 7, 453903) Remember that Telugu and not Urdu is the mother tongue of the majority of the
('82', 265, 5, 8, 453981) people in this part of the country.
('82', 265, 5, 9, 454017) What do you say to the ingenious method adopted
('82', 265, 6, 10, 454065) of carrying on pro Urdu propaganda through examination papers?
('82', 265, 7, 11, 454128) A. I admit that the method adopted is both ingenious and strange.
('82', 265, 7, 12, 454194) An examination paper is hardly a vehicle for propaganda on a question on which sharp division of opinion prevails.
('82', 265, 7, 13, 454309) I agree that Urdu is not the mother tongue of the people of H.E.H. the Nizam’s Dominions.
('82', 265, 7, 14, 454399) What proportion of the population knows Telugu I do not know.
('82', 265, 7, 15, 454461) My notion of an all India speech does not involve the displacement of the great provincial languages, but its knowledge is meant to be an addition to that of the provincial speech.
('82', 265, 7, 16, 454642) Nor do I expect that the millions will ever learn the all India speech.
('82', 265, 7, 17, 454714) It will be learnt by the politically and those who have inter provincial connections.
('82', 265, 7, 18, 454800) Indeed a correspondent suggests that in the place of an all India speech I should advocate the learning of the languages of neighbouring provinces.
('82', 265, 7, 19, 454948) Thus he says:
('82', 265, 8, 20, 454962) It is far more useful for the Assamese to know Bengali than Hindi or Urdu
('82', 265, 9, 21, 455036) and now according to you Hindi and Urdu.
('82', 265, 9, 22, 455077) If we had not the intolerable burden of learning English not merely as a second language but as a language through which all higher instruction is imparted to us, we should find it child’s play to learn our neighbours’ speech and certainly learn the all India speech for all India contacts.
('82', 265, 9, 23, 455368) In my opinion a boy or girl lacks culture and accomplishment, if he or she does not know half a dozen languages of India.
('82', 265, 9, 24, 455490) It is a sure sign of brain fag on the part of English knowing Indians when they tremble at the very thought of learning a language other than English, not excluding even their mother’s speech.
('82', 265, 9, 25, 455683) For the majority of objectors are English knowing Indians.
('82', 265, 9, 26, 455742) I have found no difficulty about the Ashram inmates learning Urdu in addition to Hindi.
('82', 265, 9, 27, 455830) And I know that in South Africa the Tamil labourers could speak Telugu and vice versa, and they had a working knowledge of Hindi.
('82', 265, 9, 28, 455960) No one had told them that they should learn Hindi.
('82', 265, 9, 29, 456011) Somehow or other they knew intuitively that they should know Hindi.
('82', 265, 9, 30, 456079) Of course
('82', 266, 0, 1, 456089) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 267
('82', 266, 1, 2, 456132) they were no scholars, but for mutual intercourse they picked up what was necessary.
('82', 266, 1, 3, 456217) They picked up also the speech of their neighbours, the Zulus.
('82', 266, 1, 4, 456280) They could not carry on their business, if they did not.
('82', 266, 1, 5, 456337) Thus most Indians knew besides their mother tongues two more Indian languages, Zulu, and a smattering of even English.
('82', 266, 1, 6, 456456) Needless to say many of them wrote no language, and most could write only ungrammatically their own mother tongues.
('82', 266, 1, 7, 456572) The moral of this is obvious.
('82', 266, 2, 8, 456602) If you dispense with the script, you pick up your neighbour’s language without effort and without difficulty, and if you are fresh and the brain is not wearied, you can learn as many scripts as you wish without any difficulty.
('82', 266, 2, 9, 456829) The study is any day interesting and stimulating.
('82', 266, 2, 10, 456879) The study of languages is an art and valuable at that.
