('82', 266, 4, 12, 456988) 324. QUESTION BOX
('82', 266, 5, 13, 457006) INTELLECTUAL CONVICTION
('82', 266, 6, 14, 457030) Q. Intellectually I am convinced that non violence is the only solution of
('82', 266, 7, 15, 457105) quarrels between man and man.
('82', 266, 7, 16, 457135) But by nature I cannot but react violently to acts of
('82', 266, 8, 17, 457189) hostility to my country or myself.
('82', 266, 8, 18, 457224) So I am unable to be content with non violent
('82', 266, 9, 19, 457270) resistance only against the Japanese.
('82', 266, 9, 20, 457308) I feel that, in addition to whatever I may be able
('82', 266, 10, 21, 457359) to do by way of non violent resistance, I should also do my utmost to help the war
('82', 266, 11, 22, 457442) effort against them.
('82', 266, 11, 23, 457463) They have no right to invade my country even though it is in
('82', 266, 12, 24, 457524) British hands and not ours.
('82', 266, 12, 25, 457552) But when I think of helping the war effort, my intellectual
('82', 266, 13, 26, 457612) conviction of non violence does not allow me to do so with peace of mind.
('82', 266, 14, 27, 457686) A. Your difficulty is a common difficulty.
('82', 266, 14, 28, 457729) But if you have real intellectual conviction, it will overcome your nature which is nothing but habit.
('82', 266, 14, 29, 457832) Your conviction should tell you that non violence is a force infinitely superior to violence.
('82', 266, 14, 30, 457926) Hence you do not need to rely upon violent assistance.
('82', 266, 14, 31, 457981) Moreover you are labouring under a fallacy.
('82', 266, 14, 32, 458025) Why do you say that the Japanese have no right to invade your country although it is in foreigners’ hands?
('82', 266, 14, 33, 458132) In the first place, the country is not yours while it is in others’ hands.
('82', 266, 14, 34, 458207) You cannot do what you like with it.
('82', 266, 14, 35, 458244) The foreigners can and do.
('82', 266, 14, 36, 458271) Secondly, if the Japanese have
('82', 267, 0, 1, 458302) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 267, 1, 2, 458344) enmity against your master, they have every right to attack what your master possesses.
('82', 267, 1, 3, 458432) We are not examining here the correctness of Japan’s conduct in going to war against Great Britain.
('82', 267, 1, 4, 458532) I am simply pointing out what seems to me to be your mental confusion.
('82', 267, 1, 5, 458603) The proper course for you is to ask the wrongful possessor to vacate your country.
('82', 267, 1, 6, 458686) When he has done it you will have the choice between violence and non violence against the Japanese attack, if it comes.
('82', 267, 1, 7, 458807) But the thing is not so simple as I have put it.
('82', 267, 1, 8, 458856) Your difficulty is real.
('82', 267, 1, 9, 458881) You feel that you cannot defend your country.
('82', 267, 1, 10, 458927) You have lost it.
('82', 267, 1, 11, 458945) The English can, if you help them.
('82', 267, 1, 12, 458980) If the English vacate the country, the Japanese are much more likely to attack undefended India if only for strategic purposes, and you will be utterly helpless against the invading host.
('82', 267, 1, 13, 459168) Therefore, seeing that the English are in India and they can defend, why not make common cause with them and answer the impendingattack?
('82', 267, 1, 14, 459305) After victory, have they not said, they would go away if they are not wanted?
('82', 267, 1, 15, 459383) This, I expect, is your argument.
('82', 267, 1, 16, 459417) In my opinion it is only plausible.
('82', 267, 1, 17, 459453) The British do not want your help on your terms, as witness the failure of the Cripps mission.
('82', 267, 1, 18, 459548) They want it on their terms.
('82', 267, 1, 19, 459577) If, therefore, victory is achieved, the British hold will be ever so much stronger than before.
('82', 267, 1, 20, 459673) If they will not trust you now, there is no warrant for supposing that they will after victory.
('82', 267, 1, 21, 459769) They will then ask you with greater force than now to produce the unity which cannot be produced whilst they are here.
('82', 267, 1, 22, 459888) You get out of all this tangle, if you adopt my method.
('82', 267, 1, 23, 459944) If you have intellectual conviction, you can approach the problem with the utmost confidence.
('82', 267, 1, 24, 460038) You are friend to all.
('82', 267, 1, 25, 460061) You say to the British with the greatest goodwill that, if they leave India, she will take care of herself and will probably escape Japanese attention, and if she cannot, she will answer it with non violence.
('82', 267, 1, 26, 460270) Then by that simple act of justice they gain your eternal friendship.
('82', 267, 1, 27, 460340) It may stand them in good stead even during the present war.
('82', 267, 1, 28, 460401) For India will then of her own free will help China, Russia and others.
('82', 267, 1, 29, 460473) If India sets her own house in order, as I have no doubt she will, India can work wonders.
('82', 267, 2, 30, 460564) BOMBAY, May 10, 1942 Harijan, 17 5 1942

('82', 269, 1, 2, 461599) 327. QUESTION BOX
('82', 269, 2, 3, 461617) IF “HARIJAN” IS PROHIBITED
('82', 269, 3, 4, 461644) Q. You are going strong.
('82', 269, 3, 5, 461669) You should know that if the people follow you it
('82', 269, 4, 6, 461718) must hinder the present war effort.
('82', 269, 4, 7, 461754) The Government cannot allow it.
('82', 269, 4, 8, 461786) If they do, you
('82', 269, 5, 9, 461802) will admit that only the British Government can show such generosity.
('82', 269, 5, 10, 461872) And what will
('82', 269, 6, 11, 461886) you do if they suppress it?
('82', 269, 7, 12, 461914) A. No Government can afford to be generous.
('82', 269, 7, 13, 461958) A man is generous when he does something at his own expense.
('82', 269, 7, 14, 462019) Governments can do nothing at their own expense.
('82', 269, 7, 15, 462068) But they always succeed in making people believe that they are generous even when they are barely or less than just.
('82', 269, 7, 16, 462185) Justice is like a debt which has to be discharged.
('82', 269, 7, 17, 462236) Therefore, if the Government permit Harijan to continue its even course, they will do so because it is proper from their point of view.
('82', 269, 7, 18, 462372) They will not hesitate to suppress it when they think it is improper not to do so.
('82', 269, 7, 19, 462455) I stated at the time of the resumption of publication that it was no part of my plan to persist in publication in spite of prohibition.
('82', 269, 7, 20, 462591) I will, therefore, again suspend publication when the Government desire it.
('82', 269, 7, 21, 462667) If they do, it will be a loss to the public.
('82', 269, 7, 22, 462712) For, apart from the three weeklies, its articles appear by special permission in Urdu Hindustan—Lucknow, Urdu Harijan—Lahore, Marathi Harijan—Wardha.
('82', 269, 7, 23, 462862) It is also published in Telugu and Oriya.
('82', 269, 7, 24, 462904) Articles are sent to them in advance.
('82', 269, 7, 25, 462942) Numerous other newspapers copy or translate articles from it week by week.
('82', 269, 7, 26, 463017) There is no generosity in tolerating the publication of such a popular weekly.
('82', 269, 7, 27, 463096) And my writings will not hinder war effort, if it is voluntary.
('82', 269, 7, 28, 463160) If they influence the people, surely there is something wrong somewhere.
('82', 269, 7, 29, 463233) It is not Harijan that should be stopped, but the wrong it exposes should be undone.
('82', 269, 7, 30, 463318) I look upon my writings as a solid contribution to war effort, for he serves a cause best who exposes its weaknesses or those of its representatives.
('82', 269, 7, 31, 463468) You ask what I would do if they suppress Harijan.
('82', 269, 7, 32, 463518) I must frankly confess I do not know.
('82', 269, 7, 33, 463556) I have cultivated the habit of not anticipating evil.
('82', 269, 7, 34, 463610) I am able to know the remedy instinctively when I am face to face with an evil.
('82', 269, 7, 35, 463690) That is how a godfearing man acts.
('82', 269, 7, 36, 463725) The fear of God disposes of every other fear.
('82', 269, 7, 37, 463771) But I can give you this
('82', 270, 0, 1, 463795) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 271
('82', 270, 1, 2, 463838) assurance that suppression of Harijan can never mean suppression of me.
('82', 270, 1, 3, 463910) BOMBAY, May 11 , 1942 Harijan, 17 5 1942
('82', 270, 2, 4, 463951) 328. TO EVERY BRITON
('82', 270, 3, 5, 463972) When I had just begun my public career in South Africa I wrote “An Open Letter to Every Briton in South Africa” 1. It had its effect.
('82', 270, 3, 6, 464106) I feel that I should repeat the example at this critical juncture in the history of the world.
('82', 270, 3, 7, 464201) This time my appeal must be to every Briton in the world.
('82', 270, 3, 8, 464259) He may be nobody in the counsels of his nation.
('82', 270, 3, 9, 464307) But in the empire of non violence every true thought counts, every true voice has its full value.
('82', 270, 3, 10, 464405) Vox populi vox dei is not a copy book maxim.
('82', 270, 3, 11, 464450) It is an expression of the solid experience of mankind.
('82', 270, 3, 12, 464506) But it has one qualification.
('82', 270, 3, 13, 464536) Its truth is confined to the field of non violence.
('82', 270, 3, 14, 464588) Violence can for the moment completely frustrate a people’s voice.
('82', 270, 3, 15, 464655) But since I work on the field of non violence only, every true thought expressed or unexpressed counts for me.
('82', 270, 4, 16, 464766) I ask every Briton to support me in my appeal to the British at this very hour to retire from every Asiatic and African possession and at least from India.
('82', 270, 4, 17, 464922) That step is essential for the safety of the world and for the destruction of Nazism and Fascism.
('82', 270, 4, 18, 465020) In this I include Japan’s ‘ism’ also.
('82', 270, 4, 19, 465058) It is a good copy of the two.
('82', 270, 4, 20, 465088) Acceptance of my appeal will confound all the military plans of all the Axis Powers and even of the military advisers of Great Britain.
('82', 270, 5, 21, 465224) If my appeal goes home, I am sure the cost of British interests in India and Africa would be nothing compared to the present ever growing cost of the war to Britain.
('82', 270, 5, 22, 465390) And when one puts morals in the scales, there is nothing but gain to Britain, India and the world.
('82', 270, 5, 23, 465489) Though I ask for their withdrawal from Asia and Africa, let me confine myself for the moment to India.
('82', 270, 5, 24, 465592) British statesmen talk glibly of India’s participation in the war.
('82', 270, 5, 25, 465659) Now India was never even formally consulted on the declaration of war.
('82', 270, 5, 26, 465730) Why should it be?
('82', 270, 5, 27, 465748) India does not belong to Indians.
('82', 270, 5, 28, 465782) It belongs to the British.
('82', 270, 5, 29, 465809) It has been even called a
('82', 270, 6, 30, 465835) 1 The title in fact was “Open Letter”, Vide “Open Letter”, before 19 12 1894.
('82', 271, 0, 1, 465913) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 271, 1, 2, 465955) British possession.
('82', 271, 1, 3, 465975) The British practically do with it as they like.
('82', 271, 1, 4, 466024) They make me—an all war resister—pay a war tax in a variety of ways.
('82', 271, 1, 5, 466093) Thus I pay two pice as war tax on every letter I post, one pice on every postcard, and two annas on every wire I send.
('82', 271, 1, 6, 466212) This is the lightest side of the dismal picture.
('82', 271, 1, 7, 466261) But it shows British ingenuity.
('82', 271, 1, 8, 466293) If I was a student of economics, I could produce startling figures as to what India has been made to pay towards the war apart from what are miscalled voluntary contributions.
('82', 271, 1, 9, 466469) No contribution made to a conqueror can be truly described as voluntary.
('82', 271, 1, 10, 466542) What a conqueror the Briton makes !
('82', 271, 1, 11, 466578) He is well saddled in his seat.
('82', 271, 1, 12, 466610) I do not exaggerate when I say that a whisper of his wish is promptly answered in India.
('82', 271, 1, 13, 466699) Britain may, therefore, be said to be at perpetual war with India which she holds by right of conquest and through an army of occupation.
('82', 271, 1, 14, 466837) How does India profit by this enforced participation in Britain’s war?
('82', 271, 1, 15, 466908) The bravely of Indian soldiers profits India nothing.
('82', 271, 2, 16, 466962) Before the Japanese menace overtakes India, India’s homesteads are being occupied by British troops—Indian and non Indian.
('82', 271, 2, 17, 467085) The dwellers are summarily ejected and expected to shift for themselves.
('82', 271, 2, 18, 467158) They are paid a paltry vacating expense which carries them nowhere.
('82', 271, 2, 19, 467226) Their occupation is gone.
('82', 271, 2, 20, 467252) They have to build their cottages and search for their livelihood.
('82', 271, 2, 21, 467319) These people do not vacate out of a spirit of patriotism.
('82', 271, 2, 22, 467377) When this incident was referred to me a few days ago, I wrote 1 in these columns that the dispossessed people should be asked to bear their lot with resignation.
('82', 271, 2, 23, 467539) But my co workers protested and invited me to go to the evacuees and console them myself or send someone to perform the impossible task.
('82', 271, 2, 24, 467676) They were right.
('82', 271, 2, 25, 467693) These poor people should never have been treated as they were.
('82', 271, 2, 26, 467756) They should have been lodged suitably at the same time that they were asked to vacate.
('82', 271, 3, 27, 467843) People in East Bengal may almost be regarded as amphibious.
('82', 271, 3, 28, 467903) They live partly on land and partly on the waters of the rivers.
('82', 271, 3, 29, 467968) They have light canoes which enable them to go from place to place.
('82', 271, 3, 30, 468036) For fear of the Japanese using the canoes the people have been called upon to surrender them.
('82', 271, 3, 31, 468130) For a Bengali to part with his canoe is almost like parting with his life.
('82', 271, 3, 32, 468205) So those who take away his canoe he regards as his enemy.
('82', 271, 4, 33, 468263) 1 Vide “Scorched earth Policy Again”, 27 4 1942.
('82', 272, 0, 1, 468312) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 273
('82', 272, 1, 2, 468355) Great Britain has to win the war.
('82', 272, 1, 3, 468389) Need she do so at India’s expense?
('82', 272, 1, 4, 468424) Should she do so?
('82', 272, 2, 5, 468442) But I have something more to add to this sad chapter.
('82', 272, 2, 6, 468496) The fal sity that envelopes Indian life is suffocating.
('82', 272, 2, 7, 468552) Almost every Indian you meet is discontented.
('82', 272, 2, 8, 468598) But he will not own it publicly.
('82', 272, 2, 9, 468631) The Govern ment employees, high and low, are no exception.
('82', 272, 2, 10, 468690) I am not giving hearsay evidence.
('82', 272, 2, 11, 468724) Many British officials know this.
('82', 272, 2, 12, 468758) But they have evolved the art of taking work from such elements.
('82', 272, 2, 13, 468823) This all pervading distrust and falsity make life worthless unless one resists it with one’s whole soul.
('82', 272, 2, 14, 468928) You may refuse to believe all I say.
('82', 272, 2, 15, 468965) Of course I shall be contradicted.
('82', 272, 2, 16, 469000) I shall survive the contradictions.
('82', 272, 2, 17, 469036) I have stated what I believe to be the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.
('82', 272, 3, 18, 469125) My people may or may not approve of this loud thinking.
('82', 272, 3, 19, 469181) I have consulted nobody.
('82', 272, 3, 20, 469206) This appeal is being written during my silence day.
('82', 272, 3, 21, 469258) I am just now concerned with Britain’s action.
('82', 272, 3, 22, 469305) When slavery was abolished in America many slaves protested, some even wept.
('82', 272, 3, 23, 469382) But protests and tears notwithstanding, slavery was abolished in law.
('82', 272, 3, 24, 469452) But the abolition was the result of a bloody war between the South and the North; and so though the Negro’s lot is considerably better than before, he still remains the outcaste of high society.
('82', 272, 3, 25, 469647) I am asking for something much higher.
('82', 272, 3, 26, 469686) I ask for a bloodless end of an unnatural domination and for a new era, even though there may be protests and wailings from some of us.
('82', 272, 4, 27, 469822) BOMBAY, May 11 , 1942 Harijan, 17 5 1942

('82', 278, 8, 10, 476136) 339. INTERVIEW TO “THE NEWS CHRONICLE”
('82', 278, 9, 11, 476175) BOMBAY,
('82', 278, 10, 12, 476183) May 14, 1942
('82', 278, 11, 13, 476196) Q. You have recently asked the British to withdraw from India.
('82', 278, 11, 14, 476259) Do you think it
('82', 278, 12, 15, 476275) possible in the present circumstances for them to withdraw all at once?
('82', 278, 12, 16, 476347) To whom are
('82', 278, 13, 17, 476359) they to entrust the administration?
('82', 278, 14, 18, 476395) A. It has cost me much to come to the conclusion that the British should withdraw from India, and it is costing me still more to work out that conclusion.
('82', 278, 14, 19, 476550) It is like asking loved ones to part, but it has become a paramount duty.
('82', 278, 14, 20, 476624) And the beauty [of] and the necessity for withdrawal lie in its being immediate.
('82', 278, 14, 21, 476705) They and we are both in the midst of fire.
('82', 278, 14, 22, 476748) If they go, there is a likelihood of both of us being safe.
('82', 278, 14, 23, 476808) If they do not, Heaven only knows what will happen.
('82', 278, 14, 24, 476860) I have said in the plainest terms that in my proposal there is no question of entrusting the administration to any person or party.
('82', 278, 14, 25, 476992) That would be a necess ary consideration if the withdrawal was part of a settlement.
('82', 278, 14, 26, 477077) Under my proposal, they have to leave India in God’s hands, but in modern parlance to anarchy, and that anarchy may lead to internecine warfare for a time or to unrestrained dacoities.
('82', 278, 14, 27, 477262) From these a true India will rise in the place of the false one we see.
('82', 278, 15, 28, 477334) Q. How is your policy of non embarrassment reconcilable with this advice?
('82', 279, 0, 1, 477408) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 280
('82', 279, 1, 2, 477450) A. My policy of non embarrassment remains intact in terms in which I have described it.
('82', 279, 1, 3, 477538) If the British withdraw, surely there is no embarrassment; not only so, they become eased of a tremendous burden, if they would calmly consider the meaning of the enslavement of a whole people.
('82', 279, 1, 4, 477732) But if they persist, well knowing that they are surrounded by hatred, they invite embarrassment.
('82', 279, 1, 5, 477829) I do not produce it by stating the truth, however unpalatable it may appear for the moment.
('82', 279, 2, 6, 477921) Q. Already there are signs of civil insecurity, and would not life be even more
('82', 279, 3, 7, 478001) insecure, were the present administration suddenly to withdraw?
('82', 279, 4, 8, 478065) A. Of course, there is civil insecurity, and I have already confessed that insecurity is likely to increase very much only to give place to real security.
('82', 279, 4, 9, 478220) The present insecurity is chronic and therefore not so much felt.
('82', 279, 4, 10, 478286) But a disease that is not felt is worse than one that is felt.
('82', 279, 5, 11, 478349) Q. Were the Japanese to invade India, what would your advice be to the Indian
('82', 279, 6, 12, 478427) people?
('82', 279, 7, 13, 478435) A. I have already said in my articles that it is just likely that the Japanese will not want to invade India, their prey having gone.
('82', 279, 7, 14, 478569) But it is equally likely that they will want to invade India in order to use her ports for strategic purposes.
('82', 279, 7, 15, 478680) Then, I would advise the people to do the same thing that I have advised them to do now, viz., offer stubborn non violent non co operation, and I make bold to say that, if the British withdraw and people here follow my advice, then non co operation will be infinitely more effective than it can be today, when it cannot be appreciated for the violent British action going on side by side.
('82', 279, 8, 16, 479069) Harijan, 24 5 1942
('82', 280, 0, 1, 479088) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 281

('82', 280, 5, 8, 479451) But it may also not be heeded.
('82', 280, 5, 9, 479482) The advice has, therefore, to be prepared for both contingencies.
('82', 280, 5, 10, 479548) I do advise the British to leave India.
('82', 280, 5, 11, 479588) I tell them to go away.
('82', 280, 5, 12, 479612) And why do I say so?
('82', 280, 5, 13, 479633) Because they will have to go anyway.

('82', 280, 5, 16, 479835) Yes, I ask them to go.

('82', 280, 5, 18, 479880) Then I shall have to see.

('82', 280, 5, 20, 480022) Or it may be by both.
('82', 280, 5, 21, 480044) Of course, you may ask that in the beginning of the war I was for non embarrassing the British and you may say: What is that policy now?
('82', 280, 5, 22, 480181) Is this consistent with it?
('82', 280, 5, 23, 480209) Let me tell you here that I think this is perfectly consistent with it.
('82', 280, 5, 24, 480281) For the British need my advice.
('82', 280, 5, 25, 480313) There will be no embarrassment for them; on the contrary.
('82', 280, 5, 26, 480371) For I say that at present the war is far from their shores.

('82', 280, 5, 29, 480497) Let them therefore go back home.

('82', 280, 5, 36, 480862) Mind, I am not pro Japanese.
('82', 280, 5, 37, 480891) Indeed, Japan is too much of an aggressor for me to be that.
('82', 280, 5, 38, 480952) But I emphatically differ from Rajaji.

('82', 284, 10, 41, 491283) The Transfer of Power, 1942 7, Vol. II, pp.
('82', 285, 0, 1, 491327) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 286
('82', 285, 1, 2, 491369) 341. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 1
('82', 285, 2, 3, 491399) BOMBAY, May 16, 1942 2
('82', 285, 3, 4, 491422) Q. Would you review the situation created by the Allahabad A.I.C.C. meeting?
('82', 285, 4, 5, 491499) What would you say regarding Rajaji’s quoting your words regarding Pakistan in
('82', 285, 5, 6, 491578) support of his latest move?
('82', 285, 6, 7, 491606) A. I would leave the Allahabad resolutions to themselves.
('82', 285, 6, 8, 491664) C. R. has quoted me correctly, and I repeat that, if Muslims want anything— no matter what it is—no power on earth can prevent them from having it.
('82', 285, 6, 9, 491812) For the condition of refusal will be to fight.
('82', 285, 6, 10, 491859) Supposing Muslims ask for something which non Muslims do not want to give or could not give, it means a fight.
('82', 285, 6, 11, 491970) This applies to both the communities.
('82', 285, 6, 12, 492008) If the Hindus want a thing and if they are all united in the demand, no non Hindus can resist them, unless they want to fight.
('82', 285, 6, 13, 492135) But my hope is that some day or other all parties will come to their senses and notinsist on their demands being accepted, and consent to go to arbitration.
('82', 285, 6, 14, 492292) It is an age long method and a civilized method, and I hope it will be accepted.
('82', 285, 7, 15, 492373) But it is from the frustration of every effort made to bring about unity by me, among many others, that has arisen the, for me, logical step that not until British power is wholly withdrawn from India can there be any real unity, because all parties will be looking to the foreign power.
('82', 285, 7, 16, 492661) For the time being it is British but it may be French, Russian, Chinese, even then it would be the same thing.
('82', 285, 7, 17, 492772) I have, therefore, come to the conclusion that real heart unity, genuine unity, is almost an impossibility unless and until British power is withdrawn and no other power takes its place, that is to say, when India not only feels but is actually independent without a master in any shape or form.
('82', 285, 7, 18, 493068) Nevertheless I shall try and welcome every effort for peace, well knowing that it is likely to be fruitless.
('82', 285, 8, 19, 493177) Q. There is a report about some new scheme that you want to propound in one
('82', 285, 9, 20, 493253) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “The Bombay Interview”.
('82', 285, 9, 21, 493310) According to The Hindu, 18 5 1942, the interview lasted for an hour and some sixty Press representatives were present.
('82', 285, 9, 22, 493429) 2 From The Hindu
('82', 286, 0, 1, 493446) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 287
('82', 286, 1, 2, 493489) of your Harijan articles about non violent non co operation if any invader came to
('82', 286, 2, 3, 493572) Could you give us an idea?
('82', 286, 3, 4, 493599) A. It is wrong.
('82', 286, 3, 5, 493615) I have no plan in mind.
('82', 286, 3, 6, 493639) If I had, I should give it to you.
('82', 286, 3, 7, 493674) But I think nothing more need be added when I have said that there should be unadulterated non violent non co operation, and if the whole of India responded and unanimously offered it, I should show that without shedding a single drop of blood Japanese arms—or any combination of arms—can be sterilized.
('82', 286, 3, 8, 493978) That involves the determination of India not to give quarter on any point whatsoever and to be ready to risk loss of several million lives.
('82', 286, 3, 9, 494118) But I would consider that cost very cheap and victory won at that cost glorious.
('82', 286, 3, 10, 494199) That India may not be ready to pay that price may be true.
('82', 286, 3, 11, 494258) I hope it is not true, but some such price must be paid by any country that wants to retain its independence.
('82', 286, 3, 12, 494368) After all, the sacrifice made by the Russians and the Chinese is enormous, and they are ready to risk all.
('82', 286, 3, 13, 494475) The same could be said of the other countries also, whether aggressors or defenders.
('82', 286, 3, 14, 494560) The cost is enormous.
('82', 286, 3, 15, 494582) Therefore, in the non violent technique I am asking India to risk no more than other countries are risking and which India would have to risk even if she offered armed resistance.
('82', 286, 4, 16, 494762) Q. But, unadulterated non violent non co operation has not been successful
('82', 286, 5, 17, 494837) against Great Britain.
('82', 286, 5, 18, 494860) How will it succeed against a new aggressor?
('82', 286, 6, 19, 494905) A. I combat the statement altogether.
('82', 286, 6, 20, 494943) Nobody has yet told me that non violent non co operation,unadulterated, has not succeeded.
('82', 286, 6, 21, 495034) It has not been offered, it is true.
('82', 286, 6, 22, 495071) Therefore, you can say that what has not been offered hitherto is not likely to be offered suddenly when India faces the Japanese arms.
('82', 286, 6, 23, 495207) I can only hope that, in the face of danger, India would be readier to offer non violent non co operation.
('82', 286, 6, 24, 495314) Perhaps India is accustomed to British rule for so many years that the Indian mind or India’s masses do not feel the pinch so much as the advent of a new power would be felt.
('82', 286, 6, 25, 495489) But your question is well put.
('82', 286, 6, 26, 495520) It is possible that India may not be able to offer non violent non co operation.
('82', 286, 6, 27, 495601) But a similar question may be put regarding armed resistance.
('82', 286, 6, 28, 495663) Several attempts have been made and they have not succeeded.
('82', 286, 6, 29, 495724) Therefore, it will not succeed against the Japanese.
('82', 286, 6, 30, 495777) That leads us to the absurd conclusion that India will never be ready for
('82', 287, 0, 1, 495851) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 288
('82', 287, 1, 2, 495893) gaining independence, and seeing that I cannot subscribe to any such proposition, I must try again and again till India is ready to respond to the call of non violent non co operation.
('82', 287, 1, 3, 496078) But if India does not respond to that call, then India must respond to the call of some leader or some organization wedded to violence.
('82', 287, 1, 4, 496214) For instance, the Hindu Mahasabha is trying to rouse the Hindu mind for an armed conflict.
('82', 287, 1, 5, 496305) It remains to be seen whether that attempt succeeds.
('82', 287, 1, 6, 496358) I for one do not believe it will succeed.
('82', 287, 2, 7, 496400) Q. Would you advise non violent non co operation against scorched earth
('82', 287, 3, 8, 496472) policy?
('82', 287, 3, 9, 496480) Would you resist the attempt to destroy sources of food and water?
('82', 287, 4, 10, 496547) A. Yes.
('82', 287, 4, 11, 496555) A time may come when I would certainly advise it, for I think it is ruinous, suicidal, and unnecessary—whether India believes in non violent non co operation or in violence.
('82', 287, 4, 12, 496729) And the Russian and Chinese examples make no appeal to me.
('82', 287, 4, 13, 496788) If some other country resorts to methods which I consider to be inhuman, I may not follow them.
('82', 287, 4, 14, 496884) If the enemy comes and helps himself to crops, I may be obliged to leave, because I cannot or care not to defend them.
('82', 287, 4, 15, 497003) I must resign myself to it.
('82', 287, 4, 16, 497031) And there is a good example for us.
('82', 287, 4, 17, 497067) A passage was quoted to me from the Islamic literature.
('82', 287, 4, 18, 497123) The Caliph issued definite instructions to the armies of Islam that they should not destroy the utility services, they should not harass the aged and women and children; and I do not know that the arms of Islam suffered any disaster because the armies obeyed those instructions.
('82', 287, 5, 19, 497402) Q. But what about factories—especially factories for the manufacture of
('82', 287, 6, 20, 497474) munitions?
('82', 287, 7, 21, 497485) A. Suppose there are factories for grinding wheat or pressing oil seeds.
('82', 287, 7, 22, 497558) I should not destroy them.
('82', 287, 7, 23, 497585) But munitions factories, yes; for I would not tolerate munitions factories in a free India if I had my way.
('82', 287, 7, 24, 497693) Textile factories I would not destroy and I would resist all such destruction.
('82', 287, 7, 25, 497772) However, it is a question of prudence.
('82', 287, 7, 26, 497811) I have not suggested immediate enforcement of the whole programme in pursuance of the demand for British withdrawal.
('82', 287, 7, 27, 497928) It is there of course.
('82', 287, 7, 28, 497951) But I am trying, if I am allowed to continue to cultivate and educate public opinion, to show that behind this demand of mine there is no ill will, no malice.
('82', 287, 7, 29, 498110) It is the most logical thing that I have suggested.
('82', 287, 7, 30, 498162) It is in the interests of all, and since it is an entirely friendly act, I am
('82', 288, 0, 1, 498240) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 289
('82', 288, 1, 2, 498283) moving cautiously, watching myself at every step.
('82', 288, 1, 3, 498333) I will do nothing in haste, but there is the fixed determination behind every act of mine that the British must withdraw.
('82', 288, 2, 4, 498455) I have mentioned anarchy.
('82', 288, 2, 5, 498481) I am convinced that we are living today in a state of ordered anarchy.
('82', 288, 2, 6, 498552) It is a misnomer to call such rule as is established in India a rule which promotes the welfare of India.
('82', 288, 2, 7, 498658) Therefore, this ordered disciplined anarchy should go, and if there is complete lawlessness in India, as a result, I would risk it, though I believe, and should like to believe, that 22 years of continuous effort at educating India along the lines of non violence will not have gone in vain, and people will evolve real popular order out of chaos.
('82', 288, 2, 8, 499006) Therefore, if I find that all the best effort fails, I would certainly invite people to resist destruction of their property.
('82', 288, 3, 9, 499132) Q. Can India give her moral sympathy or support to either of the parties to the
('82', 288, 5, 10, 499212) A. My own personal view is well known.
('82', 288, 5, 11, 499251) And if I can convert India to my view, there would be no aid to either side; but my sympathies are undoubtedly in favour of China and Russia.
('82', 288, 6, 12, 499393) Q. But what about Britain?
('82', 288, 7, 13, 499420) A. I used to say that my moral support was entirely with Britain.
('82', 288, 7, 14, 499486) I am very sorry to have to confess that today my mind refuses to give that moral support.
('82', 288, 7, 15, 499576) British behaviour towards India has filled me with great pain.
('82', 288, 7, 16, 499639) I was not quite prepared for Mr. Amery’s performances or Sir Stafford Cripps’s Mission.
('82', 288, 7, 17, 499727) These have, in my estimation, put Britain morally in the wrong.
('82', 288, 7, 18, 499791) And, therefore, though I do not wish any humiliation to Britain—and therefore no defeat—my mind refuses to give her any moral support.
('82', 288, 8, 19, 499926) Q. What about America?
('82', 288, 9, 20, 499949) A. I expressed my opinion some time ago that it was a wrong thing for America and unfortunate for the world peace that America, instead of working, as she could have worked, for world peace, identified herself with war.
('82', 288, 10, 21, 500169) Q. But was there any alternative for her?
('82', 288, 11, 22, 500211) A. I am sure she would have, if she had intended, brought about peace.
('82', 288, 11, 23, 500282) But it is my firm opinion that she did not use her opportunity.
('82', 289, 0, 1, 500346) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 290
('82', 289, 1, 2, 500388) I know that I have no right to criticize such a big nation.
('82', 289, 1, 3, 500448) I do not know all the facts that determined America to throw herself into the cauldron.
('82', 289, 1, 4, 500536) But somehow or other, opinion has forced itself upon me that America could have remained out, and even now it can do so if she divests herself of the intoxication that her immense wealth has produced.
('82', 289, 1, 5, 500737) And I would like to repeat what I have said about the withdrawal of British power from India.
('82', 289, 1, 6, 500831) Both America and Britain lack the moral basis for engaging in this war, unless they put their own houses in order, while making a fixed determination to withdraw their influence and power both from Africa and Asia, and remove the colour bar.
('82', 289, 1, 7, 501073) They have no right to talk about protecting democracies and protecting civilization and human freedom until the canker of white superiority is destroyed in its entirety.
('82', 289, 2, 8, 501243) Q. Would you advocate arbitration for the Indo British problem?
('82', 289, 2, 9, 501307) And if so, of
('82', 289, 3, 10, 501321) what sort?
('82', 289, 4, 11, 501332) A. Any day.
('82', 289, 4, 12, 501344) I suggested long ago that this question could be decided by arbitration.
('82', 289, 4, 13, 501417) How to bring that arbitration about, I do not know.
('82', 289, 4, 14, 501469) But if the British rulers will accept the principle, it should not be impossible to find impartial arbitrators though I admit it is a tremendously difficult problem to find impartial arbitrators in this case.
('82', 289, 5, 15, 501678) Q. But you may say the same thing about finding arbitrators on the domestic
('82', 289, 6, 16, 501754) question too?
('82', 289, 7, 17, 501768) It is a comparatively simpler thing.
('82', 289, 7, 18, 501805) Where British power is concerned it has such great influence and power—and rightly so—it would be difficult to get hold of arbitrators who would not be biased in favour of Great Britain and deliver a fearless and just award.
('82', 289, 8, 19, 502030) Q. Cannot there be any arbitration on the question of independence?
('82', 289, 9, 20, 502098) A. No, not on the question of independence.
('82', 289, 9, 21, 502142) It is possible only on questions on which sides may be taken.
('82', 289, 9, 22, 502204) The outstanding questionof independence should be treated as common cause.
('82', 289, 9, 23, 502279) It is only then that I can conceive possibility of arbitration on the Indo British question.
('82', 289, 9, 24, 502372) But, as I have said, it is a most difficult question.
('82', 289, 9, 25, 502426) If ever there is a real adjustment, it will come only when Britain feels that it is wrong to rule over another nation.
('82', 289, 9, 26, 502545) But when that conviction goes home, they won’t need arbitration—we in India
('82', 290, 0, 1, 502621) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 291
('82', 290, 1, 2, 502664) But if there is to be any arbitration—and I cannot logically say there should not, for if I did, it would be an arrogation of complete justice on my side —it can be done only if India’s independence is recognized.
('82', 290, 2, 3, 502878) Q. Why did you not go to America in 1931, even though you were pressingly
('82', 290, 3, 4, 502952) invited by Bishop Fisher?
('82', 290, 4, 5, 502978) A. Because I had no faith in myself.
('82', 290, 4, 6, 503015) The invitation was very pressing indeed, and the offer was sincere, and I could easily have spared a fortnight, but I had no faith that I would be able to do any good to India.
('82', 290, 4, 7, 503192) It would have been a nine days’ wonder.
('82', 290, 4, 8, 503232) I would be lionized and torn to pieces.
('82', 290, 4, 9, 503272) The American people would listen to you, lionize you, but would go their own way.
('82', 290, 4, 10, 503354) Gurudev had been there, Vivekanand had been there, and his followers are still there.
('82', 290, 4, 11, 503440) But the soul of America is untouched because of her worship of ‘the golden calf’.
('82', 290, 4, 12, 503522) As a people they are, after all is said and done, worshippers of Mammon.
('82', 290, 5, 13, 503595) Q. Does not America send her troops to India for a personal and selfish
('82', 290, 6, 14, 503667) motive?
('82', 290, 7, 15, 503675) A. I suggest a better way of putting the question: “Is it not disastrous for foreign armies to come to India when India has sufficient man power?” If you put the question like that, my answer is: “Decidedly so.”

('82', 291, 3, 4, 504023) I am not exaggerating when I say that Santiniketan is worthy of greater support than the Bangalore Research Institute for which Tata gave Rs. 30 lakhs.

('82', 292, 7, 10, 506119) DEENBANDHU MEMORIAL
('82', 292, 8, 11, 506139) I am glad to be able to inform the readers of Harijan that the efforts of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and Sheth Ghanshyamdas Birla, who had asked me to go to Bombay for eight days for the purpose of finishing the Deenbandhu Memorial collections, have been crowned with full success.
('82', 292, 8, 12, 506419) Only over Rs. 60,000 were collected in response to the appeal through the papers.
('82', 292, 8, 13, 506501) The whole of the balance of five lacs was collected during the eight days’ strenuous labour.
('82', 292, 8, 14, 506594) Bombay has never disappointed me whenever I have gone there for collections.
('82', 292, 8, 15, 506671) I am most grateful to the donors for their generosity.
('82', 292, 8, 16, 506726) They have taken a great load off my mind.
('82', 292, 8, 17, 506768) I am quite clear that they have never given to a better cause.
('82', 292, 8, 18, 506831) The memorial to Deenbandhu started by and at the wish of Gurudev became on his death memorial to Gurudev, in which the former merged.
('82', 292, 8, 19, 506965) The object of both could only be identical.
('82', 292, 8, 20, 507009) Subscriptions were required partly for the discharge of monies due by Santiniketan and largely for the building, etc., mentioned in the original appeal.
('82', 292, 8, 21, 507162) I may mention that while the donations received included large sums from wealthy men they included also small sums from unknown persons from all over India.
('82', 292, 8, 22, 507319) They were received from all communities, Parsis, Christians, Jews, Muslims and Hindus.
('82', 292, 8, 23, 507406) I repeat the thanks on behalf of the fellow signatories and myself to the donors for their generous donations as also to the friends who
('82', 292, 9, 24, 507543) 1 From the postmark

('82', 293, 1, 2, 507605) organized the collection and laboured to make it a success.
('82', 293, 2, 3, 507665) HARIJAN COLLECTIONS
('82', 293, 3, 4, 507685) If the collections I make at railway stations and at evening prayer when I am out of Sevagram are any index to the progress of the removal of untouchability it must be very substantial, for I notice that the response is more liberal than before.
('82', 293, 3, 5, 507931) Hardly a bystander at stations or a visitor to the prayer meeting refrains from giving his mite.
('82', 293, 3, 6, 508028) Much need not be made of the response.
('82', 293, 3, 7, 508067) But there can be no doubt that if the cause did not make any appeal, the response would be meagre, if any.
('82', 293, 3, 8, 508174) Whereas it was hearty and willing.
('82', 293, 3, 9, 508209) It gave me great joy as I studied the smiling faces of those who gave.

('82', 293, 3, 11, 508409) Thus the first day’s collection was Rs. 205 5 6 and the last Rs. 1342 10 9.

('82', 293, 5, 13, 508539) 345. NOTES
('82', 293, 6, 14, 508550) CONFUSION
('82', 293, 7, 15, 508560) There is evidently confusion in some minds about my invitation to the British to withdraw.
('82', 293, 7, 16, 508651) For a Britisher writes to say that he likes India and her people and would not like willingly to leave India.
('82', 293, 7, 17, 508761) He likes too my method of non violence.
('82', 293, 7, 18, 508801) Evidently the writer has confused the individual as such with the individual as the holder of power.
('82', 293, 7, 19, 508902) India has no quarrel with the British people.
('82', 293, 7, 20, 508948) I have hundreds of British friends.
('82', 293, 7, 21, 508984) Andrews’s friendship was enough to tie me to the British people.
('82', 293, 7, 22, 509049) But both he and I were fixed in our determination that British rule in India in any shape or form must end.
('82', 293, 7, 23, 509157) Hitherto the rulers have said, “We would gladly retire if we know to whom we should hand over the reins.” My answer now is, “Leave India to God.
('82', 293, 7, 24, 509302) If that is too much, then leave her to anarchy.” I invite every Britisher who loves Britain, India and the world to join me in the appeal to the British Power, and if it is rejected, to adopt such non violent measures as would compel the Power to comply with the appeal.
('82', 294, 0, 1, 509573) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 295
('82', 294, 1, 2, 509616) WHAT COULD HAVE BEEN DONE?
('82', 294, 2, 3, 509643) Some Pressmen asked me in Bombay what Sir Stafford could
('82', 294, 3, 4, 509700) have done in the absence of an agreement between the Congress and the League.
('82', 294, 3, 5, 509778) I gave the answer.
('82', 294, 3, 6, 509797) I do not know whether it has appeared anywhere.1 Anyway it is better for the public to know what answer I gave to the question.
('82', 294, 3, 7, 509925) Sir Stafford could have asked either the Congress or the League to form the cabinet.
('82', 294, 3, 8, 510010) If he had done so, probably the party they entrusted with responsibility would have succeeded in having the co operation of the other party.
('82', 294, 3, 9, 510151) In any event the Government would then have dealt with the real representatives of their party rather than having their own nominees.
('82', 294, 3, 10, 510285) I do not know that they made any such offer either to the Congress or the League.
('82', 294, 3, 11, 510367) So far as the public know the negotiations did not break over the want of agreement between the two organizations but over differences with Sir Stafford as to what powers the British Government wanted to part with during the war.
('82', 294, 4, 12, 510597) Sevagram, May 18, 1942 Harijan, 24 5 1942
('82', 294, 5, 13, 510639) 346. QUESTION BOX
('82', 294, 6, 14, 510657) THE DIFFERENCE
('82', 294, 7, 15, 510672) Q. You have repeated in your interview to the Press in Bombay what you have
('82', 294, 8, 16, 510748) said often that nothing can prevent the Muslims from having what they want unless
('82', 294, 9, 17, 510830) the objecters would fight over the issue.
('82', 294, 10, 18, 510872) 2 What is the difference between you and Shri
('82', 294, 11, 19, 510918) Rajagopalachari’s attitude?
('82', 294, 12, 20, 510946) A. Though he has quoted me in his support I see the same
('82', 294, 13, 21, 511003) difference between him and me that there is between chalk and cheese.
('82', 294, 13, 22, 511073) He yields the right of secession now to buy unity in the hope of keeping away the Japanese.
('82', 294, 13, 23, 511165) I consider the vivisection of India to be a sin.
('82', 294, 13, 24, 511214) My statement amounts to the enunciation of the proposition that

('82', 295, 1, 2, 511478) I cannot prevent my neighbour from committing a sin.
('82', 295, 1, 3, 511531) Shri Raja gopalachari would be party in the sin, if the neighbour chooses to commit it.
('82', 295, 1, 4, 511619) I cannot be party.
('82', 295, 1, 5, 511638) What is more, I am firmly of opinion that there is no unity whilst the third party is there to prevent it.
('82', 295, 1, 6, 511745) It created the artificial division and it keeps it up.
('82', 295, 1, 7, 511800) In its presence both Hindus and Muslims and for that matter all seemingly conflicting or disgruntled interests and elements will look to it for support and will get it.
('82', 295, 1, 8, 511969) Their interest is greater than the independence of their country.No one need throw my other statement in my face, viz., that there is no independence without unity.
('82', 295, 1, 9, 512134) I do not withdraw a word of it.
('82', 295, 1, 10, 512166) It is an obvious truth.
('82', 295, 1, 11, 512190) From its contemplation I have discovered the formula of inviting the British power to withdraw.
('82', 295, 1, 12, 512286) Their withdrawal does not by itself bring independence.
('82', 295, 1, 13, 512342) It may induce unity or it may lead to chaos.
('82', 295, 1, 14, 512387) There is also the risk of another power filling in the vacancy if it is there.
('82', 295, 1, 15, 512466) If, however, the withdrawal is orderly and voluntary the British not only gain a moral height but secure the ungrudging friendship of a great nation.
('82', 295, 1, 16, 512616) I wish all conflicting elements and interests will make a combined effort to rid India of foreign domination.
('82', 295, 1, 17, 512726) If they do not, any understanding with them will be like a house built on sand.
('82', 295, 1, 18, 512806) Fear of the Japanese occupation of India has blinded C. R. to the obvious truth.
('82', 295, 1, 19, 512887) Independence sheds all fear—fear of the Japanese, of anarchy, and of the wrath of the British lion.

('82', 297, 1, 2, 513709) 349. LAWLESSNESS IN SINDH
('82', 297, 2, 3, 513735) Ghanshyam, assisted by Shri Assandas, a worker in Thar Parkar, has recently visited the area affected by the Hurs’ rebellion.
('82', 297, 3, 4, 513861) He has prepared an elaborate report of which he has sent me a copy.
('82', 297, 3, 5, 513929) The following is a condensed summary of the report in the Professor’s own language:
('82', 297, 4, 6, 514013) Not many people in Sindh realize the grave situation that has arisen
('82', 297, 5, 7, 514082) owing to the activities of the Hurs.
('82', 297, 5, 8, 514119) Hurs are followers of the Pir of Pagaro who
('82', 297, 6, 9, 514163) has been arrested by Government and is said to be under detention in Nagpur.
('82', 297, 7, 10, 514240) All his followers are not Hurs.
('82', 297, 7, 11, 514272) His following is said to run in lacs.
('82', 297, 7, 12, 514310) The Hurs are
('82', 297, 8, 13, 514323) mostly concentrated in Sanghar, Sinjhoro and Shahdadpur Talukas.
('82', 297, 8, 14, 514388) They are
('82', 297, 9, 15, 514397) considered to be a criminal tribe and several of them were kept in criminal
('82', 297, 10, 16, 514473) settlements.
('82', 297, 10, 17, 514486) These were abolished some years ago.
('82', 297, 10, 18, 514523) But they were still under
('82', 297, 11, 19, 514549) orders to report themselves regularly to the police.
('82', 297, 11, 20, 514602) The Hurs believe that their
('82', 297, 12, 21, 514630) Pir has been arrested on the false reports of the police against him.
('82', 297, 12, 22, 514700) They nurse
('82', 297, 13, 23, 514711) the grievance that none of them is allowed to interview him.
('82', 297, 13, 24, 514772) They are said to
('82', 297, 14, 25, 514789) complain of policeoppression in having to report themselves daily at police
('82', 297, 15, 26, 514865) stations.
('82', 297, 16, 27, 514875) After the arrest of the Pir of Pagaro, search of his house near Sanghar and
('82', 297, 17, 28, 514951) destruction by fire of the huts attached to the bungalow where the Pir’s
('82', 297, 18, 29, 515024) followers used to gather, have so enraged the Hurs that they have started on a
('82', 297, 19, 30, 515103) fierce campaign, as a challenge to Government, of murders, dacoities, attacks
('82', 297, 20, 31, 515181) on railway stations, destruction of property in P.W.D. bungalows, cutting of
('82', 297, 21, 32, 515258) telephone and telegraph wires, making breaches in canals, etc.
('82', 297, 21, 33, 515321) There is not a
('82', 297, 22, 34, 515336) day when reports of these criminal activities are not received.
('82', 297, 22, 35, 515400) They were in the
('82', 297, 23, 36, 515417) beginning mostly confined to Sanghar, Sinjhoro and Shahdadpur Talukas, but
('82', 297, 24, 37, 515492) have now spread to other parts of Sindh also, specially the Khipro Taluka
('82', 297, 25, 38, 515566) which adjoins Sanghar Taluka.
('82', 297, 25, 39, 515596) The Hurs may be said to have risen in rebellion
('82', 297, 26, 40, 515644) against the Government with a view to get the Pir of Pagaro released.
('82', 297, 27, 41, 515714) 1 On April 1, 1942, Martial Law had been proclaimed in the area.
('82', 297, 27, 42, 515779) An official communique said, “Over a period covering more than six months the Hurs have by wholesale murder, sabotage and dacoity terrorized whole district .
('82', 297, 27, 43, 515937) .” On May 13, 1941, the Government of Sindh had issued orders under the Arms Act and under the Defence of India Rules, suspending all gun, rifle and revolver licenses held by individual non officials.
('82', 297, 27, 44, 516138) (The Indian Annual Register, 1942, Vol. I, pp.
('82', 297, 27, 45, 516185) 65 and 83 4)

('82', 298, 1, 2, 516241) have such an intense faith in him that they are prepared to sacrifice their all
('82', 298, 2, 3, 516321) and even their lives for his sake.
('82', 298, 2, 4, 516356) It is now more than six months since the Pir
('82', 298, 3, 5, 516401) of Pagaro was arrested.
('82', 298, 3, 6, 516425) In the beginning of this period the frequency of the
('82', 298, 4, 7, 516478) criminal activities of the Hurs was not as great as now.
('82', 298, 4, 8, 516535) With the passage of
('82', 298, 5, 9, 516555) time their activities have assumed not only greater frequency but have
('82', 298, 6, 10, 516626) extended to other talukas than the original three.
('82', 298, 6, 11, 516677) The Hurs have started their
('82', 298, 7, 12, 516705) own Government.
('82', 298, 7, 13, 516721) Not only have they appointed a leader whom they call their
('82', 298, 8, 14, 516780) King but have appointed commanders, captains, etc.
('82', 298, 8, 15, 516831) They are said to have
('82', 298, 9, 16, 516853) divided themselves into groups, and assigned separate jurisdiction to each
('82', 298, 10, 17, 516928) group Their activities were in the beginning directed against Government and

('82', 298, 13, 21, 517160) and are now attacking all and sundry.
('82', 298, 13, 22, 517198) No one seems to be free from their

('82', 298, 15, 24, 517309) official or a petty kotar or beldar, rich or poor, innocent or guilty.
('82', 298, 16, 25, 517380) women are not spared There is a tradition that Hurs do not attack women or
('82', 298, 17, 26, 517455) innocent persons.
('82', 298, 17, 27, 517473) But it is said latterly young and mischievous elements
('82', 298, 18, 28, 517528) among them have thrown the old traditions to the winds and spare no one.
('82', 298, 19, 29, 517601) With a view to make their activities more effective, they have started a
('82', 298, 20, 30, 517674) deliberate move for collecting rifles, guns, ammunitions, clothes, and money.
('82', 298, 21, 31, 517752) Latterly their attacks in many cases have been directed against those who are
('82', 298, 22, 32, 517830) in possession of these things.
('82', 298, 22, 33, 517861) In this way they are said to have collected many

('82', 298, 23, 35, 517962) They organize their
('82', 298, 24, 36, 517982) attacks in military fashion and are on occasions dressed in khaki shirts and
('82', 298, 25, 37, 518059) shorts.
('82', 298, 25, 38, 518067) When the Khipro Sanghar bus was attacked on the 16th April, the

('82', 298, 29, 44, 518360) to greet them thinking they were some military soldiers.
('82', 298, 29, 45, 518417) They attack and
('82', 298, 30, 46, 518433) shoot under orders.
('82', 298, 30, 47, 518453) They are also said to be levying taxes from zamindars and
('82', 298, 31, 48, 518511) merchants.
('82', 298, 31, 49, 518522) Threats are given to them that their ‘Kharas’ of wheat would be
('82', 298, 32, 50, 518586) burnt or they would be dealt with in some other way if they did not pay taxes to
('82', 298, 33, 51, 518667) them, as they declare themselves to be the Government in those areas.
('82', 298, 34, 52, 518737) said that many people do yield to their threats as otherwise not only their

('82', 298, 35, 54, 518857) There is a general belief in the
('82', 298, 36, 55, 518890) affected areas that Government are powerless to protect those who render aid to
('82', 298, 37, 56, 518970) the authorities or who refuse to submit to the dictates of the Hurs.
('82', 298, 37, 57, 519039) Several

('82', 299, 1, 2, 519089) persons who have acted thus have been murdered or been targets of other
('82', 299, 2, 3, 519161) attacks.
('82', 299, 2, 4, 519170) People are in a state of sheer helplessness.
('82', 299, 2, 5, 519215) It must not be supposed
('82', 299, 3, 6, 519239) that Hurs are responsible for all the crimes that are now being committed in

('82', 299, 5, 9, 519394) by the Hurs several unsocial and criminal elements, of which there is an

('82', 299, 9, 14, 519693) main streams of criminal activities: one of the Hurs and the other of non Hur

('82', 299, 12, 18, 519923) the situation can be realized from the fact that normal functioning of the

('82', 299, 14, 21, 520074) police posts are said to have been abolished and only one police station has

('82', 299, 18, 26, 520390) Being afraid of attack at night, they do not venture to do their normal work

('82', 299, 20, 29, 520549) Taluka Headquarters before sunset have so emboldened the Hurs and other
('82', 299, 21, 30, 520621) elements that they think the British Government has ceased to exist for them.
('82', 299, 22, 31, 520699) Like the police, the normal functioning of the Revenue Department has also to

('82', 301, 1, 10, 525480) If they remain in the Assembly they cannot give undivided attention to their task.

('82', 301, 1, 12, 525766) That should be an earnest of their desire to make room for those who think they can deal with the grave situation with better effect.

('82', 302, 1, 2, 527025) 350. LETTER TO TAYYABULLA
('82', 302, 2, 3, 527051) May 19, 1942
('82', 302, 3, 4, 527064) DEAR TAYYABULLA, I am helpless.
('82', 302, 3, 5, 527096) You should approach the President.
('82', 302, 6, 6, 527131) From a photostat: G.N. 63
('82', 302, 7, 7, 527157) 351. WHAT SHOULD BE THE MAXIMUM DEDUCTIONS FROM THE SPINNERS’ WAGES 1
('82', 302, 8, 8, 527227) Q. There are many opinions on what should be the percentage to be deducted
('82', 302, 9, 9, 527302) from the spinners’ wages, for providing khadi to them....
('82', 302, 9, 10, 527360) I request you to guide the
('82', 302, 10, 11, 527387) khadi workers by explaining through Khadi Jagat what the policy is and how the
('82', 302, 11, 12, 527466) percentage of deduction should be determined.
('82', 302, 12, 13, 527512) A. In fact in raising the wages of the spinners the Charkha Sangh was guided by only one consideration: namely, that it was its duty as a philanthropic organization to give adequate wages to those who had never got them.
('82', 302, 12, 14, 527733) The Charkha Sangh came into existence neither for those who wear khadi nor for those who want to be self sufficient in clothes but for those who produce khadi by their labour, particularly the spinners.
('82', 302, 12, 15, 527936) The idea behind it is that spinning is a source of livelihood for crores of people and if they get sufficient work, starvation can be mitigated to some extent.
('82', 302, 13, 16, 528096) Now if we want to raise the wages of the spinners we can do so only if all the people wear khadi, otherwise all the spinners cannot get enough work.
('82', 302, 13, 17, 528245) There is no need for an organization like theCharkha Sangh for helping only a few persons.
('82', 302, 13, 18, 528336) If it is obligatory for all the persons to wear khadi, then certainly the spinners must also wear it.
('82', 302, 13, 19, 528438) It will be as good as giving them a dole if the spinners do not wear khadi and we go on giving them higher wages than they demand.
('82', 302, 13, 20, 528569) To give such a dole was never the aim of the Charkha Sangh.
('82', 302, 14, 21, 528629) 1 This was originally published in Khadi Jagat.
('82', 303, 0, 1, 528677) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 304
('82', 303, 1, 2, 528719) So on the one hand it was our duty to give more wages to the spinners, on the other it was our duty to make them and their families wear khadi.
('82', 303, 1, 3, 528863) For the observance of the latter dharma we can certainly tell the spinners to utilize the extra wages they are getting in meeting the expenses on khadi.
('82', 303, 2, 4, 529016) But we would not have succeeded in doing that and so we adopted the middle path.
('82', 303, 2, 5, 529097) We made whatever progress we could.
('82', 303, 2, 6, 529133) We had no means of forcing others, have none and shall have none.
('82', 303, 2, 7, 529199) The Charkha Sangh is a symbol of ahimsa and at the same time a great experiment in it.
('82', 303, 2, 8, 529286) It is based purely on a sense of justice.
('82', 303, 2, 9, 529328) It endeavours to do justice to those who have long been denied it.
('82', 303, 2, 10, 529395) All of our decisions should therefore be guided purely by a sense of justice.
('82', 303, 3, 11, 529473) It must be remembered that our aim is to give to all the spinners an anna for an hour.
('82', 303, 3, 12, 529560) But we have fallen short of it.
('82', 303, 3, 13, 529592) We do not have the means to reach that rate.
('82', 303, 3, 14, 529637) Our tools are not such that they would enable the spinners to earn an anna for an hour’s work.
('82', 303, 4, 15, 529732) It is our duty to give higher wages to the spinners if we can in these days of rising prices.
('82', 303, 4, 16, 529826) Only the experts on charkha and those experienced in this field can decide about it.
('82', 303, 5, 17, 529911) One has to use one’s discretion while arriving at a decision.
('82', 303, 5, 18, 529973) If common sense suggests that from the increased wages of the spinners we should not make a deduction in order to make them khadi wearers, then we should under no circumstances make any deduction.
('82', 303, 5, 19, 530170) We should never make deductions by which the spinners are compelled to buy more than their family requirements.
('82', 303, 5, 20, 530282) In other words we have to regard the spinners as members of our family and collect money from them accordingly.
('82', 303, 5, 21, 530394) We should never take undue advantage of their ignorance.
('82', 303, 5, 22, 530451) We should realize their requirements and take the necessary steps.

('82', 308, 1, 2, 534853) 359. QUESTION BOX
('82', 308, 2, 3, 534871) The six 1 questions that follow are from workers who endorse my plan for the withdrawal of the British Power.
('82', 308, 2, 4, 534981) The answers have to be read in the light of the plan.
('82', 308, 2, 5, 535035) The workers should know that no plan, however wise it may be, can produce the intended effect if it does not commend itself to those for whose benefit it is presented, or if they are too weak to follow it out.
('82', 308, 2, 6, 535245) Now for my answers:
('82', 308, 3, 7, 535265) NOT RIGHT
('82', 308, 4, 8, 535275) Q. Are we right in believing that you wish the Congress and the people to
('82', 308, 5, 9, 535349) become capable as soon as possible of taking over the administration and to do so on
('82', 308, 6, 10, 535434) the first opportunity?
('82', 308, 7, 11, 535457) A. You are not right.
('82', 308, 7, 12, 535479) I cannot speak for the Congress.
('82', 308, 7, 13, 535512) But I want no organization or individual to become capable of taking over the administration.
('82', 308, 7, 14, 535606) In non violent technique, it is unthinkable.
('82', 308, 7, 15, 535651) You do not take over power.
('82', 308, 7, 16, 535679) It may descend to you being given by the people.
('82', 308, 7, 17, 535728) In an anarchical state, all turbulent elements will make a bid for power.
('82', 308, 7, 18, 535802) Those who will serve the people and will evolve order out of chaos willspend themselves in removing chaos.
('82', 308, 7, 19, 535909) If they survive, the popular will may put them in as administrators.
('82', 308, 7, 20, 535978) This is wholly different from what you have imagined.
('82', 308, 7, 21, 536032) People who make a bid for power generally fail to achieve it.
('82', 308, 8, 22, 536094) Q. In resisting unjust military or civil orders, is the primary motive
('82', 308, 9, 23, 536165) (a) protest against the Government action, (b) alleviation of the peoples’ sufferings,
('82', 308, 10, 24, 536252) or (c) a preliminary step towards the capture of power?
('82', 308, 11, 25, 536308) A. The central point of my conception is non violence.
('82', 308, 11, 26, 536363) In trying to educate the people to be without the British or any power, the chief thing is to resist all injustice, no matter how or by whom it is perpetrated.
('82', 308, 11, 27, 536523) Here resistance is not by way of protest, certainly not a preliminary step towards gaining power.
('82', 308, 11, 28, 536621) I want thousands of people to resist injustice.
('82', 308, 11, 29, 536669) If they all were to do so to seize power, they will never succeed.
('82', 308, 11, 30, 536736) It is surely enough for them to resist the injustice they feel.
('82', 308, 12, 31, 536800) 1 The answer to the sixth question was written on May 23, 1942, and hence appears under that date under the heading “Question Box”.
('82', 309, 0, 1, 536932) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 310
('82', 309, 1, 2, 536974) is in itself a duty.
('82', 309, 2, 3, 536995) Q. Do you expect individual Congressmen to offer resistance in cases where
('82', 309, 3, 4, 537070) the villagers or general public are not prepared to come forward?
('82', 309, 4, 5, 537136) A. If I can speak for Congressmen I would say most emphatically “yes”.
('82', 309, 4, 6, 537207) People who are terror struck have no gumption.
('82', 309, 4, 7, 537254) Those who have, have to intercede even at the cost of their lives.
('82', 309, 5, 8, 537321) SELF PROTECTION
('82', 309, 6, 9, 537337) Q. Shall we go to reason with the officials who refuse to allow the
('82', 309, 7, 10, 537405) organization of self protective units?
('82', 309, 7, 11, 537444) And if they do not listen.
('82', 309, 7, 12, 537471) shall we still go on?
('82', 309, 8, 13, 537493) A. People have to protect themselves against officials, against dacoits and possibly Japanese.
('82', 309, 8, 14, 537588) If they do not, they are doomed.
('82', 309, 8, 15, 537621) Therefore they may not brook any interference with their preparation.
('82', 309, 8, 16, 537691) But they may not bear arms without licence.
('82', 309, 8, 17, 537735) What I have in mind is gymnastics, drill, lathi play and the like.
('82', 309, 8, 18, 537802) The authorities are not likely to interfere with these practices.
('82', 309, 8, 19, 537868) But if they do, the people affected may disregard prohibition and take the consequences.
('82', 309, 10, 20, 537957) Q. Villagers here are much troubled for want of salt which they used to get
('82', 309, 11, 21, 538033) largely from Calcutta.
('82', 309, 11, 22, 538056) If they defy the Salt Laws they can easily make sufficient
('82', 309, 12, 23, 538115) stocks for the needs of the Province.
('82', 309, 12, 24, 538153) Cattle in these parts are given no salt.
('82', 309, 12, 25, 538194) If salt
('82', 309, 13, 26, 538202) became free this serious defect could also be removed.
('82', 309, 13, 27, 538257) May we advise the people to
('82', 309, 14, 28, 538285) make all the salt they need for the Province?
('82', 309, 14, 29, 538331) After the rains begin they will not be
('82', 309, 15, 30, 538370) able to make salt.
('82', 309, 16, 31, 538389) A. Manufacture of salt for home consumption is covered by the Irwin Gandhi Pact.
('82', 309, 16, 32, 538470) The ten mile radius at present is unworkable.
('82', 309, 16, 33, 538516) I do think that in these hard times the restriction should be relaxed and as far as possible the people should be left to help themselves.
('82', 309, 16, 34, 538655) The main revenue from salt is not likely to be affected by the laxity of administration in favour of the poor people.
('82', 309, 16, 35, 538773) I would advise local adjustment with the authorities.
('82', 309, 17, 36, 538827) The idea underlying my plan, however visionary or even mischievous it may appear to be, is that if the setting given is non violent and the workers understand and carry it out, the withdrawal of British authority can take place without much disturbance and certainly without the Japanese replacing that authority
('82', 310, 0, 1, 539140) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 311
('82', 310, 1, 2, 539183) unless, as has been suggested, the popular mind is in favour of the Japanese.
('82', 310, 2, 3, 539261) While I was preparing this note, I received a letter from Rajen Babu who writes as follows about salt:
('82', 310, 3, 4, 539364) During my tour I have made it a point to meet representatives of
('82', 310, 4, 5, 539429) merchants and traders at every place I visit, with a view to ascertaining the

('82', 310, 8, 10, 539732) developing with regard to supply of salt.

('82', 314, 2, 20, 548466) 364. QUESTION BOX
('82', 314, 3, 21, 548484) OUT OF TOUCH
('82', 314, 4, 22, 548497) Q. Do you know, being confined in Sevagram, how much you are out of touch
('82', 314, 5, 23, 548571) with the public?
('82', 314, 5, 24, 548588) If you were not you would not talk of resisting the Japanese as you
('82', 314, 6, 25, 548656) For the dislike of the British is so great that the man in the street is ready to
('82', 314, 7, 26, 548738) welcome the Japanese.
('82', 314, 8, 27, 548760) A. I cannot endorse your proposition that I am out of touch with the public.
('82', 314, 8, 28, 548837) Though I am confined in Sevagram I see all sorts of people and receive correspondence from every nook and corner of India.
('82', 314, 8, 29, 548960) Probably, therefore, I am more in touch with the people than you can be though living in a big town.
('82', 314, 8, 30, 549061) You have not the opportunity that I have of gauging the public mind.
('82', 314, 8, 31, 549130) But let us grant that what you say is right—I believe you are partially right,—my suppressing the
('82', 315, 0, 1, 549228) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 316
('82', 315, 1, 2, 549270) true remedy will not alter the public mind.
('82', 315, 1, 3, 549314) On the contrary, I am showing the futility of hatred.
('82', 315, 1, 4, 549368) I am showing that hatred injures the hater never the hated.
('82', 315, 1, 5, 549428) An Imperial power cannot act otherwise than it has been doing.
('82', 315, 1, 6, 549491) If we are strong the British becomes powerless.
('82', 315, 1, 7, 549539) I am therefore trying to wean the people from their hatred by asking them to develop the strength of mind to invite the British to withdraw and at the same time to resist the Japanese.
('82', 315, 1, 8, 549724) With the British withdrawal the incentive to welcome the Japanese goes and the strength felt in securing British withdrawal will be used for stemming the Japanese inroad.
('82', 315, 1, 9, 549895) I endorse C.R.’s proposition that the millions of India can resist the Japanese even without the possession of arms, modern and ancient, if they are properly organized.
('82', 315, 1, 10, 550064) I differ from him when he says that this can be done even when the British arms are operating without co ordination when you force yourself on the British power.
('82', 315, 1, 11, 550226) Experience teaches us that hearty co ordination and co operation is impossible where mutual trust and respect are wanting.
('82', 315, 1, 12, 550349) British presence invites the Japanese, it promotes communal disunion and other discords, and what is perhaps the worst of all, deepens the hatred born of impotence.
('82', 315, 1, 13, 550514) Orderly British withdrawal will turn the hatred into affection and will automatically remove communal distemper.
('82', 315, 1, 14, 550627) So far as I can see the two communities are unable to think or see things intheir proper perspective as long as they are under the influence of the third power.

('82', 318, 5, 8, 553786) 369. FOR RAJAJ1
('82', 318, 6, 9, 553802) There is no doubt that Rajaji is handling a cause which has isolated him from his colleagues.
('82', 318, 6, 10, 553896) But his worst enemy will not accuse him of any selfish motive behind the extraordinary energy with which he has thrown himself into the controversy of which he is the author.
('82', 318, 6, 11, 554071) It reflects the greatest credit on him.
('82', 318, 6, 12, 554111) He is entitled to a respectful hearing.
('82', 318, 6, 13, 554151) His motive is lofty.
('82', 318, 6, 14, 554172) It is a noble thing to strive for Hindu Muslim unity, equally noble to strive to ward off the Japanese intrusion.
('82', 318, 6, 15, 554286) In his opinion the two are intertwined.
('82', 318, 7, 16, 554326) Hooliganism is no answer to his argument.
('82', 318, 7, 17, 554368) The disturbances at his meetings are a sign of great intolerance.
('82', 318, 7, 18, 554434) Evolution of democracy is not possible if we are not prepared to hear the other side.
('82', 318, 7, 19, 554520) We shut the doors of reason when we refuse to listen to our opponents or having listened make fun of them.
('82', 318, 7, 20, 554627) If intolerance becomes a habit, we run the risk of missing the truth.
('82', 318, 7, 21, 554697) Whilst with the limits that nature has put upon our understanding we must act fearlessly according to the light vouchsafed to us, we must always keep an open mind and be everready to find that what we believed to be truth was, after all, untruth.
('82', 318, 7, 22, 554944) This openness of mind strengthens the truth in us and removes the dross from it, if there is any.
('82', 318, 7, 23, 555042) I plead therefore with all who are disturbing Rajaji’s meetings not to do so but to give him a patient and respectful hearing to which he is entitled.
('82', 318, 8, 24, 555193) The reader knows that I hold Rajaji to be in the wrong.
('82', 318, 8, 25, 555249) He is creating a false atmosphere.
('82', 318, 8, 26, 555284) He does not believe in Pakistan nor do the nationalist Muslims and others who concede the right of separation or secession.
('82', 318, 8, 27, 555408) They and Rajaji say that that is the way to wean the Muslim League from the demand for separation.
('82', 318, 8, 28, 555507) I am surprised that many Muslims rejoice over a concession of doubtful value.
('82', 318, 8, 29, 555585) I see nothing but seeds of further quarrel in it.
('82', 318, 8, 30, 555635) It should be
('82', 319, 0, 1, 555648) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 320
('82', 319, 1, 2, 555690) enough to state the proposition that nothing can prevent the Muslim League from having it if the Muslims really want it.
('82', 319, 1, 3, 555811) They will take it by the vote or the sword unless they will submit to arbitration.
('82', 319, 1, 4, 555894) But all this can only happen when the British Power is entirely withdrawn and the Japanese menace has abated.
('82', 319, 1, 5, 556004) Till then there is neither Pakistan nor Hindustan or any other ‘stan’.
('82', 319, 1, 6, 556075) It is today Englishtan and may be tomorrow Japanistan, if we do not take care.
('82', 319, 1, 7, 556154) If all who consider India to be their home now and for ever will pull their full weight to deliver it from the present and the impending peril, and when both the perils are finally removed, it will be time to talk of Pakistan and other ‘stan’s and to come to an amicable decision or fight.

('82', 323, 1, 2, 559655) 377. TERRIBLE IF TRUE 1
('82', 323, 2, 3, 559679) A terrible tale of ordered anarchy comes from Khurja.
('82', 323, 2, 4, 559733) A correspondent writes to say that, for no cause he can understand, practically all normal activities have been stopped.
('82', 323, 2, 5, 559854) 2 Even the sale of bamboos and mats for biers was prohibited.
('82', 323, 2, 6, 559916) Even building activities have been stopped causing the greatest inconvenience and damage.
('82', 323, 2, 7, 560006) Money is taken from the people on the slightest pretext and a reign of terror prevails.
('82', 323, 2, 8, 560094) I have given here the barest outline of the doings in Khurja in the hope that there will be full investigation and if the facts are true further damage will be prevented.

('82', 323, 4, 10, 560307) 378. INDIAN SOLDIERS RUN AMUCK?
('82', 323, 5, 11, 560339) I take the following from the report of the Secretary, B.P.C.C., on the shooting alleged to have taken place by soldiers of Indian Signal Corps on 17th and 18th instant at Nivodhai near Duttaparkar in Barasat sub division, Bengal:
('82', 323, 6, 12, 560570) A batch of Indian troops about 7 or 8, while engaged in sinking
('82', 323, 7, 13, 560634) telephone posts entered the garden of Rabindranath Bose at about 1 p.m.
('82', 323, 8, 14, 560706) the 17th May, plucked fruits and wilfully damaged green mangoes and
('82', 323, 9, 15, 560774) jack fruits, etc., whereupon Rabindra and Shashindra protested against their
('82', 323, 10, 16, 560851) conduct.
('82', 323, 10, 17, 560860) The soldiers thereupon assaulted them and kicked Shashindra when he
('82', 323, 11, 18, 560928) fell down.
('82', 323, 11, 19, 560939) Shashindra was attended by Dr. Tulsidas Sarkar, a local medical
('82', 323, 12, 20, 561003) The soldiers also raided the house of Hari Charan Das and Sashanka Das
('82', 323, 13, 21, 561074) and damaged the cooking and other utensils and threatened the local people

('82', 324, 4, 6, 561828) village on the 18th morning, when that unfortunate firing took place....
('82', 324, 5, 7, 561901) day on the 18th May, the soldiers numbering about 25 came to the scene of
('82', 324, 6, 8, 561975) occurrence with arms at about 7 a.m.
('82', 324, 6, 9, 562012) Out of these men about 12 or 13 entered
('82', 324, 7, 10, 562052) the Nivodhai village at 8.30 a.m.
('82', 324, 7, 11, 562086) and started patrolling the streets using
('82', 324, 8, 12, 562127) abusive language to the villagers and womenfolk and threatened them with
('82', 324, 9, 13, 562200) their rifles and bullets.
('82', 324, 9, 14, 562226) They, then entered the tailoring shop of Ratan Das and
('82', 324, 10, 15, 562281) assaulted him.
('82', 324, 10, 16, 562296) After assaulting Ratan Das they again entered the garden of
('82', 324, 11, 17, 562356) Robin Bose, knocked at the door and threatened to assault the female members
('82', 324, 12, 18, 562433) of the house.
('82', 324, 12, 19, 562447) The panic stricken inmates having raised a hue and cry, a large
('82', 324, 13, 20, 562511) number of villagers (40 to 50) assembled there to rescue them.
('82', 324, 13, 21, 562574) Thereupon, the
('82', 324, 14, 22, 562589) troops gave a signal to the other members of the corps who were waiting in
('82', 324, 15, 23, 562664) the neighbourhood, when they also ran to the place of occurrence.
('82', 324, 16, 24, 562730) Four or five local young men, namely, Sushil Kanjilal, Bejoy Kumar Mukherjee, Sambhu Nath Dutta and Santosh Nath approached the soldiers and requested them not to intimidate the innocent people and asked them to leave the place, whereupon they got enraged and assaulted Sushil Kanjilal on the head with the butt end of a gun (he has since been removed to Calcutta Medical School Hospital for treatment).
('82', 324, 16, 25, 563134) At this the villagers got frightened and tried to run away when Bejoy Mukherjee was pushed down by the soldiers and a tussle ensued between them, then he fell into the adjacent tank and the soldiers got hold of him and ducked him in water.
('82', 324, 16, 26, 563374) The villagers, thereupon, being exasperated ran to his rescue and some of them pelted stones at the soldiers.
('82', 324, 16, 27, 563484) They then left Bejoy in the tank and opened six rounds of shot as a result of which Bejoy was wounded and fell down.
('82', 324, 16, 28, 563601) Santosh Nath and Sambhu Dutta also received gun shot wounds and have subsequently been removed to Calcutta Medical School for treatment.
('82', 324, 16, 29, 563738) The condition of Santosh Nath is reported to be very serious.
('82', 324, 16, 30, 563800) Immediately after firing the signallers left the place dragging the body of Bejoy towards the place where the military lorry was standing.
('82', 324, 16, 31, 563939) After the soldiers had gone away, villagers began to search for the victim when Sudarshan Mukherji, Sripada Mukherji, Bojomohon Bose and others found Bejoy in a dying condition with intestines ripped open and groaning under the bush, near the Railway Home Signal in a ditch close to Rabindra’s garden.
('82', 324, 16, 32, 564241) He was carried to the nearest Kalibari where he died saying that he was dragged in and trampled upon by the booted soldiers on his chest and other parts of the body and was also bayonetted.
('82', 324, 16, 33, 564431) He could say no more and he succumbed
