('82', 333, 0, 1, 573233) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 333, 1, 2, 573275) 393. CONVERSATION WITH MEMBER’S OF THE RASHTRIYA YUVAK SANGH 1
('82', 333, 2, 3, 573338) May 28, 1942
('82', 333, 3, 4, 573351) Commenting on the poor physique of the members Gandhiji said: These days our bodies are completely devoid of muscles.
('82', 333, 3, 5, 573469) The bodies of the boys sitting opposite me, just like my body, are without muscles.
('82', 333, 3, 6, 573553) What message should I give them?
('82', 333, 3, 7, 573586) I can tell them only one thing: have good bodies and be healthy....
('82', 333, 4, 8, 573654) Instead of repeating what I have said so often it would be better that you should ask me questions and I should answer them.
('82', 333, 5, 9, 573779) Q. How can we drive away the British from here?
('82', 333, 6, 10, 573827) GANDHIJI (humorously): You do learn how to wield the lathi.
('82', 333, 6, 11, 573887) Drive them away with its help.
('82', 333, 7, 12, 573918) Q. We can do that provided we have lathis.
('82', 333, 8, 13, 573961) G. In that case you belong to my creed.
('82', 333, 8, 14, 574001) I have given up the lathi.
('82', 333, 8, 15, 574028) You too have given it up.
('82', 333, 8, 16, 574054) You people learn how to wield the lathi.
('82', 333, 8, 17, 574095) I too keep this with me.
('82', 333, 8, 18, 574120) But I do not strike anyone with it.
('82', 333, 8, 19, 574156) It is only meant for giving me support.
('82', 333, 8, 20, 574196) You should put the lathi to similar use.
('82', 333, 8, 21, 574237) Your lathis are not meant for striking others.
('82', 333, 9, 22, 574284) Two questions are implied in your question.
('82', 333, 9, 23, 574328) ‘Do we want to drive away the British or do we want to put an end to their domination?’
('82', 333, 10, 24, 574416) Members with one voice: We want to end their domination.
('82', 333, 11, 25, 574473) G. That is the correct attitude.
('82', 333, 11, 26, 574506) I have many friends among Englishmen.
('82', 333, 11, 27, 574544) But I cannot say that about all Englishmen, though I would like to be friends with all of them.
('82', 333, 11, 28, 574640) There should not be a single Englishman who is not my friend.
('82', 333, 11, 29, 574702) I want to be friendly with all the peoples of the world, not only Englishmen.
('82', 333, 11, 30, 574780) But I want to be friendly
('82', 333, 12, 31, 574806) 1 About a hundred members of the Rashtriya Yuvak Sangh, C. P., called on Gandhiji at Sevagram after their annual training camp at Wardha was over.
('82', 333, 12, 32, 574953) They spent half an hour with Gandhiji during his morning walk.
('82', 333, 12, 33, 575016) A brief report of the interview was also published in Harijan, 7 6 1942, under the heading “To Resist the Slave Drivers”.
('82', 334, 0, 1, 575138) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 335
('82', 334, 1, 2, 575181) particularly with Englishmen because I have been associated with them for the last many years.
('82', 334, 1, 3, 575276) It is immaterial what kind of association it was—let it be that they were masters and I was a slave—but we were associated.
('82', 334, 1, 4, 575400) That is the reason I want to be friendly with the British particularly.
('82', 334, 1, 5, 575472) But it is British domination and British imperialism which I want to banish from this land.
('82', 334, 1, 6, 575564) I am telling the British rulers to withdraw quietly.
('82', 334, 1, 7, 575617) It is the British domination that we want to end altogether because it is a poison which corrupts everything it touches.
('82', 334, 1, 8, 575738) This rule is an obstacle to all progress.
('82', 334, 2, 9, 575780) There are two ways of getting rid of imperialism: either we wipe out the Empire or we quit it.
('82', 334, 2, 10, 575875) I have suggested a method of quitting it.

('82', 340, 2, 3, 588311) May 28, 1942 1
('82', 340, 3, 4, 588326) Answering the question of a Press correspondent whether his present policy as
('82', 340, 4, 5, 588404) revealed by his writings did not vitiate his own declaration that he was a friend of
('82', 340, 5, 6, 588489) China, Gandhiji said: My answer is an emphatic ‘no’.
('82', 340, 5, 7, 588542) I remain the passionate friend of China that I have always claimed to be.
('82', 340, 5, 8, 588616) I know what loss of freedom means.
('82', 340, 5, 9, 588651) Therefore, I could not but be in sympathy with China which is my next door neighbour in distress.
('82', 340, 5, 10, 588749) And, if I believed in violence and if I could influence India, I would put in motion every force at my command on behalf of China to save her liberty.
('82', 340, 5, 11, 588900) In making, therefore, the suggestion which I have made about withdrawal of British power, I have not lost sight of China.
('82', 340, 5, 12, 589022) But because I have China in mind, I feel that the only effective way for India to help China is to persuade Great Britain to free India and let a free India make her full contribution to the war effort.
('82', 340, 5, 13, 589225) Instead of being sullen and discontented, India free will be a mighty force for the good of mankind in general.
('82', 340, 5, 14, 589337) It is true that the solution I have presented is a heroic solution beyond the ken of Englishmen.
('82', 340, 5, 15, 589434) But being a true friend of Britain and China and Russia, I must not suppress the solution which I believe to be eminently practical and probably the only one in order to save the situation and in order to convert the war into a power for good instead of being what it is, a peril to humanity.
('82', 340, 5, 16, 589727) Pandit Nehru told me yesterday that he heard people in Lahore and Delhi saying that I have turned pro Japanese.
('82', 340, 5, 17, 589839) I could only laugh at the suggestion, for, if I am sincere in my passion for freedom, I could not consciously or unconsciously take a step which will involve India in the position of merely changing masters.
('82', 340, 5, 18, 590047) If, in spite of my resistance to the Japanese menace with my whole soul the mishap occurs, of which I have never denied the possibility, then the blame would rest wholly on British shoulders.
('82', 340, 5, 19, 590239) I have no shadow of doubt about it.
('82', 340, 5, 20, 590275) I have made no suggestion which, even from the military

('82', 341, 1, 2, 590403) standpoint, is fraught with the slightest danger to British power or to Chinese.
('82', 341, 1, 3, 590484) It is obvious that India is not allowed to pull her weight in favour of China.
('82', 341, 1, 4, 590563) If British power is withdrawn from India in an orderly manner, Britain will be relieved of the burden of keeping the peace in India and at the same time gain in a free India an ally not in the cause of Empire—because she would have renounced in toto all her imperial designs, but in a defence, not pretended but wholly real, of human freedom.

('82', 347, 3, 13, 604117) 402. ALCHEMY OF PRODUCING FOOD
('82', 347, 4, 14, 604148) Below will be found an extract from a letter of the Hon.
('82', 347, 4, 15, 604205) Secretary of Marwari Relief Society’s Social Service Department:
('82', 347, 5, 16, 604270) We are on the threshold of an acute food shortage crisis today.
('82', 347, 6, 17, 604334) deal is being heard of the “grow more food” campaign, and it is no doubt a
('82', 347, 7, 18, 604409) move in the right direction.
('82', 347, 7, 19, 604438) But in my humble opinion, our leaders have not
('82', 347, 8, 20, 604485) given due consideration to one considerable potential source of food supply in
('82', 347, 9, 21, 604564) our country, which if successfully tapped, would feed at least 50 lakhs of our
('82', 347, 10, 22, 604643) starving fellowmen.
('82', 347, 10, 23, 604663) I refer to the tremendous waste of food that every one of
('82', 347, 11, 24, 604721) us in this country indulges in, when taking our meals morning and evening
('82', 347, 12, 25, 604795) and also the disgraceful waste that is usually seen on festive occasions.
('82', 347, 13, 26, 604869) aggregate amount thus thrown into the dust bins could easily keep 5 millions
('82', 347, 14, 27, 604946) of our countrymen from a perpetual state of semi starvation.
('82', 347, 14, 28, 605007) While passing
('82', 347, 15, 29, 605021) along the streets of Calcutta, I have been shocked to find my own brothers and
('82', 347, 16, 30, 605100) sisters picking up rotten food from the dustbins and eating it.
('82', 347, 16, 31, 605164) The thought of
('82', 347, 17, 32, 605179) such a ghastly scene which can be described as nothing short of a national
('82', 347, 18, 33, 605254) disgrace has haunted me day and night and I have felt ashamed to take my food
('82', 347, 19, 34, 605332) at home.
('82', 347, 19, 35, 605341) The Secretary further asks me to suggest ways and means of organizing a campaign popularizing the plan suggested in the letter.
('82', 347, 19, 36, 605469) The plan I can heartily recommend.
('82', 347, 19, 37, 605504) All the belligerent countries have
('82', 348, 0, 1, 605539) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 349
('82', 348, 1, 2, 605582) been forced to cut food supplies all round.
('82', 348, 1, 3, 605626) There is naturally therefore not much scope for wastage in these countries.
('82', 348, 1, 4, 605702) In our country seemingly we are not reduced to the straits to which the belligerent countries are reduced.
('82', 348, 1, 5, 605809) In reality, however, the wastage which is truly enormous is confined to the few within the cities.
('82', 348, 1, 6, 605908) The millions are living in a state of perpetual semi starvation.
('82', 348, 1, 7, 605973) For them it is like living in a chronic state of war.
('82', 348, 1, 8, 606027) Day in and day out they know not what a square meal is.
('82', 348, 1, 9, 606083) For them who have no margin the pressure of the present war can better be imagined than described.
('82', 348, 1, 10, 606182) What the Secretary suggests is worthy of consideration.
('82', 348, 1, 11, 606238) A campaign against waste can be easily organized in all the cities.
('82', 348, 1, 12, 606306) No householder should be without the knowledge of how he or she can avoid waste.
('82', 348, 1, 13, 606387) There is here no question of denial.
('82', 348, 1, 14, 606424) The question is only one of consideration for the poor.
('82', 348, 1, 15, 606480) All saving thus made will be equal to so much food production without effort.
('82', 348, 1, 16, 606558) There will have to be literature on the subject.
('82', 348, 1, 17, 606607) It should not be elaborate.
('82', 348, 1, 18, 606635) Leaflets should suffice.
('82', 348, 1, 19, 606660) They must not be argumentative.
('82', 348, 1, 20, 606692) By facts and figures they should tell the citizens how much waste they are responsible for and how they can avoid it.
('82', 348, 1, 21, 606810) The horrible superstition that the dishes of the rich should always be over full so as to leave an ample margin for leavings should be banished forthwith.
('82', 348, 1, 22, 606965) It should be considered a sign of bad breeding to leave one’s plate with a heap of uneaten things, whether at home or in a hotel.
('82', 348, 1, 23, 607095) One should regulate the helpings with strict regard to wants.
('82', 348, 1, 24, 607157) If all who are given to the evil habit of having plates piled up and merely sampling the courses served out were to follow the healthy rule here recommended much food can be saved for distribution among those who are in daily want.
('82', 348, 1, 25, 607389) I think the Marwari Relief Society which has had rich and varied experience in social service is perhaps the fittest body to take the initiative in organizing the work.
('82', 348, 1, 26, 607558) Though the problem will be much the same in all the cities, with every city there will be variations according to people’s habits.
('82', 348, 1, 27, 607689) I suggest, therefore, that the work is begun in Calcutta.
('82', 348, 1, 28, 607747) The experience gained there could be utilized in extending the scope of service.
('82', 348, 1, 29, 607828) It ought not to take more than a week to organize the work in Calcutta.
('82', 348, 1, 30, 607900) Naturally great concentration of energy and a large body of willing workers will be required for this essential and urgent service.
('82', 348, 1, 31, 608032) SEVAGRAM, May 30, 1942 Harijan, 7 6 1942

('82', 350, 7, 16, 610057) 406. A TRIPLE TRAGEDY 1
('82', 350, 8, 17, 610081) The National Herald is an institution.
('82', 350, 8, 18, 610120) It has a directorate which has no personal or financial interest in it.
('82', 350, 8, 19, 610192) It is founded by Jawaharlal Nehru.
('82', 350, 8, 20, 610227) It is only in India that the security of such a paper can be forfeited.
('82', 350, 8, 21, 610299) In fact why any security 2 at all from it?
('82', 350, 8, 22, 610342) And they need the greatest assistance possible from him in the war effort.
('82', 350, 8, 23, 610417) They have exploited his stray sayings torn from their context.
('82', 350, 8, 24, 610480) In any case, what do the Government expect from their repressive policy?
('82', 350, 8, 25, 610553) Consider this forfeiture of security in conjunction with the arrest and detention of Rafi Ahmed Kidwai, ex Minister, the organizer of the Congress in U. P. and a Director of The National Herald.
('82', 350, 8, 26, 610748) Put these two acts side by side with the wanton and almost indecent search of the A. I. C. C. Office, and the tragedy is complete.
('82', 350, 8, 27, 610879) This triple act is in my opinion a great hindrance to national war effort.
('82', 350, 8, 28, 610954) It is so mad as to amount to an invitation to the Japanese to walk into India.
('82', 350, 8, 29, 611033) It is a justification for my friendly invitation to the foreign Government to abdicate in favour of
('82', 350, 9, 30, 611133) 1 This had appeared under the heading “Notes”.

('82', 351, 4, 9, 611836) SEVAGRAM, via WARDHA, C. P., May 31, 1942
('82', 351, 5, 10, 611878) MIRA, I have your very complete illuminating letter.
('82', 351, 5, 11, 611931) The report of the interview 1 is perfect, your answers were straight, unequivocal and courageous.
('82', 351, 5, 12, 612029) I have no criticism to make.
('82', 351, 5, 13, 612058) I can only say, ‘Go on as you are doing.’ I can quite clearly see that you have gone to the right place at the right time.
('82', 351, 5, 14, 612181) I therefore need do nothing more than come straight to your questions which are all good and relevant.
('82', 351, 6, 15, 612284) (1) I think we must tell the people what they should do.
('82', 351, 6, 16, 612341) They will act according to their capacity.
('82', 351, 6, 17, 612384) If we begin to judge their capacity and give directions accordingly, our directions will be halting and even compromising which they should never be.
('82', 351, 6, 18, 612534) You will therefore read my instructions in that light.
('82', 351, 6, 19, 612589) Remember that our attitude is that of complete non co operation with Japanese army, therefore we may not help them in any way, nor may we profit by any dealings with them.
('82', 351, 6, 20, 612761) Therefore we cannot sell anything to them.
('82', 351, 6, 21, 612804) If people are not
('82', 351, 7, 22, 612822) 1 In Bapu’s Letters to Mira the addressee, who was then in Orissa, says: “I had had an interview with two English officials of the then Advisory regime.
('82', 351, 7, 23, 612975) Since we were in possession of the fact that the Government officials were to retire to the hills, forty or fifty miles inland, the moment there was news of the Japanese coming and such files as they could not take in their motor cars were to be burnt and all bridges were to be blown up, my object at the interview was to request them to retire in an orderly fashion, leaving the administrative machinery in our hands.
('82', 351, 7, 24, 613395) I specially pleaded with them to hand us over the keys of the jails and also not to take away the doctors and medical supplies of the civil hospitals.”

('82', 352, 1, 3, 613697) And if they do so the question of having any dealings with Japanese does not and should not arise.
('82', 352, 1, 4, 613796) If, however, the people have not the courage to resist Japanese unto death and not the courage and capacity to evacuate the portion invaded by the Japanese, they will do the best they can in the light of instructions.

('82', 352, 3, 15, 615049) Probably they have been brought under promise that they will deliver the country from foreign yoke.
('82', 352, 3, 16, 615149) There will be no foreign yoke and they will be expected to befriend people and obey National Government that might have been set up in place of British Government.
('82', 352, 3, 17, 615313) If the British have retired in an orderly manner leaving things in Indian hands, the whole thing can work splendidly and it might even be made difficult for Japanese to settle down in India or any part of it in peace, because they will have to deal with a population which will be sullen and resistant.
('82', 352, 3, 18, 615616) It is difficult to say what can happen.
('82', 352, 3, 19, 615656) It is enough if people are trained to cultivate the power of resistance, no matter which power is operating—the Japanese or the British.

('82', 359, 0, 1, 623927) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 359, 1, 2, 623969) 419. QUESTION BOX
('82', 359, 2, 3, 623987) IF THEY COME
('82', 359, 3, 4, 624000) Q. (1) If the Japs come, how are we to resist them non violently?
('82', 359, 4, 5, 624066) (2) What are we to do if we fall into their hands?
('82', 359, 5, 6, 624117) A. (1) These questions come from Andhradesh where the people rightly or wrongly feel that the attack is imminent.
('82', 359, 5, 7, 624231) My answer has already been given in these columns.
('82', 359, 5, 8, 624282) Neither food nor shelter is to be given nor are any dealings to be established with them.
('82', 359, 5, 9, 624372) They should be made to feel that they are not wanted.
('82', 359, 5, 10, 624426) But of course things are not going to happen quite so smoothly as the question implies.
('82', 359, 5, 11, 624514) It is a superstition to think that they will come as friends.
('82', 359, 5, 12, 624576) No attacking party has ever done so.
('82', 359, 5, 13, 624613) It spreads fire and brimstone among the populace.
('82', 359, 5, 14, 624663) It forces things from people.
('82', 359, 5, 15, 624693) If the people cannot resist fierce attack and are afraid of death, they should evacuate the infested place in order to deny compulsory service to the enemy.
('82', 359, 6, 16, 624850) (2) If unfortunately some people are captured or fall into the enemy’s hands, they are likely to be shot if they do not obey orders, e.g., render forced labour.
('82', 359, 6, 17, 625011) If the captives face death cheerfully, their task is done.
('82', 359, 6, 18, 625070) They have saved their own and their country’s honour.
('82', 359, 6, 19, 625124) They could have done nothing more if they had offered violent resistance, save perhaps taking a few Japanese lives and inviting terrible reprisals.
('82', 359, 7, 20, 625272) The thing becomes complicated when you are captured alive and subjected to unthinkable tortures to compel submission.
('82', 359, 7, 21, 625390) You will neither submit to torture nor to the orders of the enemy.
('82', 359, 7, 22, 625457) In the act of resistance you will probably die and escape humiliation.
('82', 359, 7, 23, 625528) But it is said that death is prevented to let the victim go through the agony of tortures and to serve as an example to others.
('82', 359, 7, 24, 625656) I however think that a person who would die rather than go through inhuman tortures would find honourable means of dying.
('82', 359, 8, 25, 625778) SEVAGRAM, June 3, 1942 Harijan, 14 6 1942
('82', 360, 0, 1, 625820) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 361

('82', 361, 1, 2, 627203) 422. LETTER TO AMBALAL SARABHAI
('82', 361, 2, 3, 627235) June 3, 1942
('82', 361, 3, 4, 627248) SUJNA BHAISHRI, I have your letter.
('82', 361, 3, 5, 627284) I have accordingly written to Rameshwardasji to accept your cheque.
('82', 361, 3, 6, 627352) There really never was any misunderstanding between us.
('82', 361, 3, 7, 627408) Whatever little had arisen was from our employing English.
('82', 361, 3, 8, 627467) The first part of your letter of May 22, 1942 is quite all right.
('82', 361, 3, 9, 627533) The Tagore Memorial should be what the Andrews Memorial is.
('82', 361, 3, 10, 627593) Later on you state that it should be different from the Andrews Memorial, that it should be worthy of Tagore and that I should see about it.
('82', 361, 3, 11, 627734) How can the entire Memorial be got ready with just Rs.5,000?
('82', 361, 3, 12, 627795) How can I do it?
('82', 361, 3, 13, 627812) The Andrews Memorial means improvements and innovations in Santiniketan.
('82', 361, 3, 14, 627885) And that will be a memorial to Tagore.
('82', 361, 3, 15, 627924) This is one thing and what you ask for is another.
('82', 361, 3, 16, 627975) It is possible that what you had in mind was the same thing that I said.

('82', 363, 9, 13, 630531) 425. QUESTION BOX
('82', 363, 10, 14, 630549) THE PRINCES’ DETERMINATION
('82', 363, 11, 15, 630576) Q. The Princes seem to be determined to maintain their privileges even after
('82', 363, 12, 16, 630653) the departure of the British.
('82', 363, 12, 17, 630683) Therefore there is need for a plain declaration that they
('82', 363, 13, 18, 630741) would have no place in a free India.
('82', 363, 13, 19, 630778) My feeling is that you have so far shown them
('82', 363, 14, 20, 630824) more consideration than they deserve.
('82', 363, 15, 21, 630862) A. If you are right in your judgment, the privileges themselves will destroy the Princes.
('82', 363, 15, 22, 630952) Privileges that service of the people bestows will always persist.
('82', 363, 15, 23, 631019) But most of the paraphernalia that ‘pomp and circumstance’ account for will most certainly go.
('82', 363, 16, 24, 631114) But I cannot make the declaration you will have me to make.
('82', 363, 16, 25, 631174) It is contrary to the spirit of non violence which seeks not to destroy but to purify.
('82', 363, 16, 26, 631261) That which is beyond purification dies without any outside effort even as a body which has become wholly diseased dies.
('82', 363, 17, 27, 631381) If after the total withdrawal of the British power, there is found to be no awakening among the masses India will be split up into so many feudal strongholds each striving to swallow the small fry and some bidding for overlordship.
('82', 363, 17, 28, 631613) What I am hoping and striving for is an irresistible mass urge on the part of the people and an intelligent response on the part of all privileged classes to the popular demand.
('82', 364, 0, 1, 631791) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 365
('82', 364, 1, 2, 631834) But because I know that this picture is for the time being imaginary, I am quite prepared for the worst.
('82', 364, 1, 3, 631939) Hence my statement that I would end the present state of things even at the risk of anarchy reigning supreme in the land.
('82', 364, 2, 4, 632061) SEVAGRAM, June 5, 1942 Harijan, 14 6 1942

('82', 366, 1, 2, 634196) 429. IMPORTANT QUESTIONS
('82', 366, 2, 3, 634221) [June 6, 1942] 1
('82', 366, 3, 4, 634238) A friend 2 was discussing with I me the implications of the new proposal.
('82', 366, 3, 5, 634312) As the discussion was naturally desultory, I asked him to frame his questions which I would answer through Harijan.
('82', 366, 3, 6, 634428) He agreed and gave me the following:
('82', 366, 4, 7, 634465) Q. You ask the British Government to withdraw immediately from India.
('82', 366, 5, 8, 634535) Indians thereupon form a national government, and what groups or parties would
('82', 366, 6, 9, 634614) participate in such an Indian Government?
('82', 366, 7, 10, 634656) A. My proposal is one sided, i.e., for the British Government to act upon, wholly irrespective of what Indians would do or would not do.
('82', 366, 7, 11, 634793) I have even assumed temporary chaos on their withdrawal.
('82', 366, 7, 12, 634850) But if the withdrawal takes place in an orderly manner, it is likely that on their withdrawal a provisional government will be set up by and from among the present leaders.
('82', 366, 7, 13, 635023) But another thing may also happen.
('82', 366, 7, 14, 635058) All those who have no thought of the nation but only of themselves may make a bid for power and get together the turbulent forces with which they would seek to gain control somewhere and somehow.
('82', 366, 7, 15, 635254) I should hope that with the complete, final and honest withdrawal of the British power, the wise leaders will realize their responsibility, forget their differences for the moment and set up a provisional government out of the material left by the British power.
('82', 366, 7, 16, 635517) As there would be no power regulating the admission or rejection of parties or persons to or from the council board, restraint alone will be the guide.
('82', 366, 7, 17, 635669) If that happens probably the Congress, the League and the States’ representatives will be allowed to function and they will come to a loose understanding on the formation of a provisional national Government.
('82', 366, 7, 18, 635878) All this is necessarily guesswork and nothing more.
('82', 366, 8, 19, 635930) Q. Would that Indian national government permit the United Nations to use
('82', 366, 9, 20, 636004) Indian territory as a base of military operations against Japan and other Axis powers?
('82', 366, 10, 21, 636091) A. Assuming that the national government is formed and if it
('82', 366, 11, 22, 636152) 1 From A Week with Gandhi 2 Louis Fischer
('82', 367, 0, 1, 636194) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 367, 1, 2, 636236) answers my expectations, its first act would be to enter into a treaty with the United Nations for defensive operations against aggressive powers, it being common cause that India will have nothing to do with any of the Fascist powers and India would be morally bound to help the United Nations.
('82', 367, 2, 3, 636532) Q. What further assistance would this Indian national government be ready to
('82', 367, 3, 4, 636609) render the United Nations in the course of the present war against the Fascist
('82', 367, 4, 5, 636688) aggressors?
('82', 367, 5, 6, 636700) A. If I have any hand in guiding the imagined national Government, there would be no further assistance save the toleration of the United Nations on the Indian soil under well defined conditions.
('82', 367, 5, 7, 636896) Naturally there will be no prohibition against any Indian giving his own personal help by way of being a recruit or and of giving financial aid.
('82', 367, 5, 8, 637041) It should be understood that the Indian army has been disbanded with the withdrawal of British power.
('82', 367, 5, 9, 637143) Again if I have any say in the councils of the national government, all its power, prestige and resources would be used towards bringing about world peace.
('82', 367, 5, 10, 637299) But of course after the formation of the national government my voice may be a voice in the wilderness and nationalist India may go war mad.
('82', 367, 6, 11, 637440) Q. Do you believe this collaboration between India and the Allied powers
('82', 367, 7, 12, 637513) might or should be formulated in a treaty of alliance or an agreement for mutual aid?
('82', 367, 8, 13, 637599) A. I think the question is altogether premature and in any case it will not much matter whether the relations are regulated by treaty or agreement.
('82', 367, 8, 14, 637747) I do not even see any difference.
('82', 367, 9, 15, 637781) Let me sum up my attitude.
('82', 367, 9, 16, 637808) One thing and only one thing for me is solid and certain.
('82', 367, 9, 17, 637866) This unnatural prostration of a great nation— it is neither ‘nations’ nor ‘peoples’—must cease if the victory of the Allies is to be ensured.
('82', 367, 9, 18, 638008) They lack the moral basis.
('82', 367, 9, 19, 638035) I see no difference between the Fascist or Nazi powers and the Allies.
('82', 367, 9, 20, 638106) All are exploiters, all resort to ruthlessness to the extent required to compass their end.
('82', 367, 9, 21, 638198) America and Britain are very great nations, but their greatness will count as dust before the bar of dumb humanity, whether African or Asiatic.
('82', 367, 9, 22, 638342) They and they alone have the power to undo the wrong.
('82', 367, 9, 23, 638396) They have no right to talk of human liberty and all else unless they have washed their hands clean of the pollution.
('82', 367, 9, 24, 638513) That necessary wash will be
('82', 368, 0, 1, 638541) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 369
('82', 368, 1, 2, 638584) their surest insurance of success, for they will have the good wishes— unexpressed but no less certain—of millions of dumb Asiatics and Africans.
('82', 368, 1, 3, 638730) Then, but not till then, will they be fighting for a new order.
('82', 368, 1, 4, 638794) This is the reality.
('82', 368, 1, 5, 638815) All else is speculation.
('82', 368, 1, 6, 638840) I have allowed myself, however, to indulge in it as a test of my bona fides and for the sake of explaining in a concrete manner what I mean by my proposal.
('82', 368, 2, 7, 638996) Harijan, 14 6 1942
('82', 368, 3, 8, 639015) 430. DR.
('82', 368, 3, 9, 639024) TARACHAND AND HINDUSTANI
('82', 368, 4, 10, 639049) The following was sent for the question box by Shri Murlidhar Srivastava, M.A.:
('82', 368, 5, 11, 639129) When prejudices come in, one is led to distort history.
('82', 368, 5, 12, 639185) Dr. Tarachand is
('82', 368, 6, 13, 639202) an ardent advocate of Hindustani as you are.
('82', 368, 6, 14, 639247) He has every right to hold his
('82', 368, 7, 15, 639278) view as you or I have to hold my own, but in his zeal he has grossly
('82', 368, 8, 16, 639347) misrepresented the history of Brajbhasha by declaring that no writing in Braj
('82', 368, 9, 17, 639425) is known to have appeared before the 16th century, in an attempt to prove that
('82', 368, 10, 18, 639504) Hindustani (‘Khari Boli’) has older literature than Brajbhasha.
('82', 368, 10, 19, 639568) 1 According to
('82', 368, 11, 20, 639583) him Surdas was the first poet to write in Braj in the 16th century.
('82', 368, 12, 21, 639651) learned Doctor has been quoted by you in the Harijan, dated 29 3 42, which
('82', 368, 13, 22, 639726) commands wide publicity and authority, the mistake must be pointed out.
('82', 368, 14, 23, 639798) literature prior to Surdas, you have only to read the poems of Kabir, not to
('82', 368, 15, 24, 639875) speak of Amir Khusru, some of whose verses are also in Brajbhasha.
('82', 368, 15, 25, 639942) Several
('82', 368, 16, 26, 639950) small pieces of poems are attributed to several santas and bhaktas prior to
('82', 368, 17, 27, 640026) Surdas and they can be looked into any standard history of Hindi literature.
('82', 368, 17, 28, 640103) I have removed the portion that had no bearing on the question at issue.
('82', 368, 17, 29, 640176) I sent the letter to Kakasaheb Kalelkar who made it over to Dr. Tarachand who has now sent the following reply 2 which speaks for itself:
('82', 368, 18, 30, 640314) My view that the literature of Brajbhasha is not older than the sixteenth
('82', 368, 19, 31, 640388) century is based on the following considerations:
('82', 368, 20, 32, 640438) 1. Brajbhasha is a modern language which belongs to the group named
('82', 368, 21, 33, 640506) tertiary Prakrits or New Indo Aryan.
('82', 368, 21, 34, 640543) This group developed from the secondary
('82', 368, 22, 35, 640583) 1 Vide “Hindustani”, 9 3 1942. 2 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('82', 369, 0, 1, 640651) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 369, 1, 2, 640693) Prakrits or Middle Indo Aryan....
('82', 369, 1, 3, 640727) But most scholars are agreed that secondary
('82', 369, 2, 4, 640771) Prakrit stage lasted from 600 B.C. to 1000 A.D.
('82', 369, 3, 5, 640819) 2. The secondary Prakrits which were spoken dialects received the
('82', 369, 4, 6, 640885) impetus towards literary development from the religious movements
('82', 369, 5, 7, 640951) inaugurated by Mahavira and Buddha.
('82', 369, 5, 8, 640987) Of these Prakrits, Pali became the most
('82', 369, 6, 9, 641027) important....
('82', 369, 7, 10, 641041) 3. By the sixth century A.D. the Prakrits had become fixed and dead languages....
('82', 369, 7, 11, 641123) In that century the languages of common speech, from which literary Prakrits had diverged, began to be used for literary purposes.
('82', 369, 7, 12, 641254) This phase of literary growths of the Prakrits is given the name Apabhramsha.
('82', 369, 7, 13, 641332) It lasted from 600 to 1,000 A.D. Among the Apabhramshas one acquired a position of eminence, namely, Nagara.
('82', 369, 7, 14, 641441) The varieties of Nagara were used as vehicles of literary expression in the greater part of northern India.
('82', 369, 7, 15, 641549) But besides Nagara and its varieties, there had developed Apabhramshas of the other Prakrits, like Saurseni, also.
('82', 369, 8, 16, 641664) 4. The modern Indian languages or the tertiary Prakrits developed from
('82', 369, 9, 17, 641735) these Apabhramshas.
('82', 369, 9, 18, 641755) Nagara became the parent of Rajasthani and Gujarati
('82', 369, 10, 19, 641807) languages, through a variety to which Tessitori gave the name old Western
('82', 369, 11, 20, 641881) Rajasthani.
('82', 369, 12, 21, 641893) Saurseni Apabhramsha is represented in the Prakrit grammar of
('82', 369, 13, 22, 641955) Hemchandra (d.
('82', 369, 13, 23, 641970) 1172 A.D.).
('82', 369, 13, 24, 641982) But it is difficult to determine the relationship of
('82', 369, 14, 25, 642035) Saurseni Apabhramsha with Nagara.
('82', 369, 14, 26, 642069) It seems that the Saurseni Apabhramsha
('82', 369, 15, 27, 642108) underwent a further change, which has been variously called old Western
('82', 369, 16, 28, 642180) Hindi, Avahattha, Kavyabhasha.
('82', 369, 17, 29, 642211) 5. With the arrival upon the scene of this language the stage of secondary Prakrits comes to an end, and the stage of new Indo Aryan speech begins.
('82', 369, 17, 30, 642359) The old Western Hindi which is the earliest form of the new midland speech appears to have become established in the eleventh century.
('82', 369, 17, 31, 642494) From the old Western Hindi branched out Hindustani (‘Khari’) of the North midland, Braj of the middle region and Bundeli of the southern parts.
('82', 369, 17, 32, 642638) In the twelfth century they were all spoken dialects.
('82', 369, 17, 33, 642692) In the course of the following centuries they assumed literary form.
('82', 369, 18, 34, 642761) 6. From a study of the development of these languages I have arrived at the conclusion that Hindustani (‘Khari’) was the first to develop into a literary language.
('82', 369, 18, 35, 642925) We have a continuous history of Hindustani (Deccani Urdu) from the last quarter of the 14th century onwards.
('82', 369, 18, 36, 643034) On the other hand the history of Braj literature before the 16th century is very doubtful.
('82', 369, 18, 37, 643125) SEVAGRAM, June 6, 1 942 Harijan, 14 6 1942

('82', 372, 1, 2, 644852) 435. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA
('82', 372, 2, 3, 644891) SEVAGRAM, June 6, 1942
('82', 372, 3, 4, 644914) BHAI SATIS BABU, How can I go to Bengal?

('82', 373, 1, 2, 646259) and apart from my proposal—as they had to do in Burma —what would happen?
('82', 373, 1, 3, 646333) What would India do?
('82', 373, 2, 4, 646354) Q. That is exactly what we have come to learn from you.
('82', 373, 2, 5, 646410) We would certainly
('82', 373, 3, 6, 646429) like to know that.
('82', 373, 4, 7, 646448) A. Well, therein comes my non violence.
('82', 373, 4, 8, 646488) For we have no weapons.
('82', 373, 4, 9, 646512) Mind you, we have assumed that the Commander in Chief of the united American and British Armies has decided that India is no good as a base and that they should withdraw to some other base and concentrate the Allied forces there.
('82', 373, 4, 10, 646742) We can’t help it.
('82', 373, 4, 11, 646760) We have then to depend on what strength we have.
('82', 373, 4, 12, 646809) We have no army, no military resources, no military skill either, worth the name, and non violence is the only thing we can fall back upon.
('82', 373, 4, 13, 646949) Now in theory I can prove to you that our non violent resistance can be wholly successful.
('82', 373, 4, 14, 647040) We need not kill a single Japanese, we simply give them no quarter.
('82', 373, 5, 15, 647108) Q. But that non violence can’t prevent an invasion?
('82', 373, 6, 16, 647160) A. In non violent technique, of course, there can be nothing like preventing an invasion.
('82', 373, 6, 17, 647250) They will land, but they will land on an inhospitable shore.
('82', 373, 6, 18, 647311) They may be ruthless and wipe out all the 400 millions.
('82', 373, 6, 19, 647367) That would be complete victory.
('82', 373, 6, 20, 647399) I know you will laugh at it, saying all this is superhuman, if not absurd.
('82', 373, 6, 21, 647474) I would say you are right; we may not be able to stand that terror and we may have to go through a course of subjection worse than our present state.
('82', 373, 6, 22, 647624) But we are discussing the theory.
('82', 373, 7, 23, 647658) Q. But if the British don’t withdraw?
('82', 373, 8, 24, 647696) A. I do not want them to withdraw under Indian pressure, nor driven by force of circumstances.
('82', 373, 8, 25, 647791) I want them to withdraw in their own interest, for their own good name.
('82', 373, 9, 26, 647863) Q. But what happens to your movement, if you are arrested, as we heard you
('82', 373, 10, 27, 647938) might be?
('82', 373, 10, 28, 647948) Or if Mr. Nehru is arrested?
('82', 373, 10, 29, 647977) Would not the movement go to pieces?
('82', 373, 11, 30, 648014) A. No, not if we have worked among the people.
('82', 373, 11, 31, 648061) Our arrests would work up the movement, they would stir everyone in India to do his little bit.
('82', 373, 12, 32, 648157) Q. Supposing Britain decides to fight to the last man in India, would not your
('82', 373, 13, 33, 648236) non violent non co operation help the Japanese?
('82', 373, 14, 34, 648284) A. If you mean non co operation with the British, you would be
('82', 374, 0, 1, 648347) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 375
('82', 374, 1, 2, 648390) We have not come to that stage.
('82', 374, 1, 3, 648422) I do not want to help the Japanese—not even for freeing India.
('82', 374, 1, 4, 648485) India during the past fifty or more years of her struggle for freedom has learnt the lesson of patriotism and of not bowing to any foreign power.
('82', 374, 1, 5, 648631) But when the British are offering violent battle, our non violent battle—our non violent activity—would be neutralized.
('82', 374, 1, 6, 648751) Those who believe in armed resistance and in helping the British militarily are and will be helping them.
('82', 374, 1, 7, 648857) Mr. Amery says he is getting all the men and money they need, and he is right.
('82', 374, 1, 8, 648936) For the Congress—a poor organization representing the millions of the poor of India—has not been able to collect in years what they have collected in a day by way of what I would say ‘so called’ voluntary subscription.
('82', 374, 1, 9, 649155) This Congress can only render non violent assistance.
('82', 374, 1, 10, 649209) But let me tell you, if you do not know it, that the British do not want it, they don’t set any store by it.
('82', 374, 1, 11, 649318) But whether they do it or not, violent and non violent resistance cannot go together.
('82', 374, 1, 12, 649404) So India’s non violence can at best take the form of silence—not obstructing the British forces, certainly not helping the Japanese.
('82', 374, 2, 13, 649537) Q. But not helping the British?
('82', 374, 3, 14, 649569) A. Don’t you see non violence cannot give any other aid?

('82', 374, 9, 19, 649874) A. We are indeed.

('82', 374, 10, 22, 649986) Every American feels
('82', 374, 11, 23, 650007) that we should help India to win her freedom.
('82', 374, 12, 24, 650053) A. It’s a bad job.
('82', 374, 13, 25, 650072) Q. Because it is said we are here really to help Britain and not India?
('82', 374, 14, 26, 650144) A. I say it is a bad job, because it is an imposition on India.
('82', 374, 14, 27, 650208) It is not at India’s request or with India’s consent that they are here.
('82', 374, 14, 28, 650281) It is enough irritation that we were not consulted before being dragged
('82', 375, 0, 1, 650353) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('82', 375, 1, 3, 650478) That is our original complaint.
('82', 375, 1, 4, 650510) To have brought the American forces is, in my opinion, to have made the stranglehold on us all the tighter.
('82', 375, 1, 5, 650618) You do not know what is happening in India—it is naturally not your business to go into those things.
('82', 375, 1, 6, 650720) But let me give you some facts.
('82', 375, 1, 7, 650752) Thousands of villagers are being summarily asked to vacate their homes and go elsewhere, for the site of their homesteads is needed by the military.
('82', 375, 1, 8, 650901) Now I ask, where are they to go?
('82', 375, 1, 9, 650934) Thousands of poor labourers in a certain place, I have heard today, have been asked to evacuate.

('82', 375, 1, 11, 651117) This kind of thing will not happen in an independent country.
('82', 375, 1, 12, 651179) The Sappers and Miners there would first build homes for these people, transport would be provided for them, they would be given at least six months’ maintenance allowance before they would be uprooted from their surroundings.
('82', 375, 1, 13, 651406) Are these things to happen, even before the Japanese have come here?
('82', 375, 1, 14, 651475) There is no other way, but saying to them, ‘you must go’, and if British rule ends, that moral act will save America and Britain.
('82', 375, 1, 15, 651605) If they choose to remain here, they should remain as friends, not as proprietors of India.
('82', 375, 1, 16, 651696) The American and British soldiers may remain here, if at all, by virtue of a compact with free India.

('82', 376, 1, 2, 652744) Q. If you regard the American troops as an imposition, would you regard the
('82', 376, 2, 3, 652820) American Technical Mission also in the same light?
('82', 376, 3, 4, 652871) A. A tree is judged by its fruit.
('82', 376, 3, 5, 652905) I have met Dr. Grady 1, we have had cordial talks.
('82', 376, 3, 6, 652956) I have no prejudice against Americans.
('82', 376, 3, 7, 652995) I have hundreds, if not thousands of friends, in America.
('82', 376, 3, 8, 653053) The Technical Mission may have nothing but goodwill for India.
('82', 376, 3, 9, 653116) But my point is that all the things that are happening are not happening at the invitation or wish of India.
('82', 376, 3, 10, 653225) Therefore they are all suspect.
('82', 376, 3, 11, 653257) We cannot look upon them with philosophic calmness, for the simple reason that we cannot close our eyes, as I have said, to the things that are daily happening in front of our eyes.
('82', 376, 3, 12, 653439) Areas are being vacated and turned into military camps, people being thrown on their own resources.
('82', 376, 3, 13, 653539) Hundreds, if not thousands, on their way from Burma perished without food and drink, and the wretched discrimination stared even these miserable people in the face.
('82', 376, 3, 14, 653704) One route for the whites, another for the blacks!
('82', 376, 3, 15, 653754) Provision of food and shelter for the whites, none for the blacks!
('82', 376, 3, 16, 653821) And discrimination even on their arrival in India!
('82', 376, 3, 17, 653872) India is being ground down to dust and humiliated, even before the Japanese advent, not for India’s defence —and no one knows for whose defence.
('82', 376, 3, 18, 654017) And so one fine morning I came to the decision to make this honest demand: ‘For Heaven’s sake leave India alone.
('82', 376, 3, 19, 654130) Let us breathe the air of freedom.
('82', 376, 3, 20, 654165) It may choke us, suffocate us, as it did the slaves on their emancipation.
('82', 376, 3, 21, 654240) But I want the present sham to end.’
('82', 376, 4, 22, 654277) Q. But it is the British troops you have in mind, not the American?
('82', 376, 5, 23, 654345) A. It does not make for me the slightest difference, the whole policy is one and indivisible.
('82', 376, 6, 24, 654439) Q. Is there any hope of Britain listening?
('82', 376, 7, 25, 654482) A. I will not die without that hope.
('82', 376, 7, 26, 654519) And if there is a long lease of life for me, I may even see it fulfilled.
('82', 376, 7, 27, 654593) For there is nothing unpractical in the proposal, no insuperable difficulties about it.
('82', 376, 7, 28, 654681) Let me add that if Britain is not willing to do so whole heartedly Britain does not deserve to win.
('82', 376, 8, 29, 654781) Q. Would a free India declare war against Japan?
('82', 376, 9, 30, 654830) 1 Dr. Henry Grady, head of the American Technical Mission then in India
('82', 377, 0, 1, 654902) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('82', 377, 1, 2, 654944) A. Free India need not do so.
('82', 377, 1, 3, 654974) It simply becomes the ally of the Allied Powers, simply out of gratefulness for the payment of a debt, however overdue.
('82', 377, 1, 4, 655094) Human nature thanks the debtor when he discharges the debt.
('82', 377, 2, 5, 655154) Q. How then would this alliance fit in with India’s non violence?
('82', 377, 3, 6, 655220) A. It is a good question.
('82', 377, 3, 7, 655246) The whole of India is not nonviolent.
('82', 377, 3, 8, 655284) If the whole of India had been non violent, there would have been no need for my appeal to Britain, nor would there be any fear of a Japanese invasion.
('82', 377, 3, 9, 655436) But my non violence is represented possibly by a hopeless minority, or perhaps by India’s dumb millions who are temperamentally non violent.
('82', 377, 3, 10, 655577) But there too the question may be asked: ‘What have they done?’ They have done nothing, I agree; but they may act when the supreme test comes, and they may not.
('82', 377, 3, 11, 655738) I have no non violence of millions to present to Britain, and what we have has been discounted by the British as non violence of the weak.
('82', 377, 3, 12, 655877) And so all I have done is to make this appeal on the strength of bare inherent justice, so that it might find an echo in the British heart.
('82', 377, 3, 13, 656017) It is made from a moral plane, and even as they do not hesitate to act desperately in the physical field and take grave risks, let them for once act desperately on the moral field and declare that India is independent today, irrespective of India’s demand.
('82', 377, 4, 14, 656274) Q. But what does a free India mean, if, as Mr. Jinnah said, Muslims will not
('82', 377, 5, 15, 656351) accept Hindu rule?
('82', 377, 6, 16, 656370) A. I have not asked the British to hand over India to the Congress or to the Hindus.
('82', 377, 6, 17, 656455) Let them entrust India to God or in modern parlance to anarchy.
('82', 377, 6, 18, 656519) Then all the parties will fight one another like dogs, or will, when real responsibility faces them, come to a reasonable agreement.
('82', 377, 6, 19, 656652) I shall expect non violence to arise out of that chaos.
('82', 377, 7, 20, 656708) Q. But to whom are the British to say—’India is free’?
('82', 377, 8, 21, 656763) A. To the world.
('82', 377, 8, 22, 656780) Automatically the Indian army is disbanded from that moment, and they decide to pack up as soon as they can.
('82', 377, 8, 23, 656889) Or they may declare they would pack up only after the war is over, but that they would expect no help from India, impose no taxes, raise no recruits—beyond what help India chooses to give voluntarily.
('82', 377, 8, 24, 657090) British rule will cease from that moment, no matter what happens to India
('82', 378, 0, 1, 657164) VOL. 82: 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 379
('82', 378, 1, 2, 657207) afterwards.
('82', 378, 1, 3, 657219) Today it is all a hypocricy, unreality.
('82', 378, 1, 4, 657259) I want that to end.
('82', 378, 1, 5, 657279) The new order will come only when that falsity ends.
('82', 378, 1, 6, 657332) It is an unwarranted claim Britain and America are making, the claim of saving democracy and freedom.
('82', 378, 1, 7, 657434) It is a wrong thing to make that claim when there is this terrible tragedy of holding a whole nation in bondage.
('82', 378, 2, 8, 657547) Q. What can America do to have your demand implemented?
('82', 378, 3, 9, 657603) A. If my demand is admitted to be just beyond cavil, America can insist on the implementing of the Indian demand as a condition of her financing Britain and supplying her with her matchless skill in making war machines.
('82', 378, 3, 10, 657823) He who pays the piper has the right to call the tune.
('82', 378, 3, 11, 657877) Since America has become the predominant partner in the Allied cause she is partner also in Britain’s guilt.
('82', 378, 3, 12, 657986) The Allies have no right to call their cause to be morally superior to the Nazi cause so long as they hold in custody the fairest part and one of the most ancient nations of the earth.

('82', 380, 19, 23, 661786) DEAR MR. GANDHI,

('82', 381, 22, 26, 663964) BRITISH WAR CABINET’S PROPOSALS1
('82', 381, 23, 27, 663997) The conclusions of the British War Cabinet as set out below are those which
('82', 381, 24, 28, 664073) Sir Stafford Cripps has taken with him for discussion with the Indian Leaders and the
('82', 381, 25, 29, 664159) question as to whether they will be implemented will depend upon the outcome of
('82', 381, 26, 30, 664239) these discussions which are now taking place.
('82', 381, 27, 31, 664285) His Majesty’s Government having considered the anxieties expressed in this
('82', 381, 28, 32, 664360) country and in India as to the fulfilment of promises made in regard to the future of
('82', 381, 29, 33, 664446) India have decided to lay down in precise and clear terms the steps which they propose
('82', 381, 30, 34, 664533) shall be taken for the earliest possible realization of self government in India.
('82', 381, 31, 35, 664615) object is the creation of a new Indian Union, which shall constitute a Dominion,
('82', 381, 32, 36, 664696) 1 Vide “Telegram to Stafford Cripps”, 25 3 1942 and “Letter to Jwaharlal Nehru”, after 27 3 1942.
('82', 382, 0, 1, 664794) VOL. 82 : 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 383
('82', 382, 1, 2, 664838) associated with the United Kingdom and other Dominions by a common allegiance to
('82', 382, 2, 3, 664919) the Crown but equal to them in every respect, in no way subordinate in any aspect of
('82', 382, 3, 4, 665004) its domestic or extenal affairs.
('82', 382, 4, 5, 665037) His Majesty’s Government, therefore, make the following Declaration :—
('82', 382, 5, 6, 665108) (a) Immediately upon the cessation of hostilities steps shall be taken to set up
('82', 382, 6, 7, 665189) in India in the manner described hereafter an elected body charged with the task of
('82', 382, 7, 8, 665273) framing a new Constitution for India.
('82', 382, 8, 9, 665311) (b) Provision shall be made, as set out below, for the participation of the
('82', 382, 9, 10, 665387) Indian States in the Constitution making body.
('82', 382, 10, 11, 665434) (c) His Majesty’s Government undertake to accept and implement forthwith
('82', 382, 11, 12, 665507) with Constitution so framed subject only to :
('82', 382, 12, 13, 665553) (I) The right of any province of British India that is not prepared to accept the
('82', 382, 13, 14, 665635) new Constitution to retain its present constitutional position, provision being made
('82', 382, 14, 15, 665720) for its subsequent accession if it so decides.
('82', 382, 15, 16, 665767) With such non acceding provinces, should they so desire, His Majesty’s
('82', 382, 16, 17, 665838) Government will be prepared to agree upon a new Constitution, giving them the same
('82', 382, 17, 18, 665921) full status as the Indian Union and arrived at by a procedure analogous to that here laid
('82', 382, 19, 19, 666011) (ii) The signing of a treaty which shall be negotiated between His Majesty’s
('82', 382, 20, 20, 666088) Government and the Constitution making body.
('82', 382, 20, 21, 666133) This treaty will cover all necessary
('82', 382, 21, 22, 666170) matters arising out of the complete transfer of responsibility from the British to
('82', 382, 22, 23, 666253) Indian hands, it will make provision, in accordance with the undertakings given by
('82', 382, 23, 24, 666336) His Majesty’s Government for the protection of racial and religious minorities; but
('82', 382, 24, 25, 666420) will not impose any restriction on the power of the Indian Union to decide in the
('82', 382, 25, 26, 666502) future its relationship to other Member States of the British Commonwealth.
('82', 382, 26, 27, 666578) Whether or not an Indian State elects to adhere to the Constitution it will be
('82', 382, 27, 28, 666657) necessary to negotiate a revision of its treaty arrangements so far as this may be
('82', 382, 28, 29, 666740) required in the new situation.
('82', 382, 29, 30, 666771) (d) The Constitution making body shall be composed as follows unless the
('82', 382, 30, 31, 666844) leaders of Indian opinion in the principal communities agree upon some other form
('82', 382, 31, 32, 666926) before the end of hostilities :
('82', 382, 32, 33, 666958) Immediately upon the result being known of the provincial elections which
('82', 382, 33, 34, 667032) will be necessary at the end of hostilities, the entire membership of the Lower Houses
('82', 382, 34, 35, 667119) of Provincial Legislatures shall as a single electoral college proceed to the election of
('82', 382, 35, 36, 667209) the Constitution making body by the system of proportional representation.
('82', 383, 0, 1, 667284) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 384
('82', 383, 1, 2, 667326) new body shall be in number about one tenth of the number of the electoral college.
('82', 383, 2, 3, 667410) Indian States shall be invited to appoint representatives in the same

('82', 383, 5, 6, 667632) (e) During the critical period which now faces India and until the new

('82', 383, 8, 9, 667871) their world war effort, but the task of organizing to the full the military, moral and

('82', 387, 26, 40, 679910) they do not see how it can enable to seize power.

('82', 388, 1, 2, 680609) Moreover, I do not agree that Government cannot be carried on except by the

('82', 388, 25, 37, 682275) G. That is not correct.

('82', 389, 4, 5, 683362) BRITISH GOVERNMENT’S PROPOSAL: NOTE BY THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR DOMINION AFFAIRS 1
('82', 389, 5, 6, 683447) 11, DOWNING STREET, S.W.I.,
('82', 389, 6, 7, 683475) March 2, 1942
('82', 389, 7, 8, 683489) On the 25th February the Prime Minister asked me to preside over a Cabinet
('82', 389, 8, 9, 683564) Committee to consider the present position in India, and to make recommendations.
('82', 389, 9, 10, 683646) I now submit, on behalf of the Committee, for the consideration of the War
('82', 389, 10, 11, 683721) Cabinet, the draft of a Declaration by His Majesty’s Government, regarding the future
('82', 389, 11, 12, 683807) government of India.
('82', 389, 12, 13, 683828) DRAFT DECLARATION
('82', 389, 13, 14, 683846) His Majesty’s Government, having considered the anxieties expressed in this
('82', 389, 14, 15, 683922) country and in India as to the fulfilment of the promises made in regardto the future of
('82', 389, 15, 16, 684011) India, have decided to lay down in precise and clear terms the steps which they
('82', 389, 16, 17, 684091) propose shall be taken for the earliest possible realization of self government in
('82', 389, 17, 18, 684174) The object is the creation of a new Indian Union which shall constitute a
('82', 389, 18, 19, 684248) Dominion, equal in every respect to the United Kingdom and the other Dominions of
('82', 389, 19, 20, 684330) the Crown, and free to remain in or to separate itself from the equal partnership of the
('82', 389, 20, 21, 684419) British Commonwealth of Nations.
('82', 389, 21, 22, 684452) His Majesty’s Government therefore make the following declaration:
('82', 389, 22, 23, 684519) (a) Immediately upon the cessation of hostilities, steps shall be taken to set
('82', 389, 23, 24, 684598) up in India, in the manner described hereafter, an elected body charged with the task of
('82', 389, 24, 25, 684687) framing a new Constitution for India.
('82', 389, 25, 26, 684725) (b) Provision shall be made, as set out below, for the participation of the
('82', 389, 26, 27, 684801) Indian States in the constitution making body.
('82', 389, 27, 28, 684848) (c) His Majesty’s Government undertake to accept and implement forthwith
('82', 389, 28, 29, 684921) the Constitution so framed subject only to:
('82', 389, 29, 30, 684965) (i) the right of any Province of British India that is not prepared to accept the
('82', 389, 30, 31, 685047) new Constitution to retain for the time being its present constitutional position,
('82', 389, 31, 32, 685130) provision being made for subsequent accession.
('82', 389, 32, 33, 685177) 1 Vide “That Ill fated Proposal”, 13 4 1942.
('82', 390, 0, 1, 685222) VOL. 82 : 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 391
('82', 390, 1, 2, 685266) With such non acceding Provinces, should they so desire, His Majesty’s
('82', 390, 2, 3, 685337) Government will be prepared to agree upon a new Constitution following the lines
('82', 390, 3, 4, 685418) laid down above.
('82', 390, 4, 5, 685435) (ii) the signing of a treaty which shall be negotiated between His Majesty’s
('82', 390, 5, 6, 685512) Government and the constitution making body covering all necessary matters
('82', 390, 6, 7, 685587) relating to the complete transfer of responsibility from British to Indian hands.
('82', 390, 7, 8, 685669) Whether or not an Indian State elects to adhere to the Constitution, it will be
('82', 390, 8, 9, 685749) necessary to negotiate revised Treaty arrangements, so far as this may be required in
('82', 390, 9, 10, 685835) the new situation.
('82', 390, 10, 11, 685854) (d) The constitution making body shall be composed as follows, unless the
('82', 390, 11, 12, 685928) leaders of Indian opinion in the principal communities agree upon some other form
('82', 390, 12, 13, 686010) before the end of hostilities:
('82', 390, 13, 14, 686041) Immediately upon the result being known of the Provincial elections which
('82', 390, 14, 15, 686115) will be necessary at the end of hostilities, the entire membership of the Lower Houses
('82', 390, 15, 16, 686202) of the Provincial Legislatures shall, as a single electoral college, proceed to the
('82', 390, 16, 17, 686286) election of the constitution making body by the system of proportional
('82', 390, 17, 18, 686357) representation.
('82', 390, 17, 19, 686373) This new body shall be in number about one tenth of the number of
('82', 390, 18, 20, 686439) the electoral college.
('82', 390, 19, 21, 686462) Indian States shall be invited to appoint representatives in the same
('82', 390, 20, 22, 686532) proportion of the total population as the average for British India, and with the same
('82', 390, 21, 23, 686619) powers as the British Indian members.
('82', 390, 22, 24, 686657) (e) While during the critical period which now faces India, and until the new
('82', 390, 23, 25, 686735) Constitution can be framed, His Majesty’s Government must inevitably the full
('82', 390, 24, 26, 686813) responsibility for India’s defence, they desire and invite the immediate and effective
('82', 390, 25, 27, 686900) participation of the leaders of the principal sections of the Indian people in the
('82', 390, 26, 28, 686983) counsels of their country, to give their active and constructive help in the discharge
('82', 390, 27, 29, 687070) of a task so vital and essential for the future freedom of India.

('82', 391, 2, 3, 687226) RESOLUTION PASSED BY A.I.C.C.1
('82', 391, 3, 4, 687257) May 1, 1942
('82', 391, 4, 5, 687269) In view of the imminent peril of invasion that confronts India and the attitude
('82', 391, 5, 6, 687349) of the British Government, as shown again in the recent proposals sponsored by Sir
('82', 391, 6, 7, 687432) Stafford Cripps, the All India Congress Committee has to declare afresh India’s
('82', 391, 7, 8, 687512) policy and to advise the people in regard to the action to be undertaken in the
('82', 391, 8, 9, 687592) emergencies that may arise in the immediate future.
('82', 391, 9, 10, 687644) The proposals of the British Government and their subsequent elucidation by
('82', 391, 10, 11, 687720) Sir Stafford Cripps have led to greater bitterness and distrust of that Government and
('82', 391, 11, 12, 687807) the spirit of non co operation with Britain has grown.
('82', 391, 11, 13, 687862) They have demonstrated that
('82', 391, 12, 14, 687890) even in this hour of danger, not only to India but to the cause of the United Nations,
('82', 391, 13, 15, 687977) the British Government functions as an imperialist government and refuses to
('82', 391, 14, 16, 688054) recognize the independence of India or to part with any real power.
('82', 391, 14, 17, 688122) India’s
('82', 391, 15, 18, 688130) participation in the war was a purely British act imposed upon the Indian people
('82', 391, 16, 19, 688211) without the consent of their representatives.
('82', 391, 16, 20, 688257) While India has no quarrel with the
('82', 391, 17, 21, 688293) people of any country, she has repeatedly declared her antipathy to Nazism and
('82', 391, 18, 22, 688372) Fascism as to imperialism.
('82', 391, 18, 23, 688399) If India were free she would have determined her own
('82', 391, 19, 24, 688452) policy and might have kept out of the war, though her sympathies would, in any
('82', 391, 20, 25, 688531) event, have been with the victims of aggression.
('82', 391, 20, 26, 688580) If, however, circumstances had led
('82', 391, 21, 27, 688615) her to join the war, she would have done so as a free country fighting for freedom, and
('82', 391, 22, 28, 688703) her defence would have been organized on a popular basis with a national army under
('82', 391, 23, 29, 688787) national control and leadership, and with intimate contacts with the people.
('82', 391, 24, 30, 688864) India would know how to defend herself in the event of any aggressor attacking her.
('82', 391, 25, 31, 688948) The present Indian Army is in fact an offshoot of the British Army and has
('82', 391, 26, 32, 689023) been maintained till now mainly to hold India in subjection.
('82', 391, 26, 33, 689084) It has been completely
('82', 391, 27, 34, 689107) segregated from the general population, who can in no sense regard it as their own.
('82', 391, 28, 35, 689191) The essential difference between the imperialist and the popular conceptions
('82', 391, 29, 36, 689268) of defence is demonstrated by the fact that while foreign armies are invited to India for
('82', 391, 30, 37, 689358) that defence, the vast manpower of India herself is not utilized for the purpose.
('82', 391, 30, 38, 689440) India’s
('82', 391, 31, 39, 689448) past experience teaches her that it is harmful to her interest and dangerous to the cause
('82', 391, 32, 40, 689538) of her freedom to introduce foreign armies in India.
('82', 391, 32, 41, 689591) It is significant and extraordinary
('82', 391, 33, 42, 689627) that India’s inexhaustible manpower should remain untapped while India develops
('82', 391, 34, 43, 689707) 1 Vide “Draft Resolution for A.I.C.C.”, before 24 4 1942.
('82', 392, 0, 1, 689765) VOL. 82 : 9 FEBRUARY, 1942 6 JUNE, 1942 393
('82', 392, 1, 2, 689809) into a battle ground between foreign armies fighting on her soil or on her frontiers,
('82', 392, 2, 3, 689895) and her defence is not supposed to be a subject fit for popular control.
('82', 392, 2, 4, 689968) India resents
('82', 392, 3, 5, 689982) this treatment of her people as chattels to be disposed of by foreign authority.
('82', 392, 4, 6, 690063) All India Congress Committee is convinced that India will attain her freedom through
('82', 392, 5, 7, 690148) her own strength and will retain it likewise.
('82', 392, 5, 8, 690194) The present crisis, as well as the
('82', 392, 6, 9, 690229) experience of the negotiations with Sir Stafford Cripps, makes it impossible for the
('82', 392, 7, 10, 690314) Congress to consider any schemes or proposals which retain, even in a partial
('82', 392, 8, 11, 690392) measure, British control and authority in India.
('82', 392, 8, 12, 690441) Not only the interests of India but
('82', 392, 9, 13, 690477) also Britain’s safety, and world peace and freedom demand that Britain must abandon
('82', 392, 10, 14, 690561) her hold on India.
('82', 392, 10, 15, 690580) It is on the basis of independence alone that India can deal with
('82', 392, 11, 16, 690646) Britain or other nations.
('82', 392, 11, 17, 690672) The Committee repudiates the idea that freedom can come to
('82', 392, 12, 18, 690731) India through interference or invasion by any foreign nation, whatever the
('82', 392, 13, 19, 690806) professions of that nation may be.
('82', 392, 13, 20, 690841) In case an invasion takes place it must be resisted.
('82', 392, 14, 21, 690894) Such resistance can only take the form of non violent non co operation as the
('82', 392, 15, 22, 690972) British Government has prevented the organization of national defence by the people
('82', 392, 16, 23, 691056) in any other way.
('82', 392, 16, 24, 691074) The Committee would therefore expect the people of India to offer
('82', 392, 17, 25, 691140) complete non violent non co operation to the invading forces and not to render any
('82', 392, 18, 26, 691223) assistance to them.
('82', 392, 18, 27, 691243) We may not bend the knee to the aggressor nor obey any of his
('82', 392, 19, 28, 691305) orders.
('82', 392, 19, 29, 691313) We may not look to him for favours nor fall to his bribes.
('82', 392, 19, 30, 691372) If he wishes to take
('82', 392, 20, 31, 691393) possession of our homes and our fields we will refuse to give them up even if we have
('82', 392, 21, 32, 691479) to die in the effort to resist them.
('82', 392, 21, 33, 691516) In places wherein the British and the invading
('82', 392, 22, 34, 691563) forces are fighting our non co operation will be fruitless and unnecessary.
('82', 392, 22, 35, 691639) Not to put
('82', 392, 23, 36, 691650) any obstacle in the way of British forces will often be the only way of demonstrating
('82', 392, 24, 37, 691736) our non co operation with the invader.
('82', 392, 24, 38, 691775) Judging from their attitude the British
('82', 392, 25, 39, 691815) Government do not need any help from us beyond our non interference.
('82', 392, 26, 40, 691884) The success of such a policy of non co operation and non violent resistance
('82', 392, 27, 41, 691960) to the invader will largely depend on the intensive working out of the Congress
('82', 392, 28, 42, 692040) constructive programme and more especially the programme of self sufficiency and
('82', 392, 29, 43, 692121) self protection in all parts of the country.

('82', 393, 2, 3, 692317) SECTION IN THE CONSTITUTION OF THE HINDUSTANI PRACHAR SABHA DEFINING ITS AIMS AND FUNCTIONS1
('82', 393, 3, 4, 692410) 3. AIMS: To propagate Hindustani, the national language so that it can meet
('82', 393, 4, 5, 692486) the social, political, administrative and other requirements of the country as a whole
('82', 393, 5, 6, 692573) and become the medium of communication and intercourse between the different
('82', 393, 6, 7, 692650) linguistic regions.
('82', 393, 7, 8, 692670) NOTE: Hindustani is that language which in the towns and villages of North
('82', 393, 8, 9, 692745) India Hindus, Muslims and all other people speak, understand and employ for mutual
('82', 393, 9, 10, 692828) intercourse, which is written in both the Devanagari and the Persian scripts and the
('82', 393, 10, 11, 692913) literary styles of which are today known by the names of Hindi and Urdu.
('82', 393, 11, 12, 692986) 4. FUNCTIONS OF THE SABHA: the Sabha shall conduct the following activities
('82', 393, 12, 13, 693062) to achieve its aims.
('82', 393, 13, 14, 693083) (1) To prepare a dictionary of Hindustani which all can rely upon.
('82', 393, 13, 15, 693150) To evolve a
('82', 393, 14, 16, 693162) grammar of Hindustani and prepare similar other reference works for the different
('82', 393, 15, 17, 693244) provinces.
('82', 393, 16, 18, 693255) (2) To prepare Hindustani text books for use in schools.
('82', 393, 17, 19, 693312) (3) To bring out easy to understand books in Hindustani.
('82', 393, 18, 20, 693369) (4) To conduct examinations in various places in order to propagate
('82', 393, 19, 21, 693437) Hindustani and to extend help and recognition to associations that conduct such
('82', 393, 20, 22, 693517) examinations.
('82', 393, 21, 23, 693531) (5) To prepare a glossary of technical terms in Hindustani.
('82', 393, 22, 24, 693591) (6) To endeavour to have Hindustani accepted as a compulsory subject by
('82', 393, 23, 25, 693663) provincial governments, municipal and district boards and national educational
('82', 393, 24, 26, 693742) institutions.
('82', 393, 25, 27, 693756) (7) To set up branches of the Sabha, appoint committees, collect
('82', 393, 26, 28, 693821) contributions, offer aid to publishers of Hindustani books, run schools, libraries,
('82', 393, 27, 29, 693905) reading rooms, training schools, nightschools and other institutions of a similar
('82', 393, 28, 30, 693987) nature with a view to achieving the above mentioned aims and encouraging activities.
('82', 393, 29, 31, 694072) (8) To associate with or affiliate to the Sabha such institutions as are capable
('82', 393, 30, 32, 694153) of co operating in these activities.
('82', 393, 31, 33, 694190) (9) To make all such efforts as will help fulfil the objects of the Sabha.
('82', 393, 32, 34, 694265) NOTE: no member of the Sabha shall, in his capacity as a member, derive any

('82', 394, 3, 4, 694498) APPENDIX IX INTERVIEW WITH LOUIS FISCHER 1
('82', 394, 4, 5, 694541) June 4, 1942
('82', 394, 5, 6, 694554) GANDHIJI: Now I am fully at your disposal.
('82', 394, 6, 7, 694597) LOUIS FISCHER: I feel that the Cripps mission was a turning point in Indian
('82', 394, 7, 8, 694673) history.
('82', 394, 7, 9, 694682) The country is probably now beginning to grasp the significance of
('82', 394, 8, 10, 694749) Cripps’s failure, and from that understanding big things might flow.
('82', 394, 9, 11, 694818) G. When Cripps arrived, he sent me a telegram asking me to come and see him
('82', 394, 10, 12, 694894) in New Delhi.
('82', 394, 10, 13, 694908) I did not wish to go, but I went because I thought it would do some
('82', 394, 11, 14, 694976) I had heard rumours about the contents of the British Government’s offer he
('82', 394, 12, 15, 695052) brought to India, but I had not seen the offer.
('82', 394, 12, 16, 695100) He gave it to me, and after a brief study,
('82', 394, 13, 17, 695143) I said to him, “Why did you come if this is what you have to offer?
('82', 394, 13, 18, 695211) If this is your
('82', 394, 14, 19, 695227) entire proposal to India, I would advise you to take the next plane home.” Cripps
('82', 394, 15, 20, 695309) replied, “I will consider that.”
('82', 394, 16, 21, 695342) L.F. What is your criticism of the Cripps offer?
('82', 394, 16, 22, 695391) Didn’t it promise you
('82', 394, 17, 23, 695413) dominion status with the right to secede from the British Commonwealth?
('82', 394, 18, 24, 695485) G. C. F. Andrews always used to assert that dominion status is not for India.
('82', 394, 19, 25, 695563) We have not the same relation to Britain as the dominions which are white and
('82', 394, 20, 26, 695641) settled, for the most part, by emigrants from Britain or their descendants.
('82', 394, 20, 27, 695717) We do not
('82', 394, 21, 28, 695727) wish any status conferred on us.
('82', 394, 21, 29, 695760) If a status is conferred on us, it means we are not free.
('82', 394, 22, 30, 695818) As to secession, there are big flaws.
('82', 394, 22, 31, 695856) One of the chief flaws is the provision in
('82', 394, 23, 32, 695899) the Cripps proposal regarding the Princes.
('82', 394, 23, 33, 695942) The British maintain that they must
('82', 394, 24, 34, 695978) protect the Princes under treaties which they forced on the Princes for Britain’s
('82', 394, 25, 35, 696060) advantage.
('82', 394, 25, 36, 696071) The Maharaja of Bikaner, and I take him as any X,Y,Z, reigned before the
('82', 394, 26, 37, 696144) British came and had more power then than now.
('82', 394, 26, 38, 696191) The second flaw is the recognition
('82', 394, 27, 39, 696226) of Pakistan.
('82', 394, 27, 40, 696239) The differences between Hindus and Muslims have been accentuated by
('82', 394, 28, 41, 696307) British rule.
('82', 394, 28, 42, 696321) Now they have been given their maximum scope by the Cripps offer.
('82', 394, 29, 43, 696387) Lord Minto started this when he was Viceroy [1909]2 by establishing separate
